title: The Root of All Things

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Ukkaṭṭhā, in the Subhaga Forest at the root of a magnificent sal tree.
title: The Root of All Things

segment_text: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,
title: The Root of All Things

segment_text: “Mendicants!”
title: The Root of All Things

segment_text: “Venerable sir,” they replied.
title: The Root of All Things

segment_text: The Buddha said this:
title: The Root of All Things

segment_text: “Mendicants, I will teach you the explanation of the root of all things.
title: The Root of All Things

segment_text: Listen and apply your minds well, I will speak.”
title: The Root of All Things

segment_text: “Yes, sir,” they replied.
title: The Root of All Things

title: All the Defilements

title: All the Defilements

title: All the Defilements

title: All the Defilements

segment_text: “Venerable sir,” they replied.
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: The Buddha said this:
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: “Mendicants, I will teach you the explanation of the restraint of all defilements.
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: Listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: “Yes, sir,” they replied.
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: The Buddha said this:
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: “Mendicants, I say that the ending of defilements is for one who knows and sees, not for one who does not know or see.
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: For one who knows and sees what?
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: Rational application of mind and irrational application of mind.
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: When you apply the mind irrationally, defilements arise, and once arisen they grow.
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: When you apply the mind rationally, defilements don’t arise, and those that have already arisen are given up.
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: Some defilements should be given up by seeing, some by restraint, some by using, some by enduring, some by avoiding, some by dispelling, and some by developing.
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: And what are the defilements that should be given up by seeing?
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: Take an unlearned ordinary person who has not seen the noble ones, and is neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the noble ones. They’ve not seen true persons, and are neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the true persons.
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: They don’t understand to which things they should apply the mind and to which things they should not apply the mind.
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: So they apply the mind to things they shouldn’t and don’t apply the mind to things they should.
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: And what are the things to which they apply the mind but should not?
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: They are the things that, when the mind is applied to them, give rise to unarisen defilements and make arisen defilements grow: the defilements of sensual desire,
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: desire to be reborn,
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: and ignorance.
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: These are the things to which they apply the mind but should not.
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: And what are the things to which they do not apply the mind but should?
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: They are the things that, when the mind is applied to them, do not give rise to unarisen defilements and give up arisen defilements: the defilements of sensual desire,
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: desire to be reborn,
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: and ignorance.
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: These are the things to which they do not apply the mind but should.
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: Because of applying the mind to what they should not and not applying the mind to what they should, unarisen defilements arise and arisen defilements grow.
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: This is how they apply the mind irrationally:
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: ‘Did I exist in the past? Did I not exist in the past? What was I in the past? How was I in the past? After being what, what did I become in the past?
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: Will I exist in the future? Will I not exist in the future? What will I be in the future? How will I be in the future? After being what, what will I become in the future?’
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: Or they are undecided about the present thus:
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: ‘Am I? Am I not? What am I? How am I? This sentient being—where did it come from? And where will it go?’
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: When they apply the mind irrationally in this way, one of the following six views arises in them and is taken as a genuine fact.
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: The view: ‘My self survives.’
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: The view: ‘My self does not survive.’
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: The view: ‘I perceive the self with the self.’
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: The view: ‘I perceive what is not-self with the self.’
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: The view: ‘I perceive the self with what is not-self.’
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: Or they have such a view:
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: ‘This self of mine is he, the speaker, the knower who experiences the results of good and bad deeds in all the different realms. This self is permanent, everlasting, eternal, and imperishable, and will last forever and ever.’
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: This is called a misconception, the thicket of views, the desert of views, the twist of views, the dodge of views, the fetter of views.
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: An unlearned ordinary person who is fettered by views is not freed from rebirth, old age, and death, from sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: They’re not freed from suffering, I say.
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: But take a learned noble disciple who has seen the noble ones, and is skilled and trained in the teaching of the noble ones. They’ve seen true persons, and are skilled and trained in the teaching of the true persons.
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: They understand to which things they should apply the mind and to which things they should not apply the mind.
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: So they apply the mind to things they should and don’t apply the mind to things they shouldn’t.
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: And what are the things to which they don’t apply the mind and should not?
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: They are the things that, when the mind is applied to them, give rise to unarisen defilements and make arisen defilements grow: the defilements of sensual desire,
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: desire to be reborn,
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: and ignorance.
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: These are the things to which they don’t apply the mind and should not.
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: And what are the things to which they do apply the mind and should?
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: They are the things that, when the mind is applied to them, do not give rise to unarisen defilements and give up arisen defilements: the defilements of sensual desire,
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: desire to be reborn,
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: and ignorance.
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: These are the things to which they do apply the mind and should.
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: Because of not applying the mind to what they should not and applying the mind to what they should, unarisen defilements don’t arise and arisen defilements are given up.
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: They rationally apply the mind: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: And as they do so, they give up three fetters:
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: substantialist view, doubt, and misapprehension of precepts and observances.
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: These are called the defilements that should be given up by seeing.
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: And what are the defilements that should be given up by restraint?
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: Take a mendicant who, reflecting rationally, lives restraining the faculty of the eye.
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: For the distressing and feverish defilements that might arise in someone who lives without restraint of the eye faculty do not arise when there is such restraint.
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: Reflecting rationally, they live restraining the faculty of the ear …
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: the nose …
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: the tongue …
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: the body …
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: the mind.
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: For the distressing and feverish defilements that might arise in someone who lives without restraint of the mind faculty do not arise when there is such restraint.
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: For the distressing and feverish defilements that might arise in someone who lives without restraint do not arise when there is such restraint.
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: These are called the defilements that should be given up by restraint.
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: And what are the defilements that should be given up by using?
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: Take a mendicant who, reflecting rationally, makes use of robes:
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: ‘Only for the sake of warding off cold and heat; for warding off the touch of flies, mosquitoes, wind, sun, and reptiles; and for covering up the private parts.’
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: Reflecting rationally, they make use of almsfood:
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: ‘Not for fun, indulgence, adornment, or decoration, but only to sustain this body, to avoid harm, and to support spiritual practice. In this way, I shall put an end to old discomfort and not give rise to new discomfort, and I will have the means to keep going, blamelessness, and a comfortable abiding.’
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: Reflecting rationally, they make use of lodgings:
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: ‘Only for the sake of warding off cold and heat; for warding off the touch of flies, mosquitoes, wind, sun, and reptiles; to shelter from harsh weather and to enjoy retreat.’
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: Reflecting rationally, they make use of medicines and supplies for the sick:
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: ‘Only for the sake of warding off the pains of illness and to promote good health.’
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: For the distressing and feverish defilements that might arise in someone who lives without using these things do not arise when they are used.
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: These are called the defilements that should be given up by using.
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: And what are the defilements that should be given up by enduring?
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: Take a mendicant who, reflecting rationally, endures cold, heat, hunger, and thirst. They endure the touch of flies, mosquitoes, wind, sun, and reptiles. They endure rude and unwelcome criticism. And they put up with physical pain—sharp, severe, acute, unpleasant, disagreeable, and life-threatening.
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: For the distressing and feverish defilements that might arise in someone who lives without enduring these things do not arise when they are endured.
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: These are called the defilements that should be given up by enduring.
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: And what are the defilements that should be given up by avoiding?
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: Take a mendicant who, reflecting rationally, avoids a wild elephant, a wild horse, a wild ox, a wild dog, a snake, a stump, thorny ground, a pit, a cliff, a swamp, and a sewer.
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: Reflecting rationally, they avoid sitting on inappropriate seats, walking in inappropriate neighborhoods, and mixing with bad friends—whatever sensible spiritual companions would believe to be a bad setting.
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: For the distressing and feverish defilements that might arise in someone who lives without avoiding these things do not arise when they are avoided.
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: These are called the defilements that should be given up by avoiding.
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: And what are the defilements that should be given up by dispelling?
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: Take a mendicant who, reflecting rationally, doesn’t tolerate a sensual, malicious, or cruel thought that has arisen, but gives it up, gets rid of it, eliminates it, and obliterates it. They don’t tolerate any bad, unskillful qualities that have arisen, but give them up, get rid of them, eliminate them, and obliterate them.
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: For the distressing and feverish defilements that might arise in someone who lives without dispelling these things do not arise when they are dispelled.
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: These are called the defilements that should be given up by dispelling.
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: And what are the defilements that should be given up by developing?
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: It’s when a mendicant, reflecting rationally, develops the awakening factors of mindfulness,
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: investigation of principles,
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: energy,
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: rapture,
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: tranquility,
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: immersion,
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: and equanimity, which rely on seclusion, fading away, and cessation, and ripen as letting go.
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: For the distressing and feverish defilements that might arise in someone who lives without developing these things do not arise when they are developed.
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: These are called the defilements that should be given up by developing.
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: Now, take a mendicant who, by seeing, has given up the defilements that should be given up by seeing. By restraint, they’ve given up the defilements that should be given up by restraint. By using, they’ve given up the defilements that should be given up by using. By enduring, they’ve given up the defilements that should be given up by enduring. By avoiding, they’ve given up the defilements that should be given up by avoiding. By dispelling, they’ve given up the defilements that should be given up by dispelling. By developing, they’ve given up the defilements that should be given up by developing.
title: All the Defilements

segment_text: They’re called a mendicant who lives having restrained all defilements, who has cut off craving, untied the fetters, and by rightly comprehending conceit has made an end of suffering.”
title: All the Defilements

title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: Before my awakening—when I was still unawakened but intent on awakening—I too thought,
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: ‘Remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest are challenging. It’s hard to maintain seclusion and hard to find joy in solitude.
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: The forests seem to rob the mind of a mendicant who isn’t immersed in samādhi.’
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: Then I thought,
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: ‘There are ascetics and brahmins with unpurified conduct of body, speech, and mind who frequent remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest. Those ascetics and brahmins summon unskillful fear and dread because of these defects in their conduct.
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: But I don’t frequent remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest with unpurified conduct of body, speech, and mind.
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: My conduct is purified.
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: I am one of those noble ones who frequent remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest with purified conduct of body, speech, and mind.’
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: Seeing this purity of conduct in myself I felt even more unruffled about staying in the forest.
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: Then I thought,
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: ‘There are ascetics and brahmins with unpurified livelihood who frequent remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest. Those ascetics and brahmins summon unskillful fear and dread because of these defects in their livelihood.
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: But I don’t frequent remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest with unpurified livelihood.
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: My livelihood is purified.
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: I am one of those noble ones who frequent remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest with purified livelihood.’
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: Seeing this purity of livelihood in myself I felt even more unruffled about staying in the forest.
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: Then I thought,
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: ‘There are ascetics and brahmins full of desire for sensual pleasures, with acute lust …
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: I am not full of desire …’
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: ‘There are ascetics and brahmins full of ill will, with malicious intentions …
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: I have a heart full of love …’
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: ‘There are ascetics and brahmins overcome with dullness and drowsiness …
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: I am free of dullness and drowsiness …’
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: ‘There are ascetics and brahmins who are restless, with no peace of mind …
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: My mind is peaceful …’
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: ‘There are ascetics and brahmins who are doubting and uncertain …
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: I’ve gone beyond doubt …’
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: ‘There are ascetics and brahmins who glorify themselves and put others down …
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: I don’t glorify myself and put others down …’
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: ‘There are ascetics and brahmins who are cowardly and craven …
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: I don’t get startled …’
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: ‘There are ascetics and brahmins who enjoy possessions, honor, and popularity …
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: I have few wishes …’
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: ‘There are ascetics and brahmins who are lazy and lack energy …
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: I am energetic …’
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: ‘There are ascetics and brahmins who are unmindful and lack situational awareness …
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: I am mindful …’
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: ‘There are ascetics and brahmins who lack immersion, with straying minds …
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: I am accomplished in immersion …’
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: ‘There are ascetics and brahmins who are witless and idiotic who frequent remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest. Those ascetics and brahmins summon unskillful fear and dread because of the defects of witlessness and stupidity.
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: But I don’t frequent remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest witless and idiotic.
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: I am accomplished in wisdom.
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: I am one of those noble ones who frequent remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest accomplished in wisdom.’
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: Seeing this accomplishment of wisdom in myself I felt even more unruffled about staying in the forest.
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: Then I thought,
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: ‘There are certain nights that are recognized as specially portentous:
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: the fourteenth, fifteenth, and eighth of the fortnight.
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: On such nights, why don’t I stay in awe-inspiring and hair-raising shrines in parks, forests, and trees? In such lodgings, hopefully I might see that fear and dread.’
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: Some time later, that’s what I did.
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: As I was staying there a deer came by, or a peacock snapped a twig, or the wind rustled the leaves.
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: Then I thought,
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: ‘Is this that fear and dread coming?’
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: Then I thought,
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: ‘Why do I always meditate expecting that fear to come?
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: Why don’t I get rid of that fear and dread just as it comes, while remaining just as I am?’
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: Then that fear and dread came upon me as I was walking.
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: I didn’t stand still or sit down or lie down until I had got rid of that fear and dread while walking.
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: Then that fear and dread came upon me as I was standing.
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: I didn’t walk or sit down or lie down until I had got rid of that fear and dread while standing.
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: Then that fear and dread came upon me as I was sitting.
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: I didn’t lie down or stand still or walk until I had got rid of that fear and dread while sitting.
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: Then that fear and dread came upon me as I was lying down.
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: I didn’t sit up or stand still or walk until I had got rid of that fear and dread while lying down.
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: There are some ascetics and brahmins who perceive that it’s day when in fact it’s night, or perceive that it’s night when in fact it’s day.
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: This meditation of theirs is delusional, I say.
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: I perceive that it’s night when in fact it is night, and perceive that it’s day when in fact it is day.
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: And if there’s anyone of whom it may be rightly said that
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: a being not liable to delusion has arisen in the world for the welfare and happiness of the people, out of sympathy for the world, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans, it’s of me that this should be said.
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: My energy was roused up and unflagging, my mindfulness was established and lucid, my body was tranquil and undisturbed, and my mind was immersed in samādhi and unified.
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: Quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, I entered and remained in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected were stilled, I entered and remained in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: And with the fading away of rapture, I entered and remained in the third absorption, where I meditated with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: With the giving up of pleasure and pain, and the ending of former happiness and sadness, I entered and remained in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: When my mind had become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—I extended it toward recollection of past lives. I recollected many kinds of past lives.
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: That is: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. I remembered: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so I recollected my many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: This was the first knowledge, which I achieved in the first watch of the night.
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: Ignorance was destroyed and knowledge arose; darkness was destroyed and light arose, as happens for a meditator who is diligent, keen, and resolute.
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: When my mind had become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—I extended it toward knowledge of the death and rebirth of sentient beings.
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, I saw sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. I understood how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds: ‘These dear beings did bad things by way of body, speech, and mind. They denounced the noble ones; they had wrong view; and they chose to act out of that wrong view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. These dear beings, however, did good things by way of body, speech, and mind. They never denounced the noble ones; they had right view; and they chose to act out of that right view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.’ And so, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, I saw sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. I understood how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds.
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: This was the second knowledge, which I achieved in the middle watch of the night.
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: Ignorance was destroyed and knowledge arose; darkness was destroyed and light arose, as happens for a meditator who is diligent, keen, and resolute.
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: When my mind had become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—I extended it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements.
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: I truly understood: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: I truly understood: ‘These are defilements’ … ‘This is the origin of defilements’ … ‘This is the cessation of defilements’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of defilements’.
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: Knowing and seeing like this, my mind was freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: When it was freed, I knew it was freed.
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: I understood: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’”
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: This was the third knowledge, which I achieved in the final watch of the night.
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: Ignorance was destroyed and knowledge arose; darkness was destroyed and light arose, as happens for a meditator who is diligent, keen, and resolute.
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: Brahmin, you might think:
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: ‘Perhaps the ascetic Gotama is not free of greed, hate, and delusion even today, and that is why he still frequents remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest.’
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: But you should not see it like this.
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: I see two reasons to frequent remote lodgings in the wilderness and the forest.
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: I see happiness for myself in this life, and I have sympathy for future generations.”
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: “Indeed, worthy Gotama has sympathy for future generations, since he is a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha.
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: Excellent, worthy Gotama! Excellent, worthy Gotama!
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, worthy Gotama has made the teaching clear in many ways.
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: I go for refuge to the worthy Gotama, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: From this day forth, may the worthy Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
title: Fear and Dread

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
title: Unblemished

segment_text: There Sāriputta addressed the mendicants:
title: Unblemished

segment_text: “Reverends, mendicants!”
title: Unblemished

segment_text: “Reverend,” they replied.
title: Unblemished

segment_text: Sāriputta said this:
title: Unblemished

segment_text: “Reverends, these four people are found in the world.
title: Unblemished

segment_text: What four?
title: Unblemished

segment_text: One person with a blemish doesn’t truly understand: ‘There is a blemish in me.’
title: Unblemished

segment_text: But another person with a blemish does truly understand: ‘There is a blemish in me.’
title: Unblemished

segment_text: One person without a blemish doesn’t truly understand: ‘There is no blemish in me.’
title: Unblemished

segment_text: But another person without a blemish does truly understand: ‘There is no blemish in me.’
title: Unblemished

segment_text: In this case, of the two persons with a blemish, the one who doesn’t understand is said to be worse,
title: Unblemished

segment_text: while the one who does understand is better.
title: Unblemished

segment_text: And of the two persons without a blemish, the one who doesn’t understand is said to be worse,
title: Unblemished

segment_text: while the one who does understand is better.”
title: Unblemished

segment_text: When he said this, Venerable Mahāmoggallāna said to him:
title: Unblemished

segment_text: “What is the cause, Reverend Sāriputta, what is the reason why, of the two persons with a blemish, one is said to be worse and one better?
title: Unblemished

segment_text: And what is the cause, what is the reason why, of the two persons without a blemish, one is said to be worse and one better?”
title: Unblemished

segment_text: “Reverends, take the case of the person who has a blemish and does not understand it. You can expect that they won’t generate enthusiasm, make an effort, or rouse up energy to give up that blemish.
title: Unblemished

segment_text: And they will die with greed, hate, and delusion, blemished, with a corrupted mind.
title: Unblemished

segment_text: Suppose a bronze cup was brought from a shop or smithy covered with dirt or stains.
title: Unblemished

segment_text: And the owners neither used it or had it cleaned, but kept it in a dirty place.
title: Unblemished

segment_text: Over time, wouldn’t that bronze cup get even dirtier and more stained?”
title: Unblemished

segment_text: “Yes, reverend.”
title: Unblemished

segment_text: “In the same way, take the case of the person who has a blemish and does not understand it. You can expect that …
title: Unblemished

segment_text: they will die with a corrupted mind.
title: Unblemished

segment_text: Take the case of the person who has a blemish and does understand it. You can expect that they will generate enthusiasm, make an effort, and rouse up energy to give up that blemish.
title: Unblemished

segment_text: And they will die without greed, hate, and delusion, unblemished, with an uncorrupted mind.
title: Unblemished

title: Unblemished

segment_text: “Reverend, the word ‘blemish’ is spoken of.
title: Unblemished

segment_text: But what is ‘blemish’ a term for?”
title: Unblemished

segment_text: “Reverend, ‘blemish’ is a term for the spheres of bad, unskillful wishes.
title: Unblemished

segment_text: It’s possible that some mendicant might wish:
title: Unblemished

segment_text: ‘If I commit an offense, I hope the mendicants don’t find out!’
title: Unblemished

title: Unblemished

segment_text: has committed an offense.
title: Unblemished

segment_text: Thinking, ‘The mendicants have found out about my offense,’
title: Unblemished

segment_text: And that anger and that bitterness
title: Unblemished

segment_text: are both blemishes.
title: Unblemished

title: Unblemished

title: Unblemished

segment_text: But it’s possible that the mendicants do accuse that mendicant in the middle of the Saṅgha …

title: Unblemished

title: Unblemished

title: Unblemished

segment_text: But it’s possible that the mendicants will enter the village for the meal putting some other mendicant at the very front …

segment_text: It’s possible that some mendicant might wish:
title: Unblemished

title: Unblemished

title: Unblemished

title: Unblemished

title: Unblemished

title: Unblemished

segment_text: But it’s possible that some other mendicant teaches the Dhamma …
title: Unblemished

segment_text: It’s possible that some mendicant might wish:
title: Unblemished

segment_text: ‘Oh, I hope that the monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen will honor, respect, revere, and venerate me alone, not some other mendicant.’
title: Unblemished

segment_text: But it’s possible that some other mendicant is honored, respected, revered, and venerated …
title: Unblemished

segment_text: It’s possible that some mendicant might wish:
title: Unblemished

segment_text: ‘I hope I get the nicest robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick, not some other mendicant.’
title: Unblemished

title: Unblemished

title: Unblemished

segment_text: they get angry and bitter.
title: Unblemished

segment_text: And that anger and that bitterness
title: Unblemished

segment_text: are both blemishes.
title: Unblemished

segment_text: ‘Blemish’ is a term for these spheres of bad, unskillful wishes.
title: Unblemished

segment_text: Suppose these spheres of bad, unskillful wishes are seen and heard to be not given up by a mendicant. Even though they dwell in the wilderness, in remote lodgings, eat only almsfood, wander indiscriminately for almsfood, wear rag robes, and wear shabby robes, their spiritual companions don’t honor, respect, revere, and venerate them.
title: Unblemished

segment_text: Why is that?
title: Unblemished

segment_text: It’s because these spheres of bad, unskillful wishes are seen and heard to be not given up by that venerable.
title: Unblemished

segment_text: Suppose a bronze cup was brought from a shop or smithy clean and bright.
title: Unblemished

segment_text: The owners were to prepare it with the carcass of a snake, a dog, or a human, cover it with a bronze lid, and parade it through the market-place.
title: Unblemished

segment_text: When people saw it they’d say:
title: Unblemished

segment_text: ‘My good man, what is it that you’re carrying like a precious treasure?’
title: Unblemished

segment_text: So they’d open up the lid for people to look inside.
title: Unblemished

segment_text: But as soon as they saw it they were filled with loathing, revulsion, and disgust.
title: Unblemished

segment_text: Not even those who were hungry wanted to eat it, let alone those who had eaten.
title: Unblemished

segment_text: In the same way, when these spheres of bad, unskillful wishes are seen and heard to be not given up by a mendicant … their spiritual companions don’t honor, respect, revere, and venerate them.

segment_text: In the same way, there are those faithless people who went forth from the lay life to homelessness not out of faith but to earn a livelihood. They’re devious, deceitful, and sneaky. They’re restless, insolent, fickle, scurrilous, and loose-tongued. They do not guard their sense doors or eat in moderation, and they are not dedicated to wakefulness. They don’t care about the ascetic life, and don’t keenly respect the training. They’re indulgent and slack, leaders in backsliding, neglecting seclusion, lazy, and lacking energy. They’re unmindful, lacking situational awareness and immersion, with straying minds, witless and idiotic. segment_text: But there are those gentlemen who went forth from the lay life to homelessness out of faith. They’re not devious, deceitful, and sneaky. They’re not restless, insolent, fickle, scurrilous, and loose-tongued. They guard their sense doors and eat in moderation, and they are dedicated to wakefulness. They care about the ascetic life, and keenly respect the training. They’re not indulgent or slack, nor are they leaders in backsliding, neglecting seclusion. They’re energetic and determined. They’re mindful, with situational awareness, immersion, and unified minds; wise and clever. title: The Simile of the Cloth

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
title: The Simile of the Cloth

segment_text: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,
title: The Simile of the Cloth

segment_text: “Mendicants!”
title: The Simile of the Cloth

segment_text: “Venerable sir,” they replied.
title: The Simile of the Cloth

segment_text: The Buddha said this:
title: The Simile of the Cloth

segment_text: “Suppose, mendicants, there was a cloth that was dirty and soiled.
title: The Simile of the Cloth

segment_text: No matter what dye the dyer applied—whether blue or yellow or red or magenta—it would look poorly dyed and impure in color.
title: The Simile of the Cloth

segment_text: Why is that?
title: The Simile of the Cloth

segment_text: Because of the impurity of the cloth.
title: The Simile of the Cloth

segment_text: In the same way, when the mind is corrupt, a bad destiny is to be expected.
title: The Simile of the Cloth

segment_text: Suppose there was a cloth that was pure and clean.
title: The Simile of the Cloth

segment_text: No matter what dye the dyer applied—whether blue or yellow or red or magenta—it would look well dyed and pure in color.
title: The Simile of the Cloth

segment_text: Why is that?
title: The Simile of the Cloth

segment_text: Because of the purity of the cloth.
title: The Simile of the Cloth

segment_text: In the same way, when the mind isn’t corrupt, a good destiny is to be expected.
title: The Simile of the Cloth

segment_text: And what are the corruptions of the mind?
title: The Simile of the Cloth

segment_text: Covetousness and immoral greed, ill will, anger, acrimony, disdain, contempt, jealousy, stinginess, deceit, deviousness, obstinacy, aggression, conceit, arrogance, vanity, and negligence are corruptions of the mind.
title: The Simile of the Cloth

segment_text: A mendicant who understands that covetousness and immoral greed are corruptions of the mind gives them up.
title: The Simile of the Cloth

segment_text: A mendicant who understands that ill will …
title: The Simile of the Cloth

segment_text: negligence is a corruption of the mind gives it up.
title: The Simile of the Cloth

segment_text: When they have understood these corruptions of the mind
title: The Simile of the Cloth

segment_text: for what they are, and have given them up,
title: The Simile of the Cloth

segment_text: they have experiential confidence in the Buddha:
title: The Simile of the Cloth

segment_text: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’
title: The Simile of the Cloth

segment_text: They have experiential confidence in the teaching:
title: The Simile of the Cloth

segment_text: ‘The teaching is well explained by the Buddha—apparent in the present life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves.’
title: The Simile of the Cloth

segment_text: They have experiential confidence in the Saṅgha:
title: The Simile of the Cloth

segment_text: ‘The Saṅgha of the Buddha’s disciples is practicing the way that’s good, direct, systematic, and proper. It consists of the four pairs, the eight individuals. This is the Saṅgha of the Buddha’s disciples that is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of greeting with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.’
title: The Simile of the Cloth

segment_text: When a mendicant has discarded, eliminated, released, given up, and relinquished to this extent, thinking, ‘I have experiential confidence in the Buddha …
title: The Simile of the Cloth

segment_text: the teaching …
title: The Simile of the Cloth

segment_text: the Saṅgha,’ they find inspiration in the meaning and the teaching, and find joy connected with the teaching.
title: The Simile of the Cloth

segment_text: Thinking: ‘I have discarded, eliminated, released, given up, and relinquished to this extent,’ they find inspiration in the meaning and the teaching, and find joy connected with the teaching.
title: The Simile of the Cloth

segment_text: When they’re joyful, rapture springs up. When the mind is full of rapture, the body becomes tranquil. When the body is tranquil, they feel bliss. And when they’re blissful, the mind becomes immersed in samādhi.
title: The Simile of the Cloth

segment_text: When a mendicant of such ethics, such qualities, and such wisdom eats boiled fine rice with the dark grains picked out and served with many soups and sauces, that is no obstacle for them.
title: The Simile of the Cloth

segment_text: Compare with cloth that is dirty and soiled; it can be made pure and clean by pure water. Or native gold, which can be made pure and bright by a forge.
title: The Simile of the Cloth

segment_text: In the same way, when a mendicant of such ethics, such qualities, and such wisdom eats boiled fine rice with the dark grains picked out and served with many soups and sauces, that is no obstacle for them.
title: The Simile of the Cloth

In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of love to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.

title: Right View

segment_text: “Reverends, they speak of this thing called ‘right view’.
title: Right View

segment_text: How do you define a noble disciple who has right view, whose view is correct, who has experiential confidence in the teaching, and has come to the true teaching?”
title: Right View

segment_text: “Reverend, we would travel a long way to learn the meaning of this statement in the presence of Venerable Sāriputta.

title: Right View

segment_text: “Yes, reverend,” they replied.
title: Right View

segment_text: Sāriputta said this:
title: Right View

segment_text: “A noble disciple understands the unskillful and its root, and the skillful and its root.
title: Right View

segment_text: When they’ve done this, they’re defined as a noble disciple who has right view, whose view is correct, who has experiential confidence in the teaching, and has come to the true teaching.
title: Right View

segment_text: But what is the unskillful and what is its root? And what is the skillful and what is its root?
title: Right View

segment_text: Killing living creatures, stealing, and sexual misconduct; speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical; and covetousness, ill will, and wrong view.
title: Right View

segment_text: This is called the unskillful.
title: Right View

segment_text: And what is the root of the unskillful?
title: Right View

segment_text: Greed, hate, and delusion.
title: Right View

segment_text: This is called the root of the unskillful.
title: Right View

segment_text: And what is the skillful?
title: Right View

segment_text: Avoiding killing living creatures, stealing, and sexual misconduct; avoiding speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical; contentment, good will, and right view.
title: Right View

segment_text: This is called the skillful.
title: Right View

segment_text: And what is the root of the skillful?
title: Right View

segment_text: Contentment, love, and understanding.
title: Right View

segment_text: This is called the root of the skillful.
title: Right View

segment_text: A noble disciple understands in this way the unskillful and its root, and the skillful and its root. They’ve completely given up the underlying tendency to greed, got rid of the underlying tendency to repulsion, and eradicated the underlying tendency to the view and conceit ‘I am’. They’ve given up ignorance and given rise to knowledge, and make an end of suffering in this very life.
title: Right View

segment_text: When they’ve done this, they’re defined as a noble disciple who has right view, whose view is correct, who has experiential confidence in the teaching, and has come to the true teaching.”

segment_text: There are these three defilements.
title: Right View

segment_text: The defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.
title: Right View

segment_text: Defilement originates from ignorance. Defilement ceases when ignorance ceases. The practice that leads to the cessation of defilement is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:
title: Right View

segment_text: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

segment_text: A noble disciple understands in this way defilement, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation. They’ve completely given up the underlying tendency to greed, got rid of the underlying tendency to repulsion, and eradicated the underlying tendency to the view and conceit ‘I am’. They’ve given up ignorance and given rise to knowledge, and make an end of suffering in this very life.

title: The Shorter Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying outside the city of Vesālī in a woodland grove west of the town.

segment_text: Furthermore, the Realized One recollects many kinds of past lives. That is: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. He remembers: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so he recollects his many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: Since he truly understands this, this is a power of the Realized One. …
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: Furthermore, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, the Realized One sees sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. He understands how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds. ‘These dear beings did bad things by way of body, speech, and mind. They denounced the noble ones; they had wrong view; and they chose to act out of that wrong view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. These dear beings, however, did good things by way of body, speech, and mind. They never denounced the noble ones; they had right view; and they chose to act out of that right view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.’ And so, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, he sees sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. He understands how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: Since he truly understands this, this is a power of the Realized One. …

segment_text: Sāriputta, there are these four kinds of reproduction.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: What four?
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: Reproduction for creatures born from an egg, from a womb, from moisture, or spontaneously.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: And what is reproduction from an egg?
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: There are beings who are born by breaking out of an eggshell.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: This is called reproduction from an egg.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: And what is reproduction from a womb?
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: There are beings who are born by breaking out of the amniotic sac.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: This is called reproduction from a womb.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: And what is reproduction from moisture?
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: There are beings who are born in a rotten fish, in a rotten carcass, in rotten dough, in a cesspool or a sump.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: This is called reproduction from moisture.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: And what is spontaneous reproduction?
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: Gods, hell-beings, certain humans, and certain beings in the lower realms.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: This is called spontaneous reproduction.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: These are the four kinds of reproduction.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: Sāriputta, I recall having practiced a spiritual path consisting of four factors.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: I used to be a fervent mortifier, the ultimate fervent mortifier. I used to live rough, the ultimate rough-liver. I used to live in disgust of sin, the ultimate one living in disgust of sin. I used to be secluded, in ultimate seclusion.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: And this is what my fervent mortification was like. I went naked, ignoring conventions. I licked my hands, and didn’t come or stop when asked. I didn’t consent to food brought to me, or food prepared specially for me, or an invitation for a meal.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: I didn’t receive anything from a pot or bowl; or from someone who keeps sheep, or who has a weapon or a shovel in their home; or where a couple is eating; or where there is a woman who is pregnant, breastfeeding, or who lives with a man; or where food for distribution is advertised; or where there’s a dog waiting or flies buzzing. I accepted no fish or meat or beer or wine, and drank no fermented gruel.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: I went to just one house for alms, taking just one mouthful, or two houses and two mouthfuls, up to seven houses and seven mouthfuls.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: I fed on one saucer a day, two saucers a day, up to seven saucers a day.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: I ate once a day, once every second day, up to once a week, and so on, even up to once a fortnight. I lived committed to the practice of eating food at set intervals.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: I ate herbs, millet, wild rice, poor rice, water lettuce, rice bran, scum from boiling rice, sesame flour, grass, or cow dung. I survived on forest roots and fruits, or eating fallen fruit.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: I wore robes of sunn hemp, mixed hemp, corpse-wrapping cloth, rags, lodh tree bark, antelope hide (whole or in strips), kusa grass, bark, wood-chips, human hair, horse-tail hair, or owls’ wings.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: I tore out hair and beard, committed to this practice.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: I constantly stood, refusing seats.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: I squatted, committed to the endeavor of squatting.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: I lay on a mat of thorns, making a mat of thorns my bed.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: I was devoted to ritual bathing three times a day, including the evening.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: And so I lived committed to practicing these various ways of mortifying and tormenting the body.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: Such was my practice of fervent mortification.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: And this is what my rough living was like.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: The dust and dirt built up on my body over many years until it started flaking off.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: It’s like the trunk of a pale-moon ebony tree, which builds up bark over many years until it starts flaking off.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: But it didn’t occur to me:
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: ‘Oh, this dust and dirt must be rubbed off by my hand or another’s.’
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: That didn’t occur to me.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: Such was my rough living.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: And this is what my living in disgust of sin was like.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: I’d step forward or back ever so mindfully, so I was full of pity regarding even a drop of water, thinking:
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: ‘May I not injure any little creatures on unclear ground.’
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: Such was my living in disgust of sin.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: And this is what my seclusion was like.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: I would plunge deep into a wilderness region and stay there.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: When I saw a cowherd or a shepherd, or someone gathering grass or sticks, or a lumberjack, I’d flee from forest to forest, from thicket to thicket, from valley to valley, from uplands to uplands.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: Why is that?
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: So that I wouldn’t see them, nor they me.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: I fled like a wild deer seeing a human being.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: Such was my practice of seclusion.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: I would go on all fours into the cow-pens after the cattle had left and eat the dung of the young suckling calves.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: As long as my own urine and excrement lasted, I would even eat that.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: Such was my eating of most unnatural things.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: I would plunge deep into an awe-inspiring forest grove and stay there.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: It was so awe-inspiring that
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: normally it would make your hair stand on end if you weren’t free of greed.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: And on days such as the cold spell when the snow falls in the January winter, I stayed in the open by night and in the forest by day.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: But in the last month of summer I’d stay in the open by day and in the forest by night.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: And then these verses, which were neither supernaturally inspired, nor learned before in the past, occurred to me:
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: ‘Scorched and frozen,
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: alone in the awe-inspiring forest.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: Naked, no fire to sit beside,
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: the sage still pursues his quest.’
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: I would make my bed in a charnel ground, with the bones of the dead for a pillow.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: Then village louts would come up to me. They’d spit and piss on me, throw mud on me, even poke sticks in my ears.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: But I don’t recall ever having a bad thought about them.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: Such was my abiding in equanimity.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: ‘Purity comes from food.’
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: They say:
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: ‘Let’s live on jujubes.’
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: So they eat jujubes and jujube powder, and drink jujube juice.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: And they enjoy many jujube concoctions.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: I recall eating just a single jujube.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: You might think that
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: at that time the jujubes must have been very big.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: But you should not see it like this.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: The jujubes then were at most the same size as today.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: Eating so very little, my body became extremely emaciated.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: Due to eating so little, my major and minor limbs became like the joints of an eighty-year-old or a dying man,
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: my bottom became like a camel’s hoof,
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: my vertebrae stuck out like beads on a string,
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: and my ribs were as gaunt as the broken-down rafters on an old barn.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: Due to eating so little, the gleam of my eyes sank deep in their sockets, like the gleam of water sunk deep down a well.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: Due to eating so little, my scalp shriveled and withered like a green bitter-gourd in the wind and sun.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: Due to eating so little, the skin of my belly stuck to my backbone, so that when I tried to rub the skin of my belly I grabbed my backbone, and when I tried to rub my backbone I rubbed the skin of my belly.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: Due to eating so little, when I tried to urinate or defecate I fell face down right there.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: Due to eating so little, when I tried to relieve my body by rubbing my limbs with my hands, the hair, rotted at its roots, fell out.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: ‘Purity comes from food.’
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: They say:
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: ‘Let’s live on mung beans.’ …
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: ‘Let’s live on sesame.’ …
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: ‘Let’s live on ordinary rice.’ …
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: Due to eating so little, when I tried to relieve my body by rubbing my limbs with my hands, the hair, rotted at its roots, fell out.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: But Sāriputta, I did not achieve any superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones by that conduct, that practice, that grueling work.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: Why is that?
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: Because I didn’t achieve that noble wisdom that’s noble and emancipating, and which delivers one who practices it to the complete ending of suffering.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: ‘Purity comes from transmigration.’
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: But it’s not easy to find a realm that I haven’t previously transmigrated to in all this long time, except for the gods of the pure abodes.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: For if I had transmigrated to the gods of the pure abodes I would not have returned to this realm again.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: ‘Purity comes from rebirth.’
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: But it’s not easy to find any rebirth that I haven’t previously been reborn in …
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: ‘Purity comes from abode of rebirth.’
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: But it’s not easy to find an abode where I haven’t previously abided …
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: ‘Purity comes from sacrifice.’
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: But it’s not easy to find a sacrifice that I haven’t previously offered in all this long time, when I was an anointed aristocratic king or a well-to-do brahmin.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar
