title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: ‘Purity comes from serving the sacred flame.’
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: But it’s not easy to find a fire that I haven’t previously served in all this long time, when I was an anointed aristocratic king or a well-to-do brahmin.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: ‘So long as this gentleman is youthful, young, with pristine black hair, blessed with youth, in the prime of life he will be endowed with perfect lucidity of wisdom.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: But when he’s old, elderly, and senior, advanced in years, and has reached the final stage of life—eighty, ninety, or a hundred years old—he will lose his lucidity of wisdom.’
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: But you should not see it like this.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: For now I am old, elderly, and senior, I’m advanced in years, and have reached the final stage of life. I am eighty years old.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: Suppose I had four disciples with a lifespan of a hundred years. And they each were perfect in memory, range, retention, and perfect lucidity of wisdom.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: Imagine how easily a well-trained expert archer with a strong bow would shoot a light arrow across the shadow of a palm tree.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: That’s how extraordinary they were in memory, range, retention, and perfect lucidity of wisdom.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: They’d bring up questions about the four kinds of mindfulness meditation again and again, and I would answer each question. They’d remember the answers and not ask the same question twice.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: And they’d pause only to eat and drink, go to the toilet, and sleep to dispel weariness. But the Realized One would not run out of Dhamma teachings, words and phrases of the teachings, or spontaneous answers.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: And at the end of a hundred years my four disciples would pass away.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: Even if you have to carry me around on a stretcher, there will never be any deterioration in the Realized One’s lucidity of wisdom.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: And if there’s anyone of whom it may be rightly said that
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: a being not liable to delusion has arisen in the world for the welfare and happiness of the people, out of sympathy for the world, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans, it’s of me that this should be said.”
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: Now at that time Venerable Nāgasamāla was standing behind the Buddha fanning him.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: Then he said to the Buddha:
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: “It’s incredible, sir, it’s amazing!
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: While I was listening to this exposition of the teaching my hair stood up!
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: What is the name of this exposition of the teaching?”
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: “Well then, Nāgasamāla, you may remember this exposition of the teaching as ‘The Hair-raising Discourse’.”
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: That is what the Buddha said.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: Satisfied, Venerable Nāgasamāla approved what the Buddha said.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Lion’s Roar

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: Then several mendicants robed up in the morning and, taking their bowls and robes, entered Sāvatthī for alms.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: Then it occurred to them,
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: “It’s too early to wander for alms in Sāvatthī.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: Why don’t we visit the monastery of the wanderers of other religions?”
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: Then they went to the monastery of the wanderers of other religions and exchanged greetings with the wanderers there.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, they sat down to one side. The wanderers said to them:
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: “Reverends, the ascetic Gotama advocates the complete understanding of sensual pleasures, and so do we.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: The ascetic Gotama advocates the complete understanding of forms, and so do we.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: The ascetic Gotama advocates the complete understanding of feelings, and so do we.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: What, then, is the difference between the ascetic Gotama’s teaching and instruction and ours?”
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: Those mendicants neither approved nor dismissed that statement of the wanderers of other religions.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: They got up from their seat, thinking,
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: “We will learn the meaning of this statement from the Buddha himself.”
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: Then, after the meal, when they returned from almsround, they went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened. The Buddha said:
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: “Mendicants, when wanderers of other religions say this, you should say to them:
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: ‘But reverends, what’s the gratification, the drawback, and the escape when it comes to sensual pleasures?
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: What’s the gratification, the drawback, and the escape when it comes to forms?
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: What’s the gratification, the drawback, and the escape when it comes to feelings?’
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: Questioned like this, the wanderers of other religions would be stumped, and, in addition, would get frustrated.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: Why is that?
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: Because they’re out of their element.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: I don’t see anyone in this world—with its gods, Māras, and Divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans—who could provide a satisfying answer to these questions except for the Realized One or his disciple or someone who has heard it from them.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: And what is the gratification of sensual pleasures?
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: There are these five kinds of sensual stimulation.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: What five?
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: Sights known by the eye, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: Sounds known by the ear …
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: Smells known by the nose …
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: Tastes known by the tongue …
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: Touches known by the body, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: These are the five kinds of sensual stimulation.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: The pleasure and happiness that arise from these five kinds of sensual stimulation: this is the gratification of sensual pleasures.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: And what is the drawback of sensual pleasures?
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: It’s when a gentleman earns a living by means such as
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: arithmetic, accounting, calculating, farming, trade, raising cattle, archery, government service, or one of the professions.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: But they must face cold and heat, being hurt by the touch of flies, mosquitoes, wind, sun, and reptiles, and risking death from hunger and thirst.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: This is a drawback of sensual pleasures apparent in the present life, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: That gentleman might try hard, strive, and make an effort, but fail to earn any money.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: If this happens, they sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion, saying:
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: ‘Oh, my hard work is wasted. My efforts are fruitless!’
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: This too is a drawback of sensual pleasures apparent in the present life, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: That gentleman might try hard, strive, and make an effort, and succeed in earning money.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: But they experience pain and sadness when they try to protect it, thinking:
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: ‘How can I prevent my wealth from being taken by rulers or bandits, consumed by fire, swept away by flood, or taken by unloved heirs?’
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: And even though they protect it and ward it, rulers or bandits take it, or fire consumes it, or flood sweeps it away, or unloved heirs take it.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: They sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion:
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: ‘What once was mine is gone.’
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: This too is a drawback of sensual pleasures apparent in the present life, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: Furthermore, for the sake of sensual pleasures kings fight with kings, aristocrats fight with aristocrats, brahmins fight with brahmins, and householders fight with householders. A mother fights with her child, child with mother, father with child, and child with father. Brother fights with brother, brother with sister, sister with brother, and friend fights with friend.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: Once they’ve started quarreling, arguing, and disputing, they attack each other with fists, stones, rods, and swords,
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: resulting in death and deadly pain.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: This too is a drawback of sensual pleasures apparent in the present life, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: Furthermore, for the sake of sensual pleasures they don their sword and shield, fasten their bow and arrows, and plunge into a battle massed on both sides, with arrows and spears flying and swords flashing.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: There they are struck with arrows and spears, and their heads are chopped off,
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: resulting in death and deadly pain.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: This too is a drawback of sensual pleasures apparent in the present life, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: Furthermore, for the sake of sensual pleasures they don their sword and shield, fasten their bow and arrows, and charge wetly plastered bastions, with arrows and spears flying and swords flashing.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: There they are struck with arrows and spears, splashed with dung, crushed by a superior force, and their heads are chopped off,
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: resulting in death and deadly pain.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: This too is a drawback of sensual pleasures apparent in the present life, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: Furthermore, for the sake of sensual pleasures they break into houses, plunder wealth, steal from isolated buildings, commit highway robbery, and commit adultery.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: The rulers would arrest them and subject them to various punishments—
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: whipping, caning, and clubbing; cutting off hands or feet, or both; cutting off ears or nose, or both; the ‘porridge pot’, the ‘shell-shave’, the ‘Rāhu’s mouth’, the ‘garland of fire’, the ‘burning hand’, the ‘bulrush twist’, the ‘bark dress’, the ‘antelope’, the ‘meat hook’, the ‘coins’, the ‘caustic pickle’, the ‘twisting bar’, the ‘straw mat’; being splashed with hot oil, being fed to the dogs, being impaled alive, and being beheaded.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: These result in death and deadly pain.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: This too is a drawback of sensual pleasures apparent in the present life, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: Furthermore, for the sake of sensual pleasures, they conduct themselves badly by way of body, speech, and mind.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: This is a drawback of sensual pleasures to do with lives to come, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: And what is the escape from sensual pleasures?
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: Removing and giving up desire and greed for sensual pleasures: this is the escape from sensual pleasures.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: There are ascetics and brahmins who don’t truly understand sensual pleasures’ gratification, drawback, and escape in this way for what they are. It’s impossible for them to completely understand sensual pleasures themselves, or to instruct another so that, practicing accordingly, they will completely understand sensual pleasures.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: There are ascetics and brahmins who do truly understand sensual pleasures’ gratification, drawback, and escape in this way for what they are. It is possible for them to completely understand sensual pleasures themselves, or to instruct another so that, practicing accordingly, they will completely understand sensual pleasures.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: And what is the gratification of forms?
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: Suppose there was a girl of the brahmins, aristocrats, or householders in her fifteenth or sixteenth year, neither too tall nor too short, neither too thin nor too fat, neither too dark nor too fair. Is she not at the height of her beauty and prettiness?”
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: “Yes, sir.”
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: “The pleasure and happiness that arise from this beauty and prettiness
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: is the gratification of forms.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: And what is the drawback of forms?
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: Suppose that some time later you were to see that same sister—eighty, ninety, or a hundred years old—bent double, crooked, leaning on a staff, trembling as they walk, ailing, past their prime, with teeth broken, hair grey and scanty or bald, skin wrinkled, and limbs blotchy.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: What do you think, mendicants?
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: Has not that former beauty vanished and the drawback become clear?”
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: “Yes, sir.”
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: “This is the drawback of forms.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: Furthermore, suppose that you were to see that same sister sick, suffering, gravely ill, collapsed in her own urine and feces, being picked up by some and put down by others.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: What do you think, mendicants?
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: Has not that former beauty vanished and the drawback become clear?”
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: “Yes, sir.”
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: “This too is the drawback of forms.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: Furthermore, suppose that you were to see that same sister as a corpse discarded in a charnel ground. And it had been dead for one, two, or three days, bloated, livid, and festering.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: What do you think, mendicants?
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: Has not that former beauty vanished and the drawback become clear?”
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: “Yes, sir.”
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: “This too is the drawback of forms.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: Furthermore, suppose that you were to see that same sister as a corpse discarded in a charnel ground. And it was being devoured by crows, hawks, vultures, herons, dogs, tigers, leopards, jackals, and many kinds of little creatures …
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: Furthermore, suppose that you were to see that same sister as a corpse discarded in a charnel ground.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: And it had been reduced to a skeleton with flesh and blood, held together by sinews … a skeleton rid of flesh but smeared with blood, and held together by sinews … a skeleton rid of flesh and blood, held together by sinews …
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: bones rid of sinews scattered in every direction. Here a hand-bone, there a foot-bone, here an ankle bone, there a shin-bone, here a thigh-bone, there a hip-bone, here a rib-bone, there a back-bone, here an arm-bone, there a neck-bone, here a jaw-bone, there a tooth, here the skull. …
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: Furthermore, suppose that you were to see that same sister as a corpse discarded in a charnel ground.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: And it had been reduced to white bones, the color of shells … decrepit bones, heaped in a pile … bones rotted and crumbled to powder.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: Removing and giving up desire and greed for forms: this is the escape from forms.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: And what is the gratification of feelings?
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: It’s when a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: At that time a mendicant doesn’t intend to hurt themselves, hurt others, or hurt both;
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: they feel only feelings that are not hurtful.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: Freedom from being hurt is the ultimate gratification of feelings, I say.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: Furthermore, a mendicant enters and remains in the second absorption …
title: The Longer Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: And what is the drawback of feelings?

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans, near Kapilavatthu in the Banyan Tree Monastery.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: Then Mahānāma the Sakyan went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: “For a long time, sir, I have understood your teaching like this:
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: ‘Greed, hate, and delusion are corruptions of the mind.’
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: Despite understanding this, sometimes my mind is occupied by thoughts of greed, hate, and delusion.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: I wonder what qualities remain in me that I have such thoughts?”
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: “Mahānāma, there is a quality that remains in you that makes you have such thoughts.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: For if you had given up that quality you would not still be living at home and enjoying sensual pleasures.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: But because you haven’t given up that quality you are still living at home and enjoying sensual pleasures.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: Sensual pleasures give little gratification and much suffering and distress, and they are all the more full of drawbacks.

segment_text: they can return to sensual pleasures.

segment_text: they do not return to sensual pleasures.

segment_text: If this happens, they sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion, saying: ‘Oh, my hard work is wasted. My efforts are fruitless!’
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: This too is a drawback of sensual pleasures apparent in the present life, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: That gentleman might try hard, strive, and make an effort, and succeed in earning money.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: But they experience pain and sadness when they try to protect it, thinking:
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: ‘How can I prevent my wealth from being taken by rulers or bandits, consumed by fire, swept away by flood, or taken by unloved heirs?’
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: And even though they protect it and ward it, rulers or bandits take it, or fire consumes it, or flood sweeps it away, or unloved heirs take it.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: They sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion:
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: ‘What once was mine is gone.’
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: This too is a drawback of sensual pleasures apparent in the present life, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: Furthermore, for the sake of sensual pleasures kings fight with kings, aristocrats fight with aristocrats, brahmins fight with brahmins, and householders fight with householders. A mother fights with her child, child with mother, father with child, and child with father. Brother fights with brother, brother with sister, sister with brother, and friend fights with friend.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: Once they’ve started quarreling, arguing, and disputing, they attack each other with fists, stones, rods, and swords,
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: resulting in death and deadly pain.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: This too is a drawback of sensual pleasures apparent in the present life, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: Furthermore, for the sake of sensual pleasures they don their sword and shield, fasten their bow and arrows, and plunge into a battle massed on both sides, with arrows and spears flying and swords flashing.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: There they are struck with arrows and spears, and their heads are chopped off,
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: resulting in death and deadly pain.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: This too is a drawback of sensual pleasures apparent in the present life, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: Furthermore, for the sake of sensual pleasures they don their sword and shield, fasten their bow and arrows, and charge wetly plastered bastions, with arrows and spears flying and swords flashing.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: There they are struck with arrows and spears, splashed with dung, crushed by a superior force, and their heads are chopped off,
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: resulting in death and deadly pain.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: This too is a drawback of sensual pleasures apparent in the present life, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: Furthermore, for the sake of sensual pleasures they break into houses, plunder wealth, steal from isolated buildings, commit highway robbery, and commit adultery.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: The rulers would arrest them and subject them to various punishments—
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: whipping, caning, and clubbing; cutting off hands or feet, or both; cutting off ears or nose, or both; the ‘porridge pot’, the ‘shell-shave’, the ‘Rāhu’s mouth’, the ‘garland of fire’, the ‘burning hand’, the ‘bulrush twist’, the ‘bark dress’, the ‘antelope’, the ‘meat hook’, the ‘coins’, the ‘caustic pickle’, the ‘twisting bar’, the ‘straw mat’; being splashed with hot oil, being fed to the dogs, being impaled alive, and being beheaded.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: These result in death and deadly pain.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: This too is a drawback of sensual pleasures apparent in the present life, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: Furthermore, for the sake of sensual pleasures, they conduct themselves badly by way of body, speech, and mind.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: This is a drawback of sensual pleasures to do with lives to come, a mass of suffering caused by sensual pleasures.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: Mahānāma, this one time I was staying near Rājagaha, on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: Now at that time several Jain ascetics on the slopes of Isigili at the Black Rock were constantly standing, refusing seats. And they felt painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings due to overexertion.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: Then in the late afternoon, I came out of retreat and went to the Black Rock to visit those Jain ascetics. I said to them,
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: ‘Reverends, why are you constantly standing, refusing seats, so that you suffer painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings due to overexertion?’
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: When I said this, those Jain ascetics said to me,
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: ‘Reverend, the Jain ascetic of the Ñātika clan claims to be all-knowing and all-seeing, to know and see everything without exception, thus:
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: “Knowledge and vision are constantly and continually present to me, while walking, standing, sleeping, and waking.”
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: He says,
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: “O Jain ascetics, you have done bad deeds in a past life. Wear them away with these severe and grueling austerities.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: And when in the present you are restrained in body, speech, and mind, you’re not doing any bad deeds for the future.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: So, due to eliminating past deeds by fervent mortification, and not doing any new deeds, there’s nothing to come up in the future.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: With no future consequence, deeds end. With the ending of deeds, suffering ends. With the ending of suffering, feeling ends. And with the ending of feeling, all suffering will have been worn away.”
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: We endorse and accept this, and we are satisfied with it.’
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: When they said this, I said to them,
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: ‘But reverends, do you know
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: for sure that you existed in the past, and it is not the case that you did not exist?’
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: ‘No we don’t, reverend.’
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: ‘But reverends, do you know
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: for sure that you did bad deeds in the past?’
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: ‘No we don’t, reverend.’
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: ‘But reverends, do you know
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: that you did such and such bad deeds?’
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: ‘No we don’t, reverend.’
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: ‘But reverends, do you know
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: that so much suffering has already been worn away? Or that so much suffering still remains to be worn away? Or that when so much suffering is worn away all suffering will have been worn away?’
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: ‘No we don’t, reverend.’
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: ‘But reverends, do you know
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: about giving up unskillful qualities in this very life and embracing skillful qualities?’
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: ‘No we don’t, reverend.’
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: ‘So it seems that you don’t know any of these things.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: That being so, when those in the world who are violent and bloody-handed and of cruel livelihood are reborn among humans they go forth as Jain ascetics.’
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: ‘Reverend Gotama, pleasure is not gained through pleasure; pleasure is gained through pain.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: For if pleasure were to be gained through pleasure, King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha would gain pleasure, since he lives in greater pleasure than Venerable Gotama.’
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: ‘Clearly the venerables have spoken rashly, without reflection.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: Rather, I’m the one who should be asked about
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: who lives in greater pleasure, King Bimbisāra or Venerable Gotama?’
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: ‘Clearly we spoke rashly and without reflection.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: But let that be. Now we ask Venerable Gotama:
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: “Who lives in greater pleasure, King Bimbisāra or Venerable Gotama?”’
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: ‘Well then, reverends, I’ll ask you about this in return, and you can answer as you like.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: What do you think, reverends?
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: Is King Bimbisāra capable of experiencing perfect happiness for seven days and nights without moving his body or speaking?’
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: ‘No he is not, reverend.’
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: ‘What do you think, reverends?
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: Is King Bimbisāra capable of experiencing perfect happiness for six days …
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: five days …
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: four days …
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: three days …
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: two days …
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: one day?’
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: ‘No he is not, reverend.’
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: ‘But I am capable of experiencing perfect happiness for one day and night without moving my body or speaking.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: I am capable of experiencing perfect happiness for two days …
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: three days …
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: four days …
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: five days …
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: six days …
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: seven days.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: What do you think, reverends? This being so, who lives in greater pleasure, King Bimbisāra or I?’
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: ‘This being so, Venerable Gotama lives in greater pleasure than King Bimbisāra.’”
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: That is what the Buddha said.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: Satisfied, Mahānāma the Sakyan approved what the Buddha said.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Mass of Suffering

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: Measuring Up

segment_text: At one time Venerable Mahāmoggallāna was staying in the land of the Bhaggas at Crocodile Hill, in the deer park at Bhesakaḷā’s Wood.
title: Measuring Up

segment_text: There Venerable Mahāmoggallāna addressed the mendicants:
title: Measuring Up

segment_text: “Reverends, mendicants!”
title: Measuring Up

segment_text: “Reverend,” they replied.
title: Measuring Up

segment_text: Venerable Mahāmoggallāna said this:
title: Measuring Up

segment_text: “Suppose a mendicant invites
title: Measuring Up

segment_text: other mendicants to admonish them. But they’re hard to admonish, having qualities that make them hard to admonish. They’re impatient, and don’t take instruction respectfully. So their spiritual companions don’t think it’s worth advising and instructing them, and that person doesn’t gain their trust.
title: Measuring Up

segment_text: And what are the qualities that make them hard to admonish?
title: Measuring Up

segment_text: Firstly, a mendicant has corrupt wishes, having fallen under the sway of corrupt wishes.
title: Measuring Up

segment_text: This is a quality that makes them difficult to admonish.
title: Measuring Up

segment_text: Furthermore, a mendicant glorifies themselves and puts others down. …
title: Measuring Up

segment_text: They’re irritable, overcome by anger …
title: Measuring Up

segment_text: They’re irritable, and acrimonious due to anger …
title: Measuring Up

segment_text: They’re irritable, and stubborn due to anger …
title: Measuring Up

segment_text: They’re irritable, and blurt out words bordering on anger …
title: Measuring Up

segment_text: When accused, they object to the accuser …
title: Measuring Up

segment_text: When accused, they rebuke the accuser …
title: Measuring Up

segment_text: When accused, they retort to the accuser …
title: Measuring Up

segment_text: When accused, they dodge the issue, distract the discussion with irrelevant points, and display annoyance, hate, and bitterness …
title: Measuring Up

segment_text: When accused, they are unable to account for the evidence …
title: Measuring Up

segment_text: They are offensive and contemptuous …
title: Measuring Up

segment_text: They’re jealous and stingy …
title: Measuring Up

segment_text: They’re devious and deceitful …
title: Measuring Up

segment_text: They’re obstinate and arrogant …
title: Measuring Up

segment_text: Furthermore, a mendicant is attached to their own views, holding them tight, and refusing to let go.
title: Measuring Up

segment_text: This too is a quality that makes them difficult to admonish.
title: Measuring Up

segment_text: These are the qualities that make them hard to admonish.
title: Measuring Up

segment_text: Suppose a mendicant doesn’t invite
title: Measuring Up

segment_text: other mendicants to admonish them. But they’re easy to admonish, having qualities that make them easy to admonish. They’re accepting, and take instruction respectfully. So their spiritual companions think it’s worth advising and instructing them, and that person gains their trust.
title: Measuring Up

segment_text: And what are the qualities that make them easy to admonish?
title: Measuring Up

segment_text: Firstly, a mendicant doesn’t have corrupt wishes …
title: Measuring Up

segment_text: Furthermore, a mendicant isn’t attached to their own views, not holding them tight, but letting them go easily.
title: Measuring Up

segment_text: These are the qualities that make them easy to admonish.
title: Measuring Up

segment_text: In such a case, a mendicant should measure themselves like this.
title: Measuring Up

segment_text: ‘This person has corrupt wishes, having fallen under the sway of corrupt wishes. And I don’t like or approve of this person.
title: Measuring Up

segment_text: And if I were to fall under the sway of corrupt wishes, others wouldn’t like or approve of me.’
title: Measuring Up

segment_text: A mendicant who knows this should give rise to the thought: ‘I will not fall under the sway of corrupt wishes.’ …
title: Measuring Up

segment_text: ‘This person is attached to their own views, holding them tight and refusing to let go. And I don’t like or approve of this person.
title: Measuring Up

segment_text: And if I were to be attached to my own views, holding them tight and refusing to let go, others wouldn’t like or approve of me.’
title: Measuring Up

segment_text: A mendicant who knows this should give rise to the thought: ‘I will not be attached to my own views, holding them tight, but will let them go easily.’
title: Measuring Up

segment_text: In such a case, a mendicant should check themselves like this:
title: Measuring Up

segment_text: ‘Do I have corrupt wishes? Have I fallen under the sway of corrupt wishes?’
title: Measuring Up

segment_text: Suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows that
title: Measuring Up

segment_text: they have fallen under the sway of corrupt wishes. Then they should make an effort to give up those bad, unskillful qualities.
title: Measuring Up

segment_text: But suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows that
title: Measuring Up

segment_text: they haven’t fallen under the sway of corrupt wishes. Then they should meditate with rapture and joy, training day and night in skillful qualities. …
title: Measuring Up

segment_text: Suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows that
title: Measuring Up

segment_text: they are attached to their own views, holding them tight, and refusing to let go. Then they should make an effort to give up those bad, unskillful qualities.
title: Measuring Up

segment_text: Suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant knows that
title: Measuring Up

segment_text: they’re not attached to their own views, holding them tight, but let them go easily. Then they should meditate with rapture and joy, training day and night in skillful qualities.
title: Measuring Up

segment_text: Suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant sees that they haven’t given up all these bad, unskillful qualities. Then they should make an effort to give them all up.
title: Measuring Up

segment_text: But suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant sees that they have given up all these bad, unskillful qualities. Then they should meditate with rapture and joy, training day and night in skillful qualities.
title: Measuring Up

segment_text: Suppose there was a woman or man who was young, youthful, and fond of adornments, and they check their own reflection in a clean bright mirror or a clear bowl of water. If they see any dirt or blemish there, they’d try to remove it.
title: Measuring Up

segment_text: But if they don’t see any dirt or blemish there, they’re happy, thinking:
title: Measuring Up

segment_text: ‘How fortunate that I’m clean!’
title: Measuring Up

segment_text: In the same way, suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant sees that they haven’t given up all these bad, unskillful qualities. Then they should make an effort to give them all up.
title: Measuring Up

segment_text: But suppose that, upon checking, a mendicant sees that they have given up all these bad, unskillful qualities. Then they should meditate with rapture and joy, training day and night in skillful qualities.”
title: Measuring Up

segment_text: This is what Venerable Mahāmoggallāna said.
title: Measuring Up

segment_text: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what Venerable Mahāmoggallāna said.
title: Measuring Up

segment_text: So I have heard.

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans, near Kapilavatthu in the Banyan Tree Monastery.
title: The Honey-Cake

segment_text: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Kapilavatthu for alms.
title: The Honey-Cake

segment_text: He wandered for alms in Kapilavatthu. After the meal, on his return from almsround, he went to the Great Wood for the day’s meditation,
title: The Honey-Cake

segment_text: plunged deep into it, and sat at the root of a young wood-apple tree to meditate.
title: The Honey-Cake

segment_text: Daṇḍapāṇi the Sakyan, while going for a walk,
title: The Honey-Cake

segment_text: plunged deep into the Great Wood. He approached the Buddha and exchanged greetings with him.
title: The Honey-Cake

segment_text: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he stood to one side leaning on his staff, and said to the Buddha,
title: The Honey-Cake

segment_text: “What is the ascetic’s doctrine? What does he assert?”
title: The Honey-Cake

segment_text: “Good sir, my doctrine is such that one does not conflict with anyone in this world with its gods, Māras, and Divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans. And it is such that perceptions do not underlie the brahmin who lives detached from sensual pleasures, without indecision, stripped of worry, and rid of craving for rebirth in this or that state.
title: The Honey-Cake

segment_text: That is my doctrine, and that is what I assert.”
title: The Honey-Cake

segment_text: When he had spoken, Daṇḍapāṇi shook his head, waggled his tongue, raised his eyebrows until his brow puckered in three furrows, and departed leaning on his staff.
title: The Honey-Cake

segment_text: When he had spoken, one of the mendicants said to him,
title: The Honey-Cake

title: The Honey-Cake

segment_text: And how is it that perceptions do not underlie the Buddha, the brahmin who lives detached from sensual pleasures, without indecision, stripped of worry, and rid of craving for rebirth in this or that state?”
title: The Honey-Cake

segment_text: “Mendicant, judgments driven by proliferating perceptions beset a person.
title: The Honey-Cake

title: The Honey-Cake

segment_text: This is where these bad, unskillful qualities cease without anything left over.”
title: The Honey-Cake

segment_text: ‘This thought of harmlessness has arisen in me.

segment_text: It doesn’t lead to hurting myself, hurting others, or hurting both. It nourishes wisdom, it’s on the side of freedom from distress, and it leads to extinguishment.’
title: Two Kinds of Thought

segment_text: If I were to keep on thinking and considering this all night …
title: Two Kinds of Thought

segment_text: all day …
title: Two Kinds of Thought

segment_text: all night and day, I see no danger that would come from that.
title: Two Kinds of Thought

segment_text: Still, thinking and considering for too long would tire my body.
title: Two Kinds of Thought

segment_text: And when the body is tired, the mind is stressed.
title: Two Kinds of Thought

segment_text: And when the mind is stressed, it’s far from immersion.
title: Two Kinds of Thought

segment_text: So I stilled, settled, unified, and immersed my mind internally.
title: Two Kinds of Thought

segment_text: Why is that?
title: Two Kinds of Thought

segment_text: So that my mind would not be stressed.
title: Two Kinds of Thought

segment_text: Whatever a mendicant frequently thinks about and considers becomes their heart’s inclination.
title: Two Kinds of Thought

segment_text: If they often think about and consider thoughts of renunciation, they’ve given up sensual thought to cultivate the thought of renunciation. Their mind inclines to thoughts of renunciation.
title: Two Kinds of Thought

segment_text: If they often think about and consider thoughts of good will … their mind inclines to thoughts of good will.
title: Two Kinds of Thought

segment_text: If they often think about and consider thoughts of harmlessness … their mind inclines to thoughts of harmlessness.
title: Two Kinds of Thought

segment_text: Suppose it’s the last month of summer, when all the crops have been gathered within a village, and a cowherd must take care of the cattle. While at the root of a tree or in the open he need only be mindful that
title: Two Kinds of Thought

segment_text: the cattle are there.
title: Two Kinds of Thought

segment_text: In the same way I needed only to be mindful that
title: Two Kinds of Thought

segment_text: those things were there.
title: Two Kinds of Thought

segment_text: My energy was roused up and unflagging, my mindfulness was established and lucid, my body was tranquil and undisturbed, and my mind was immersed in samādhi and unified.
title: Two Kinds of Thought

segment_text: Quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, I entered and remained in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
title: Two Kinds of Thought

segment_text: As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected were stilled, I entered and remained in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.
title: Two Kinds of Thought

segment_text: And with the fading away of rapture, I entered and remained in the third absorption, where I meditated with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’
title: Two Kinds of Thought

segment_text: With the giving up of pleasure and pain, and the ending of former happiness and sadness, I entered and remained in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.
title: Two Kinds of Thought

segment_text: When my mind had immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—I extended it toward recollection of past lives.
title: Two Kinds of Thought

segment_text: I recollected many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
title: Two Kinds of Thought

segment_text: This was the first knowledge, which I achieved in the first watch of the night.
title: Two Kinds of Thought

segment_text: Ignorance was destroyed and knowledge arose; darkness was destroyed and light arose, as happens for a meditator who is diligent, keen, and resolute.
title: Two Kinds of Thought

segment_text: When my mind had become immersed in samādhi like this, I extended it toward knowledge of the death and rebirth of sentient beings.
title: Two Kinds of Thought

segment_text: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, I saw sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. I understood how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds.
title: Two Kinds of Thought

segment_text: This was the second knowledge, which I achieved in the middle watch of the night.
title: Two Kinds of Thought

segment_text: Ignorance was destroyed and knowledge arose; darkness was destroyed and light arose, as happens for a meditator who is diligent, keen, and resolute.
title: Two Kinds of Thought

segment_text: When my mind had become immersed in samādhi like this, I extended it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements.
title: Two Kinds of Thought

segment_text: I truly understood: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’
title: Two Kinds of Thought

segment_text: I truly understood: ‘These are defilements’ … ‘This is the origin of defilements’ … ‘This is the cessation of defilements’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of defilements.’
title: Two Kinds of Thought

segment_text: Knowing and seeing like this, my mind was freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.
title: Two Kinds of Thought

segment_text: I understood: ‘Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is nothing further for this place.’
title: Two Kinds of Thought

segment_text: This was the third knowledge, which I achieved in the last watch of the night.
title: Two Kinds of Thought

segment_text: Ignorance was destroyed and knowledge arose; darkness was destroyed and light arose, as happens for a meditator who is diligent, keen, and resolute.
title: Two Kinds of Thought

segment_text: Suppose that in a forested wilderness there was an expanse of low-lying marshes,
title: Two Kinds of Thought

segment_text: and a large herd of deer lived nearby.
title: Two Kinds of Thought

segment_text: Then along comes a person who wants to harm, injure, and threaten them.
title: Two Kinds of Thought

segment_text: They close off the safe, secure path that leads to happiness, and open the wrong path. There they plant domesticated male and female deer as decoys
title: Two Kinds of Thought

segment_text: so that, in due course, that herd of deer would fall to ruin and disaster.
title: Two Kinds of Thought

segment_text: Then along comes a person who wants to help keep the herd of deer safe.
title: Two Kinds of Thought

segment_text: They open up the safe, secure path that leads to happiness, and close off the wrong path. They get rid of the decoys
title: Two Kinds of Thought

segment_text: so that, in due course, that herd of deer would grow, increase, and mature.
title: Two Kinds of Thought

segment_text: I’ve made up this simile to make a point.
title: Two Kinds of Thought

segment_text: And this is what it means.
title: Two Kinds of Thought

segment_text: ‘An expanse of low-lying marshes’ is a term for sensual pleasures.
title: Two Kinds of Thought

segment_text: ‘A large herd of deer’ is a term for sentient beings.
title: Two Kinds of Thought

segment_text: ‘A person who wants to harm, injure, and threaten them’ is a term for Māra the Wicked.
title: Two Kinds of Thought

segment_text: ‘The wrong path’ is a term for the wrong eightfold path, that is,
title: Two Kinds of Thought

segment_text: wrong view, wrong thought, wrong speech, wrong action, wrong livelihood, wrong effort, wrong mindfulness, and wrong immersion.
title: Two Kinds of Thought

segment_text: ‘A domesticated male deer’ is a term for greed and relishing.
title: Two Kinds of Thought

segment_text: ‘A domesticated female deer’ is a term for ignorance.
title: Two Kinds of Thought

segment_text: ‘A person who wants to help keep the herd of deer safe’ is a term for the Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.
title: Two Kinds of Thought

segment_text: ‘The safe, secure path that leads to happiness’ is a term for the noble eightfold path, that is:
title: Two Kinds of Thought

segment_text: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.
title: Two Kinds of Thought

segment_text: So, mendicants, I have opened up the safe, secure path to happiness and closed off the wrong path. And I have got rid of the male and female decoys.
title: Two Kinds of Thought

segment_text: Out of sympathy, I’ve done what a teacher should do who wants what’s best for their disciples.
title: Two Kinds of Thought

segment_text: Here are these roots of trees, and here are these empty huts. Practice absorption, mendicants! Don’t be negligent! Don’t regret it later! This is my instruction to you.”
title: Two Kinds of Thought

segment_text: That is what the Buddha said.
title: Two Kinds of Thought

segment_text: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
title: Two Kinds of Thought

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: How to Stop Thinking

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
title: How to Stop Thinking

segment_text: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,
title: How to Stop Thinking

segment_text: “Mendicants!”
title: How to Stop Thinking

segment_text: “Venerable sir,” they replied.
title: How to Stop Thinking

segment_text: The Buddha said this:
title: How to Stop Thinking

segment_text: “Mendicants, a mendicant committed to the higher mind should focus on five subjects from time to time.
title: How to Stop Thinking

segment_text: What five?
title: How to Stop Thinking

segment_text: Take a mendicant who is focusing on some subject that gives rise to bad, unskillful thoughts connected with desire, hate, and delusion. That mendicant should focus on some other subject connected with the skillful.
title: How to Stop Thinking

segment_text: As they do so, those bad thoughts are given up and come to an end.
title: How to Stop Thinking

segment_text: Their mind becomes stilled internally; it settles, unifies, and becomes immersed in samādhi.
title: How to Stop Thinking

segment_text: It’s like a deft mason or their apprentice who’d knock out or extract a large peg with a finer peg.
title: How to Stop Thinking

segment_text: In the same way, a mendicant … should focus on some other basis of meditation connected with the skillful …
title: How to Stop Thinking

segment_text: Now, suppose that mendicant is focusing on some other subject connected with the skillful, but bad, unskillful thoughts connected with desire, hate, and delusion keep coming up. They should examine the drawbacks of those thoughts:
title: How to Stop Thinking

segment_text: ‘So these thoughts are unskillful, they’re blameworthy, and they result in suffering.’
title: How to Stop Thinking

segment_text: As they do so, those bad thoughts are given up and come to an end.
title: How to Stop Thinking

segment_text: Their mind becomes stilled internally; it settles, unifies, and becomes immersed in samādhi.
title: How to Stop Thinking

segment_text: Suppose there was a woman or man who was young, youthful, and fond of adornments. If the carcass of a snake or a dog or a human were hung around their neck, they’d be horrified, repelled, and disgusted.
title: How to Stop Thinking

segment_text: In the same way, a mendicant … should examine the drawbacks of those thoughts …
title: How to Stop Thinking

segment_text: Now, suppose that mendicant is examining the drawbacks of those thoughts, but bad, unskillful thoughts connected with desire, hate, and delusion keep coming up. They should try to forget and ignore them.
title: How to Stop Thinking

segment_text: As they do so, those bad thoughts are given up and come to an end.
title: How to Stop Thinking

segment_text: Their mind becomes stilled internally; it settles, unifies, and becomes immersed in samādhi.
title: How to Stop Thinking

segment_text: Suppose there was a person with clear eyes, and some undesirable sights came into their range of vision.
title: How to Stop Thinking

segment_text: They’d just close their eyes or look away.
title: How to Stop Thinking

segment_text: In the same way, a mendicant … those bad thoughts are given up and come to an end …
title: How to Stop Thinking

segment_text: Now, suppose that mendicant is ignoring and forgetting about those thoughts, but bad, unskillful thoughts connected with desire, hate, and delusion keep coming up. They should focus on stopping the formation of thoughts.
title: How to Stop Thinking

segment_text: As they do so, those bad thoughts are given up and come to an end.
title: How to Stop Thinking

segment_text: Their mind becomes stilled internally; it settles, unifies, and becomes immersed in samādhi.
title: How to Stop Thinking

segment_text: Suppose there was a person walking quickly.
title: How to Stop Thinking

segment_text: They’d think:
title: How to Stop Thinking

segment_text: ‘Why am I walking so quickly?
title: How to Stop Thinking

segment_text: Why don’t I slow down?’
title: How to Stop Thinking

segment_text: So they’d slow down.
title: How to Stop Thinking

segment_text: They’d think:
title: How to Stop Thinking

segment_text: ‘Why am I walking slowly?
title: How to Stop Thinking

segment_text: Why don’t I stand still?’
title: How to Stop Thinking

segment_text: So they’d stand still.
title: How to Stop Thinking

segment_text: They’d think:
title: How to Stop Thinking

segment_text: ‘Why am I standing still?
title: How to Stop Thinking

segment_text: Why don’t I sit down?’
title: How to Stop Thinking

segment_text: So they’d sit down.
title: How to Stop Thinking

segment_text: They’d think:
title: How to Stop Thinking

segment_text: ‘Why am I sitting?
title: How to Stop Thinking

segment_text: Why don’t I lie down?’
title: How to Stop Thinking

segment_text: So they’d lie down.
title: How to Stop Thinking

segment_text: And so that person would reject successively coarser postures and adopt more subtle ones.
title: How to Stop Thinking

segment_text: In the same way, a mendicant … those thoughts are given up and come to an end …
title: How to Stop Thinking

segment_text: Now, suppose that mendicant is focusing on stopping the formation of thoughts, but bad, unskillful thoughts connected with desire, hate, and delusion keep coming up.
title: How to Stop Thinking

segment_text: With teeth clenched and tongue pressed against the roof of the mouth, they should squeeze, squash, and crush mind with mind.
title: How to Stop Thinking

segment_text: As they do so, those bad thoughts are given up and come to an end.
title: How to Stop Thinking

segment_text: Their mind becomes stilled internally; it settles, unifies, and becomes immersed in samādhi.
title: How to Stop Thinking

segment_text: It’s like a strong man who grabs a weaker man by the head or throat or shoulder and squeezes, squashes, and crushes them.
title: How to Stop Thinking

segment_text: In the same way, a mendicant …
title: How to Stop Thinking

segment_text: with teeth clenched and tongue pressed against the roof of the mouth, should squeeze, squash, and crush mind with mind.
title: How to Stop Thinking

segment_text: As they do so, those bad thoughts are given up and come to an end.
title: How to Stop Thinking

segment_text: Their mind becomes stilled internally; it settles, unifies, and becomes immersed in samādhi.
title: How to Stop Thinking

segment_text: Now, take the mendicant who is focusing on some subject that gives rise to bad, unskillful thoughts connected with desire, hate, and delusion. They focus on some other subject connected with the skillful …
title: How to Stop Thinking

segment_text: They examine the drawbacks of those thoughts …
title: How to Stop Thinking

segment_text: They try to forget and ignore about those thoughts …
title: How to Stop Thinking

segment_text: They focus on stopping the formation of thoughts …
title: How to Stop Thinking

segment_text: With teeth clenched and tongue pressed against the roof of the mouth, they squeeze, squash, and crush mind with mind. When they succeed in each of these things, those bad thoughts are given up and come to an end.
title: How to Stop Thinking

segment_text: Their mind becomes stilled internally; it settles, unifies, and becomes immersed in samādhi.
title: How to Stop Thinking

segment_text: This is called a mendicant who is a master of the ways of thought.
title: How to Stop Thinking

segment_text: They will think what they want to think, and they won’t think what they don’t want to think.
title: How to Stop Thinking

segment_text: They’ve cut off craving, untied the fetters, and by rightly comprehending conceit have made an end of suffering.”
title: How to Stop Thinking

segment_text: That is what the Buddha said.
title: How to Stop Thinking

segment_text: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
title: How to Stop Thinking

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: Now at that time, Venerable Phagguna of the Top-Knot was spending too long mixing closely with some nuns.
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: So much so that
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: if any mendicant criticized those nuns in his presence, Phagguna of the Top-Knot got angry and upset, and even instigated disciplinary proceedings.
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: And if any mendicant criticized Phagguna of the Top-Knot in their presence, those nuns got angry and upset, and even instigated disciplinary proceedings.
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: That’s how close Phagguna of the Top-Knot was with those nuns.
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what was going on.
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: So the Buddha addressed one of the monks,
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: “Please, monk, in my name tell the mendicant Phagguna of the Top-Knot that
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: the teacher summons him.”
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: “Yes, sir,” that monk replied. He went to Phagguna of the Top-Knot and said to him,
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: “Reverend Phagguna, the teacher summons you.”
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: “Yes, reverend,” Phagguna replied. He went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him:
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: “Is it really true, Phagguna, that you’ve been spending too long mixing closely with some nuns?
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: So much so that
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: if any mendicant criticizes those nuns in your presence, you get angry and upset, and even instigate disciplinary proceedings?
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: And if any mendicant criticizes you in those nuns’ presence, they get angry and upset, and even instigate disciplinary proceedings?
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: Is that how close you’ve become with those nuns?”
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: “Yes, sir.”
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: “Phagguna, are you not a gentleman who has gone forth out of faith from the lay life to homelessness?”
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: “Yes, sir.”
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: “As such, it’s not appropriate for you to mix so closely with those nuns.
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: So if anyone criticizes those nuns in your presence, you should give up any desires or thoughts of domestic life.
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: If that happens, you should train like this:
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: ‘My mind will not degenerate. I will blurt out no bad words. I will remain full of sympathy, with a heart of love and no secret hate.’
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: That’s how you should train.
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: So even if someone strikes those nuns with fists, stones, rods, and swords in your presence, you should give up any desires or thoughts of domestic life.
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: If that happens, you should train like this:
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: ‘My mind will not degenerate. I will blurt out no bad words. I will remain full of sympathy, with a heart of love and no secret hate.’
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: That’s how you should train.
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: So if anyone criticizes you in your presence, you should give up any desires or thoughts of domestic life.
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: If that happens, you should train like this: ‘My mind will not degenerate. I will blurt out no bad words. I will remain full of sympathy, with a heart of love and no secret hate.’
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: That’s how you should train.
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: So Phagguna, even if someone strikes you with fists, stones, rods, and swords, you should give up any desires or thoughts of domestic life.
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: If that happens, you should train like this: ‘My mind will not degenerate. I will blurt out no bad words. I will remain full of sympathy, with a heart of love and no secret hate.’
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: That’s how you should train.”
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: Then the Buddha said to the mendicants:
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: “Mendicants, I used to be satisfied with the mendicants.
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: Once, I addressed them:
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: ‘I eat my food in one sitting per day.
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: Doing so, I find that I’m healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: You too should eat your food in one sitting per day.
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: Doing so, you’ll find that you’re healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.’
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: I didn’t have to keep on instructing those mendicants;
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: I just had to prompt their mindfulness.
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: Suppose a chariot stood harnessed to thoroughbreds at a level crossroads, with a goad ready.
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: A deft horse trainer, a master charioteer, might mount the chariot, taking the reins in his right hand and goad in the left. He’d drive out and back wherever he wishes, whenever he wishes.
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: In the same way, I didn’t have to keep on instructing those mendicants;
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: I just had to prompt their mindfulness.
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: So, mendicants, you too should give up what’s unskillful and devote yourselves to skillful qualities.
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: In this way you’ll achieve growth, improvement, and maturity in this teaching and training.
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: Suppose that not far from a town or village there was a large grove of sal trees
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: that was choked with castor-oil weeds.
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: Then along comes a person who wants to help protect and nurture that grove.
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: They’d cut down the crooked sal saplings that were robbing the sap, and throw them out. They’d clean up the interior of the grove,
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: and properly care for the straight, well-formed sal saplings.
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: In this way, in due course, that sal grove would grow, increase, and mature.
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: In the same way, mendicants, you too should give up what’s unskillful and devote yourselves to skillful qualities.
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: In this way you’ll achieve growth, improvement, and maturity in this teaching and training.
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: Once upon a time, mendicants, right here in Sāvatthī there was a housewife named Vedehikā.
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: She had this good reputation:
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: ‘The housewife Vedehikā is sweet, even-tempered, and calm.’
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: Now, Vedehikā had a bonded maid named Kāḷī who was deft, tireless, and well-organized in her work.
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: Then Kāḷī thought,
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: ‘My mistress has a good reputation as being
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: sweet, even-tempered, and calm.
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: But does she actually have anger in her and just not show it? Or does she have no anger?
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: Or is it just because my work is well-organized that she doesn’t show anger, even though she still has it inside?
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: Why don’t I test my mistress?’
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: So Kāḷī got up during the day.
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: Vedehikā said to her,
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: ‘Oi wench, Kāḷī!’
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: ‘What is it, ma’am?’
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: ‘You’re getting up in the day—what’s up with you, wench?’
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: ‘Nothing, ma’am.’
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: ‘Oh, so nothing’s up, you naughty maid, but you get up in the day!’ Angry and upset, she scowled.
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: Then Kāḷī thought,
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: ‘My mistress actually has anger in her and just doesn’t show it; it’s not that she has no anger.
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: It’s just because my work is well-organized that she doesn’t show anger, even though she still has it inside.
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: Why don’t I test my mistress further?’
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: So Kāḷī got up later in the day.
title: The Simile of the Saw

title: The Simile of the Saw

title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: ‘Oh, so nothing’s up, you naughty maid, but you get up even later in the day!’ Angry and upset, she grabbed a door-pin and hit Kāḷī on the head, cracking it open.
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: Then Kāḷī, with blood pouring from her cracked skull, denounced her mistress to the neighbors,
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: ‘See, ladies, what the sweet one did!
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: See what the even-tempered one did! See what the calm one did!
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: How on earth can she grab a door-pin and hit her only maid on the head, cracking it open, just for getting up late?’
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: Then after some time the housewife Vedehikā got this bad reputation:
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: ‘The housewife Vedehikā is fierce, ill-tempered, and not calm at all.’
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: In the same way, a mendicant may be the sweetest of the sweet, the most even-tempered of the even-tempered, the calmest of the calm, so long as they don’t encounter any disagreeable criticism.
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: But it’s when they encounter disagreeable criticism that you’ll know whether they’re really sweet, even-tempered, and calm.
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: I don’t say that a mendicant is easy to admonish if they make themselves easy to admonish only for the sake of robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: Why is that?
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: Because when they don’t get robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick, they’re no longer easy to admonish.
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: But when a mendicant is easy to admonish purely because they honor, respect, revere, worship, and venerate the teaching, then I say that they’re easy to admonish.
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: So, mendicants, you should train yourselves: ‘We will be easy to admonish purely because we honor, respect, revere, worship, and venerate the teaching.’
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: That’s how you should train.
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: Mendicants, there are these five ways in which others might criticize you.
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: Their speech may be timely or untimely,
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: true or false,
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: gentle or harsh,
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: beneficial or harmful,
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: from a heart of love or from secret hate.
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: When others criticize you, they may do so in any of these ways.
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: If that happens, you should train like this:
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: ‘Our minds will not degenerate. We will blurt out no bad words. We will remain full of sympathy, with a heart of love and no secret hate.
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: We will meditate spreading a heart of love to that person. And with them as a basis, we will meditate spreading a heart full of love to everyone in the world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.’
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: That’s how you should train.
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: Suppose a person was to come along carrying a spade and basket
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: and say,
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: ‘I shall make this great earth be without earth!’
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: And they’d dig all over, scatter all over, spit all over, and urinate all over, saying,
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: ‘Be without earth! Be without earth!’
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: What do you think, mendicants?
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: Could that person make this great earth be without earth?”
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: “No, sir.
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: Why is that?
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: Because this great earth is deep and limitless.
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: It’s not easy to make it be without earth.
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: That person will eventually get weary and frustrated.”
title: The Simile of the Saw
