title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: Even if low-down bandits were to sever you limb from limb with a two-handed saw, anyone who had a malevolent thought on that account would not be following my instructions.
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: If that happens, you should train like this:
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: ‘Our minds will not degenerate. We will blurt out no bad words. We will remain full of sympathy, with a heart of love and no secret hate.
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: We will meditate spreading a heart of love to that person. And with them as a basis, we will meditate spreading a heart full of love to everyone in the world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.’
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: That’s how you should train.
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: If you frequently reflect on this advice on the simile of the saw,
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: do you see any criticism, large or small, that you could not endure?”
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: “No, sir.”
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: “So, mendicants, you should frequently reflect on this advice on the simile of the saw.
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: This will be for your lasting welfare and happiness.”
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: That is what the Buddha said.
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
title: The Simile of the Saw

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: Now at that time a mendicant called Ariṭṭha, who had previously been a vulture trapper, had the following harmful misconception:
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: “As I understand the Buddha’s teaching, the acts that he says are obstructions are not really obstructions for the one who performs them.”
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: Several mendicants heard about this.
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: They went up to Ariṭṭha and said to him,
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: “Is it really true, Reverend Ariṭṭha, that you have such a harmful misconception:
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: ‘As I understand the Buddha’s teaching, the acts that he says are obstructions are not really obstructions for the one who performs them’?”
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: “Absolutely, reverends. As I understand the Buddha’s teaching, the acts that he says are obstructions are not really obstructions for the one who performs them.”
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: Then, wishing to dissuade Ariṭṭha from his view, the mendicants pursued, pressed, and grilled him,
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: “Don’t say that, Ariṭṭha! Don’t misrepresent the Buddha, for misrepresentation of the Buddha is not good. And the Buddha would not say that.
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: In many ways the Buddha has said that obstructive acts are obstructive, and that they really do obstruct the one who performs them.
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: The Buddha says that sensual pleasures give little gratification and much suffering and distress, and they are all the more full of drawbacks.
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: With the similes of a skeleton …
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: a scrap of meat …
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: a grass torch …
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: a pit of glowing coals …
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: a dream …
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: borrowed goods …
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: fruit on a tree …
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: a butcher’s knife and chopping board …
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: swords and spears …
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: a snake’s head, the Buddha says that sensual pleasures give little gratification and much suffering and distress, and they are all the more full of drawbacks.”
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: But even though the mendicants pursued, pressed, and grilled him in this way, Ariṭṭha obstinately stuck to his misconception and insisted on it.
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: When they weren’t able to dissuade Ariṭṭha from his view, the mendicants went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened.
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: So the Buddha addressed one of the monks,
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: “Please, monk, in my name tell the mendicant Ariṭṭha, formerly a vulture trapper, that
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: the teacher summons him.”
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: “Yes, sir,” that monk replied. He went to Ariṭṭha and said to him,
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: “Reverend Ariṭṭha, the teacher summons you.”
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: “Yes, reverend,” Ariṭṭha replied. He went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him,
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: “Is it really true, Ariṭṭha, that you have such a harmful misconception:
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: ‘As I understand the Buddha’s teaching, the acts that he says are obstructions are not really obstructions for the one who performs them’?”
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: “Absolutely, sir. As I understand the Buddha’s teaching, the acts that he says are obstructions are not really obstructions for the one who performs them.”
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: “Futile man, who on earth have you ever known me to teach in that way?
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: Haven’t I said in many ways that obstructive acts are obstructive, and that they really do obstruct the one who performs them?
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: I’ve said that sensual pleasures give little gratification and much suffering and distress, and they are all the more full of drawbacks.
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: With the similes of a skeleton …
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: a scrap of meat …
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: a grass torch …
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: a pit of glowing coals …
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: a dream …
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: borrowed goods …
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: fruit on a tree …
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: a butcher’s knife and chopping board …
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: swords and spears …
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: a snake’s head, I’ve said that sensual pleasures give little gratification and much suffering and distress, and they are all the more full of drawbacks.
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: But still you misrepresent me by your wrong grasp, harm yourself, and create much wickedness.
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: This will be for your lasting harm and suffering.”
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: Then the Buddha said to the mendicants,
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: “What do you think, mendicants?
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: Has this mendicant Ariṭṭha kindled even a spark of ardor in this teaching and training?”
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: “How could that be, sir?
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: No, sir.”
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: When this was said, Ariṭṭha sat silent, dismayed, shoulders drooping, downcast, depressed, with nothing to say.
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: Knowing this, the Buddha said,
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: “Futile man, you will be known by your own harmful misconception.
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: I’ll question the mendicants about this.”
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: Then the Buddha said to the mendicants,
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: “Mendicants, do you understand my teaching as Ariṭṭha does, when he misrepresents me by his wrong grasp, harms himself, and creates much wickedness?”
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: “No, sir.
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: For in many ways the Buddha has told us that obstructive acts are obstructive, and that they really do obstruct the one who performs them.
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: The Buddha has said that sensual pleasures give little gratification and much suffering and distress, and they are all the more full of drawbacks.
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: With the similes of a skeleton …
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: a snake’s head, the Buddha has said that sensual pleasures give little gratification and much suffering and distress, and they are all the more full of drawbacks.”
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: “Good, good, mendicants! It’s good that you understand my teaching like this.
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: For in many ways I have said that obstructive acts are obstructive …
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: I’ve said that sensual pleasures give little gratification and much suffering and distress, and they are all the more full of drawbacks.
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: But still this Ariṭṭha misrepresents me by his wrong grasp, harms himself, and creates much wickedness.
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: This will be for his lasting harm and suffering.
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: Truly, mendicants, it is quite impossible to perform sensual acts without sensual desires, sensual perceptions, and sensual thoughts.
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: Take a futile person who memorizes the teaching—
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: statements, mixed prose & verse, discussions, verses, inspired exclamations, legends, stories of past lives, amazing stories, and elaborations.
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: But they don’t examine the meaning of those teachings with wisdom,
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: and so don’t come to an acceptance of them after deliberation.
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: They memorize the teaching for the sake of finding fault and winning debates.
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: They don’t realize the goal for which they memorized them.
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: Because they’re wrongly grasped, those teachings lead to their lasting harm and suffering.
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: Why is that?
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: Because of their wrong grasp of the teachings.
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: Suppose there was a person in need of a cobra. And while wandering in search of a cobra
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: they’d see a big cobra,
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: and grasp it by the coil or the tail.
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: But that cobra would twist back and bite them on the hand or the arm or other major or minor limb,
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: resulting in death or deadly pain.
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: Why is that?
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: Because of their wrong grasp of the cobra.
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: In the same way, a futile person memorizes the teaching …
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: and those teachings lead to their lasting harm and suffering.
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: Why is that?
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: Because of their wrong grasp of the teachings.
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: Now, take a gentleman who memorizes the teaching—
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: statements, mixed prose & verse, discussions, verses, inspired exclamations, legends, stories of past lives, amazing stories, and elaborations.
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: And once he’s memorized them, he examines their meaning with wisdom,
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: and comes to an acceptance of them after deliberation.
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: He doesn’t memorize the teaching for the sake of finding fault and winning debates.
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: He realizes the goal for which he memorized them.
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: Because they’re correctly grasped, those teachings lead to his lasting welfare and happiness.
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: Why is that?
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: Because of his correct grasp of the teachings.
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: Suppose there was a person in need of a cobra. And while wandering in search of a cobra
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: they’d see a big cobra,
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: and hold it down carefully with a cleft stick.
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: Only then would they correctly grasp it by the neck.
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: And even though that cobra might wrap its coils around that person’s hand or arm or some other major or minor limb, that wouldn’t result in death or deadly pain.
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: Why is that?
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: Because of their correct grasp of the cobra.
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: In the same way, a gentleman memorizes the teaching …
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: and those teachings lead to his lasting welfare and happiness.
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: Why is that?
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: Because of his correct grasp of the teachings.
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: So, mendicants, when you understand what I’ve said, you should remember it accordingly.
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: But if I’ve said anything that you don’t understand, you should ask me about it, or some competent mendicants.
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: Mendicants, I will teach you a simile of the teaching as a raft: for crossing over, not for holding on.
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: Listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: “Yes, sir,” they replied.
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: The Buddha said this:
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: “Suppose there was a person traveling along the road.
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: They’d see a large deluge, whose near shore was dubious and perilous, while the far shore was a sanctuary free of peril.
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: But there was no ferryboat or bridge for crossing over.
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: They’d think,
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: ‘Why don’t I gather grass, sticks, branches, and leaves and make a raft? Riding on the raft, and paddling with my hands and feet, I can safely reach the far shore.’
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: And so they’d do exactly that.
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: And when they’d crossed over to the far shore, they’d think,
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: ‘This raft has been very helpful to me.
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: Riding on the raft, and paddling with my hands and feet, I have safely crossed over to the far shore.
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: Why don’t I hoist it on my head or pick it up on my shoulder and go wherever I want?’
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: What do you think, mendicants?
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: Would that person be doing what should be done with that raft?”
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: “No, sir.”
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: “And what, mendicants, should that person do with the raft?
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: When they’d crossed over they should think,
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: ‘This raft has been very helpful to me. …
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: Why don’t I beach it on dry land or set it adrift on the water and go wherever I want?’
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: That’s what that person should do with the raft.
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: In the same way, I have taught a simile of the teaching as a raft: for crossing over, not for holding on.
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: By understanding the simile of the raft, you will even give up the teachings, let alone what is not the teachings.
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: Mendicants, there are these six grounds for views.
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: What six?
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: Take an unlearned ordinary person who has not seen the noble ones, and is neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the noble ones. They’ve not seen true persons, and are neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the true persons.

segment_text: Such a mendicant is one who is called ‘one who has lifted the cross-bar’, ‘one who has filled in the moat’, ‘one who has pulled up the pillar’, ‘one who is unimpeded’, and also ‘a noble one with banner lowered and burden dropped, detached’.

segment_text: Thus the teaching has been well explained by me, made clear, opened, illuminated, and stripped of patchwork.

segment_text: In this teaching there are mendicants who are perfected, who have ended the defilements, completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their own goal, utterly ended the fetter of continued existence, and are rightly freed through enlightenment. For them, there is no cycle of rebirths to be found. …
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: In this teaching there are mendicants who have given up the five lower fetters. All of them are reborn spontaneously. They are extinguished there, and are not liable to return from that world. …
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: In this teaching there are mendicants who, having given up three fetters, and weakened greed, hate, and delusion, are once-returners. All of them come back to this world once only, then make an end of suffering. …
title: The Simile of the Cobra

segment_text: In this teaching there are mendicants who have ended three fetters. All of them are stream-enterers, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, bound for awakening. …

segment_text: In this teaching there are mendicants who are followers of teachings, or followers by faith. All of them are bound for awakening.

segment_text: Then, when the night had passed, Kassapa the Prince went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened. Then he asked:
title: The Termite Mound

segment_text: “Sir, what is the termite mound? What is the fuming by night and flaming by day? Who is the brahmin, and who the clever one? What are the sword, the digging, the sticking point, the bullfrog, the forked path, the filter of ash, the tortoise, the butcher’s knife and chopping board, and the scrap of meat? And what is the cobra?”
title: The Termite Mound

segment_text: “Mendicant, ‘termite mound’ is a term for this body made up of the four principal states, produced by mother and father, built up from rice and porridge, liable to impermanence, to wearing away and erosion, to breaking up and destruction.

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.

segment_text: Then several mendicants who had completed the rainy season residence in their native land went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to them:

segment_text: ‘Personally having few wishes, they speak to the mendicants on having few wishes. Personally having contentment, seclusion, aloofness, energy, ethics, immersion, wisdom, freedom, and the knowledge and vision of freedom, they speak to the mendicants on all these things. They’re an adviser and counselor, one who educates, encourages, fires up, and inspires their spiritual companions.’”
title: Chariots at the Ready

segment_text: Mendicants, before my awakening—when I was still unawakened but intent on awakening—I too, being liable to be reborn, sought what is also liable to be reborn. Myself liable to grow old, fall sick, die, sorrow, and become corrupted, I sought what is also liable to these things.
title: The Noble Quest

segment_text: Then it occurred to me:
title: The Noble Quest

title: The Noble Quest

segment_text: Why don’t I seek that which is free of rebirth, old age, sickness, death, sorrow, and corruption, the supreme sanctuary from the yoke, extinguishment?’

segment_text: Who will quickly understand this teaching?’
title: The Noble Quest

segment_text: Then it occurred to me,
title: The Noble Quest

segment_text: ‘The group of five mendicants were very helpful to me. They looked after me during my time of resolute striving.
title: The Noble Quest

segment_text: Why don’t I teach them first of all?’
title: The Noble Quest

segment_text: Then I thought,
title: The Noble Quest

segment_text: ‘Where are the group of five mendicants staying these days?’
title: The Noble Quest

segment_text: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman I saw that the group of five mendicants were staying near Varanasi, in the deer park at Isipatana.
title: The Noble Quest

segment_text: So, when I had stayed in Uruvelā as long as I pleased, I set out for Varanasi.
title: The Noble Quest

title: The Noble Quest

segment_text: and said,
title: The Noble Quest

title: The Noble Quest

title: The Noble Quest

title: The Noble Quest

title: The Noble Quest

segment_text: unsullied in the midst of all things.

title: The Noble Quest

title: The Noble Quest

title: The Noble Quest

segment_text: There is no-one like me.
title: The Noble Quest

segment_text: In the world with its gods,
title: The Noble Quest

segment_text: I have no rival.
title: The Noble Quest

segment_text: For in this world, I am the perfected one;
title: The Noble Quest

title: The Noble Quest

title: The Noble Quest

title: The Noble Quest

title: The Noble Quest

title: The Noble Quest

title: The Noble Quest

segment_text: have reached the ending of defilements.
title: The Noble Quest

segment_text: I have conquered bad qualities, Upaka—
title: The Noble Quest

segment_text: that’s why I’m a victor.’
title: The Noble Quest

segment_text: When I had spoken, Upaka said: ‘If you say so, reverend.’ Shaking his head, he took a wrong turn and left.
title: The Noble Quest

segment_text: Traveling stage by stage, I arrived at Varanasi, and went to see the group of five mendicants in the deer park at Isipatana.
title: The Noble Quest

segment_text: The group of five mendicants saw me coming off in the distance
title: The Noble Quest

segment_text: and stopped each other, saying,
title: The Noble Quest

segment_text: ‘Here comes the ascetic Gotama. He’s so indulgent; he strayed from the struggle and returned to indulgence.
title: The Noble Quest

segment_text: We shouldn’t bow to him or rise for him or receive his bowl and robe.
title: The Noble Quest

segment_text: But we can set out a seat; he can sit if he likes.’
title: The Noble Quest

segment_text: Yet as I drew closer, the group of five mendicants were unable to stop themselves as they had agreed.
title: The Noble Quest

segment_text: Some came out to greet me and receive my bowl and robe, some spread out a seat, while others set out water for washing my feet.
title: The Noble Quest

segment_text: But they still addressed me by name and as ‘reverend’.
title: The Noble Quest

segment_text: So I said to them,
title: The Noble Quest

segment_text: ‘Mendicants, don’t address me by name and as “reverend”.
title: The Noble Quest

segment_text: The Realized One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha.
title: The Noble Quest

segment_text: Listen up, mendicants: I have achieved freedom from death! I shall instruct you, I will teach you the Dhamma.
title: The Noble Quest

segment_text: By practicing as instructed you will soon realize the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life. You will live having achieved with your own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.’
title: The Noble Quest

segment_text: But they said to me,
title: The Noble Quest

segment_text: As the group of five mendicants were being advised and instructed by me like this, being themselves liable to be reborn, understanding the drawbacks in being liable to be reborn, they sought that which is free of rebirth, the supreme sanctuary from the yoke, extinguishment—and they found it. Being themselves liable to grow old, fall sick, die, sorrow, and become corrupted, understanding the drawbacks in these things, they sought that which is free of old age, sickness, death, sorrow, and corruption, the supreme sanctuary from the yoke, extinguishment—and they found it.
title: The Noble Quest

segment_text: Knowledge and vision arose in them:
title: The Noble Quest

segment_text: ‘Our freedom is unshakable; this is our last rebirth; now there’ll be no more future lives.’
title: The Noble Quest

segment_text: Mendicants, there are these five kinds of sensual stimulation.
title: The Noble Quest

segment_text: What five?
title: The Noble Quest

segment_text: Sights known by the eye, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
title: The Noble Quest

segment_text: Sounds known by the ear …
title: The Noble Quest

segment_text: Smells known by the nose …
title: The Noble Quest

segment_text: Tastes known by the tongue …
title: The Noble Quest

segment_text: Touches known by the body, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
title: The Noble Quest

segment_text: These are the five kinds of sensual stimulation.
title: The Noble Quest

segment_text: There are ascetics and brahmins who enjoy these five kinds of sensual stimulation tied, infatuated, attached, blind to the drawbacks, and not understanding the escape. You should understand that they
title: The Noble Quest

segment_text: have met with calamity and disaster, and the Wicked One can do with them what he wants.
title: The Noble Quest

title: The Noble Quest

segment_text: Suppose there was a wild deer wandering in the forest that walked, stood, sat, and laid down in confidence.
title: The Noble Quest

title: The Noble Quest

segment_text: In the same way, a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
title: The Noble Quest

segment_text: This is called a mendicant who has blinded Māra, put out his eyes without a trace, and gone where the Wicked One cannot see.
title: The Noble Quest

segment_text: Furthermore, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, a mendicant enters and remains in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.
title: The Noble Quest

segment_text: This is called a mendicant who has blinded Māra …
title: The Noble Quest

segment_text: Furthermore, with the fading away of rapture, a mendicant enters and remains in the third absorption, where they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’
title: The Noble Quest

segment_text: This is called a mendicant who has blinded Māra …
title: The Noble Quest

segment_text: Furthermore, giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, a mendicant enters and remains in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.
title: The Noble Quest

segment_text: This is called a mendicant who has blinded Māra …
title: The Noble Quest

segment_text: Furthermore, a mendicant, going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the ending of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite space.
title: The Noble Quest

segment_text: This is called a mendicant who has blinded Māra …
title: The Noble Quest

segment_text: Furthermore, a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite consciousness.
title: The Noble Quest

segment_text: This is called a mendicant who has blinded Māra …
title: The Noble Quest

segment_text: Furthermore, a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, enters and remains in the dimension of nothingness.
title: The Noble Quest

segment_text: This is called a mendicant who has blinded Māra …
title: The Noble Quest

segment_text: Furthermore, a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of nothingness, enters and remains in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.
title: The Noble Quest

segment_text: This is called a mendicant who has blinded Māra …
title: The Noble Quest

segment_text: Furthermore, a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, enters and remains in the cessation of perception and feeling. And, having seen with wisdom, their defilements come to an end.
title: The Noble Quest

segment_text: Soon after going forth, living withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, they realize the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life. They live having achieved with their own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

segment_text: In the same way, brahmin, a Realized One arises in the world, perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: He realizes with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras, and divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: He proclaims a teaching that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely complete and pure.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: A householder hears that teaching, or a householder’s child, or someone reborn in a good family.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: They gain faith in the Realized One,
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: and reflect,
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: ‘Life at home is cramped and dirty, life gone forth is wide open.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: It’s not easy for someone living at home to lead the spiritual life utterly full and pure, like a polished shell.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: Why don’t I shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness?’
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: After some time they give up a large or small fortune, and a large or small family circle. They shave off hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: Once they’ve gone forth, they take up the training and livelihood of the mendicants. They give up killing living creatures, renouncing the rod and the sword. They’re scrupulous and kind, living full of sympathy for all living beings.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: They give up stealing. They take only what’s given, and expect only what’s given. They keep themselves clean by not thieving.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: They give up unchastity. They are chaste, set apart, avoiding the vulgar act of sex.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: They give up lying. They speak the truth and stick to the truth. They’re honest and dependable, and don’t trick the world with their words.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: They give up divisive speech. They don’t repeat in one place what they heard in another so as to divide people against each other. Instead, they reconcile those who are divided, supporting unity, delighting in harmony, loving harmony, speaking words that promote harmony.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: They give up harsh speech. They speak in a way that’s mellow, pleasing to the ear, lovely, going to the heart, polite, likable, and agreeable to the people.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: They give up talking nonsense. Their words are timely, true, and meaningful, in line with the teaching and training. They say things at the right time which are valuable, reasonable, succinct, and beneficial.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: They refrain from injuring plants and seeds.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: They eat in one part of the day, abstaining from eating at night and at the wrong time.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: They refrain from seeing shows of dancing, singing, and music.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: They refrain from beautifying and adorning themselves with garlands, fragrance, and makeup.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: They refrain from high and luxurious beds.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: They refrain from receiving gold and currency,
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: raw grains,
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: raw meat,
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: women and girls,
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: male and female bondservants,
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: goats and sheep,
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: chickens and pigs,
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: elephants, cows, horses, and mares,
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: and fields and land.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: They refrain from running errands and messages;
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: buying and selling;
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: falsifying weights, metals, or measures;
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: bribery, fraud, cheating, and duplicity;
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: mutilation, murder, abduction, banditry, plunder, and violence.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: They’re content with robes to look after the body and almsfood to look after the belly. Wherever they go, they set out taking only these things.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: They’re like a bird: wherever it flies, wings are its only burden.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: In the same way, a mendicant is content with robes to look after the body and almsfood to look after the belly. Wherever they go, they set out taking only these things.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: When they have this entire spectrum of noble ethics, they experience a blameless happiness inside themselves.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: When they see a sight with their eyes, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: If the faculty of sight were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of sight, and achieving its restraint.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: When they hear a sound with their ears …
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: When they smell an odor with their nose …
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: When they taste a flavor with their tongue …
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: When they feel a touch with their body …
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: When they know an idea with their mind, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: If the faculty of mind were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of mind, and achieving its restraint.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: When they have this noble sense restraint, they experience an unsullied bliss inside themselves.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: They act with situational awareness when going out and coming back; when looking ahead and aside; when bending and extending the limbs; when bearing the outer robe, bowl and robes; when eating, drinking, chewing, and tasting; when urinating and defecating; when walking, standing, sitting, sleeping, waking, speaking, and keeping silent.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: When they have this entire spectrum of noble ethics, this noble contentment, this noble sense restraint, and this noble mindfulness and situational awareness,
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: they frequent a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: After the meal, they return from almsround, sit down cross-legged, set their body straight, and establish mindfulness in their presence.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: Giving up covetousness for the world, they meditate with a heart rid of covetousness, cleansing the mind of covetousness.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: Giving up ill will and malevolence, they meditate with a mind rid of ill will, full of sympathy for all living beings, cleansing the mind of ill will.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: Giving up dullness and drowsiness, they meditate with a mind rid of dullness and drowsiness, perceiving light, mindful and aware, cleansing the mind of dullness and drowsiness.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: Giving up restlessness and remorse, they meditate without restlessness, their mind peaceful inside, cleansing the mind of restlessness and remorse.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: Giving up doubt, they meditate having gone beyond doubt, not undecided about skillful qualities, cleansing the mind of doubt.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: They give up these five hindrances, corruptions of the heart that weaken wisdom.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: Then, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, they enter and remain in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: This, brahmin, is that which is called ‘a footprint of the Realized One’ and also ‘a trace of the Realized One’ and also ‘a mark of the Realized One’.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: But a noble disciple does not yet come to the conclusion,
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: ‘The Blessed One is a fully awakened Buddha. The teaching is well explained. The Saṅgha is practicing well.’
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: Furthermore, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, a mendicant enters and remains in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: This too is what is called ‘a footprint of the Realized One’ …
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: Furthermore, with the fading away of rapture, a mendicant enters and remains in the third absorption, where they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: This too is what is called ‘a footprint of the Realized One’ …
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: Furthermore, giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, a mendicant enters and remains in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: This too is what is called ‘a footprint of the Realized One’ …
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward recollection of past lives.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: They recollect many kinds of past lives, that is, one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. … They recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: This too is what is called ‘a footprint of the Realized One’ …
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward knowledge of the death and rebirth of sentient beings.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: With clairvoyance that is purified and surpasses the human, they understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: This too is what is called ‘a footprint of the Realized One’ …
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: They truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: They truly understand: ‘These are defilements’ … ‘This is the origin of defilements’ … ‘This is the cessation of defilements’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of defilements.’
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: This, brahmin, is what is called ‘a footprint of the Realized One’ and also ‘a trace of the Realized One’ and also ‘a mark of the Realized One’.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: At this point a noble disciple has not yet come to a conclusion, but they are coming to the conclusion,
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: ‘The Blessed One is a fully awakened Buddha. The teaching is well explained. The Saṅgha is practicing well.’
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: Knowing and seeing like this, their mind is freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: This, brahmin, is what is called ‘a footprint of the Realized One’ and also ‘a trace of the Realized One’ and also ‘a mark of the Realized One’.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: At this point a noble disciple has come to the conclusion,
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: ‘The Blessed One is a fully awakened Buddha. The teaching is well explained. The Saṅgha is practicing well.’
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: And it is at this point that the simile of the elephant’s footprint has been completed in detail.”
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: When he had spoken, the brahmin Jānussoṇi said to the Buddha,
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: “Excellent, worthy Gotama! Excellent!
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, worthy Gotama has made the teaching clear in many ways.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: I go for refuge to the worthy Gotama, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: From this day forth, may the worthy Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
title: The Shorter Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: There Sāriputta addressed the mendicants,
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: “Reverends, mendicants!”
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: “Reverend,” they replied.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: Sāriputta said this:
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: “The footprints of all creatures that walk can fit inside an elephant’s footprint, so an elephant’s footprint is said to be the biggest of them all.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: In the same way, all skillful qualities are included in the four noble truths.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: What four?
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: The noble truths of suffering, the origin of suffering, the cessation of suffering, and the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: And what is the noble truth of suffering?
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: Rebirth is suffering; old age is suffering; death is suffering; sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress are suffering; not getting what you wish for is suffering. In brief, the five grasping aggregates are suffering.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: And what are the five grasping aggregates?
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: They are as follows: the grasping aggregates of form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: And what is the grasping aggregate of form?
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: The four principal states, and form derived from the four principal states.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: And what are the four principal states?
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: The elements of earth, water, fire, and air.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: And what is the earth element?
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: The earth element may be interior or exterior.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: And what is the interior earth element?
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: Anything internal, pertaining to an individual, that’s hard, solid, and appropriated. This includes:
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: head hair, body hair, nails, teeth, skin, flesh, sinews, bones, bone marrow, kidneys, heart, liver, diaphragm, spleen, lungs, intestines, mesentery, undigested food, feces; or anything else internal, pertaining to an individual, that’s hard, solid, and appropriated.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: This is called the interior earth element.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: The interior earth element and the exterior earth element are just the earth element.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: This should be truly seen with right understanding like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: When you truly see with right understanding, you grow disillusioned with the earth element, detaching the mind from the earth element.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: There comes a time when the exterior water element flares up.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: At that time the exterior earth element vanishes.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: So for all its great age, the earth element will be revealed as impermanent, liable to end, vanish, and perish.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: What then of this ephemeral body appropriated by craving? Rather than ‘I’ or ‘mine’ or ‘I am’, they consider it to be none of these things.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: If others abuse, attack, harass, and trouble that mendicant, they understand:
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: ‘This painful feeling born of ear contact has arisen in me.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: That’s dependent, not independent.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: Dependent on what?
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: Dependent on contact.’
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: They see that contact, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness are impermanent.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: Based on that element alone, their mind leaps forth, gains confidence, settles down, and becomes decided.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: Others might treat that mendicant with disliking, loathing, and detestation,
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: striking them with fists, stones, sticks, and swords.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: They understand:
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: ‘This body is such that fists, stones, sticks, and swords strike it.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: But the Buddha has said in the Advice on the Simile of the Saw:
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: “Even if low-down bandits were to sever you limb from limb with a two-handed saw, anyone who had a malevolent thought on that account would not be following my instructions.”
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: My energy shall be roused up and unflagging, my mindfulness established and lucid, my body tranquil and undisturbed, and my mind immersed in samādhi and unified.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: Gladly now, let fists, stones, sticks, and swords strike this body! For this is how the instructions of the Buddhas are followed.’
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: While recollecting the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha in this way, equanimity based on the skillful may not become stabilized in them.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: In that case they stir up a sense of urgency:
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: ‘It’s my loss, my misfortune,
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: that while recollecting the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha in this way, equanimity based on the skillful does not become stabilized in me.’
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: They’re like a daughter-in-law who stirs up a sense of urgency when they see their father-in-law.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: But if, while recollecting the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha in this way, equanimity based on the skillful does become stabilized in them, they’re happy with that.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: At this point, much has been done by that mendicant.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: And what is the water element?
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: The water element may be interior or exterior.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: And what is the interior water element?
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: Anything internal, pertaining to an individual, that’s water, watery, and appropriated. This includes:
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: bile, phlegm, pus, blood, sweat, fat, tears, grease, saliva, snot, synovial fluid, urine; or anything else internal, pertaining to an individual, that’s water, watery, and appropriated.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: This is called the interior water element.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: The interior water element and the exterior water element are just the water element.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: This should be truly seen with right understanding like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: When you truly see with right understanding, you grow disillusioned with the water element, detaching the mind from the water element.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: There comes a time when the exterior water element flares up.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: It sweeps away villages, towns, cities, countries, and regions.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: There comes a time when the water in the ocean sinks down a hundred leagues, or two, three, four, five, six, up to seven hundred leagues.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: There comes a time when the water in the ocean stands just seven palm trees deep, or six, five, four, three, two, or even just one palm tree deep.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: There comes a time when the water in the ocean stands just seven fathoms deep, or six, five, four, three, two, or even just one fathom deep.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: There comes a time when the water in the ocean stands just half a fathom deep, or waist deep, or knee deep, or even just ankle deep.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: There comes a time when there’s not even enough water left in the great ocean to wet the tip of the toe.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: So for all its great age, the water element will be revealed as impermanent, liable to end, vanish, and perish.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: What then of this ephemeral body appropriated by craving? Rather than ‘I’ or ‘mine’ or ‘I am’, they consider it to be none of these things. …
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: If, while recollecting the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha in this way, equanimity based on the skillful does become stabilized in them, they’re happy with that.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: At this point, much has been done by that mendicant.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: And what is the fire element?
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: The fire element may be interior or exterior.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: And what is the interior fire element?
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: Anything internal, pertaining to an individual that’s fire, fiery, and appropriated. This includes:
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: that which warms, that which ages, that which heats you up when feverish, that which properly digests food and drink; or anything else internal, pertaining to an individual, that’s fire, fiery, and appropriated.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: This is called the interior fire element.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: The interior fire element and the exterior fire element are just the fire element.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: This should be truly seen with right understanding like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: When you truly see with right understanding, you grow disillusioned with the fire element, detaching the mind from the fire element.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: There comes a time when the exterior fire element flares up.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: It burns up villages, towns, cities, countries, and regions until
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: it reaches a green field, a roadside, a cliff’s edge, a body of water, or cleared parkland, where it’s extinguished due to not being fed.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: There comes a time when they go looking for a fire, taking just a chicken feather or a scrap of sinew as kindling.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: So for all its great age, the fire element will be revealed as impermanent, liable to end, vanish, and perish.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: What then of this ephemeral body appropriated by craving? Rather than ‘I’ or ‘mine’ or ‘I am’, they consider it to be none of these things. …
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: If, while recollecting the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha in this way, equanimity based on the skillful does become stabilized in them, they’re happy with that.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: At this point, much has been done by that mendicant.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: And what is the air element?
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: The air element may be interior or exterior.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: And what is the interior air element?
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: Anything internal, pertaining to an individual, that’s air, airy, and appropriated. This includes:
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: winds that go up or down, winds in the belly or the bowels, winds that flow through the limbs, in-breaths and out-breaths; or anything else internal, pertaining to an individual, that’s air, airy, and appropriated.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: This is called the interior air element.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: The interior air element and the exterior air element are just the air element.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: This should be truly seen with right understanding like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: When you truly see with right understanding, you grow disillusioned with the air element, detaching the mind from the air element.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: There comes a time when the exterior air element flares up.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: It sweeps away villages, towns, cities, countries, and regions.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: There comes a time, in the last month of summer, when they look for wind by using a palm-leaf or fan, and even the grasses in the drip-fringe of a thatch roof don’t stir.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: So for all its great age, the air element will be revealed as impermanent, liable to end, vanish, and perish.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: What then of this ephemeral body appropriated by craving? Rather than ‘I’ or ‘mine’ or ‘I am’, they consider it to be none of these things.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: If others abuse, attack, harass, and trouble that mendicant, they understand:
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: ‘This painful feeling born of ear contact has arisen in me.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: That’s dependent, not independent.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: Dependent on what?
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: Dependent on contact.’
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: They see that contact, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness are impermanent.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: Based on that element alone, their mind leaps forth, gains confidence, settles down, and becomes decided.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: Others might treat that mendicant with disliking, loathing, and detestation, striking them with fists, stones, sticks, and swords.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: They understand: ‘This body is such that fists, stones, sticks, and swords strike it.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: But the Buddha has said in the Advice on the Simile of the Saw: “Even if low-down bandits were to sever you limb from limb with a two-handed saw, anyone who had a thought of hate on that account would not be following my instructions.”
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: My energy shall be roused up and unflagging, my mindfulness established and lucid, my body tranquil and undisturbed, and my mind immersed in samādhi.
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

segment_text: Gladly now, let fists, stones, sticks, and swords strike this body! For this is how the instructions of the Buddhas are followed.’
title: The Longer Simile of the Elephant’s Footprint

title: The Longer Simile of the Heartwood

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain, not long after Devadatta had left.
title: The Longer Simile of the Heartwood

segment_text: There the Buddha spoke to the mendicants about Devadatta:
title: The Longer Simile of the Heartwood

segment_text: “Mendicants, take the case of a gentleman who has gone forth out of faith from the lay life to homelessness, thinking,
title: The Longer Simile of the Heartwood

segment_text: ‘I’m swamped by rebirth, old age, and death; by sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress. I’m swamped by suffering, mired in suffering.
title: The Longer Simile of the Heartwood

segment_text: Hopefully I can find an end to this entire mass of suffering.’
title: The Longer Simile of the Heartwood

segment_text: When they’ve gone forth they generate possessions, honor, and popularity.
title: The Longer Simile of the Heartwood

segment_text: They’re happy with that, and they’ve got all they wished for.
title: The Longer Simile of the Heartwood

segment_text: And they glorify themselves and put others down because of that:
title: The Longer Simile of the Heartwood

segment_text: ‘I’m the one with possessions, honor, and popularity. These other mendicants are obscure and insignificant.’
title: The Longer Simile of the Heartwood

segment_text: And so they become indulgent and fall into negligence on account of those possessions, honor, and popularity. And being negligent they live in suffering.
title: The Longer Simile of the Heartwood

segment_text: Suppose there was a person in need of heartwood. And while wandering in search of heartwood he’d come across a large tree standing with heartwood. But, passing over the heartwood, softwood, bark, and shoots, he’d cut off the branches and leaves and depart imagining they were heartwood.
title: The Longer Simile of the Heartwood

segment_text: If a person with clear eyes saw him they’d say,
title: The Longer Simile of the Heartwood

segment_text: ‘This gentleman doesn’t know what heartwood, softwood, bark, shoots, or branches and leaves are.
title: The Longer Simile of the Heartwood

segment_text: That’s why he passed them over, cut off the branches and leaves, and departed imagining they were heartwood.
title: The Longer Simile of the Heartwood

segment_text: Whatever he needs to make from heartwood, he won’t succeed.’ …

title: The Longer Simile of the Heartwood

title: The Shorter Simile of the Heartwood

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Heartwood

segment_text: Then the brahmin Piṅgalakoccha went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Heartwood

segment_text: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to the Buddha:
title: The Shorter Simile of the Heartwood

segment_text: “Worthy Gotama, there are those ascetics and brahmins who lead an order and a community, and tutor a community. They’re well-known and famous religious founders, deemed holy by many people.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Heartwood

segment_text: Namely: Pūraṇa Kassapa, the bamboo-staffed ascetic Gosāla, Ajita of the hair blanket, Pakudha Kaccāyana, Sañjaya Belaṭṭhiputta, and the Jain ascetic of the Ñātika clan.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Heartwood

segment_text: According to their own claims, did all of them have direct knowledge, or none of them, or only some?”
title: The Shorter Simile of the Heartwood

segment_text: “Enough, brahmin, let this be:
title: The Shorter Simile of the Heartwood

segment_text: ‘According to their own claims, did all of them have direct knowledge, or none of them, or only some?’
title: The Shorter Simile of the Heartwood

segment_text: I will teach you the Dhamma.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Heartwood

segment_text: Listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”
title: The Shorter Simile of the Heartwood

segment_text: “Yes, worthy sir,” Piṅgalakoccha replied.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Heartwood

title: The Shorter Simile of the Heartwood
