title: The Shorter Simile of the Heartwood

segment_text: And what are those things that are better and finer than knowledge and vision?
title: The Shorter Simile of the Heartwood

segment_text: Take a mendicant who, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Heartwood

segment_text: This is something better and finer than knowledge and vision.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Heartwood

segment_text: Furthermore, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, a mendicant enters and remains in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Heartwood

segment_text: This too is something better and finer than knowledge and vision.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Heartwood

segment_text: Furthermore, with the fading away of rapture, a mendicant enters and remains in the third absorption, where they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’
title: The Shorter Simile of the Heartwood

segment_text: This too is something better and finer than knowledge and vision.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Heartwood

segment_text: Furthermore, giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, a mendicant enters and remains in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Heartwood

segment_text: This too is something better and finer than knowledge and vision.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Heartwood

segment_text: Furthermore, a mendicant, going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the ending of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite space.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Heartwood

segment_text: This too is something better and finer than knowledge and vision.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Heartwood

segment_text: Furthermore, a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite consciousness.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Heartwood

segment_text: This too is something better and finer than knowledge and vision.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Heartwood

segment_text: Furthermore, a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, enters and remains in the dimension of nothingness.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Heartwood

segment_text: This too is something better and finer than knowledge and vision.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Heartwood

segment_text: Furthermore, take a mendicant who, going totally beyond the dimension of nothingness, enters and remains in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Heartwood

segment_text: This too is something better and finer than knowledge and vision.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Heartwood

segment_text: Furthermore, take a mendicant who, going totally beyond the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, enters and remains in the cessation of perception and feeling. And, having seen with wisdom, their defilements come to an end.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Heartwood

segment_text: This too is something better and finer than knowledge and vision.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Heartwood

segment_text: These are the things that are better and finer than knowledge and vision.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Heartwood

segment_text: Suppose there was a person in need of heartwood. And while wandering in search of heartwood he’d come across a large tree standing with heartwood. He’d cut out just the heartwood and depart knowing it was heartwood.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Heartwood

segment_text: Whatever he needs to make from heartwood, he will succeed.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Heartwood

segment_text: That’s what this person is like, I say.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Heartwood

segment_text: And so, brahmin, this spiritual life is not lived for the sake of possessions, honor, and popularity, or for accomplishment in ethics, or for accomplishment in immersion, or for knowledge and vision.
title: The Shorter Simile of the Heartwood

segment_text: Rather, the goal, heartwood, and final end of the spiritual life is the unshakable freedom of heart.”
title: The Shorter Simile of the Heartwood

segment_text: When he had spoken, the brahmin Piṅgalakoccha said to the Buddha,
title: The Shorter Simile of the Heartwood

segment_text: “Excellent, worthy Gotama! Excellent! …
title: The Shorter Simile of the Heartwood

segment_text: From this day forth, may the worthy Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
title: The Shorter Simile of the Heartwood

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying at Ñātika in the brick house.
title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: Now at that time the venerables Anuruddha, Nandiya, and Kimbila were staying in the sal forest park at Gosiṅga.
title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: Then in the late afternoon, the Buddha came out of retreat and went to that park.
title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: The park keeper saw the Buddha coming off in the distance
title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: and said to him,
title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: “Don’t come into this park, ascetic.
title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: There are three gentlemen staying here whose nature is to desire self-knowledge.
title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: Do not disturb them.”
title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: Anuruddha heard the park keeper conversing with the Buddha,
title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: and said to him,
title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: “Don’t keep the Buddha out, good park keeper!
title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: Our Teacher, the Blessed One, has arrived.”
title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: Then Anuruddha went to Nandiya and Kimbila, and said to them,
title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: “Come forth, venerables, come forth! Our Teacher, the Blessed One, has arrived!”
title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: Then Anuruddha, Nandiya, and Kimbila came out to greet the Buddha.
title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: One received his bowl and robe, one spread out a seat, and one set out water for washing his feet.
title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: The Buddha sat on the seat spread out,
title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: and washed his feet.
title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: Those venerables bowed and sat down to one side.
title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: The Buddha said to Anuruddha,
title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: “I hope you’re keeping well, Anuruddha and friends; I hope you’re all right. And I hope you’re having no trouble getting almsfood.”
title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: “We’re keeping well, Blessed One, we’re getting by. And we have no trouble getting almsfood.”
title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: “I hope you’re living in harmony, appreciating each other, without quarreling, blending like milk and water, and regarding each other with kindly eyes?”
title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: “Indeed, sir, we live in harmony like this.”
title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: “But how do you live this way?”
title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: “In this case, sir, I think,
title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: ‘I’m fortunate, so very fortunate,
title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: to live together with spiritual companions such as these.’
title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: I consistently treat these venerables with kindness by way of body, speech, and mind, both in public and in private.
title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: I think,
title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: ‘Why don’t I set aside my own ideas and just go along with these venerables’ ideas?’
title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: And that’s what I do.
title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: Though we’re different in body, sir, we’re one in mind, it seems to me.”
title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: And the venerables Nandiya and Kimbila spoke likewise, and they added:
title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: “That’s how we live in harmony, appreciating each other, without quarreling, blending like milk and water, and regarding each other with kindly eyes.”
title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: “Good, good, Anuruddha and friends!
title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: But I hope you’re living diligently, keen, and resolute?”
title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: “Indeed, sir, we live diligently.”
title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: “But how do you live this way?”
title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: “In this case, sir, whoever returns first from almsround prepares the seats, and puts out the drinking water and the rubbish bin.
title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: If there’s anything left over, whoever returns last eats it if they like. Otherwise they throw it out where there is little that grows, or drop it into water that has no living creatures.
title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: Then they put away the seats, drinking water, and rubbish bin, and sweep the refectory.
title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: If someone sees that the pot of water for washing, drinking, or the toilet is empty they set it up.
title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: If he can’t do it, he summons another with a wave of the hand, and they set it up by lending each other a hand to lift. But we don’t break into speech for that reason.
title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: And every five days we sit together for the whole night and discuss the teachings.
title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: That’s how we live diligently, keen, and resolute.”
title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: “Good, good, Anuruddha and friends!
title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: But as you live diligently like this, have you achieved any superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones, a comfortable meditation?”
title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: “How could we not, sir?
title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: Then the Buddha educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired the venerables Anuruddha, Nandiya, and Kimbila with a Dhamma talk, after which he got up from his seat and left.
title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: The venerables then accompanied the Buddha for a little way before turning back. Nandiya and Kimbila said to Anuruddha,
title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: “Did we ever tell you that we had
title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: gained such and such meditations and attainments, up to the ending of defilements, as you revealed to the Buddha?”
title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: “The venerables did not tell me that they had
title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: gained such meditations and attainments. But I discovered it by comprehending your minds,
title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: and deities also told me.
title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: I answered when the Buddha directly asked about it.”
title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: Then the native spirit Dīgha Parajana went up to the Buddha, bowed, stood to one side, and said to him,
title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: “The Vajjis are lucky! The Vajjian people are so very lucky
title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: that the Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha stays there, as well as these three gentlemen,
title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: the venerables Anuruddha, Nandiya, and Kimbila.”
title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: Hearing the cry of Dīgha Parajana, the earth gods raised the cry …
title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: the gods of the thirty-three …

segment_text: the gods of Yama …
title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: the venerables Anuruddha, Nandiya, and Kimbila.”
title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: “That’s so true, Dīgha! That’s so true!
title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

title: The Shorter Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: The Longer Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying in the sal forest park at Gosiṅga, together with several well-known senior disciples, such as
title: The Longer Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: the venerables Sāriputta, Mahāmoggallāna, Mahākassapa, Anuruddha, Revata, Ānanda, and others.
title: The Longer Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Mahāmoggallāna came out of retreat, went to Venerable Mahākassapa, and said,
title: The Longer Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: “Come, Reverend Kassapa, let’s go to Venerable Sāriputta to hear the teaching.”
title: The Longer Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: “Yes, reverend,” Mahākassapa replied.
title: The Longer Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: Then, together with Venerable Anuruddha, they went to Sāriputta to hear the teaching.
title: The Longer Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: Seeing them, Venerable Ānanda
title: The Longer Discourse at Gosiṅga

title: The Longer Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: and invited him also.
title: The Longer Discourse at Gosiṅga

title: The Longer Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: and said to Ānanda,
title: The Longer Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: “Come, Venerable Ānanda.
title: The Longer Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: Welcome to Ānanda, the Buddha’s attendant, who is so close to the Buddha.
title: The Longer Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: Ānanda, the sal forest park at Gosiṅga is lovely, the night is bright, the sal trees are in full blossom, and heavenly scents seem to float on the air.
title: The Longer Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: What kind of mendicant would beautify this park?”
title: The Longer Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: “Reverend Sāriputta, it’s a mendicant who is very learned, remembering and keeping what they’ve learned. These teachings are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased, describing a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure. They are very learned in such teachings, remembering them, rehearsing them, mentally scrutinizing them, and comprehending them theoretically.
title: The Longer Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: And they teach the four assemblies in order to uproot the underlying tendencies with well-rounded and coherent words and phrases.
title: The Longer Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: That’s the kind of mendicant who would beautify this park.”
title: The Longer Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: When he had spoken, Sāriputta said to Revata,
title: The Longer Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: “Reverend Revata, Ānanda has answered by speaking from his heart.
title: The Longer Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: And now we ask you the same question.”
title: The Longer Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: “Reverend Sāriputta, it’s a mendicant who enjoys retreat and loves retreat. They’re committed to inner serenity of the heart, they don’t neglect absorption, they’re endowed with discernment, and they frequent empty huts.
title: The Longer Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: That’s the kind of mendicant who would beautify this park.”
title: The Longer Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: When he had spoken, Sāriputta said to Anuruddha,
title: The Longer Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: “Reverend Anuruddha, Revata has answered by speaking from his heart.
title: The Longer Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: And now we ask you the same question.”
title: The Longer Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: “Reverend Sāriputta, it’s a mendicant who surveys a thousandfold galaxy with clairvoyance that is purified and surpasses the human,
title: The Longer Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: just as a person with clear eyes could survey a thousand orbits from the upper floor of a royal longhouse.
title: The Longer Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: That’s the kind of mendicant who would beautify this park.”
title: The Longer Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: When he had spoken, Sāriputta said to Mahākassapa,
title: The Longer Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: “Reverend Kassapa, Anuruddha has answered by speaking from his heart.
title: The Longer Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: And now we ask you the same question.”
title: The Longer Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: “Reverend Sāriputta, it’s a mendicant who lives in the wilderness, eats only almsfood, wears rag robes, and owns just three robes; and they praise these things. They are of few wishes, content, secluded, aloof, and energetic; and they praise these things. They are accomplished in ethics, immersion, wisdom, freedom, and the knowledge and vision of freedom; and they praise these things.
title: The Longer Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: That’s the kind of mendicant who would beautify this park.”
title: The Longer Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: When he had spoken, Sāriputta said to Mahāmoggallāna,
title: The Longer Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: “Reverend Moggallāna, Mahākassapa has answered by speaking from his heart.
title: The Longer Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: And now we ask you the same question.”
title: The Longer Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: “Reverend Sāriputta, it’s when two mendicants engage in discussion about the teaching. They question each other and answer each other’s questions without faltering, and their discussion on the teaching flows on.
title: The Longer Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: That’s the kind of mendicant who would beautify this park.”
title: The Longer Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: Then Mahāmoggallāna said to Sāriputta,
title: The Longer Discourse at Gosiṅga

segment_text: “Reverend Moggallāna, it’s when a mendicant masters their mind and is not mastered by it.

segment_text: Then Sāriputta said to those venerables,

title: The Longer Discourse on the Cowherd

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Cowherd

segment_text: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,
title: The Longer Discourse on the Cowherd

segment_text: “Mendicants!”
title: The Longer Discourse on the Cowherd

segment_text: “Venerable sir,” they replied.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Cowherd

segment_text: The Buddha said this:
title: The Longer Discourse on the Cowherd

segment_text: “Mendicants, a cowherd with eleven factors can’t maintain and expand a herd of cattle.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Cowherd

segment_text: What eleven?
title: The Longer Discourse on the Cowherd

segment_text: It’s when a cowherd doesn’t know form, is unskilled in characteristics, doesn’t pick out flies’ eggs, doesn’t dress wounds, doesn’t spread smoke, doesn’t know the ford, doesn’t know satisfaction, doesn’t know the trail, is not skilled in ranges, milks dry, and doesn’t show extra respect to the bulls who are fathers and leaders of the herd.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Cowherd

segment_text: A cowherd with these eleven factors can’t maintain and expand a herd of cattle.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Cowherd

segment_text: In the same way, a mendicant with eleven qualities can’t achieve growth, improvement, or maturity in this teaching and training.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Cowherd

segment_text: What eleven?
title: The Longer Discourse on the Cowherd

segment_text: It’s when a mendicant doesn’t know form, is unskilled in characteristics, doesn’t pick out flies’ eggs, doesn’t dress wounds, doesn’t spread smoke, doesn’t know the ford, doesn’t know satisfaction, doesn’t know the trail, is not skilled in ranges, milks dry, and doesn’t show extra respect to senior mendicants of long standing, long gone forth, fathers and leaders of the Saṅgha.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Cowherd

segment_text: And how does a mendicant not know form?
title: The Longer Discourse on the Cowherd

segment_text: It’s when a mendicant doesn’t truly understand that all form is the four principal states, or form derived from the four principal states.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Cowherd

segment_text: That’s how a mendicant doesn’t know form.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Cowherd

segment_text: And how is a mendicant not skilled in characteristics?
title: The Longer Discourse on the Cowherd

segment_text: It’s when a mendicant doesn’t understand that a fool is characterized by their deeds, and an astute person is characterized by their deeds.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Cowherd

segment_text: That’s how a mendicant isn’t skilled in characteristics.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Cowherd

segment_text: And how does a mendicant not pick out flies’ eggs?
title: The Longer Discourse on the Cowherd

segment_text: It’s when a mendicant tolerates a sensual, malicious, or cruel thought that has arisen. They tolerate any bad, unskillful qualities that have arisen. They don’t give them up, get rid of them, eliminate them, and obliterate them.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Cowherd

segment_text: That’s how a mendicant doesn’t pick out flies’ eggs.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Cowherd

segment_text: And how does a mendicant not dress wounds?
title: The Longer Discourse on the Cowherd

segment_text: When a mendicant sees a sight with their eyes, they get caught up in the features and details.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Cowherd

segment_text: Since the faculty of sight is left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure become overwhelming. They don’t practice restraint, they don’t protect the faculty of sight, and they don’t achieve its restraint.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Cowherd

segment_text: When they hear a sound with their ears …
title: The Longer Discourse on the Cowherd

segment_text: smell an odor with their nose …
title: The Longer Discourse on the Cowherd

segment_text: taste a flavor with their tongue …
title: The Longer Discourse on the Cowherd

segment_text: feel a touch with their body …
title: The Longer Discourse on the Cowherd

segment_text: know an idea with their mind, they get caught up in the features and details.

segment_text: Since the faculty of the mind is left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure become overwhelming. They don’t practice restraint, they don’t protect the faculty of the mind, and they don’t achieve its restraint.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Cowherd

segment_text: That’s how a mendicant doesn’t dress wounds.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Cowherd

segment_text: And how does a mendicant not spread smoke?
title: The Longer Discourse on the Cowherd

segment_text: It’s when a mendicant doesn’t teach others the Dhamma in detail as they learned and memorized it.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Cowherd

segment_text: That’s how a mendicant doesn’t spread smoke.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Cowherd

segment_text: And how does a mendicant not know the ford?
title: The Longer Discourse on the Cowherd

segment_text: It’s when a mendicant doesn’t from time to time go up to those mendicants who are very learned—inheritors of the heritage, who have memorized the teachings, the monastic law, and the outlines—and ask them questions:

segment_text: That’s how a mendicant doesn’t know the trail.

title: The Shorter Discourse on the Cowherd

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Vajjis near Ukkacelā on the bank of the Ganges river.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Cowherd

segment_text: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Cowherd

segment_text: “Mendicants!”
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Cowherd

segment_text: “Venerable sir,” they replied.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Cowherd

segment_text: The Buddha said this:
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Cowherd

segment_text: “Once upon a time, mendicants, there was an unintelligent Magadhan cowherd. In the last month of the rainy season, in autumn, without inspecting the near shore or the far shore, he drove his cattle across a place with no ford on the Ganges river to the northern shore among the Suvidehans.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Cowherd

segment_text: But the cattle bunched up in mid-stream and came to ruin right there.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Cowherd

segment_text: Why is that?
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Cowherd

segment_text: Because the unintelligent cowherd failed to inspect the shores before driving the cattle across at a place with no ford.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Cowherd

segment_text: In the same way, there are ascetics and brahmins who are unskilled in this world and the other world, unskilled in Māra’s dominion and its opposite, and unskilled in Death’s dominion and its opposite. If anyone thinks they are worth listening to and trusting, it will be for their lasting harm and suffering.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Cowherd

segment_text: Once upon a time, mendicants, there was an intelligent Magadhan cowherd. In the last month of the rainy season, in autumn, after inspecting the near shore and the far shore, he drove his cattle across a ford on the Ganges river to the northern shore among the Suvidehans.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Cowherd

segment_text: First he drove across the bulls, the fathers and leaders of the herd.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Cowherd

segment_text: They breasted the stream of the Ganges and safely reached the far shore.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Cowherd

segment_text: Then he drove across the strong and tractable cattle.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Cowherd

segment_text: They too breasted the stream of the Ganges and safely reached the far shore.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Cowherd

segment_text: Then he drove across the bullocks and heifers.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Cowherd

segment_text: They too breasted the stream of the Ganges and safely reached the far shore.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Cowherd

segment_text: Then he drove across the calves and weak cattle.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Cowherd

segment_text: They too breasted the stream of the Ganges and safely reached the far shore.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Cowherd

segment_text: Once it happened that a baby calf had just been born. Urged on by its mother’s lowing, even it managed to breast the stream of the Ganges and safely reach the far shore.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Cowherd

segment_text: Why is that?
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Cowherd

segment_text: Because the intelligent cowherd inspected both shores before driving the cattle across at a ford.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Cowherd

segment_text: In the same way, there are ascetics and brahmins who are skilled in this world and the other world, skilled in Māra’s dominion and its opposite, and skilled in Death’s dominion and its opposite. If anyone thinks they are worth listening to and trusting, it will be for their lasting welfare and happiness.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Cowherd

segment_text: Just like the bulls, fathers and leaders of the herd, who crossed the Ganges to safety
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Cowherd

segment_text: are the mendicants who are perfected, who have ended the defilements, completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their own goal, utterly ended the fetter of continued existence, and are rightly freed through enlightenment. Having breasted Māra’s stream, they have safely crossed over to the far shore.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Cowherd

title: The Shorter Discourse on the Cowherd

title: The Shorter Discourse on the Cowherd

title: The Shorter Discourse on the Cowherd

segment_text: are the mendicants who, with the ending of three fetters, and the weakening of greed, hate, and delusion, are once-returners. They come back to this world once only, then make an end of suffering. They too, having breasted Māra’s stream, will safely cross over to the far shore.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Cowherd

title: The Shorter Discourse on the Cowherd

segment_text: are the mendicants who, with the ending of three fetters are stream-enterers, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, bound for awakening. They too, having breasted Māra’s stream, will safely cross over to the far shore.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Cowherd

title: The Shorter Discourse on the Cowherd

title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Now at that time Saccaka, the son of Jain parents, was staying in Vesālī. He was a debater and clever speaker deemed holy by many people.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: He was telling a crowd in Vesālī,
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: “I don’t see any ascetic or brahmin who would not shake and rock and tremble, sweating from the armpits, were I to take them on in debate—not a leader of an order or a community, or the tutor of a community, and not even one who claims to be a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Even an insentient post would shake and rock and tremble were I to take it on in debate.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: How much more then a human being!”
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Then Venerable Assaji robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Vesālī for alms.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: As Saccaka was going for a walk he saw Assaji coming off in the distance.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: He approached him and exchanged greetings with him.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, Saccaka stood to one side and said to Assaji,
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: “Worthy Assaji, how does the ascetic Gotama guide his disciples? And on what topics does instruction to his disciples generally proceed?”
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: “Aggivessana, this is how the ascetic Gotama guides his disciples, and his instructions to disciples generally proceed on these topics:
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: ‘Form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness are impermanent.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness are not-self.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: All conditions are impermanent. All things are not-self.’
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: This is how the ascetic Gotama guides his disciples, and how instruction to his disciples generally proceeds.”
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: “It’s sad to hear, worthy Assaji, that the ascetic Gotama has such a doctrine.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Hopefully, some time or other I’ll get to meet the worthy Gotama, and we can have a discussion. And hopefully I can dissuade him from this harmful misconception.”
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Now at that time around five hundred Licchavis were sitting together at the town hall on some business.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Then Saccaka went up to them and said,
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: “Come forth, good Licchavīs, come forth! Today I am going to have a discussion with the ascetic Gotama.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: If he stands by the position stated to me by one of his well-known disciples—a mendicant named Assaji—I’ll take him on in debate and drag him to and fro and round about, like a strong man would grab a fleecy sheep and drag it to and fro and round about!
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Taking him on in debate, I’ll drag him to and fro and round about, like a strong brewer’s worker would toss a large brewer’s sieve into a deep lake, grab it by the corners, and drag it to and fro and round about!
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Taking him on in debate, I’ll shake him down and about, and give him a beating, like a strong brewer’s mixer would grab a strainer by the corners and shake it down and about, and give it a beating!
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: I’ll play a game of hemp-washing with the ascetic Gotama, like a sixty-year-old elephant would plunge into a deep lotus pond and play a game of hemp-washing!
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Come forth, good Licchavīs, come forth! Today I am going to have a discussion with the ascetic Gotama.”
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: At that, some of the Licchavis said,
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: “How can the ascetic Gotama refute Saccaka’s doctrine, when it is Saccaka who will refute Gotama’s doctrine?”
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: But some of the Licchavis said,
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: “Who is Saccaka to refute the Buddha’s doctrine, when it is the Buddha who will refute Saccaka’s doctrine?”
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Then Saccaka, escorted by the five hundred Licchavis, went to the hall with the peaked roof in the Great Wood.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: At that time several mendicants were walking mindfully in the open air.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Then Saccaka went up to them and said,
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: “Good fellows, where is the worthy Gotama at present?
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: For we want to see him.”
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: “Aggivessana, the Buddha has plunged deep into the Great Wood and is sitting at the root of a tree for the day’s meditation.”
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Then Saccaka, together with a large group of Licchavis, went to see the Buddha in the Great Wood, and exchanged greetings with him.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Before sitting down to one side, some of the Licchavīs bowed, some exchanged greetings and polite conversation, some held up their joined palms toward the Buddha, some announced their name and clan, while some kept silent.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Then Saccaka said to the Buddha,
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: “I’d like to ask the worthy Gotama about a certain point, if you’d take the time to answer.”
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: “Ask what you wish, Aggivessana.”
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: “How does the worthy Gotama guide his disciples? And on what topics does instruction to his disciples generally proceed?”

segment_text: “This is how I guide my disciples, and my instructions to disciples generally proceed on these topics:
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: ‘Form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness are impermanent.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness are not-self.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: All conditions are impermanent. All things are not-self.’
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: This is how I guide my disciples, and how instruction to my disciples generally proceeds.”
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: “A simile strikes me, worthy Gotama.”
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: “Then speak as you feel inspired,” said the Buddha.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: “All the plants and seeds that achieve growth, increase, and maturity do so depending on the earth and grounded on the earth.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: All the hard work that gets done depends on the earth and is grounded on the earth.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: In the same way, an individual’s self is form. Grounded on form they create merit and wickedness. An individual’s self is feeling … perception … choices … consciousness. Grounded on consciousness they create merit and wickedness.”
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: “Aggivessana, are you not saying this:
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: ‘Form is my self, feeling is my self, perception is my self, choices are my self, consciousness is my self’?”
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: “Indeed, worthy Gotama, that is what I am saying.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: “Then, worthy Gotama, what I am saying is this:

segment_text: ‘Form is my self, feeling is my self, perception is my self, choices are my self, consciousness is my self’.”
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: “Well then, Aggivessana, I’ll ask you about this in return, and you can answer as you like.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: What do you think, Aggivessana?
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Consider an anointed aristocratic king such as Pasenadi of Kosala or Ajātasattu of Magadha, son of the princess of Videha.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Would they have the power in their own realm to execute those who have incurred execution, fine those who have incurred fines, or banish those who have incurred banishment?”
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: “An anointed king would have such power, worthy Gotama.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: “No, worthy Gotama.”
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: “What do you think, Aggivessana?
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Consider someone who resorts, draws near, and clings to suffering, regarding it thus: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self.’ Would such a person be able to completely understand suffering themselves, or live having wiped out suffering?”
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: “How could they?
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: No, worthy Gotama.”
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: “What do you think, Aggivessana?
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: This being so, aren’t you someone who resorts, draws near, and clings to suffering, regarding it thus: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: “How could I not?
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Yes, worthy Gotama.”
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: “Suppose, Aggivessana, there was a person in need of heartwood. Wandering in search of heartwood, they’d take a sharp axe and enter a forest.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: There they’d see a big banana tree, straight and young and grown free of defects.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: They’d cut it down at the base, cut off the top, and unroll the coiled sheaths.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: But they wouldn’t even find sapwood, much less heartwood.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: In the same way, when pursued, pressed, and grilled by me on your own doctrine, you turn out to be vacuous, hollow, and mistaken.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: But it was you who stated before the assembly of Vesālī:
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: ‘I don’t see any ascetic or brahmin who would not shake and rock and tremble, sweating from the armpits, were I to take them on in debate—not a leader of an order or a community, or the tutor of a community, and not even one who claims to be a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Even an insentient post would shake and rock and tremble were I to take it on in debate.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: How much more then a human being!’
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: But sweat is pouring from your forehead; it’s soaked through your robe and drips on the ground.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: While I now have no sweat on my body.”
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: So the Buddha revealed his golden body to the assembly.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: When this was said, Saccaka sat silent, dismayed, shoulders drooping, downcast, depressed, with nothing to say.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Knowing this, the Licchavi Dummukha said to the Buddha,
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: “A simile strikes me, Blessed One.”
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: “Then speak as you feel inspired,” said the Buddha.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: “Sir, suppose there was a lotus pond not far from a town or village,
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: and a crab lived there.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Then several boys or girls would leave the town or village and go to the pond, where they’d pull out the crab and put it on dry land.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Whenever that crab extended a claw, those boys or girls would snap, crack, and break it off with a stick or a stone.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: And when that crab’s claws had all been snapped, cracked, and broken off it wouldn’t be able to return down into that lotus pond.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: In the same way, sir, the Buddha has snapped, cracked, and broken off all Saccaka’s twists, ducks, and dodges.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Now he can’t get near the Buddha again looking for a debate.”
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: But Saccaka said to him,
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: “Hold on, Dummukha, hold on! I wasn’t talking with you, I was talking with the worthy Gotama.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Worthy Gotama, leave aside that statement I made—as did various other ascetics and brahmins—
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: it was, like, just a bit of nonsense.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: How do you define a disciple of the worthy Gotama who follows instructions and responds to advice; who has gone beyond doubt, got rid of indecision, gained assurance, and is independent of others in the Teacher’s instructions?”
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: “It’s when one of my disciples truly sees any kind of form at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; solid or subtle; inferior or superior; far or near: *all* form—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: They truly see any kind of feeling …
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: perception …
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: choices …
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: consciousness at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; solid or subtle; inferior or superior; far or near: *all* consciousness—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: That’s how to define one of my disciples who follows instructions and responds to advice; who has gone beyond doubt, got rid of indecision, gained assurance, and is independent of others in the Teacher’s instructions.”
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: “But how do you define a mendicant who is a perfected one, with defilements ended, who has completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their own true goal, utterly ended the fetter of continued existence, and is rightly freed through enlightenment?”
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: “It’s when a mendicant truly sees any kind of form at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; coarse or fine; inferior or superior; far or near: *all* form—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’ And having seen this with right understanding they’re freed by not grasping.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: They truly see any kind of feeling …
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: perception …
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: choices …
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: consciousness at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; solid or subtle; inferior or superior; far or near: *all* consciousness—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’ And having seen this with right understanding they’re freed by not grasping.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: That’s how to define a mendicant who is a perfected one, with defilements ended, who has completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their own true goal, utterly ended the fetter of continued existence, and is rightly freed through enlightenment.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: A mendicant whose mind is freed like this has three unsurpassable qualities:
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: unsurpassable seeing, practice, and freedom.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: They honor, respect, esteem, and venerate only the Realized One:
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: ‘The Blessed One is awakened, tamed, serene, crossed over, and quenched. And he teaches Dhamma for awakening, self-control, serenity, crossing over, and extinguishment.’”
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: When he had spoken, Saccaka said to him,
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: “Worthy Gotama, it was rude and impudent of me to imagine I could attack you in debate.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: For a person might find safety after attacking a rutting elephant, but not after attacking the worthy Gotama.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: A person might find safety after attacking a blazing mass of fire, but not after attacking the worthy Gotama.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: They might find safety after attacking a poisonous viper, but not after attacking the worthy Gotama.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: It was rude and impudent of me to imagine I could attack you in debate.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Would the worthy Gotama together with the mendicant Saṅgha please accept tomorrow’s meal from me?”
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: The Buddha consented with silence.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Then, knowing that the Buddha had consented, Saccaka addressed those Licchavis,
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: “Listen, gentlemen. I have invited the ascetic Gotama together with the Saṅgha of mendicants for tomorrow’s meal.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: You may all bring me what you think is suitable.”
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Then, when the night had passed, those Licchavis presented Saccaka with an offering of five hundred servings of food.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: And Saccaka had delicious fresh and cooked foods prepared in his own park. Then he had the Buddha informed of the time, saying,
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: “It’s time, worthy Gotama, the meal is ready.”
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to Saccaka’s park, where he sat on the seat spread out, together with the Saṅgha of mendicants.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Then Saccaka served and satisfied the mendicant Saṅgha headed by the Buddha with his own hands with delicious fresh and cooked foods.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: When the Buddha had eaten and washed his hand and bowl, Saccaka took a low seat and sat to one side.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Then Saccaka said to the Buddha,
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: “Worthy Gotama, may the merit and the growth of merit in this gift be for the happiness of the donors.”
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: “Aggivessana, whatever comes from giving to a recipient of a religious donation such as yourself—who is not free of greed, hate, and delusion—will accrue to the donors.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Whatever comes from giving to a recipient of a religious donation such as myself—who is free of greed, hate, and delusion—will accrue to you.”
title: The Shorter Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Now at that time in the morning the Buddha, being properly dressed, took his bowl and robe, wishing to enter Vesālī for alms.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Then as Saccaka, the son of Jain parents, was going for a walk he approached the hall with the peaked roof in the Great Wood.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Venerable Ānanda saw him coming off in the distance,
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: and said to the Buddha,
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: “Sir, Saccaka, the son of Jain parents, is coming. He’s a debater and clever speaker deemed holy by many people.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: He wants to discredit the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Please, sir, sit for an hour out of sympathy.”
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: The Buddha sat on the seat spread out.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Then Saccaka went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him. When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to the Buddha,
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: “Worthy Gotama, there are some ascetics and brahmins who live committed to the practice of developing physical endurance, without developing the mind.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: They suffer painful physical feelings.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: This happened to someone once. Their thighs became paralyzed, their heart burst, hot blood gushed from their mouth, and they went mad and lost their mind.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Their mind was subject to the body, and the body had power over it.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Why is that?
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Because their mind was not developed.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: There are some ascetics and brahmins who live committed to the practice of developing the mind, without developing physical endurance.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: They suffer painful mental feelings.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: This happened to someone once. Their thighs became paralyzed, their heart burst, hot blood gushed from their mouth, and they went mad and lost their mind.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Their body was subject to the mind, and the mind had power over it.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Why is that?
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Because their physical endurance was not developed.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: It occurs to me that
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: The worthy Gotama’s disciples must live committed to the practice of developing the mind, without developing physical endurance.”
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: “But Aggivessana, what have you heard about the development of physical endurance?”
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: “Take, for example,
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Nanda Vaccha, Kisa Saṅkicca, and the bamboo-staffed ascetic Gosāla.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: They go naked, ignoring conventions. They lick their hands, and don’t come or wait when called. They don’t consent to food brought to them, or food prepared on their behalf, or an invitation for a meal.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: They don’t receive anything from a pot or bowl; or from someone who keeps sheep, or who has a weapon or a shovel in their home; or where a couple is eating; or where there is a woman who is pregnant, breastfeeding, or who lives with a man; or where there’s a dog waiting or flies buzzing. They accept no fish or meat or beer or wine, and drink no fermented gruel.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: They go to just one house for alms, taking just one mouthful, or two houses and two mouthfuls, up to seven houses and seven mouthfuls.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: They feed on one saucer a day, two saucers a day, up to seven saucers a day.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: They eat once a day, once every second day, up to once a week, and so on, even up to once a fortnight. They live committed to the practice of eating food at set intervals.”
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: “But Aggivessana, do they get by on so little?”
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: “No, worthy Gotama.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Sometimes they eat luxury fresh and cooked foods and drink a variety of luxury beverages.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: They gather their body’s strength, build it up, and get fat.”
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: “What they earlier gave up, they later got back. That is how there is the increase and decrease of this body.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: But Aggivessana, what have you heard about development of the mind?”
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: When Saccaka was questioned by the Buddha about development of the mind, he was stumped.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: So the Buddha said to Saccaka,
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: “The development of physical endurance that you have described is not the legitimate development of physical endurance in the noble one’s training.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: And since you don’t even understand the development of physical endurance, how can you possibly understand the development of the mind?
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Still, as to how someone is undeveloped in physical endurance and mind, and how someone is developed in physical endurance and mind,
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: “Yes, worthy sir,” replied Saccaka.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: The Buddha said this:
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: “And how is someone undeveloped in physical endurance and mind?
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Take an unlearned ordinary person who has a pleasant feeling.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: When they experience a pleasant feeling they become full of lust for it.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Then that pleasant feeling ceases.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: And when it ceases, a painful feeling arises.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: When they suffer painful feeling, they sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Because their physical endurance is undeveloped, pleasant feelings occupy the mind. And because their mind is undeveloped, painful feelings occupy the mind.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Anyone whose mind is occupied by both pleasant and painful feelings like this is undeveloped both in physical endurance and in mind.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: And how is someone developed in physical endurance and mind?
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Take a learned noble disciple who has a pleasant feeling.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: When they experience a pleasant feeling they don’t become full of lust for it.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Then that pleasant feeling ceases.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: And when it ceases, painful feeling arises.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: When they suffer painful feelings they don’t sorrow or wail or lament, beating their breast and falling into confusion.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Because their physical endurance is developed, pleasant feelings don’t occupy the mind. And because their mind is developed, painful feelings don’t occupy the mind.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Anyone whose mind is not occupied by both pleasant and painful feelings like this is developed both in physical endurance and in mind.”
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: “I am quite confident that the worthy Gotama
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: is developed in physical endurance and in mind.”
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: “Your words are clearly invasive and intrusive, Aggivessana.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Nevertheless, I will answer you.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Ever since I shaved off my hair and beard, dressed in ocher robes, and went forth from the lay life to homelessness, it has not been possible for any pleasant or painful feeling to occupy my mind.”
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: “Worthy Gotama mustn’t have experienced the kind of pleasant or painful feelings that would occupy the mind.”
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: “How could I not, Aggivessana?
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Before my awakening—when I was still unawakened but intent on awakening—I thought:
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: ‘Life at home is cramped and dirty, life gone forth is wide open.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: It’s not easy for someone living at home to lead the spiritual life utterly full and pure, like a polished shell.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Why don’t I shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness?’
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Some time later, while still with pristine black hair, blessed with youth, in the prime of life—though my mother and father wished otherwise, weeping with tearful faces—I shaved off my hair and beard, dressed in ocher robes, and went forth from the lay life to homelessness.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Once I had gone forth I set out to discover what is skillful, seeking the supreme state of sublime peace. I approached Āḷāra Kālāma and said to him,
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: ‘Reverend Kālāma, I wish to lead the spiritual life in this teaching and training.’
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Āḷāra Kālāma replied,
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: ‘Stay, venerable.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: This teaching is such that a sensible person can soon realize their own tradition with their own insight and live having achieved it.’
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: I quickly memorized that teaching.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: As far as lip-recital and verbal repetition went, I spoke the doctrine of knowledge, the elder doctrine. I claimed to know and see, and so did others.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Then it occurred to me,
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: ‘It is not solely by mere faith that Āḷāra Kālāma declares: “I realize this teaching with my own insight, and live having achieved it.”
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Surely he meditates knowing and seeing this teaching.’
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: So I approached Āḷāra Kālāma and said to him,
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: ‘Reverend Kālāma, to what extent do you say you’ve realized this teaching with your own insight?’
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: When I said this, he declared the dimension of nothingness.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Then it occurred to me,
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: ‘It’s not just Āḷāra Kālāma who has faith,
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: energy,
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: mindfulness,
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: immersion,
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: and wisdom; I too have these things.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Why don’t I make an effort to realize the same teaching that Āḷāra Kālāma says he has realized with his own insight?’
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: I quickly realized that teaching with my own insight, and lived having achieved it.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: So I approached Āḷāra Kālāma and said to him,
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: ‘Reverend Kālāma, is it up to this point that you realized this teaching with your own insight, and declare having achieved it?’
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: ‘I have, reverend.’
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: ‘I too have realized this teaching with my own insight up to this point, and live having achieved it.’
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: ‘We are fortunate, reverend, so very fortunate
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: to see a venerable such as yourself as one of our spiritual companions!
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: So the teaching that I’ve realized with my own insight, and declare having achieved it, you’ve realized with your own insight, and dwell having achieved it.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: The teaching that you’ve realized with your own insight, and dwell having achieved it, I’ve realized with my own insight, and declare having achieved it.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: So the teaching that I know, you know, and the teaching you know, I know.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: I am like you and you are like me.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Come now, reverend! We should both lead this community together.’
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: And that is how my tutor Āḷāra Kālāma placed me, his pupil, on the same position as him, and honored me with lofty praise.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Then it occurred to me,
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: ‘This teaching doesn’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment. It only leads as far as rebirth in the dimension of nothingness.’
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Realizing that this teaching was inadequate, I left disappointed.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: energy,
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: mindfulness,
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: immersion,
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: and wisdom; I too have these things.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Why don’t I make an effort to realize the same teaching that Rāma said he had realized with his own insight?’
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: I quickly realized that teaching with my own insight, and lived having achieved it.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: So I approached Uddaka son of Rāma and said to him,
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: ‘Reverend, had Rāma realized this teaching with his own insight up to this point, and declared having achieved it?’
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: ‘He had, reverend.’
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: ‘I too have realized this teaching with my own insight up to this point, and live having achieved it.’
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: ‘We are fortunate, reverend, so very fortunate
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: to see a venerable such as yourself as one of our spiritual companions!
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: The teaching that Rāma had realized with his own insight, and declared having achieved it, you have realized with your own insight, and dwell having achieved it. The teaching that you’ve realized with your own insight, and dwell having achieved it, Rāma had realized with his own insight, and declared having achieved it.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: So the teaching that Rāma directly knew, you know, and the teaching you know, Rāma directly knew.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Rāma was like you and you are like Rāma.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Come now, reverend! You should lead this community.’
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: And that is how my spiritual companion Uddaka son of Rāma placed me in the position of a tutor and honored me with lofty praise.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Then it occurred to me,
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: ‘This teaching doesn’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment. It only leads as far as rebirth in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.’
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Realizing that this teaching was inadequate, I left disappointed.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: I set out to discover what is skillful, seeking the supreme state of sublime peace. Traveling stage by stage in the Magadhan lands, I arrived at the town of Senā in Uruvelā.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: There I saw a delightful park, a lovely grove with a flowing river that was clean and charming, with smooth banks. And nearby was a village to resort to for alms.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Then it occurred to me,
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: ‘This park is truly delightful, a lovely grove with a flowing river that’s clean and charming, with smooth banks. And nearby there’s a village to resort to for alms.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: This is good enough for striving for a gentleman wanting to strive.’
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: So I sat down right there, thinking:
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: ‘This is good enough for striving.’
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: And then these three similes, which were neither supernaturally inspired, nor learned before in the past, occurred to me.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Suppose there was a green, sappy log, and it was lying in water.

title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: “No, worthy Gotama.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Why not?
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Because it’s a green, sappy log, and it’s lying in the water.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: That person will eventually get weary and frustrated.”
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: ‘Good fellow, don’t practice totally cutting off food.

segment_text: Then I thought,
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: ‘If I claim to be completely fasting while these deities are infusing heavenly nectar in my pores, that would be a lie on my part.’
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: So I dismissed those deities, saying, ‘There’s no need.’

segment_text: Then it occurred to me,
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: ‘Why don’t I just take a little bit of food each time, a handful of broth made from mung beans, horse gram, chickpeas, or green gram?’

segment_text: So that’s what I did,
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: until my body became extremely emaciated.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Due to eating so little, my major and minor limbs became like the joints of an eighty-year-old or a dying man,
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: my bottom became like a camel’s hoof,
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: my vertebrae stuck out like beads on a string,
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: and my ribs were as gaunt as the broken-down rafters on an old barn.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Due to eating so little, the gleam of my eyes sank deep in their sockets, like the gleam of water sunk deep down a well.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Due to eating so little, my scalp shriveled and withered like a green bitter-gourd in the wind and sun.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Due to eating so little, the skin of my belly stuck to my backbone, so that when I tried to rub the skin of my belly I grabbed my backbone, and when I tried to rub my backbone I rubbed the skin of my belly.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Due to eating so little, when I tried to urinate or defecate I fell face down right there.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Due to eating so little, when I tried to relieve my body by rubbing my limbs with my hands, the hair, rotted at its roots, fell out.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Then some people saw me and said: ‘The ascetic Gotama is black.’
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Some said: ‘He’s not black, he’s brown.’
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Some said: ‘He’s neither black nor brown. The ascetic Gotama has tawny skin.’
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: That’s how far the pure, bright complexion of my skin had been ruined by taking so little food.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Then I thought,
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: ‘Whatever ascetics and brahmins have experienced painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings due to overexertion—whether in the past, future, or present—this is as far as it goes, no-one has done more than this.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: But I have not achieved any superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones by this severe, grueling work.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Could there be another path to awakening?’
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Then it occurred to me,
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: ‘I recall sitting in the cool shade of a black plum tree while my father the Sakyan was off working. Quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, I entered and remained in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Could that be the path to awakening?’
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Stemming from that memory came the understanding:
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: ‘*That* is the path to awakening!’
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Then it occurred to me,
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: ‘Why am I afraid of that pleasure, for it has nothing to do with sensual pleasures or unskillful qualities?’
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Then I thought,
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: ‘I’m not afraid of that pleasure, for it has nothing to do with sensual pleasures or unskillful qualities.’
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Then I thought,
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: ‘I can’t achieve that pleasure with a body so excessively emaciated. Why don’t I eat some solid food, some rice and porridge?’

segment_text: Now at that time the five mendicants were attending on me, thinking,

title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: After eating solid food and gathering my strength, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, I entered and remained in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.

segment_text: But even such pleasant feeling did not occupy my mind.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected were stilled, I entered and remained in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: But even such pleasant feeling did not occupy my mind.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: And with the fading away of rapture, I entered and remained in the third absorption, where I meditated with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: But even such pleasant feeling did not occupy my mind.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: But even such pleasant feeling did not occupy my mind.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: When my mind had immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—I extended it toward recollection of past lives.

title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: When my mind had immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—I extended it toward knowledge of the death and rebirth of sentient beings.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, I saw sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. I understood how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: This was the second knowledge, which I achieved in the middle watch of the night.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Ignorance was destroyed and knowledge arose; darkness was destroyed and light arose, as happens for a meditator who is diligent, keen, and resolute.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka
