title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: When my mind had immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—I extended it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: I truly understood: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: I truly understood: ‘These are defilements’ … ‘This is the origin of defilements’ … ‘This is the cessation of defilements’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of defilements.’
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Knowing and seeing like this, my mind was freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: When it was freed, I knew it was freed.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: I understood: ‘Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is nothing further for this place.’
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: This was the third knowledge, which I achieved in the last watch of the night.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Ignorance was destroyed and knowledge arose; darkness was destroyed and light arose, as happens for a meditator who is diligent, keen, and resolute.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: But even such pleasant feeling did not occupy my mind.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Aggivessana, I recall teaching the Dhamma to an assembly of many hundreds,
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: and each person thought
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: that I was teaching the Dhamma especially for them.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: But it should not be seen like this.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: The Realized One teaches others only so that they can understand.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: When that talk was finished, I stilled, settled, unified, and immersed my mind in samādhi internally, using the same meditation subject as a basis of immersion that I used before, which I regularly use to meditate.”
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: “I’d believe that of the worthy Gotama, just like a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: But do you ever recall sleeping during the day?”
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: “I do recall that in the last month of the summer, I have spread out my outer robe folded in four and lain down in the lion’s posture—on the right side, placing one foot on top of the other—mindful and aware.”
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: “Some ascetics and brahmins call that a deluded abiding.”
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: “That’s not how to define whether someone is deluded or not.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: But as to how to define whether someone is deluded or not,
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: “Yes, worthy sir,” replied Saccaka.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: The Buddha said this:
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: “Anyone who has not given up the defilements that are corrupting, leading to future lives, hurtful, resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death is deluded, I say.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: For it’s not giving up the defilements that makes you deluded.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Anyone who has given up the defilements that are corrupting, leading to future lives, hurtful, resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death—is not deluded, I say.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: For it’s giving up the defilements that makes you not deluded.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: The Realized One has given up the defilements that are corrupting, leading to future lives, hurtful, resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death. He has cut them off at the root, made them like a palm stump, obliterated them so they are unable to arise in the future.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Just as a palm tree with its crown cut off is incapable of further growth,
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: in the same way, the Realized One has given up the defilements so they are unable to arise in the future.”
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: When he had spoken, Saccaka said to him,
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: “It’s incredible, worthy Gotama, it’s amazing!
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: How when the worthy Gotama is repeatedly attacked with inappropriate and intrusive criticism, the complexion of his skin brightens and the color of his face becomes clear, just like a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha!
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: I recall taking on Pūraṇa Kassapa in debate.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: He dodged the issue, distracting the discussion with irrelevant points, and displaying annoyance, hate, and bitterness.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: But when the worthy Gotama is repeatedly attacked with inappropriate and intrusive criticism, the complexion of his skin brightens and the color of his face becomes clear, just like a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: I recall taking on the bamboo-staffed ascetic Gosāla,
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Ajita of the hair blanket,
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Pakudha Kaccāyana,
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Sañjaya Belaṭṭhiputta,
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: and the Jain ascetic of the Ñātika clan in debate.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: They all dodged the issue, distracting the discussion with irrelevant points, and displaying annoyance, hate, and bitterness.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: But when the worthy Gotama is repeatedly attacked with inappropriate and intrusive criticism, the complexion of his skin brightens and the color of his face becomes clear, just like a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Well, now, worthy Gotama, I must go.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: I have many duties, and much to do.”
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: “Please, Aggivessana, go at your convenience.”
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: Then Saccaka, the son of Jain parents, having approved and agreed with what the Buddha said, got up from his seat and left.
title: The Longer Discourse With Saccaka

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in the stilt longhouse of Migāra’s mother in the Eastern Monastery.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: And then Sakka, lord of gods, went up to the Buddha, bowed, stood to one side, and said to him:
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: “Sir, how do you briefly define a mendicant who is freed through the ending of craving, who has reached the ultimate end, the ultimate sanctuary from the yoke, the ultimate spiritual life, the ultimate goal, and is best among gods and humans?”
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: “lord of gods, take a mendicant who has heard:
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: ‘Nothing is worth insisting on.’
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: When a mendicant has heard that
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: nothing is worth insisting on,
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: they directly know all things. Directly knowing all things, they completely understand all things. Completely understanding all things, when they experience any kind of feeling—pleasant, unpleasant, or neutral—
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: they meditate observing impermanence, dispassion, cessation, and letting go in those feelings.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: Meditating in this way, they don’t grasp at anything in the world.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: Not grasping, they’re not anxious. Not being anxious, they personally become extinguished.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: That’s how I briefly define a mendicant who is freed through the ending of craving, who has reached the ultimate end, the ultimate sanctuary from the yoke, the ultimate spiritual life, the ultimate goal, and is best among gods and humans.”
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: Then Sakka, lord of gods, having approved and agreed with what the Buddha said, bowed and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before vanishing right there.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: Now at that time Venerable Mahāmoggallāna was sitting not far from the Buddha.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: He thought,
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: “Did that spirit comprehend what the Buddha said when he agreed with him, or not?
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: Why don’t I find out?”
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: And then Venerable Mahāmoggallāna, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, vanished from the Eastern Monastery and reappeared among the gods of the thirty-three.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: Now at that time Sakka was amusing himself in the Single Lotus Park, supplied and provided with a heavenly orchestra.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: Seeing Mahāmoggallāna coming off in the distance,
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: he dismissed the orchestra, approached Mahāmoggallāna, and said,
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: “Come, my good Moggallāna! Welcome, good fellow!
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: It’s been a long time since you took the opportunity to come here.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: Sit, my good Moggallāna, this seat is for you.”
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: Mahāmoggallāna sat down on the seat spread out,
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: while Sakka took a low seat and sat to one side.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: Mahāmoggallāna said to him,
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: “Kosiya, how did the Buddha briefly explain freedom through the ending of craving?
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: Please share this talk with me so that I can also get to hear it.”
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: “My good Moggallāna, I have many duties, and much to do,
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: not only for myself, but also for the gods of the thirty-three.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: Still, what is properly heard, learned, attended, and memorized does not vanish all of a sudden.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: Once upon a time, a battle was fought between the gods and the titans.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: In that battle the gods won and the titans lost.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: When I returned from that battle as a conqueror, I created the Palace of Victory.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: The Palace of Victory has a hundred towers.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: Each tower has seven hundred chambers.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: Each chamber has seven nymphs.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: Each nymph has seven maids.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: Would you like to see the lovely Palace of Victory?”
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: Mahāmoggallāna consented with silence.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: Then, putting Venerable Mahāmoggallāna in front, Sakka, lord of gods, and Vessavaṇa, the Great King, went to the Palace of Victory.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: When they saw Moggallāna coming off in the distance, Sakka’s maids,
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: being discreet and prudent, each went to her own bedroom.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: They were just like a daughter-in-law who is discreet and prudent when they see their father-in-law.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: Then Sakka and Vessavaṇa encouraged Moggallāna to wander and explore the palace, saying,
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: “See, in the palace, my good Moggallāna, this lovely thing!
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: And that lovely thing!”
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: “That looks beautiful for the venerable Kosiya, as befits one who has made merit in the past.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: Humans, when they see something lovely, also say:
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: ‘It looks beautiful enough for the gods of the thirty-three!’
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: That looks beautiful for the venerable Kosiya, as befits one who has made merit in the past.”
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: Then Moggallāna thought,
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: “This spirit lives much too negligently.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: Why don’t I stir up a sense of urgency in him?”
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: Then Moggallāna used his psychic power to make the Palace of Victory shake and rock and tremble with his big toe.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: Then Sakka, Vessavaṇa, and the gods of the thirty-three, their minds full of wonder and amazement, thought,
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: “Oh lord, how incredible, how amazing!
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: The ascetic has such power and might that he makes the god’s home shake and rock and tremble with his big toe!”
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: Knowing that Sakka was shocked and awestruck, Moggallāna said to him,
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: Soon after Moggallāna left, Sakka’s maids said to him,
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: “Good fellow, was that the Blessed One, your Teacher?”
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: “No, it was not.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: That was my spiritual companion Venerable Mahāmoggallāna.”
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: “You’re fortunate, good fellow, so very fortunate,
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: to have a spiritual companion of such power and might!
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: We can’t believe that’s not the Blessed One, your Teacher!”
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: Then Mahāmoggallāna went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: “Sir, do you recall briefly explaining freedom through the ending of craving to a certain well-known and illustrious spirit?”
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: “I do, Moggallāna.” And the Buddha retold all that happened when Sakka came to visit him, adding:
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: “That’s how I recall briefly explaining freedom through the ending of craving to Sakka, lord of gods.”
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: That is what the Buddha said.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: Satisfied, Venerable Mahāmoggallāna approved what the Buddha said.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: Now at that time a mendicant called Sāti, the fisherman’s son, had the following harmful misconception:
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: “As I understand the Buddha’s teaching, it is this very same consciousness that roams and transmigrates, not another.”
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: Several mendicants heard about this.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: They went up to Sāti and said to him,
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: “Is it really true, Reverend Sāti, that you have such a harmful misconception:
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: ‘As I understand the Buddha’s teaching, it is this very same consciousness that roams and transmigrates, not another’?”
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: “Absolutely, reverends. As I understand the Buddha’s teaching, it is this very same consciousness that roams and transmigrates, not another.”
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: Then, wishing to dissuade Sāti from his view, the mendicants pursued, pressed, and grilled him,
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: “Don’t say that, Sāti! Don’t misrepresent the Buddha, for misrepresentation of the Buddha is not good. And the Buddha would not say that.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: In many ways the Buddha has said that consciousness is dependently originated, since without a cause, consciousness does not come to be.”
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: But even though the mendicants pressed him in this way, Sāti obstinately stuck to his misconception and insisted on it.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: When they weren’t able to dissuade Sāti from his view, the mendicants went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: So the Buddha addressed one of the monks,
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: “Please, monk, in my name tell the mendicant Sāti that
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: the teacher summons him.”
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: “Yes, sir,” that monk replied. He went to Sāti and said to him,
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: “Reverend Sāti, the teacher summons you.”
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: “Yes, reverend,” Sāti replied. He went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him,
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: “Is it really true, Sāti, that you have such a harmful misconception:
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: ‘As I understand the Buddha’s teaching, it is this very same consciousness that roams and transmigrates, not another’?”
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: “Absolutely, sir. As I understand the Buddha’s teaching, it is this very same consciousness that roams and transmigrates, not another.”
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: “Sāti, what is that consciousness?”
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: “Sir, he is the speaker, the knower who experiences the results of good and bad deeds in all the different realms.”
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: “Futile man, who on earth have you ever known me to teach in that way?
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: Haven’t I said in many ways that consciousness is dependently originated, since consciousness does not arise without a cause?
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: But still you misrepresent me by your wrong grasp, harm yourself, and create much wickedness.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: This will be for your lasting harm and suffering.”
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: Then the Buddha said to the mendicants,
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: “What do you think, mendicants?
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: Has this mendicant Sāti kindled even a spark of ardor in this teaching and training?”
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: “How could that be, sir?
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: No, sir.”
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: When this was said, Sāti sat silent, dismayed, shoulders drooping, downcast, depressed, with nothing to say.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: Knowing this, the Buddha said,
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: “Futile man, you will be known by your own harmful misconception.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: Then the Buddha said to the mendicants,
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: “Mendicants, do you understand my teachings as Sāti does, when he misrepresents me by his wrong grasp, harms himself, and creates much wickedness?”

title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: For in many ways the Buddha has told us that consciousness is dependently originated, since without a cause, consciousness does not come to be.”
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: “Good, good, mendicants!
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: “Good, mendicants! You have been guided by me with this teaching that’s apparent in the present life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves.

segment_text: Mendicants, when three things come together an embryo is conceived.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: In a case where the mother and father come together, but the mother is not in the fertile phase of her menstrual cycle, and the virile spirit is not ready, the embryo is not conceived.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: In a case where the mother and father come together, the mother is in the fertile phase of her menstrual cycle, but the virile spirit is not ready, the embryo is not conceived.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: But when these three things come together—the mother and father come together, the mother is in the fertile phase of her menstrual cycle, and the virile spirit is ready—an embryo is conceived.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: The mother nurtures the embryo in her womb for nine or ten months at great risk to her heavy burden.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: When nine or ten months have passed, the mother gives birth at great risk to her heavy burden.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: When the infant is born she nourishes it with her own blood.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: For mother’s milk is regarded as blood in the training of the Noble One.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: That boy grows up and his faculties mature.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: He accordingly plays childish games such as toy plows, tipcat, somersaults, pinwheels, toy measures, toy carts, and toy bows.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: That boy grows up and his faculties mature further.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: He accordingly amuses himself, supplied and provided with the five kinds of sensual stimulation.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: Sights known by the eye, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.

title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: When they see a sight with their eyes, if it’s pleasant they desire it, but if it’s unpleasant they dislike it. They live with mindfulness of the body unestablished and their heart restricted.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: And they don’t truly understand the freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom where those arisen bad, unskillful qualities cease without anything left over.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: Being so full of favoring and opposing, when they experience any kind of feeling—pleasant, unpleasant, or neutral—they approve, welcome, and keep clinging to it.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: But consider when a Realized One arises in the world, perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: He has realized with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras, and divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: He proclaims a teaching that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: He reveals an entirely full and pure spiritual life.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: A householder hears that teaching, or a householder’s child, or someone reborn in a good family.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: They gain faith in the Realized One
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: and reflect,
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: ‘Life at home is cramped and dirty, life gone forth is wide open.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: It’s not easy for someone living at home to lead the spiritual life utterly full and pure, like a polished shell.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: Why don’t I shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from lay life to homelessness?’
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: After some time they give up a large or small fortune, and a large or small family circle. They shave off hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: Once they’ve gone forth, they take up the training and livelihood of the mendicants. They give up killing living creatures, renouncing the rod and the sword. They’re scrupulous and kind, living full of sympathy for all living beings.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: They give up stealing. They take only what’s given, and expect only what’s given. They keep themselves clean by not thieving.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: They give up unchastity. They are chaste, set apart, avoiding the vulgar act of sex.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: They give up lying. They speak the truth and stick to the truth. They’re honest and dependable, and don’t trick the world with their words.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: They give up divisive speech. They don’t repeat in one place what they heard in another so as to divide people against each other. Instead, they reconcile those who are divided, supporting unity, delighting in harmony, loving harmony, speaking words that promote harmony.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: They give up harsh speech. They speak in a way that’s mellow, pleasing to the ear, lovely, going to the heart, polite, likable and agreeable to the people.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: They give up talking nonsense. Their words are timely, true, and meaningful, in line with the teaching and training. They say things at the right time which are valuable, reasonable, succinct, and beneficial.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: They refrain from injuring plants and seeds.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: They eat in one part of the day, abstaining from eating at night and food at the wrong time.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: They refrain from seeing shows of dancing, singing, and music .
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: They refrain from beautifying and adorning themselves with garlands, fragrance, and makeup.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: They refrain from high and luxurious beds.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: They refrain from receiving gold and currency,
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: raw grains,
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: raw meat,
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: women and girls,
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: male and female bondservants,
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: goats and sheep,
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: chickens and pigs,
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: elephants, cows, horses, and mares,
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: and fields and land.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: They refrain from running errands and messages;
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: buying and selling;
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: falsifying weights, metals, or measures;
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: bribery, fraud, cheating, and duplicity;
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: mutilation, murder, abduction, banditry, plunder, and violence.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: They’re content with robes to look after the body and almsfood to look after the belly. Wherever they go, they set out taking only these things.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: They’re like a bird: wherever it flies, wings are its only burden.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: In the same way, a mendicant is content with robes to look after the body and almsfood to look after the belly. Wherever they go, they set out taking only these things.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: When they have this entire spectrum of noble ethics, they experience a blameless happiness inside themselves.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: When they see a sight with their eyes, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: If the faculty of sight were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of sight, and achieving its restraint.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: When they hear a sound with their ears …
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: When they smell an odor with their nose …
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: When they taste a flavor with their tongue …
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: When they feel a touch with their body …
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: When they know an idea with their mind, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: If the faculty of mind were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of mind, and achieving its restraint.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: When they have this noble sense restraint, they experience an unsullied bliss inside themselves.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: They act with situational awareness when going out and coming back; when looking ahead and aside; when bending and extending the limbs; when bearing the outer robe, bowl and robes; when eating, drinking, chewing, and tasting; when urinating and defecating; when walking, standing, sitting, sleeping, waking, speaking, and keeping silent.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: When they have this entire spectrum of noble ethics, this noble contentment, this noble sense restraint, and this noble mindfulness and situational awareness,
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: they frequent a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: After the meal, they return from almsround, sit down cross-legged, set their body straight, and establish mindfulness in their presence.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: Giving up covetousness for the world, they meditate with a heart rid of covetousness, cleansing the mind of covetousness.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: Giving up ill will and malevolence, they meditate with a mind rid of ill will, full of sympathy for all living beings, cleansing the mind of ill will.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: Giving up dullness and drowsiness, they meditate with a mind rid of dullness and drowsiness, perceiving light, mindful and aware, cleansing the mind of dullness and drowsiness.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: Giving up restlessness and remorse, they meditate without restlessness, their mind peaceful inside, cleansing the mind of restlessness and remorse.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: Giving up doubt, they meditate having gone beyond doubt, not undecided about skillful qualities, cleansing the mind of doubt.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: They give up these five hindrances, corruptions of the heart that weaken wisdom.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: Then, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, they enter and remain in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: Furthermore, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, a mendicant enters and remains in the second absorption …
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: third absorption …
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: fourth absorption.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: When they see a sight with their eyes, if it’s pleasant they don’t desire it, and if it’s unpleasant they don’t dislike it. They live with mindfulness of the body established and a limitless heart.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: And they truly understand the freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom where those arisen bad, unskillful qualities cease without anything left over.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: Having given up favoring and opposing, when they experience any kind of feeling—pleasant, unpleasant, or neutral—they don’t approve, welcome, or keep clinging to it.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: As a result, relishing of feelings ceases.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: When their relishing ceases, grasping ceases. When grasping ceases, continued existence ceases. When continued existence ceases, rebirth ceases. When rebirth ceases, old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress cease.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: Mendicants, you should memorize this brief statement on freedom through the ending of craving. But the mendicant Sāti, the fisherman’s son, is caught in a vast net of craving, a tangle of craving.”
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: That is what the Buddha said.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Ending of Craving

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Aṅgas, near the Aṅgan town named Assapura.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: “Mendicants!”
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: “Venerable sir,” they replied.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: The Buddha said this:
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: “Mendicants, people label you as ascetics.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: And when they ask you what you are, you claim to be ascetics.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: Given this label and this claim, you should train like this: ‘We will undertake and follow the things that make one an ascetic and a brahmin. That way our label will be accurate and our claim correct.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: Any robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick that we use will be very fruitful and beneficial for the donor. And our going forth will not be wasted, but will be fruitful and fertile.’
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: And what are the things that make one an ascetic and a brahmin?
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: You should train like this: ‘We will have conscience and prudence.’
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: Now, mendicants, you might think,
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: ‘We have conscience and prudence. This is sufficient; enough has been done. We have achieved the goal of life as an ascetic. There is nothing more to do.’ And you might rest content with just that much.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: I declare this to you, mendicants, I announce this to you:
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: ‘You who seek to be true ascetics, do not lose sight of the goal of the ascetic life while there is still more to do.’
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: What more is there to do?
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: You should train like this: ‘Our bodily behavior will be pure, clear, open, neither inconsistent nor secretive.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: And we won’t glorify ourselves or put others down on account of our pure bodily behavior.’
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: Now, mendicants, you might think,
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: ‘We have conscience and prudence, and our bodily behavior is pure.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: This is sufficient …’
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: I declare this to you, mendicants, I announce this to you:
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: You should train like this: ‘Our verbal behavior …
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: mental behavior …
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: Now, mendicants, you might think,

segment_text: ‘We have conscience and prudence, our bodily, verbal, and mental behavior is pure, and our livelihood is pure.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: This is sufficient; enough has been done. We have achieved the goal of life as an ascetic. There is nothing more to do.’ And you might rest content with just that much.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: What more is there to do?
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: You should train yourselves like this: ‘We will restrain our sense doors.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: When we see a sight with our eyes, we won’t get caught up in the features and details.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: If the faculty of sight were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure would become overwhelming. For this reason, we will practice restraint, we will protect the faculty of sight, and we will achieve its restraint.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: When we hear a sound with our ears …
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: When we smell an odor with our nose …
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: When we taste a flavor with our tongue …
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: When we feel a touch with our body …
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: When we know an idea with our mind, we won’t get caught up in the features and details.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: If the faculty of mind were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure would become overwhelming. For this reason, we will practice restraint, we will protect the faculty of mind, and we will achieve its restraint.’
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: Now, mendicants, you might think,
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: ‘We have conscience and prudence, our bodily, verbal, and mental behavior is pure, our livelihood is pure, and our sense doors are restrained.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: This is sufficient …’
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: What more is there to do?
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: You should train yourselves like this: ‘We will not eat too much. We will only eat after reflecting rationally on our food.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: We will eat not for fun, indulgence, adornment, or decoration, but only to sustain this body, to avoid harm, and to support spiritual practice. In this way, we shall put an end to old discomfort and not give rise to new discomfort, and we will have the means to keep going, blamelessness, and a comfortable abiding.’
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: Now, mendicants, you might think,
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: ‘We have conscience and prudence, our bodily, verbal, and mental behavior is pure, our livelihood is pure, our sense doors are restrained, and we don’t eat too much.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: This is sufficient …’
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: What more is there to do?
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: You should train yourselves like this: ‘We will be dedicated to wakefulness. When practicing walking and sitting meditation by day, we will purify our mind from obstacles.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: In the first watch of the night, we will continue to practice walking and sitting meditation.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: In the middle watch, we will lie down in the lion’s posture—on the right side, placing one foot on top of the other—mindful and aware, and focused on the time of getting up.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: In the last watch, we will get up and continue to practice walking and sitting meditation, purifying our mind from obstacles.’
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: Now, mendicants, you might think,
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: ‘We have conscience and prudence, our bodily, verbal, and mental behavior is pure, our livelihood is pure, our sense doors are restrained, we don’t eat too much, and we are dedicated to wakefulness.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: This is sufficient …’
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: What more is there to do?
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: You should train yourselves like this: ‘We will have situational awareness and mindfulness. We will act with situational awareness when going out and coming back; when looking ahead and aside; when bending and extending the limbs; when bearing the outer robe, bowl and robes; when eating, drinking, chewing, and tasting; when urinating and defecating; when walking, standing, sitting, sleeping, waking, speaking, and keeping silent.’
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: Now, mendicants, you might think,
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: ‘We have conscience and prudence, our bodily, verbal, and mental behavior is pure, our livelihood is pure, our sense doors are restrained, we don’t eat too much, we are dedicated to wakefulness, and we have mindfulness and situational awareness.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: This is sufficient …’
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: What more is there to do?
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: Take a mendicant who frequents a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: After the meal, they return from almsround, sit down cross-legged, set their body straight, and establish mindfulness in their presence.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: Giving up covetousness for the world, they meditate with a heart rid of covetousness, cleansing the mind of covetousness.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: Giving up ill will and malevolence, they meditate with a mind rid of ill will, full of sympathy for all living beings, cleansing the mind of ill will.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: Giving up dullness and drowsiness, they meditate with a mind rid of dullness and drowsiness, perceiving light, mindful and aware, cleansing the mind of dullness and drowsiness.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: Giving up restlessness and remorse, they meditate without restlessness, their mind peaceful inside, cleansing the mind of restlessness and remorse.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: Giving up doubt, they meditate having gone beyond doubt, not undecided about skillful qualities, cleansing the mind of doubt.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: Suppose a man who has gotten into debt were to apply himself to work,
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: and his efforts proved successful.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: He would pay off the original loan and have enough left over to support his partner.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: Thinking about this,
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: he’d be filled with joy and happiness.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: Suppose a person was sick, suffering, and gravely ill. They’d lose their appetite and get physically weak.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: But after some time they’d recover from that illness, and regain their appetite and their strength.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: Thinking about this,
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: they’d be filled with joy and happiness.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: Suppose a person was imprisoned in a jail.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: But after some time they were released from jail, safe and sound, with no loss of wealth.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: Thinking about this,
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: they’d be filled with joy and happiness.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: Suppose a person was a bondservant. They would not be their own master, but indentured to another, unable to go where they wish.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: But after some time they’d be freed from servitude. They would be their own master, not indentured to another, an emancipated individual able to go where they wish.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: Thinking about this,
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: they’d be filled with joy and happiness.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: Suppose there was a person with wealth and property who was traveling along a desert road.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: But after some time they crossed over the desert, safe and sound, with no loss of wealth.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: Thinking about this,
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: they’d be filled with joy and happiness.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: In the same way, as long as these five hindrances are not given up inside themselves, a mendicant regards them as a debt, a disease, a prison, slavery, and a desert crossing.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: But when these five hindrances are given up inside themselves, a mendicant regards this as freedom from debt, good health, release from prison, emancipation, and a place of sanctuary at last.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: They give up these five hindrances, corruptions of the heart that weaken wisdom.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: Then, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, they enter and remain in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: They drench, steep, fill, and spread their body with rapture and bliss born of seclusion. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with rapture and bliss born of seclusion.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: It’s like when a deft bathroom attendant or their apprentice pours bath powder into a bronze dish, sprinkling it little by little with water. They knead it until the ball of bath powder is soaked and saturated with moisture, spread through inside and out; yet no moisture oozes out.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: In the same way, a mendicant drenches, steeps, fills, and spreads their body with rapture and bliss born of seclusion. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with rapture and bliss born of seclusion.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: Furthermore, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, a mendicant enters and remains in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: They drench, steep, fill, and spread their body with rapture and bliss born of immersion. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with rapture and bliss born of immersion.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: It’s like a deep lake fed by spring water. There’s no inlet to the east, west, north, or south, and the heavens would not properly bestow showers from time to time. But the stream of cool water welling up in the lake drenches, steeps, fills, and spreads throughout the lake. There’s no part of the lake that’s not spread through with cool water.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: In the same way, a mendicant drenches, steeps, fills, and spreads their body with rapture and bliss born of immersion. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with rapture and bliss born of immersion.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: Furthermore, with the fading away of rapture, a mendicant enters and remains in the third absorption, where they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: They drench, steep, fill, and spread their body with bliss free of rapture. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with bliss free of rapture.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: It’s like a pool with blue water lilies, or pink or white lotuses. Some of them sprout and grow in the water without rising above it, thriving underwater. From the tip to the root they’re drenched, steeped, filled, and soaked with cool water. There’s no part of them that’s not soaked with cool water.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: In the same way, a mendicant drenches, steeps, fills, and spreads their body with bliss free of rapture. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with bliss free of rapture.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: Furthermore, giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, a mendicant enters and remains in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: They sit spreading their body through with pure bright mind. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with pure bright mind.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: It’s like someone sitting wrapped from head to foot with white cloth. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread over with white cloth.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: In the same way, they sit spreading their body through with pure bright mind. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with pure bright mind.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward recollection of past lives.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: They recollect many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: Suppose a person was to leave their home village and go to another village. From that village they’d go to yet another village. And from that village they’d return to their home village. They’d think: ‘I went from my home village to another village. There I stood like this, sat like that, spoke like this, or kept silent like that. From that village I went to yet another village. There too I stood like this, sat like that, spoke like this, or kept silent like that. And from that village I returned to my home village.’
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: In the same way, a mendicant recollects their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward knowledge of the death and rebirth of sentient beings.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: Suppose there were two houses with doors. A person with clear eyes standing in between them would see humans entering and leaving a house and wandering to and fro.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: In the same way, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: They truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: They truly understand: ‘These are defilements’ … ‘This is the origin of defilements’ … ‘This is the cessation of defilements’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of defilements.’
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: Knowing and seeing like this, their mind is freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: Suppose that in a mountain glen there was a lake that was transparent, clear, and unclouded. A person with clear eyes standing on the bank would see the clams and mussels, and pebbles and gravel, and schools of fish swimming about or staying still.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: They’d think:
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: ‘This lake is transparent, clear, and unclouded. And here are the clams and mussels, and pebbles and gravel, and schools of fish swimming about or staying still.’
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: In the same way, a mendicant truly understands: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: They understand: ‘… there is nothing further for this place.’
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: This mendicant is one who is called an ‘ascetic’, a ‘brahmin’, a ‘bathed initiate’, a ‘knowledge master’, a ‘scholar’, a ‘noble one’, and also a ‘perfected one’.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: And how is a mendicant an ascetic?
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: They have assuaged the bad, unskillful qualities that are corrupting, leading to future lives, hurtful, resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: That’s how a mendicant is an ascetic.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: And how is a mendicant a brahmin?
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: They have banished the bad, unskillful qualities.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: That’s how a mendicant is a brahmin.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: And how is a mendicant a bathed initiate?
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: They have bathed off the bad, unskillful qualities.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: That’s how a mendicant is a bathed initiate.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: And how is a mendicant a knowledge master?
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: They have known the bad, unskillful qualities.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: That’s how a mendicant is a knowledge master.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: And how is a mendicant a scholar?
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: They have scoured off the bad, unskillful qualities.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: That’s how a mendicant is a scholar.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: And how is a mendicant a noble one?
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: They have nobbled their foes, the bad, unskillful qualities.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: That’s how a mendicant is a noble one.
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: And how is a mendicant a perfected one?
title: The Longer Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: They are impeccably remote from the bad, unskillful qualities that are corrupting, leading to future lives, hurtful, resulting in suffering and future rebirth, old age, and death.

title: The Shorter Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Aṅgas, near the Aṅgan town named Assapura.

segment_text: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,
title: The Shorter Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: “Mendicants!”
title: The Shorter Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: “Venerable sir,” they replied.
title: The Shorter Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: The Buddha said this:
title: The Shorter Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: “Mendicants, people label you as ascetics.
title: The Shorter Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: And when they ask you what you are, you claim to be ascetics.
title: The Shorter Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: Given this label and this claim, you should train like this: ‘We will practice in the way that is proper for an ascetic. That way our label will be accurate and our claim correct.
title: The Shorter Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: Any robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick that we use will be very fruitful and beneficial for the donor. And our going forth will not be wasted, but will be fruitful and fertile.’
title: The Shorter Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: And how does a mendicant not practice in the way that is proper for an ascetic?
title: The Shorter Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: Any mendicant who has not given up covetousness, ill will, irritability, acrimony, disdain, contempt, jealousy, stinginess, deviousness, deceit, corrupt wishes, and wrong view
title: The Shorter Discourse at Assapura

segment_text: is not practicing in the way that is proper for an ascetic, I say. And that is due to not giving up these stains, defects, and dregs of an ascetic, these grounds for rebirth in places of loss, to be experienced in bad places.

segment_text: I say that such a mendicant’s going forth may be compared to the kind of weapon called ‘deadborn’—double-edged, whetted with yellow arsenic—that has been covered and wrapped in an outer robe.

segment_text: I say that you don’t deserve the label ‘outer robe wearer’ just because you wear an outer robe.

title: The People of Sālā

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was wandering in the land of the Kosalans together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants when he arrived at a village of the Kosalan brahmins named Sālā.

segment_text: The brahmins and householders of Sālā heard,
title: The People of Sālā

segment_text: “It seems the ascetic Gotama—a Sakyan, gone forth from a Sakyan family—while wandering in the land of the Kosalans has arrived at Sālā, together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants.

segment_text: He has this good reputation:
title: The People of Sālā

segment_text: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’
title: The People of Sālā

segment_text: He has realized with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras, and divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others.
title: The People of Sālā

segment_text: He proclaims a teaching that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased.
title: The People of Sālā

segment_text: He reveals an entirely full and pure spiritual life.
title: The People of Sālā

segment_text: It’s good to see such perfected ones.”
title: The People of Sālā

segment_text: Then the brahmins and householders of Sālā went up to the Buddha. Before sitting down to one side, some bowed, some exchanged greetings and polite conversation, some held up their joined palms toward the Buddha, some announced their name and clan, while some kept silent. Seated to one side they said to the Buddha:
title: The People of Sālā

segment_text: “What is the cause, worthy Gotama, what is the reason why some sentient beings, when their body breaks up, after death, are reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell?
title: The People of Sālā

segment_text: And what is the cause, worthy Gotama, what is the reason why some sentient beings, when their body breaks up, after death, are reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm?”
title: The People of Sālā

segment_text: “Unprincipled and immoral conduct is the reason why some sentient beings, when their body breaks up, after death, are reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
title: The People of Sālā

segment_text: Principled and moral conduct is the reason why some sentient beings, when their body breaks up, after death, are reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.”

segment_text: “We don’t understand the detailed meaning of the worthy Gotama’s brief statement.

segment_text: And how is unprincipled and immoral conduct threefold by way of body?
title: The People of Sālā

segment_text: It’s when a certain person kills living creatures. They’re violent, bloody-handed, a hardened killer, merciless to living beings.
title: The People of Sālā

segment_text: They steal. With the intention to commit theft, they take the wealth or belongings of others from village or wilderness.
title: The People of Sālā

segment_text: They commit sexual misconduct. They have sexual relations with women who have their mother, father, both mother and father, brother, sister, relatives, or clan as guardian. They have sexual relations with a woman who is protected on principle, or who has a husband, or whose violation is punishable by law, or even one who has been garlanded as a token of betrothal.
title: The People of Sālā

segment_text: This is how unprincipled and immoral conduct is threefold by way of body.

segment_text: It’s when a certain person lies. segment_text: They speak divisively. They repeat in one place what they heard in another so as to divide people against each other. And so they divide those who are harmonious, supporting division, delighting in division, loving division, speaking words that promote division.

segment_text: This is how unprincipled and immoral conduct is fourfold by way of speech.

segment_text: The Buddha said that these five grasping aggregates are substantial reality.”

title: The Shorter Elaboration

segment_text: craving for sensual pleasures, craving to continue existence, and craving to end existence.
title: The Shorter Elaboration

segment_text: The Buddha said that this is the origin of substantial reality.”

title: The Shorter Elaboration

segment_text: “It’s the fading away and cessation of that very same craving with nothing left over; giving it away, letting it go, releasing it, and not clinging to it.

segment_text: The Buddha said that this is the cessation of substantial reality.”
title: The Shorter Elaboration

segment_text: “Ma’am, they speak of the practice that leads to the cessation of substantial reality.

segment_text: “The practice that leads to the cessation of substantial reality that the Buddha spoke of is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:

title: The Shorter Elaboration

segment_text: “But ma’am, which process arises first for a mendicant who is emerging from the cessation of perception and feeling: physical, verbal, or mental?”
title: The Shorter Elaboration

segment_text: “The mental process arises first, then physical, then verbal.”
title: The Shorter Elaboration

segment_text: “But ma’am, when a mendicant has emerged from the attainment of the cessation of perception and feeling, how many kinds of contact do they experience?”
title: The Shorter Elaboration

segment_text: “They experience three kinds of contact: emptiness, signless, and undirected contacts.”
title: The Shorter Elaboration

segment_text: “But ma’am, when a mendicant has emerged from the attainment of the cessation of perception and feeling, what does their mind slant, slope, and incline to?”
title: The Shorter Elaboration

segment_text: “Their mind slants, slopes, and inclines to seclusion.”
title: The Shorter Elaboration

segment_text: “But ma’am, how many feelings are there?”
title: The Shorter Elaboration

segment_text: “There are three feelings:
title: The Shorter Elaboration

segment_text: pleasant, painful, and neutral feeling.”
title: The Shorter Elaboration

segment_text: “What are these three feelings?”
title: The Shorter Elaboration

segment_text: “Anything felt physically or mentally as pleasant or enjoyable.
title: The Shorter Elaboration

segment_text: This is pleasant feeling.
title: The Shorter Elaboration

segment_text: Anything felt physically or mentally as painful or unpleasant.
title: The Shorter Elaboration

segment_text: This is painful feeling.
title: The Shorter Elaboration

segment_text: Anything felt physically or mentally as neither pleasurable nor painful.
title: The Shorter Elaboration

segment_text: This is neutral feeling.”
title: The Shorter Elaboration

segment_text: “What is pleasant and what is painful regarding each of the three feelings?”
title: The Shorter Elaboration

segment_text: “Pleasant feeling is pleasant when it remains and painful when it perishes.
title: The Shorter Elaboration

segment_text: Painful feeling is painful when it remains and pleasant when it perishes.
title: The Shorter Elaboration

segment_text: Neutral feeling is pleasant in the presence of knowledge, and painful in the presence of ignorance.”
title: The Shorter Elaboration

segment_text: “What underlying tendencies underlie each of the three feelings?”
title: The Shorter Elaboration

segment_text: “The underlying tendency for greed underlies pleasant feeling. The underlying tendency for repulsion underlies painful feeling. The underlying tendency for ignorance underlies neutral feeling.”
title: The Shorter Elaboration

segment_text: “Do these underlying tendencies always underlie these feelings?”
title: The Shorter Elaboration

segment_text: “No, they do not.”
title: The Shorter Elaboration

segment_text: “What should be given up in regard to each of these three feelings?”
title: The Shorter Elaboration

segment_text: “The underlying tendency to greed should be given up when it comes to pleasant feeling. The underlying tendency to repulsion should be given up when it comes to painful feeling. The underlying tendency to ignorance should be given up when it comes to neutral feeling.”
title: The Shorter Elaboration

segment_text: “Should these underlying tendencies be given up regarding all instances of these feelings?”
title: The Shorter Elaboration

segment_text: “No, not in all instances.
title: The Shorter Elaboration

segment_text: Take a mendicant who, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
title: The Shorter Elaboration

segment_text: With this they give up greed, and the underlying tendency to greed does not lie within that.
title: The Shorter Elaboration

segment_text: And take a mendicant who reflects:
title: The Shorter Elaboration

segment_text: ‘Oh, when will I enter and remain in the same dimension that the noble ones enter and remain in today?’
title: The Shorter Elaboration

segment_text: Nursing such a longing for the supreme liberations gives rise to sadness due to longing.
title: The Shorter Elaboration

segment_text: With this they give up repulsion, and the underlying tendency to repulsion does not lie within that.
title: The Shorter Elaboration

segment_text: Take a mendicant who, giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, enters and remains in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.
title: The Shorter Elaboration

segment_text: With this they give up ignorance, and the underlying tendency to ignorance does not lie within that.”
title: The Shorter Elaboration

segment_text: “But ma’am, what is the counterpart of pleasant feeling?”
title: The Shorter Elaboration

segment_text: “Painful feeling.”
title: The Shorter Elaboration

segment_text: “What is the counterpart of painful feeling?”
title: The Shorter Elaboration

segment_text: “Pleasant feeling.”
title: The Shorter Elaboration

segment_text: “What is the counterpart of neutral feeling?”
title: The Shorter Elaboration

segment_text: “Ignorance.”
title: The Shorter Elaboration

segment_text: “What is the counterpart of ignorance?”
title: The Shorter Elaboration

segment_text: “Knowledge.”
title: The Shorter Elaboration

segment_text: “What is the counterpart of knowledge?”
title: The Shorter Elaboration

segment_text: “Freedom.”
title: The Shorter Elaboration

segment_text: “What is the counterpart of freedom?”
title: The Shorter Elaboration

segment_text: “Extinguishment.”
title: The Shorter Elaboration

segment_text: “What is the counterpart of extinguishment?”
title: The Shorter Elaboration

segment_text: “Your question goes too far, Visākha. You couldn’t figure out the limit of questions.
title: The Shorter Elaboration

segment_text: For extinguishment is the culmination, destination, and end of the spiritual life.
title: The Shorter Elaboration

segment_text: If you wish, go to the Buddha and ask him this question. You should remember it in line with his answer.”
title: The Shorter Elaboration

segment_text: And then the layman Visākha approved and agreed with what the nun Dhammadinnā said. He got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled her, keeping her on his right. Then he went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side,
title: The Shorter Elaboration

segment_text: and informed the Buddha of all they had discussed.
title: The Shorter Elaboration

segment_text: When he had spoken, the Buddha said to him,
title: The Shorter Elaboration

segment_text: “The nun Dhammadinnā is astute, Visākha, she has great wisdom.
title: The Shorter Elaboration

segment_text: If you came to me and asked this question, I would answer it in exactly the same way as the nun Dhammadinnā.
title: The Shorter Elaboration

segment_text: That is what it means, and that’s how you should remember it.”
title: The Shorter Elaboration

segment_text: That is what the Buddha said.
title: The Shorter Elaboration

segment_text: Satisfied, the layman Visākha approved what the Buddha said.
title: The Shorter Elaboration

segment_text: So I have heard.

title: The Shorter Discourse on Taking Up Practices

title: The Shorter Discourse on Taking Up Practices
