segment_text: There are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:
title: The Shorter Discourse on Taking Up Practices

segment_text: They say,
title: The Shorter Discourse on Taking Up Practices

segment_text: ‘What future danger do those ascetics and brahmins see in sensual pleasures that they speak of giving up sensual pleasures, and advocate the complete understanding of sensual pleasures?

segment_text: And there they feel painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings.
title: The Shorter Discourse on Taking Up Practices

segment_text: They say,
title: The Shorter Discourse on Taking Up Practices

segment_text: It’s when someone goes naked, ignoring conventions. They lick their hands, and don’t come or wait when called. They don’t consent to food brought to them, or food prepared on their behalf, or an invitation for a meal.
title: The Shorter Discourse on Taking Up Practices

segment_text: They don’t receive anything from a pot or bowl; or from someone who keeps sheep, or who has a weapon or a shovel in their home; or where a couple is eating; or where there is a woman who is pregnant, breastfeeding, or who lives with a man; or where there’s a dog waiting or flies buzzing. They accept no fish or meat or beer or wine, and drink no fermented gruel.
title: The Shorter Discourse on Taking Up Practices

segment_text: They go to just one house for alms, taking just one mouthful, or two houses and two mouthfuls, up to seven houses and seven mouthfuls.
title: The Shorter Discourse on Taking Up Practices

segment_text: They feed on one saucer a day, two saucers a day, up to seven saucers a day.
title: The Shorter Discourse on Taking Up Practices

segment_text: They eat once a day, once every second day, up to once a week, and so on, even up to once a fortnight. They live committed to the practice of eating food at set intervals.
title: The Shorter Discourse on Taking Up Practices

segment_text: They eat herbs, millet, wild rice, poor rice, water lettuce, rice bran, scum from boiling rice, sesame flour, grass, or cow dung. They survive on forest roots and fruits, or eating fallen fruit.
title: The Shorter Discourse on Taking Up Practices

segment_text: They wear robes of sunn hemp, mixed hemp, corpse-wrapping cloth, rags, lodh tree bark, antelope hide (whole or in strips), kusa grass, bark, wood-chips, human hair, horse-tail hair, or owls’ wings.
title: The Shorter Discourse on Taking Up Practices

segment_text: They tear out their hair and beard, committed to this practice.

segment_text: They squat, committed to the endeavor of squatting.
title: The Shorter Discourse on Taking Up Practices

segment_text: They lie on a mat of thorns, making a mat of thorns their bed.

segment_text: They’re devoted to ritual bathing three times a day, including the evening.

title: The Shorter Discourse on Taking Up Practices

segment_text: It’s when someone with pleasure and happiness doesn’t kill living creatures, steal, or commit sexual misconduct. They don’t use speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical. And they’re contented, kind-hearted, with right view. Because of these things they experience pleasure and happiness.
title: The Great Discourse on Taking Up Practices

segment_text: And when their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.
title: The Great Discourse on Taking Up Practices

segment_text: This is called the way of taking up practices that is pleasant now and results in future pleasure.
title: The Great Discourse on Taking Up Practices

segment_text: These are the four ways of taking up practices.
title: The Great Discourse on Taking Up Practices

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

segment_text: The Buddha said this:
title: The Inquirer

segment_text: “Mendicants, a mendicant who is an inquirer, unable to comprehend another’s mind, should scrutinize the Realized One to understand whether he is a fully awakened Buddha or not.”
title: The Inquirer

segment_text: “Our teachings are rooted in the Buddha. He is our guide and our refuge. Sir, may the Buddha himself please clarify the meaning of this. The mendicants will listen and remember it.”
title: The Inquirer

title: The Inquirer

segment_text: “Yes, sir,” they replied.

segment_text: ‘Can anything corrupt be seen or heard in the Realized One or not?’
title: The Inquirer

segment_text: Scrutinizing him they find that
title: The Inquirer

segment_text: ‘Are certain dangers found in that venerable mendicant who has achieved fame and renown?’

segment_text: For, mendicants, so long as a mendicant has not achieved fame and renown, certain dangers are not found in them.

title: The Inquirer

segment_text: ‘Because, whether that venerable is staying in a community or alone, some people there are in a good state or a sorry state, some instruct a group, and some are seen among pleasures of the flesh while others remain unsullied. Yet that venerable doesn’t look down on them for that.

segment_text: Also, I have heard and learned this in the presence of the Buddha:

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Kosambī, in Ghosita’s Monastery.
title: The Mendicants of Kosambī

segment_text: Now at that time the mendicants of Kosambī were arguing, quarreling, and disputing, continually wounding each other with barbed words.
title: The Mendicants of Kosambī

segment_text: They couldn’t persuade each other or be persuaded, nor could they convince each other or be convinced.
title: The Mendicants of Kosambī

segment_text: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what was happening.
title: The Mendicants of Kosambī

segment_text: So the Buddha addressed one of the monks,
title: The Mendicants of Kosambī

segment_text: “Please, monk, in my name tell those mendicants that
title: The Mendicants of Kosambī

segment_text: the teacher summons them.”
title: The Mendicants of Kosambī

segment_text: “Yes, sir,” that monk replied. He went to those monks and said,
title: The Mendicants of Kosambī

segment_text: “Venerables, the teacher summons you.”
title: The Mendicants of Kosambī

segment_text: “Yes, reverend,” those monks replied. They went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to them,
title: The Mendicants of Kosambī

segment_text: “Is it really true, mendicants, that you have been arguing, quarreling, and disputing, continually wounding each other with barbed words?
title: The Mendicants of Kosambī

segment_text: And that you can’t persuade each other or be persuaded, nor can you convince each other or be convinced?”
title: The Mendicants of Kosambī

segment_text: “Yes, sir,” they said.
title: The Mendicants of Kosambī

segment_text: “What do you think, mendicants?
title: The Mendicants of Kosambī

segment_text: When you’re arguing, quarreling, and disputing, continually wounding each other with barbed words, are you treating your spiritual companions with kindness by way of body, speech, and mind, both in public and in private?”
title: The Mendicants of Kosambī

segment_text: “No, sir.”
title: The Mendicants of Kosambī

segment_text: “So it seems that when you’re arguing you are not treating each other with kindness.
title: The Mendicants of Kosambī

segment_text: So what exactly do you know and see, you futile men, that you behave in such a way?
title: The Mendicants of Kosambī

segment_text: This will be for your lasting harm and suffering.”
title: The Mendicants of Kosambī

segment_text: Then the Buddha said to the mendicants:
title: The Mendicants of Kosambī

segment_text: “Mendicants, these six warm-hearted qualities make for fondness and respect, conducing to inclusion, harmony, and unity, without quarreling.
title: The Mendicants of Kosambī

segment_text: What six?
title: The Mendicants of Kosambī

segment_text: Firstly, a mendicant consistently treats their spiritual companions with bodily kindness, both in public and in private.
title: The Mendicants of Kosambī

segment_text: This warm-hearted quality makes for fondness and respect, conducing to inclusion, harmony, and unity, without quarreling.
title: The Mendicants of Kosambī

segment_text: Furthermore, a mendicant consistently treats their spiritual companions with verbal kindness …
title: The Mendicants of Kosambī

segment_text: Furthermore, a mendicant consistently treats their spiritual companions with mental kindness …
title: The Mendicants of Kosambī

segment_text: Furthermore, a mendicant shares without reservation any material things they have gained by legitimate means, even the food placed in the alms-bowl, using them in common with their ethical spiritual companions …
title: The Mendicants of Kosambī

segment_text: Furthermore, a mendicant lives according to the precepts shared with their spiritual companions, both in public and in private. Those precepts are intact, impeccable, spotless, and unmarred, liberating, praised by sensible people, not mistaken, and leading to immersion. …
title: The Mendicants of Kosambī

segment_text: Furthermore, a mendicant lives according to the view shared with their spiritual companions, both in public and in private. That view is noble and emancipating, and delivers one who practices it to the complete ending of suffering.
title: The Mendicants of Kosambī

segment_text: This warm-hearted quality makes for fondness and respect, conducing to inclusion, harmony, and unity, without quarreling.
title: The Mendicants of Kosambī

segment_text: These six warm-hearted qualities make for fondness and respect, conducing to inclusion, harmony, and unity, without quarreling.
title: The Mendicants of Kosambī

segment_text: Of these six warm-hearted qualities, the chief is the view that is noble and emancipating, and delivers one who practices it to the complete ending of suffering. It holds and binds everything together.
title: The Mendicants of Kosambī

segment_text: It’s like a bungalow. The roof-peak is the chief point, which holds and binds everything together.
title: The Mendicants of Kosambī

segment_text: In the same way, of these six warm-hearted qualities, the chief is the view that is noble and emancipating, and delivers one who practices it to the complete ending of suffering. It holds and binds everything together.
title: The Mendicants of Kosambī

segment_text: And how does the view that is noble and emancipating lead one who practices it to the complete ending of suffering?
title: The Mendicants of Kosambī

title: The Mendicants of Kosambī

segment_text: ‘Is there anything that I’m overcome with internally and haven’t given up, because of which I might not accurately know and see?’
title: The Mendicants of Kosambī

title: The Mendicants of Kosambī

segment_text: If a mendicant is overcome with ill will,

segment_text: dullness and drowsiness,
title: The Mendicants of Kosambī

title: The Mendicants of Kosambī

segment_text: doubt,

title: The Mendicants of Kosambī

segment_text: pursuing speculation about the next world,
title: The Mendicants of Kosambī

segment_text: or arguing, quarreling, and disputing, continually wounding others with barbed words, it’s their mind that’s overcome.
title: The Mendicants of Kosambī

segment_text: They understand,
title: The Mendicants of Kosambī

segment_text: ‘There is nothing that I’m overcome with internally and haven’t given up, because of which I might not accurately know and see.
title: The Mendicants of Kosambī

segment_text: My mind is properly disposed for awakening to the truths.’
title: The Mendicants of Kosambī

segment_text: This is the first knowledge they have achieved that is noble and transcendent, and is distinct from that of ordinary people.
title: The Mendicants of Kosambī

segment_text: Furthermore, a noble disciple reflects,
title: The Mendicants of Kosambī

segment_text: ‘When I develop, cultivate, and make much of this view, do I personally gain serenity and quenching?’
title: The Mendicants of Kosambī

title: The Mendicants of Kosambī

segment_text: ‘When I develop, cultivate, and make much of this view, I personally gain serenity and quenching.’

title: On the Invitation of Divinity

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
title: On the Invitation of Divinity

segment_text: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,
title: On the Invitation of Divinity

segment_text: “Mendicants!”
title: On the Invitation of Divinity

segment_text: “Venerable sir,” they replied.
title: On the Invitation of Divinity

segment_text: The Buddha said this:
title: On the Invitation of Divinity

segment_text: “This one time, mendicants, I was staying near Ukkaṭṭhā, in the Subhaga Forest at the root of a magnificent sal tree.
title: On the Invitation of Divinity

segment_text: Now at that time Baka the Divinity had the following harmful misconception:
title: On the Invitation of Divinity

segment_text: ‘This is permanent, this is everlasting, this is eternal, this is whole, this is not liable to pass away. For this is where there’s no being born, growing old, dying, passing away, or being reborn. And there’s no other escape beyond this.’
title: On the Invitation of Divinity

segment_text: Then I knew what Baka the Divinity was thinking.
title: On the Invitation of Divinity

segment_text: As easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, I vanished from the Subhaga Forest and reappeared in that realm of divinity.
title: On the Invitation of Divinity

segment_text: Then Kakusandha the Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha, addressed the mendicants:
title: The Condemnation of Māra

segment_text: in the hope of upsetting your minds so that he can find a vulnerability.
title: The Condemnation of Māra

segment_text: Come, all you mendicants, meditate observing the ugliness of the body, perceiving the repulsiveness of food, perceiving dissatisfaction with the whole world, and observing the impermanence of all conditions.’
title: The Condemnation of Māra

segment_text: When those mendicants were instructed and advised by the Buddha Kakusandha in this way, they went to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut, where they meditated observing the ugliness of the body, perceiving the repulsiveness of food, perceiving dissatisfaction with the whole world, and observing the impermanence of all conditions.
title: The Condemnation of Māra

segment_text: Then the Buddha Kakusandha robed up in the morning and, taking this bowl and robe, entered the village for alms with Venerable Vidhura as his second monk.

segment_text: Then the Buddha Kakusandha turned to gaze back, the way that elephants do, saying,

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Campā on the banks of the Gaggarā Lotus Pond together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: Then Pessa the elephant driver’s son and Kandaraka the wanderer went to see the Buddha. When they had approached, Pessa bowed and sat down to one side.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: But the wanderer Kandaraka exchanged greetings with the Buddha and stood to one side.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: He looked around the mendicant Saṅgha, who were so very silent, and said to the Buddha:
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: “It’s incredible, worthy Gotama, it’s amazing!
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: How the mendicant Saṅgha has been led to practice properly by the worthy Gotama!
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: All the perfected ones, the fully awakened Buddhas in the past or the future who lead the mendicant Saṅgha to practice properly will at best do so
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: like the worthy Gotama does in the present.”
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: “That’s so true, Kandaraka! That’s so true!
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: All the perfected ones, the fully awakened Buddhas in the past or the future who lead the mendicant Saṅgha to practice properly will at best do so
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: like I do in the present.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: For in this mendicant Saṅgha there are perfected mendicants, who have ended the defilements, completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their own goal, utterly ended the fetter of continued existence, and are rightly freed through enlightenment.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: And in this mendicant Saṅgha there are trainee mendicants who are consistently ethical, living consistently, alert, living alertly.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: They meditate with their minds firmly established in the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: What four?
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: It’s when a mendicant meditates by observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: They meditate observing an aspect of the mind—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: They meditate observing an aspect of principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.”
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: When he had spoken, Pessa said to the Buddha:
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: “It’s incredible, sir, it’s amazing!
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: How well described by the Buddha are the four kinds of mindfulness meditation! They are in order to purify sentient beings, to get past sorrow and crying, to make an end of pain and sadness, to discover the system, and to realize extinguishment.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: For we white-clothed laypeople also from time to time meditate with our minds well established in the four kinds of mindfulness meditation.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: We meditate observing an aspect of the body …
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: feelings …
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: mind …
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: principles—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: It’s incredible, sir, it’s amazing!
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: How the Buddha knows what’s best for sentient beings, even though humans continue to be so shady, rotten, and tricky.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: For human beings are shady, sir,
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: while beasts are obvious.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: For I can drive an elephant in training,
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: and while going back and forth in Campā it’ll try all the tricks, bluffs, ruses, and feints that it can.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: But my bondservants, servants, and workers behave one way by body, another by speech, and their minds another.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: It’s incredible, sir, it’s amazing!
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: How the Buddha knows what’s best for sentient beings, even though humans continue to be so shady, rotten, and tricky.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: For human beings are shady, sir,
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: while beasts are obvious.”
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: “That’s so true, Pessa! That’s so true!
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: For human beings are shady,
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: while beasts are obvious.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: Pessa, these four people are found in the world.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: What four?
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: One person mortifies themselves, committed to the practice of mortifying themselves.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: One person mortifies others, committed to the practice of mortifying others.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: One person mortifies themselves and others, committed to the practice of mortifying themselves and others.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: One person doesn’t mortify either themselves or others, committed to the practice of not mortifying themselves or others.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: They live without wishes in this very life, quenched, cooled, experiencing bliss, with self become divine.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: Which one of these four people do you like the sound of?”
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: “Sir, I don’t like the sound of the first three people.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: I only like the sound of the last person, who doesn’t mortify either themselves or others.”
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: “But why don’t you like the sound of those three people?”
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: “Sir, the person who mortifies themselves does so even though they want to be happy and recoil from pain.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: That’s why I don’t like the sound of that person.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: The person who mortifies others does so even though others want to be happy and recoil from pain.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: That’s why I don’t like the sound of that person.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: The person who mortifies themselves and others does so even though both themselves and others want to be happy and recoil from pain.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: That’s why I don’t like the sound of that person.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: The person who doesn’t mortify either themselves or others—living without wishes, quenched, cooled, experiencing bliss, with self become divine—does not torment themselves or others, both of whom want to be happy and recoil from pain.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: That’s why I like the sound of that person.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: Well, now, sir, I must go.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: I have many duties, and much to do.”
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: “Please, Pessa, go at your convenience.”
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: And then Pessa the elephant driver’s son approved and agreed with what the Buddha said. He got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before leaving.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: Then, not long after he had left, the Buddha addressed the mendicants:
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: “Mendicants, Pessa the elephant driver’s son is astute.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: He has great wisdom.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: If he had sat here an hour so that I could have analyzed these four people in detail, he would have greatly benefited.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: Still, even with this much he has already greatly benefited.”
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: “Now is the time, Blessed One! Now is the time, Holy One!
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: May the Buddha analyze these four people in detail. The mendicants will listen and remember it.”
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: “Well then, mendicants, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: “Yes, sir,” they replied.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: The Buddha said this:
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: “And what person mortifies themselves, committed to the practice of mortifying themselves? It’s when a person goes naked, ignoring conventions. They lick their hands, and don’t come or wait when called. They don’t consent to food brought to them, or food prepared for them, or an invitation for a meal.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: They don’t receive anything from a pot or bowl; or from someone who keeps sheep, or who has a weapon or a shovel in their home; or where a couple is eating; or where there is a woman who is pregnant, breastfeeding, or who lives with a man; or where there’s a dog waiting or flies buzzing. They accept no fish or meat or beer or wine, and drink no fermented gruel.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: They go to just one house for alms, taking just one mouthful, or two houses and two mouthfuls, up to seven houses and seven mouthfuls.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: They feed on one saucer a day, two saucers a day, up to seven saucers a day.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: They eat once a day, once every second day, up to once a week, and so on, even up to once a fortnight. They live committed to the practice of eating food at set intervals.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: They eat herbs, millet, wild rice, poor rice, water lettuce, rice bran, scum from boiling rice, sesame flour, grass, or cow dung. They survive on forest roots and fruits, or eating fallen fruit.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: They wear robes of sunn hemp, mixed hemp, corpse-wrapping cloth, rags, lodh tree bark, antelope hide (whole or in strips), kusa grass, bark, wood-chips, human hair, horse-tail hair, or owls’ wings.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: They tear out their hair and beard, committed to this practice.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: They constantly stand, refusing seats.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: They squat, committed to the endeavor of squatting.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: They lie on a mat of thorns, making a mat of thorns their bed.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: They’re devoted to ritual bathing three times a day, including the evening.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: And so they live committed to practicing these various ways of mortifying and tormenting the body.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: This is called a person who mortifies themselves, being committed to the practice of mortifying themselves.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: And what person mortifies others, committed to the practice of mortifying others?
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: It’s when a person is a slaughterer of sheep, pigs, or poultry, a hunter or trapper, a fisher, a bandit, an executioner, a butcher, a jailer, or someone with some other kind of cruel livelihood.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: This is called a person who mortifies others, being committed to the practice of mortifying others.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: And what person mortifies themselves and others, being committed to the practice of mortifying themselves and others?
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: It’s when a person is an anointed aristocratic king or a well-to-do brahmin.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: He has a new ceremonial hall built to the east of the citadel. He shaves off his hair and beard, dresses in a rough antelope hide, and smears his body with ghee and oil. Scratching his back with antlers, he enters the hall with his chief queen and the brahmin high priest.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: There he lies on the bare ground strewn with grass.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: The king feeds on the milk from one teat of a cow that has a calf of the same color. The chief queen feeds on the milk from the second teat. The brahmin high priest feeds on the milk from the third teat. The milk from the fourth teat is served to the sacred flame. The calf feeds on the remainder.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: He says:
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: ‘Slaughter this many bulls, bullocks, heifers, goats, rams, and horses for the sacrifice! Fell this many trees and reap this much grass for the sacrificial equipment!’
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: His bondservants, servants, and workers do their jobs under threat of punishment and danger, weeping with tearful faces.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: This is called a person who mortifies themselves and others, being committed to the practice of mortifying themselves and others.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: And what person doesn’t mortify either themselves or others, but lives without wishes, quenched, cooled, experiencing bliss, with self become divine?
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: It’s when a Realized One arises in the world, perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: He has realized with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras, and divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: He proclaims a teaching that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: A householder hears that teaching, or a householder’s child, or someone reborn in a good family.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: They gain faith in the Realized One
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: and reflect:
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: ‘Life at home is cramped and dirty, life gone forth is wide open.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: It’s not easy for someone living at home to lead the spiritual life utterly full and pure, like a polished shell.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: Why don’t I shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness?’
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: After some time they give up a large or small fortune, and a large or small family circle. They shave off hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: Once they’ve gone forth, they take up the training and livelihood of the mendicants. They give up killing living creatures, renouncing the rod and the sword. They’re scrupulous and kind, living full of sympathy for all living beings.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: They give up stealing. They take only what’s given, and expect only what’s given. They keep themselves clean by not thieving.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: They give up unchastity. They are chaste, set apart, avoiding the vulgar act of sex.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: They give up lying. They speak the truth and stick to the truth. They’re honest and dependable, and don’t trick the world with their words.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: They give up divisive speech. They don’t repeat in one place what they heard in another so as to divide people against each other. Instead, they reconcile those who are divided, supporting unity, delighting in harmony, loving harmony, speaking words that promote harmony.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: They give up harsh speech. They speak in a way that’s mellow, pleasing to the ear, lovely, going to the heart, polite, likable and agreeable to the people.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: They give up talking nonsense. Their words are timely, true, and meaningful, in line with the teaching and training. They say things at the right time which are valuable, reasonable, succinct, and beneficial.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: They refrain from injuring plants and seeds.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: They eat in one part of the day, abstaining from eating at night and food at the wrong time.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: They refrain from seeing shows of dancing, singing, and music .
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: They refrain from beautifying and adorning themselves with garlands, fragrance, and makeup.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: They refrain from high and luxurious beds.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: They refrain from receiving gold and currency,
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: raw grains,
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: raw meat,
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: women and girls,
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: male and female bondservants,
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: goats and sheep,
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: chickens and pigs,
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: elephants, cows, horses, and mares,
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: and fields and land.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: They refrain from running errands and messages;
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: buying and selling;
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: falsifying weights, metals, or measures;
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: bribery, fraud, cheating, and duplicity;
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: mutilation, murder, abduction, banditry, plunder, and violence.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: They’re content with robes to look after the body and almsfood to look after the belly. Wherever they go, they set out taking only these things.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: They’re like a bird: wherever it flies, wings are its only burden.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: In the same way, a mendicant is content with robes to look after the body and almsfood to look after the belly. Wherever they go, they set out taking only these things.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: When they have this entire spectrum of noble ethics, they experience a blameless happiness inside themselves.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: When they see a sight with their eyes, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: If the faculty of sight were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of sight, and achieving its restraint.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: When they hear a sound with their ears …
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: When they smell an odor with their nose …
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: When they taste a flavor with their tongue …
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: When they feel a touch with their body …
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: When they know an idea with their mind, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: If the faculty of mind were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of mind, and achieving its restraint.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: When they have this noble sense restraint, they experience an unsullied bliss inside themselves.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: They act with situational awareness when going out and coming back; when looking ahead and aside; when bending and extending the limbs; when bearing the outer robe, bowl and robes; when eating, drinking, chewing, and tasting; when urinating and defecating; when walking, standing, sitting, sleeping, waking, speaking, and keeping silent.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: When they have this entire spectrum of noble ethics, this noble contentment, this noble sense restraint, and this noble mindfulness and situational awareness,
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: they frequent a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: After the meal, they return from almsround, sit down cross-legged, set their body straight, and establish mindfulness in their presence.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: Giving up covetousness for the world, they meditate with a heart rid of covetousness, cleansing the mind of covetousness.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: Giving up ill will, they meditate with a mind rid of ill will, full of sympathy for all living beings, cleansing the mind of ill will and malevolence.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: Giving up dullness and drowsiness, they meditate with a mind rid of dullness and drowsiness, perceiving light, mindful and aware, cleansing the mind of dullness and drowsiness.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: Giving up restlessness and remorse, they meditate without restlessness, their mind peaceful inside, cleansing the mind of restlessness and remorse.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: Giving up doubt, they meditate having gone beyond doubt, not undecided about skillful qualities, cleansing the mind of doubt.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: They give up these five hindrances, corruptions of the heart that weaken wisdom.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: Then, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, they enter and remain in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, they enter and remain in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: And with the fading away of rapture, they enter and remain in the third absorption, where they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: Giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, they enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward recollection of past lives.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: They recollect many kinds of past lives, that is, one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. They remember: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so they recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward knowledge of the death and rebirth of sentient beings.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds: ‘These dear beings did bad things by way of body, speech, and mind. They denounced the noble ones; they had wrong view; and they chose to act out of that wrong view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. These dear beings, however, did good things by way of body, speech, and mind. They never denounced the noble ones; they had right view; and they chose to act out of that right view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.’ And so, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: They truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: They truly understand: ‘These are defilements’ … ‘This is the origin of defilements’ … ‘This is the cessation of defilements’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of defilements’.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: Knowing and seeing like this, their mind is freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: This is called a person who neither mortifies themselves or others, being committed to the practice of not mortifying themselves or others.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: They live without wishes in this very life, quenched, cooled, experiencing bliss, with self become divine.”
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: That is what the Buddha said.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
title: With Kandaraka

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: The Wealthy Citizen

segment_text: At one time Venerable Ānanda was staying near Vesālī in the little village of Beluva.
title: The Wealthy Citizen

segment_text: Now at that time the householder Dasama, a wealthy citizen, had arrived at Pāṭaliputta on some business.
title: The Wealthy Citizen

segment_text: He went to the Chicken Monastery, approached a certain mendicant, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,
title: The Wealthy Citizen

segment_text: “Sir, where is Venerable Ānanda now staying?
title: The Wealthy Citizen

segment_text: For I want to see him.”
title: The Wealthy Citizen

segment_text: “Householder, Venerable Ānanda is staying near Vesālī in the little village of Beluva.”
title: The Wealthy Citizen

segment_text: Then the householder Dasama, having concluded his business there, went to the little village of Beluva in Vesālī to see Ānanda. He bowed, sat down to one side, and said to Ānanda:
title: The Wealthy Citizen

segment_text: “Honorable Ānanda, is there one thing that has been rightly explained by the Blessed One—who knows and sees, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha—practicing which a diligent, keen, and resolute mendicant’s mind is freed, their defilements are ended, and they arrive at the supreme sanctuary from the yoke?”
title: The Wealthy Citizen

segment_text: “There is, householder.”
title: The Wealthy Citizen

segment_text: “And what is that one thing?”
title: The Wealthy Citizen

segment_text: “Householder, it’s when a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
title: The Wealthy Citizen

segment_text: Then they reflect:
title: The Wealthy Citizen

segment_text: ‘Even this first absorption is produced by choices and intentions.’
title: The Wealthy Citizen

segment_text: They understand: ‘But whatever is produced by choices and intentions is impermanent and liable to cessation.’
title: The Wealthy Citizen

segment_text: Abiding in that they attain the ending of defilements.
title: The Wealthy Citizen

segment_text: If they don’t attain the ending of defilements, with the ending of the five lower fetters they’re reborn spontaneously, because of their passion and love for that meditation. They are extinguished there, and are not liable to return from that world.
title: The Wealthy Citizen

segment_text: This is one thing that has been rightly explained by the Blessed One—who knows and sees, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha—practicing which a diligent, keen, and resolute mendicant’s mind is freed, their defilements are ended, and they arrive at the supreme sanctuary from the yoke.
title: The Wealthy Citizen

segment_text: Furthermore, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, they enter and remain in the second absorption …
title: The Wealthy Citizen

segment_text: third absorption …
title: The Wealthy Citizen

segment_text: fourth absorption …
title: The Wealthy Citizen

segment_text: Furthermore, a mendicant meditates spreading a heart full of love to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of love to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.
title: The Wealthy Citizen

segment_text: Then they reflect:
title: The Wealthy Citizen

segment_text: ‘Even this heart’s release by love is produced by choices and intentions.’
title: The Wealthy Citizen

segment_text: They understand: ‘But whatever is produced by choices and intentions is impermanent and liable to cessation.’ …
title: The Wealthy Citizen

segment_text: Furthermore, a mendicant meditates spreading a heart full of compassion …
title: The Wealthy Citizen

segment_text: rejoicing …
title: The Wealthy Citizen

segment_text: equanimity …
title: The Wealthy Citizen

segment_text: Furthermore, householder, a mendicant, going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the ending of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite space.
title: The Wealthy Citizen

segment_text: Then they reflect:
title: The Wealthy Citizen

segment_text: ‘Even this attainment of the dimension of infinite space is produced by choices and intentions.’
title: The Wealthy Citizen

segment_text: They understand: ‘But whatever is produced by choices and intentions is impermanent and liable to cessation.’ …
title: The Wealthy Citizen

segment_text: Furthermore, a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite consciousness. …
title: The Wealthy Citizen

segment_text: Furthermore, a mendicant, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, enters and remains in the dimension of nothingness.
title: The Wealthy Citizen

segment_text: Then they reflect:
title: The Wealthy Citizen

segment_text: ‘Even this attainment of the dimension of nothingness is produced by choices and intentions.’
title: The Wealthy Citizen

segment_text: They understand: ‘But whatever is produced by choices and intentions is impermanent and liable to cessation.’
title: The Wealthy Citizen

title: The Wealthy Citizen

segment_text: If they don’t attain the ending of defilements, with the ending of the five lower fetters they’re reborn spontaneously because of their passion and love for that meditation. They are extinguished there, and are not liable to return from that world.
title: The Wealthy Citizen

segment_text: This too is one thing that has been rightly explained by the Blessed One—who knows and sees, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha—practicing which a diligent, keen, and resolute mendicant’s mind is freed, their defilements are ended, and they arrive at the supreme sanctuary from the yoke.”
title: The Wealthy Citizen

segment_text: When he said this, the householder Dasama said to Venerable Ānanda,
title: The Wealthy Citizen

segment_text: “Honorable Ānanda, suppose a person was looking for an entrance to a hidden treasure. And all at once they’d come across eleven entrances!
title: The Wealthy Citizen

segment_text: In the same way, I was searching for the door to freedom from death. And all at once I found eleven doors to freedom from death for cultivation.
title: The Wealthy Citizen

segment_text: Suppose a person had a house with eleven doors. If the house caught fire they’d be able to flee to safety through any one of those doors.
title: The Wealthy Citizen

segment_text: In the same way, I’m able to flee to safety through any one of these eleven doors to freedom from death.
title: The Wealthy Citizen

segment_text: Sir, those of other religions seek a fee for the tutor. Why shouldn’t I make an offering to Venerable Ānanda?”
title: The Wealthy Citizen

segment_text: Then the householder Dasama, having assembled the Saṅgha from Vesālī and Pāṭaliputta, served and satisfied them with his own hands with delicious fresh and cooked foods.
title: The Wealthy Citizen

segment_text: He clothed each and every mendicant in a pair of garments, with a set of three robes for Ānanda. And he had a dwelling worth five hundred built for Ānanda.
title: The Wealthy Citizen

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: A Trainee

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans, near Kapilavatthu in the Banyan Tree Monastery.
title: A Trainee

segment_text: Now at that time a new town hall had recently been constructed for the Sakyans of Kapilavatthu. It had not yet been occupied by an ascetic or brahmin or any person at all.
title: A Trainee

segment_text: Then the Sakyans of Kapilavatthu went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:
title: A Trainee

segment_text: “Sir, a new town hall has recently been constructed for the Sakyans of Kapilavatthu. It has not yet been occupied by an ascetic or brahmin or any person at all.
title: A Trainee

segment_text: May the Buddha be the first to use it, and only then will the Sakyans of Kapilavatthu use it.
title: A Trainee

segment_text: That would be for the lasting welfare and happiness of the Sakyans of Kapilavatthu.”
title: A Trainee

segment_text: The Buddha consented with silence.
title: A Trainee

segment_text: Then, knowing that the Buddha had consented, the Sakyans got up from their seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on their right. Then they went to the new town hall, where they spread carpets all over, prepared seats, set up a water jar, and placed an oil lamp. Then they went back to the Buddha,
title: A Trainee

segment_text: bowed, stood to one side,
title: A Trainee

segment_text: and told him of their preparations, saying,
title: A Trainee

segment_text: “Please, sir, come at your convenience.”
title: A Trainee

segment_text: Then the Buddha robed up and, taking his bowl and robe, went to the new town hall together with the Saṅgha of mendicants. Having washed his feet he entered the town hall and sat against the central column facing east.
title: A Trainee

segment_text: The Saṅgha of mendicants also washed their feet, entered the town hall, and sat against the west wall facing east, with the Buddha right in front of them.
title: A Trainee

segment_text: The Sakyans of Kapilavatthu also washed their feet, entered the town hall, and sat against the east wall facing west, with the Buddha right in front of them.
title: A Trainee

segment_text: The Buddha spent much of the night educating, encouraging, firing up, and inspiring the Sakyans with a Dhamma talk. Then he addressed Venerable Ānanda,
title: A Trainee

segment_text: “Ānanda, speak about the practicing trainee to the Sakyans of Kapilavatthu as you feel inspired.
title: A Trainee

segment_text: My back is sore,
title: A Trainee

segment_text: I’ll stretch it.”
title: A Trainee

segment_text: “Yes, sir,” Ānanda replied.
title: A Trainee

segment_text: And then the Buddha spread out his outer robe folded in four and laid down in the lion’s posture—on the right side, placing one foot on top of the other—mindful and aware, and focused on the time of getting up.
title: A Trainee

segment_text: Then Ānanda addressed Mahānāma the Sakyan:
title: A Trainee

segment_text: “Mahānāma, a noble disciple is accomplished in ethics, guards the sense doors, eats in moderation, and is dedicated to wakefulness. They have seven good qualities, and they get the four absorptions—blissful meditations in this life that belong to the higher mind—when they want, without trouble or difficulty.
title: A Trainee

segment_text: And how is a noble disciple accomplished in ethics?
title: A Trainee

segment_text: It’s when a noble disciple is ethical, restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and resorting for alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.
title: A Trainee

segment_text: That’s how a noble disciple is ethical.
title: A Trainee

segment_text: And how does a noble disciple guard the sense doors?
title: A Trainee

segment_text: When a noble disciple sees a sight with their eyes, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.
title: A Trainee

segment_text: If the faculty of sight were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of sight, and achieving its restraint.
title: A Trainee

segment_text: When they hear a sound with their ears …
title: A Trainee

segment_text: When they smell an odor with their nose …
title: A Trainee

segment_text: When they taste a flavor with their tongue …
title: A Trainee

segment_text: When they feel a touch with their body …
title: A Trainee

segment_text: When they know an idea with their mind, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.
title: A Trainee

segment_text: If the faculty of mind were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of mind, and achieving its restraint.
title: A Trainee

segment_text: That’s how a noble disciple guards the sense doors.
title: A Trainee

segment_text: And how does a noble disciple eat in moderation?
title: A Trainee

segment_text: It’s when a noble disciple reflects rationally on the food that they eat:
title: A Trainee

segment_text: ‘Not for fun, indulgence, adornment, or decoration, but only to sustain this body, to avoid harm, and to support spiritual practice. In this way, I shall put an end to old discomfort and not give rise to new discomfort, and I will have the means to keep going, blamelessness, and a comfortable abiding.’
title: A Trainee

segment_text: That’s how a noble disciple eats in moderation.
title: A Trainee

segment_text: And how is a noble disciple dedicated to wakefulness?
title: A Trainee

segment_text: It’s when a noble disciple practices walking and sitting meditation by day, purifying their mind from obstacles.
title: A Trainee

segment_text: In the first watch of the night, they continue to practice walking and sitting meditation.
title: A Trainee

segment_text: In the middle watch, they lie down in the lion’s posture—on the right side, placing one foot on top of the other—mindful and aware, and focused on the time of getting up.
title: A Trainee

segment_text: In the last watch, they get up and continue to practice walking and sitting meditation, purifying their mind from obstacles.
title: A Trainee

segment_text: That’s how a noble disciple is dedicated to wakefulness.
title: A Trainee

segment_text: And how does a noble disciple have seven good qualities?
title: A Trainee

segment_text: It’s when a noble disciple has faith in the Realized One’s awakening:
title: A Trainee

segment_text: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’
title: A Trainee

segment_text: They have a conscience. They’re conscientious about bad conduct by way of body, speech, and mind, and conscientious about having any bad, unskillful qualities.
title: A Trainee

segment_text: They exercise prudence. They’re prudent when it comes to bad conduct by way of body, speech, and mind, and prudent when it comes to acquiring any bad, unskillful qualities.
title: A Trainee

segment_text: They’re very learned, remembering and keeping what they’ve learned. These teachings are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased, describing a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure. They are very learned in such teachings, remembering them, rehearsing them, mentally scrutinizing them, and comprehending them theoretically.
title: A Trainee

segment_text: They live with energy roused up for giving up unskillful qualities and embracing skillful qualities. They’re strong, staunchly vigorous, not slacking off when it comes to developing skillful qualities.
title: A Trainee

segment_text: They’re mindful. They have utmost mindfulness and alertness, and can remember and recall what was said and done long ago.
title: A Trainee

segment_text: They’re wise. They have the wisdom of arising and passing away which is noble, penetrative, and leads to the complete ending of suffering.
title: A Trainee

segment_text: That’s how a noble disciple has seven good qualities.
title: A Trainee

segment_text: And how does a noble disciple get the four absorptions—blissful meditations in this life that belong to the higher mind—when they want, without trouble or difficulty?
title: A Trainee

segment_text: It’s when a noble disciple, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption …
title: A Trainee

segment_text: second absorption …
title: A Trainee

segment_text: third absorption …
title: A Trainee

segment_text: fourth absorption.
title: A Trainee

segment_text: That’s how a noble disciple gets the four absorptions—blissful meditations in this life that belong to the higher mind—when they want, without trouble or difficulty.
title: A Trainee

segment_text: When a noble disciple is accomplished in ethics, guards the sense doors, eats in moderation, and is dedicated to wakefulness; and they have seven good qualities, and they get the four absorptions—blissful meditations in this life that belong to the higher mind—when they want, without trouble or difficulty, they are called a noble disciple who is a practicing trainee. Their eggs are unspoiled, and they are capable of breaking out of their shell, becoming awakened, and achieving the supreme sanctuary from the yoke.
title: A Trainee

segment_text: Suppose there was a chicken with eight or ten or twelve eggs. And she properly sat on them to keep them warm and incubated. Even if that chicken doesn’t wish,
title: A Trainee

segment_text: ‘If only my chicks could break out of the eggshell with their claws and beak and hatch safely!’
title: A Trainee

segment_text: Still they can break out and hatch safely.
title: A Trainee

segment_text: In the same way, when a noble disciple is practicing all these things they are called a noble disciple who is a practicing trainee. Their eggs are unspoiled, and they are capable of breaking out of their shell, becoming awakened, and achieving the supreme sanctuary from the yoke.
title: A Trainee

segment_text: Relying on this supreme purity of mindfulness and equanimity, that noble disciple recollects their many kinds of past lives.
title: A Trainee

segment_text: That is: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. … And so they recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
title: A Trainee

segment_text: This is their first breaking out, like a chick from an eggshell.
title: A Trainee

segment_text: Relying on this supreme purity of mindfulness and equanimity, that noble disciple, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, sees sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. … They understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds.
title: A Trainee

segment_text: This is their second breaking out, like a chick from an eggshell.
title: A Trainee
