title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Aṅguttarāpans, near the town of theirs named Āpaṇa.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Āpaṇa for alms.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: He wandered for alms in Āpaṇa. After the meal, on his return from almsround, he went to a certain forest grove for the day’s meditation.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: Having plunged deep into it, he sat at the root of a certain tree to meditate.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: Potaliya the householder also approached that forest grove while going for a walk. He was well dressed in sarong and cloak, with parasol and sandals. Having plunged deep into it, he went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he stood to one side, and the Buddha said to him,
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: “There are seats, householder. Please sit if you wish.”
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: When he said this, Potaliya was angry and upset. Thinking, “The ascetic Gotama addresses me as ‘householder’!” he stayed silent.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: For a second time …
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: and a third time the Buddha said to him,
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: “There are seats, householder. Please sit if you wish.”
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: When he said this, Potaliya was angry and upset. Thinking, “The ascetic Gotama addresses me as ‘householder’!” he said to the Buddha,
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: “Worthy Gotama, it is neither proper nor appropriate for you to address me as ‘householder’.”
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: “Well, householder, you have the features, attributes, and signs of a householder.”
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: “Worthy Gotama, it’s because I have refused all work and cut off all business.”
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: “Householder, in what way have you refused all work and cut off all business?”
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: “Worthy Gotama, all the money, grain, gold, and silver I used to have has been handed over to my children as their inheritance. And in this matter I do not advise or reprimand them, but live with nothing more than food and clothes.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: That’s how I have refused all work and cut off all business.”
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: “The cutting off of business as you describe it is one thing, householder, but the cutting off of business in the noble one’s training is quite different.”
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: “But what, sir, is cutting off of business in the noble one’s training?
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: Sir, please teach me this.”
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: “Well then, householder, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: “Yes, sir,” said Potaliya.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: The Buddha said this:
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: “Householder, these eight things lead to the cutting off of business in the noble one’s training.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: What eight?
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: Killing living creatures should be given up, relying on not killing living creatures.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: Stealing should be given up, relying on not stealing.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: Lying should be given up, relying on speaking the truth.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: Divisive speech should be given up, relying on speech that isn’t divisive.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: Greed and lust should be given up, relying on not being greedy and lustful.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: Blaming and insulting should be given up, relying on not blaming and not insulting.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: Anger and distress should be given up, relying on not being angry and distressed.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: Arrogance should be given up, relying on not being arrogant.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: These are the eight things—stated in brief without being analyzed in detail—that lead to the cutting off of business in the noble one’s training.”
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: “Sir, please teach me these eight things in detail out of sympathy.”
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: “Well then, householder, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: “Yes, sir,” said Potaliya.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: The Buddha said this:
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: “‘Killing living creatures should be given up, relying on not killing living creatures.’ That’s what I said, but why did I say it?
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: It’s when a noble disciple reflects:
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: ‘I am practicing to give up and cut off the fetters that might cause me to kill living creatures.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: But if I were to kill living creatures, because of that I would reprimand myself; sensible people, after examination, would criticize me; and when my body breaks up, after death, I could expect to be reborn in a bad place.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: And killing living creatures is itself a fetter and a hindrance.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: The distressing and feverish defilements that might arise because of killing living creatures do not occur in someone who does not kill living creatures.’
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: ‘Killing living creatures should be given up, relying on not killing living creatures.’
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: ‘Stealing …
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: lying …
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: divisive speech …
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: greed and lust …
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: blaming and insulting …
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: anger and distress …
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: Arrogance should be given up, relying on not being arrogant.’ That’s what I said, but why did I say it?
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: It’s when a noble disciple reflects:
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: ‘I am practicing to give up and cut off the fetters that might cause me to be arrogant.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: But if I were to be arrogant, because of that I would reprimand myself; sensible people, after examination, would criticize me; and when my body breaks up, after death, I could expect to be reborn in a bad place.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: And arrogance is itself a fetter and a hindrance.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: The distressing and feverish defilements that might arise because of arrogance do not occur in someone who is not arrogant.’
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: ‘Arrogance should be given up by not being arrogant.’
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: That’s what I said, and this is why I said it.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: These are the eight things—stated in brief and analyzed in detail—that lead to the cutting off of business in the noble one’s training.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: But just this much does not constitute the cutting off of business in each and every respect in the noble one’s training.”
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: “But, sir, how is there the cutting off of business in each and every respect in the noble one’s training?
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: Sir, please teach me this.”
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: “Well then, householder, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: “Yes, sir,” said Potaliya.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: The Buddha said this:
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: “Householder, suppose a dog weak with hunger was hanging around a butcher’s shop.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: A deft butcher or their apprentice would toss them a skeleton scraped clean of flesh and smeared in blood.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: What do you think, householder?
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: Gnawing on such a fleshless skeleton, would that dog still get rid of its hunger?”
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: “No, sir.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: Why not?
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: Because that skeleton is scraped clean of flesh and smeared in blood.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: That dog will eventually get weary and frustrated.”
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: “In the same way, a noble disciple reflects:
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: ‘With the simile of a skeleton the Buddha said that sensual pleasures give little gratification and much suffering and distress, and they are all the more full of drawbacks.’
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: Having truly seen this with right understanding, they reject equanimity based on diversity and develop only the equanimity based on unity, where all kinds of grasping to the worldly pleasures of the flesh cease without anything left over.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: Suppose a vulture or a crow or a hawk was to grab a scrap of meat and fly away.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: Other vultures, crows, and hawks would keep chasing it, pecking and clawing.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: What do you think, householder?
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: If that vulture, crow, or hawk doesn’t quickly let go of that scrap of meat, wouldn’t that result in death or deadly suffering for them?”
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: “Yes, sir.” …
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: “Suppose a person carrying a blazing grass torch was to walk against the wind.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: What do you think, householder?
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: If that person doesn’t quickly let go of that blazing grass torch, wouldn’t they burn their hands or arm or other major or minor limb, resulting in death or deadly suffering for them?”
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: “Yes, sir.” …
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: “Suppose there was a pit of glowing coals deeper than a man’s height, full of glowing coals that neither flamed nor smoked.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: Then a person would come along who wants to live and doesn’t want to die, who wants to be happy and recoils from pain.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: Two strong men would grab them by the arms and drag them towards the pit of glowing coals.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: What do you think, householder?
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: Wouldn’t that person writhe and struggle to and fro?”
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: “Yes, sir.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: Why is that?
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: For that person knows: ‘If I fall in that pit of glowing coals, that’d result in my death or deadly pain.’” …
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: “Suppose a person was to see delightful parks, woods, meadows, and lotus ponds in a dream.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: But when they woke they couldn’t see them at all. …
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: Suppose a man had borrowed some goods—a gentleman’s carriage and fine jeweled earrings—
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: and preceded and surrounded by these he proceeded through the middle of Āpaṇa.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: When people saw him they’d say:
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: ‘This must be a wealthy man! For that’s how the wealthy enjoy their wealth.’
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: But when the owners saw him, they’d take back what was theirs.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: What do you think? Would that be enough for that man to get upset?”
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: “Yes, sir.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: Why is that?
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: Because the owners took back what was theirs.” …
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: “Suppose there was a dense forest grove not far from a town or village.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: And there was a tree laden with fruit, yet none of the fruit had fallen to the ground.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: And along came a person in need of fruit, wandering in search of fruit.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: Having plunged deep into that forest grove, they’d see that tree laden with fruit.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: They’d think:
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: ‘That tree is laden with fruit, yet none of the fruit has fallen to the ground.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: But I know how to climb a tree.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: Why don’t I climb the tree, eat as much as I like, then fill my pouch?’
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: And that’s what they’d do.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: And along would come a second person in need of fruit, wandering in search of fruit, carrying a sharp axe.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: Having plunged deep into that forest grove, they’d see that tree laden with fruit.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: They’d think:
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: ‘That tree is laden with fruit, yet none of the fruit has fallen to the ground.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: But I don’t know how to climb a tree.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: Why don’t I chop this tree down at the root, eat as much as I like, then fill my pouch?’
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: And so they’d chop the tree down at the root.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: What do you think, householder?
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: If the first person, who climbed the tree, doesn’t quickly come down, when that tree fell wouldn’t they break their hand or arm or other major or minor limb, resulting in death or deadly suffering for them?”
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: “Yes, sir.”
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: “In the same way, a noble disciple reflects:
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: ‘With the simile of the fruit tree the Buddha said that sensual pleasures give little gratification and much suffering and distress, and they are all the more full of drawbacks.’
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: Having truly seen this with right understanding, they reject equanimity based on diversity and develop only the equanimity based on unity, where all kinds of grasping to the worldly pleasures of the flesh cease without anything left over.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: Relying on this supreme purity of mindfulness and equanimity, that noble disciple recollects their many kinds of past lives.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: That is: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. … They recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: Relying on this supreme purity of mindfulness and equanimity, that noble disciple, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, sees sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. … They understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: Relying on this supreme purity of mindfulness and equanimity, that noble disciple realizes the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: That’s how there is the cutting off of business in each and every respect in the noble one’s training.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: What do you think, householder?
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: Do you regard yourself as having cut off business in a way comparable to the cutting off of business in each and every respect in the noble one’s training?”
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: “Who am I compared to one who has cut off business in each and every respect in the noble one’s training?
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: I am far from that.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: Sir, I used to think that the wanderers following other religions were thoroughbreds, and I fed them and treated them accordingly, but they were not actually thoroughbreds.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: I thought that the mendicants were not thoroughbreds, and I fed them and treated them accordingly, but they actually were thoroughbreds.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: But now I shall understand that the wanderers following other religions are not actually thoroughbreds, and I will feed them and treat them accordingly.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: And I shall understand that the mendicants actually are thoroughbreds, and I will feed them and treat them accordingly.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: The Buddha has inspired me to have love, confidence, and respect for ascetics!
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: Excellent, sir! Excellent!
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, the Buddha has made the teaching clear in many ways.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: I go for refuge to the Buddha, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
title: With Potaliya the Householder

segment_text: From this day forth, may the Buddha remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
title: With Potaliya the Householder

title: With Jīvaka

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Nāḷandā in Pāvārika’s mango grove.

segment_text: Then the Jain ascetic Dīgha Tapassī wandered for alms in Nāḷandā. After the meal, on his return from almsround, he went to Pāvārika’s mango grove. There he approached the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.

segment_text: But it is possible that Gotama could become Upāli’s disciple.”
title: With Upāli

segment_text: For a second time …
title: With Upāli

title: With Upāli

segment_text: that it was really true.
title: With Upāli

segment_text: “It is impossible …
title: With Upāli

segment_text: Well, Tapassī, I’d better go and find out for myself whether or not Upāli has become Gotama’s disciple.”
title: With Upāli

segment_text: Then the Jain Ñātika went to Upāli’s home together with a large following of Jain ascetics.
title: With Upāli

segment_text: The gatekeeper saw him coming off in the distance
title: With Upāli

segment_text: and said to him:
title: With Upāli

segment_text: “Wait, sir, do not enter.
title: With Upāli

segment_text: From now on the householder Upāli has become a disciple of the ascetic Gotama.
title: With Upāli

segment_text: His gate is closed to Jain monks and nuns, and opened for the Buddha’s monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen.
title: With Upāli

segment_text: If you require almsfood, wait here, they will bring it to you.”
title: With Upāli

segment_text: “Well then, my good gatekeeper, go to Upāli and say:
title: With Upāli

segment_text: ‘Sir, the Jain Ñātika is waiting outside the gates together with a large following of Jain ascetics.
title: With Upāli

segment_text: He wishes to see you.’”
title: With Upāli

segment_text: “Yes, sir,” replied the gatekeeper. He went to Upāli and relayed what was said.
title: With Upāli

segment_text: Upāli said to him, “Well, then, my good gatekeeper, prepare seats in the hall of the middle gate.”
title: With Upāli

segment_text: “Yes, sir,” replied the gatekeeper. He did as he was asked, then returned to Upāli and said,
title: With Upāli

segment_text: “Sir, seats have been prepared in the hall of the middle gate.
title: With Upāli

segment_text: Please go at your convenience.”
title: With Upāli

segment_text: Then Upāli went to the hall of the middle gate, where he sat on the highest and finest seat. He addressed the gatekeeper,
title: With Upāli

segment_text: “Well then, my good gatekeeper, go to the Jain Ñātika and say to him:
title: With Upāli

segment_text: ‘Sir, Upāli says
title: With Upāli

segment_text: you may enter if you wish.’”
title: With Upāli

segment_text: “Yes, sir,” replied the gatekeeper. He went to the Jain Ñātika and relayed what was said.
title: With Upāli

segment_text: Then the Jain Ñātika went to the hall of the middle gate together with a large following of Jain ascetics.
title: With Upāli

segment_text: Previously, when Upāli saw the Jain Ñātika coming, he would go out to greet him and, having wiped off the highest and finest seat with his upper robe, he would embrace him and sit him down.
title: With Upāli

segment_text: But today, having seated himself on the highest and finest seat, he said to the Jain Ñātika,
title: With Upāli

segment_text: “There are seats, sir.
title: With Upāli

segment_text: Please sit if you wish.”
title: With Upāli

segment_text: When he said this, the Jain Ñātika said to him:
title: With Upāli

segment_text: “You’re mad, householder! You’re a moron!
title: With Upāli

segment_text: You said: ‘I’ll go and refute the ascetic Gotama’s doctrine.’ But you come back caught in the vast net of his doctrine.
title: With Upāli

segment_text: Suppose a man went to deliver a pair of testicles, but came back castrated. Or they went to deliver eyes, but came back blinded.
title: With Upāli

segment_text: In the same way, you said: ‘I’ll go and refute the ascetic Gotama’s doctrine.’ But you come back caught in the vast net of his doctrine.
title: With Upāli

segment_text: You’ve been converted by the ascetic Gotama’s conversion magic!”
title: With Upāli

segment_text: “Sir, this conversion magic is excellent.
title: With Upāli

segment_text: This conversion magic is lovely!
title: With Upāli

segment_text: If my loved ones—relatives and kin—were to be converted by this, it would be for their lasting welfare and happiness.
title: With Upāli

segment_text: If all the aristocrats, brahmins, peasants, and menials were to be converted by this, it would be for their lasting welfare and happiness.
title: With Upāli

segment_text: If the whole world—with its gods, Māras, and divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—were to be converted by this, it would be for their lasting welfare and happiness.
title: With Upāli

segment_text: Well then, sir, I shall give you a simile.
title: With Upāli

segment_text: For by means of a simile some sensible people understand the meaning of what is said.
title: With Upāli

segment_text: Once upon a time there was an old brahmin, elderly and senior. His wife was a young brahmin lady who was pregnant and about to give birth.
title: With Upāli

segment_text: Then she said to the brahmin,
title: With Upāli

segment_text: ‘Go, brahmin, buy a baby monkey from the market and bring it back so it can be a playmate for my child.’
title: With Upāli

segment_text: When she said this, the brahmin said to her,
title: With Upāli

segment_text: ‘Wait, my dear, until you give birth.
title: With Upāli

segment_text: If your child is a boy, I’ll buy you a male monkey,
title: With Upāli

segment_text: but if it’s a girl, I’ll buy a female monkey.’
title: With Upāli

segment_text: For a second time,
title: With Upāli

segment_text: and a third time she said to the brahmin,
title: With Upāli

segment_text: ‘Go, brahmin, buy a baby monkey from the market and bring it back so it can be a playmate for my child.’
title: With Upāli

segment_text: Then that brahmin, because of his love for the brahmin lady, bought a male baby monkey at the market, brought it to her, and said,
title: With Upāli

segment_text: ‘I’ve bought this male baby monkey for you so it can be a playmate for your child.’
title: With Upāli

segment_text: When he said this, she said to him,
title: With Upāli

segment_text: ‘Go, brahmin, take this monkey to Rattapāṇi the dyer and say,
title: With Upāli

segment_text: “Worthy Rattapāṇi, I wish to have this monkey dyed the color of yellow greasepaint, pounded and re-pounded, and pressed on both sides.”’
title: With Upāli

segment_text: Then that brahmin, because of his love for the brahmin lady, took the monkey to Rattapāṇi the dyer and said,
title: With Upāli

segment_text: ‘Worthy Rattapāṇi, I wish to have this monkey dyed the color of yellow greasepaint, pounded and re-pounded, and pressed on both sides.’
title: With Upāli

segment_text: When he said this, Rattapāṇi said to him,
title: With Upāli

segment_text: ‘Sir, this monkey can withstand a dying, but not a pounding or a pressing.’
title: With Upāli

segment_text: In the same way, the doctrine of the foolish Jains looks fine initially—for fools, not for the astute—but can’t withstand being scrutinized or pressed.
title: With Upāli

segment_text: Then some time later that brahmin took a new pair of garments to Rattapāṇi the dyer and said,
title: With Upāli

segment_text: ‘Worthy Rattapāṇi, I wish to have this new pair of garments dyed the color of yellow greasepaint, pounded and re-pounded, and pressed on both sides.’
title: With Upāli

segment_text: When he said this, Rattapāṇi said to him,
title: With Upāli

segment_text: ‘Sir, this pair of garments can withstand a dying, a pounding, and a pressing.’
title: With Upāli

segment_text: In the same way, the doctrine of the Buddha looks fine initially—for the astute, not for fools—and it can withstand being scrutinized and pressed.”
title: With Upāli

segment_text: “Householder, the king and his retinue know you as
title: With Upāli

segment_text: a disciple of the Jain Ñātika.
title: With Upāli

segment_text: Whose disciple should we remember you as?”
title: With Upāli

segment_text: When he had spoken, the householder Upāli got up from his seat, arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms in the direction of the Buddha, and said to the Jain Ñātika,
title: With Upāli

segment_text: “Well then, sir, hear whose disciple I am:
title: With Upāli

segment_text: The attentive one, free of delusion,
title: With Upāli

segment_text: with hard-heartedness dissolved, victor in battle;
title: With Upāli

segment_text: he’s untroubled and very even-minded,
title: With Upāli

segment_text: with the virtue of an elder and the wisdom of a saint,
title: With Upāli

segment_text: immaculate in the midst of it all:
title: With Upāli

segment_text: he is the Buddha, and I am his disciple.
title: With Upāli

segment_text: He has no indecision, he’s content,
title: With Upāli

segment_text: joyful, he has spat out the world’s bait;
title: With Upāli

segment_text: he has completed the ascetic’s task as a man,
title: With Upāli

segment_text: a man who bears his final body;
title: With Upāli

segment_text: he’s beyond compare, he’s stainless:
title: With Upāli

segment_text: he is the Buddha, and I am his disciple.
title: With Upāli

segment_text: He’s free of doubt, he’s skillful,
title: With Upāli

segment_text: he’s a trainer, an excellent charioteer;
title: With Upāli

segment_text: supreme, with brilliant qualities,
title: With Upāli

segment_text: confident, his light shines forth;
title: With Upāli

segment_text: he has cut off conceit, he’s a hero:
title: With Upāli

segment_text: he is the Buddha, and I am his disciple.
title: With Upāli

segment_text: The boss bull, immeasurable,
title: With Upāli

segment_text: profound, sagacious;
title: With Upāli

segment_text: he is the maker of sanctuary, knowledgeable,
title: With Upāli

segment_text: firm in principle and restrained;
title: With Upāli

segment_text: he has slipped his chains and is liberated:
title: With Upāli

segment_text: he is the Buddha, and I am his disciple.
title: With Upāli

segment_text: He’s a giant, living remotely,
title: With Upāli

segment_text: he’s ended the fetters and is liberated;
title: With Upāli

segment_text: he’s skilled in debate and cleansed,
title: With Upāli

segment_text: with banner lowered, desireless;
title: With Upāli

segment_text: he’s tamed, and doesn’t proliferate:
title: With Upāli

segment_text: he is the Buddha, and I am his disciple.
title: With Upāli

segment_text: He is the seventh sage, free of deceit,
title: With Upāli

segment_text: with three knowledges, he has attained to divinity,
title: With Upāli

segment_text: he has bathed, he knows philology,
title: With Upāli

segment_text: he’s tranquil, he understands what is known;
title: With Upāli

segment_text: he is Sakka the Able, Purindada the Firstgiver:
title: With Upāli

segment_text: he is the Buddha, and I am his disciple.
title: With Upāli

segment_text: The noble one, evolved,
title: With Upāli

segment_text: he has attained the goal and explains it;
title: With Upāli

segment_text: he is mindful, discerning,
title: With Upāli

segment_text: neither leaning forward nor pulling back,
title: With Upāli

segment_text: he’s unstirred, attained to mastery:
title: With Upāli

segment_text: he is the Buddha, and I am his disciple.
title: With Upāli

segment_text: Transcendent, he practices absorption,
title: With Upāli

segment_text: no inner thoughts arising, he is pure,
title: With Upāli

segment_text: independent and fearless;
title: With Upāli

segment_text: secluded, he has reached the peak,
title: With Upāli

segment_text: crossed over, he helps others across:
title: With Upāli

segment_text: he is the Buddha, and I am his disciple.
title: With Upāli

segment_text: He’s peaceful, his wisdom is vast,
title: With Upāli

segment_text: with great wisdom, he’s free of greed;
title: With Upāli

segment_text: he is the Realized One, the Holy One,
title: With Upāli

segment_text: unrivaled, unequaled,
title: With Upāli

segment_text: assured, and subtle:
title: With Upāli

segment_text: he is the Buddha, and I am his disciple.
title: With Upāli

segment_text: He has cut off craving and is awakened,
title: With Upāli

segment_text: free of fuming, unsullied;
title: With Upāli

segment_text: a mighty spirit worthy of offerings,
title: With Upāli

segment_text: best of men, inestimable,
title: With Upāli

segment_text: grand, he has reached the peak of glory:
title: With Upāli

segment_text: he is the Buddha, and I am his disciple.”
title: With Upāli

segment_text: “But when did you compose these praises of the ascetic Gotama’s beautiful qualities, householder?”
title: With Upāli

segment_text: “Sir, suppose there was a large heap of many different flowers. A deft garland-maker or their apprentice could tie them into a colorful garland.
title: With Upāli

segment_text: In the same way, the Buddha has many beautiful qualities to praise, many hundreds of such qualities.
title: With Upāli

segment_text: Who, sir, would not praise the praiseworthy?”
title: With Upāli

segment_text: Unable to bear this honor paid to the Buddha, the Jain Ñātika spewed hot blood from his mouth there and then.
title: With Upāli

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Koliyans, where they have a town named Haliddavasana.
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: Then Puṇṇa the Koliyan, a cow votary, and the naked ascetic Seniya, a dog votary, went to see the Buddha. Puṇṇa bowed to the Buddha and sat down to one side, while Seniya exchanged greetings and polite conversation with him before sitting down to one side curled up like a dog.
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: Puṇṇa said to the Buddha,
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: “Sir, this naked ascetic Seniya the dog votary does a hard thing: he eats food placed on the ground.
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: For a long time he has undertaken that observance to behave like a dog.
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: Where will he be reborn in his next life?”
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: “Enough, Puṇṇa, let it be. Don’t ask me that.”
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: For a second time …
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: and a third time, Puṇṇa said to the Buddha,
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: “Sir, this naked ascetic Seniya does a hard thing: he eats food placed on the ground.
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: For a long time he has undertaken that observance to behave like a dog.
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: Where will he be reborn in his next life?”
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: “Clearly, Puṇṇa, I’m not getting through to you when I say:
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: ‘Enough, Puṇṇa, let it be. Don’t ask me that.’
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: Nevertheless, I will answer you.
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: Take someone who develops the dog observance fully and uninterruptedly. They develop a dog’s ethics, a dog’s mentality, and a dog’s behavior fully and uninterruptedly.
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in the company of dogs.
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: But if they have such a view: ‘By this precept or observance or fervent austerity or spiritual life, may I become one of the gods!’ This is their wrong view.
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: An individual with wrong view is reborn in one of two places, I say: hell or the animal realm.
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: So if the dog observance succeeds it leads to rebirth in the company of dogs, but if it fails it leads to hell.”
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: When he said this, Seniya cried and burst out in tears.
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: The Buddha said to Puṇṇa,
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: “This is what I didn’t get through to you when I said:
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: ‘Enough, Puṇṇa, let it be. Don’t ask me that.’”
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: Seniya said, “Sir, I’m not crying because of what the Buddha said.
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: But, sir, for a long time I have undertaken this observance to behave like a dog.
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: Sir, this Puṇṇa is a cow votary.
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: For a long time he has undertaken that observance to behave like a cow.
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: “Yes, sir,” he replied.
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: The Buddha said this:
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: “Puṇṇa, I declare these four kinds of deeds, having realized them with my own insight.
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: What four?
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: There are dark deeds with dark results;
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: bright deeds with bright results;
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: dark and bright deeds with dark and bright results; and
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: neither dark nor bright deeds with neither dark nor bright results, which lead to the ending of deeds.
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: And what are dark deeds with dark results?
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: It’s when someone makes hurtful choices by way of body, speech, and mind.
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: Having made these choices, they’re reborn in a hurtful world,
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: where hurtful contacts strike them.
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: Touched by hurtful contacts, they experience hurtful feelings that are exclusively painful—like the beings in hell.
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: This is how a being is born from a being.
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: For your deeds determine your rebirth,
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: and when you’re reborn contacts strike you.
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: This is why I say that sentient beings are heirs to their deeds.
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: These are called dark deeds with dark results.
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: And what are bright deeds with bright results?
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: It’s when someone makes pleasing choices by way of body, speech, and mind.
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: Having made these choices, they are reborn in a pleasing world,
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: where pleasing contacts strike them.
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: Touched by pleasing contacts, they experience pleasing feelings of perfect happiness—like the gods of universal beauty.
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: This is how a being is born from a being.
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: For your deeds determine your rebirth,

title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: And what are dark and bright deeds with dark and bright results?
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: It’s when someone makes both hurtful and pleasing choices by way of body, speech, and mind.
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: Having made these choices, they are reborn in a world that is both hurtful and pleasing,
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: where hurtful and pleasing contacts strike them.
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: Touched by both hurtful and pleasing contacts, they experience both hurtful and pleasing feelings that are a mixture of pleasure and pain—like humans, some gods, and some beings in the underworld.
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: This is how a being is born from a being.
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: For what you do brings about your rebirth,
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: and when you’re reborn contacts strike you.

title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: These are called neither dark nor bright deeds with neither dark nor bright results, which lead to the ending of deeds.
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: These are the four kinds of deeds that I declare, having realized them with my own insight.”

segment_text: When he had spoken, Puṇṇa the Koliyan said to the Buddha,
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: “Excellent, sir! Excellent! …
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: From this day forth, may the Buddha remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: And Seniya the naked ascetic said to the Buddha,
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: “Excellent, sir! Excellent! …
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: I go for refuge to the Buddha, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: Sir, may I receive the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence?”
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: “Seniya, if someone formerly ordained in another sect wishes to take the going forth, the ordination in this teaching and training, they must spend four months on probation. When four months have passed, if the mendicants are satisfied, they’ll give the going forth, the ordination into monkhood.
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: However, I have recognized individual differences in this matter.”
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: “Sir, if four months probation are required in such a case, I’ll spend four years on probation. When four years have passed, if the mendicants are satisfied, let them give me the going forth, the ordination into monkhood.”
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: And the naked ascetic Seniya received the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence.
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: Not long after his ordination, Venerable Seniya, living alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, soon realized the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life. He lived having achieved with his own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: He understood: “Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is nothing further for this place.”
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: And Venerable Seniya became one of the perfected.
title: The Ascetic Who Behaved Like a Dog

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: Then Prince Abhaya went up to the Jain ascetic of the Ñātika clan, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Jain Ñātika said to him,
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: “Come, prince, refute the ascetic Gotama’s doctrine.
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: Then you will get a good reputation:
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: ‘Prince Abhaya refuted the doctrine of the ascetic Gotama, so mighty and powerful!’”
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: “But sir, how am I to do this?”
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: “Here, prince, go to the ascetic Gotama and say to him:
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: ‘Sir, may the Realized One utter speech that is disliked by others?’
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: When he’s asked this, if he answers:
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: ‘He may, prince,’ say this to him,
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: ‘Then, sir, what exactly is the difference between you and an ordinary person?
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: For even an ordinary person may utter speech that is disliked by others.’
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: But if he answers,
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: ‘He may not, prince,’ say this to him:
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: ‘Then, sir, why exactly did you declare of Devadatta:
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: “Devadatta is going to a place of loss, to hell, there to remain for an eon, irredeemable”?
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: Devadatta was angry and upset with what you said.’
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: When you put this dilemma to him, the Buddha won’t be able to either spit it out or swallow it down.
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: He’ll be like a man with an iron cross stuck in his throat, unable to either spit it out or swallow it down.”
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: “Yes, sir,” replied Abhaya. He got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Jain Ñātika, keeping him on his right. Then he went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side.
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: Then he looked up at the sun and thought,
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: “It’s too late to refute the Buddha’s doctrine today.
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: I shall refute his doctrine in my own home tomorrow.” He said to the Buddha,
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: “Sir, may the Buddha please accept tomorrow’s meal from me, together with three other monks.”
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: The Buddha consented with silence.
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: Then, knowing that the Buddha had consented, Abhaya got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before leaving.
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: Then when the night had passed, the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to Abhaya’s home, and sat down on the seat spread out.
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: Then Abhaya served and satisfied the Buddha with his own hands with delicious fresh and cooked foods.
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: When the Buddha had eaten and washed his hand and bowl, Abhaya took a low seat, sat to one side,
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: and said to him,
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: “Sir, may the Realized One utter speech that is disliked by others?”
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: “This matter is not categorical, prince.”
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: “Then the Jains have lost in this, sir.”
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: “But prince, why do you say that
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: the Jains have lost in this?”
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: Then Abhaya told the Buddha all that had happened.
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: Now at that time a little baby boy was sitting in Prince Abhaya’s lap.
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: Then the Buddha said to Abhaya,
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: “What do you think, prince?
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: If—because of your negligence or his nursemaid’s negligence—your boy were to put a stick or stone in his mouth, what would you do to him?”
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: “I’d try to take it out, sir.
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: If that didn’t work, I’d cradle his head with my left hand and take it out using a hooked finger of my right hand, even if it drew blood.
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: Why is that?
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: Because I have sympathy for the boy, sir.”
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: “In the same way, prince, the Realized One does not utter speech that he knows to be untrue, false, and pointless, and which is disliked by others.
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: The Realized One does not utter speech that he knows to be true and correct, but which is harmful and disliked by others.
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: The Realized One knows the right time to speak so as to explain what he knows to be true, correct, and beneficial, but which is disliked by others.
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: The Realized One does not utter speech that he knows to be untrue, false, and pointless, but which is liked by others.
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: The Realized One does not utter speech that he knows to be true and correct, but which is harmful, even if it is liked by others.
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: The Realized One knows the right time to speak so as to explain what he knows to be true, correct, and beneficial, and which is liked by others.
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: Why is that?
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: Because the Realized One has sympathy for sentient beings.”
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: “Sir, there are clever aristocrats, brahmins, householders, or ascetics who come to see you with a question already planned.
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: Do you think beforehand that if they ask you like this, you’ll answer like that, or does the answer just strike you on the spot?”
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: “Well then, prince, I’ll ask you about this in return, and you can answer as you like.
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: What do you think, prince?
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: Are you skilled in the various parts of a chariot?”
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: “I am, sir.”
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: “What do you think, prince?
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: When they come to you and ask:
title: With Prince Abhaya

title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: Do you think beforehand that if they ask you like this, you’ll answer like that, or does the answer appear to you on the spot?”
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: “Sir, I’m well-known as a charioteer skilled in a chariot’s parts.
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: All the major and minor parts are well-known to me.
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: The answer just appears to me on the spot.”
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: “In the same way, when clever aristocrats, brahmins, householders, or ascetics come to see me with a question already planned, the answer just strikes me on the spot.
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: Why is that?
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: Because the Realized One has clearly comprehended the principle of the teachings, so that the answer just strikes him on the spot.”
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: When he had spoken, Prince Abhaya said to the Buddha,
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: “Excellent, sir! Excellent! …
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: From this day forth, may the Buddha remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
title: With Prince Abhaya

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: The Many Kinds of Feeling

title: The Many Kinds of Feeling

title: The Many Kinds of Feeling

segment_text: “Chamberlain, the Buddha has spoken of three feelings:
title: The Many Kinds of Feeling

title: The Many Kinds of Feeling

title: The Many Kinds of Feeling

title: The Many Kinds of Feeling

segment_text: He’s spoken of two feelings:
title: The Many Kinds of Feeling

title: The Many Kinds of Feeling

segment_text: The Buddha said that neutral feeling is included as a peaceful and subtle kind of pleasure.”

title: The Many Kinds of Feeling

title: The Many Kinds of Feeling

title: The Many Kinds of Feeling

segment_text: “Ānanda, the explanation by the mendicant Udāyī, which the chamberlain Pañcakaṅga didn’t agree with, was quite correct. But the explanation by Pañcakaṅga, which Udāyī didn’t agree with, was also quite correct.
title: The Many Kinds of Feeling

segment_text: In one explanation I’ve spoken of two feelings. In another explanation I’ve spoken of three feelings, or five, six, eighteen, thirty-six, or a hundred and eight feelings.
title: The Many Kinds of Feeling

segment_text: I’ve explained the teaching in all these different ways.
title: The Many Kinds of Feeling

segment_text: This being so, you can expect that those who don’t concede, approve, or agree with what has been well spoken will argue, quarrel, and fight, continually wounding each other with barbed words.
title: The Many Kinds of Feeling

segment_text: I’ve explained the teaching in all these different ways.
title: The Many Kinds of Feeling

segment_text: This being so, you can expect that those who do concede, approve, or agree with what has been well spoken will live in harmony, appreciating each other, without quarreling, blending like milk and water, and regarding each other with kindly eyes.
title: The Many Kinds of Feeling

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was wandering in the land of the Kosalans together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants when he arrived at a village of the Kosalan brahmins named Sālā.
title: Unfailing

segment_text: The brahmins and householders of Sālā heard:
title: Unfailing

segment_text: “It seems the ascetic Gotama—a Sakyan, gone forth from a Sakyan family—wandering in the land of the Kosalans has arrived at Sālā, together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants.
title: Unfailing

segment_text: He has this good reputation:
title: Unfailing

segment_text: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’
title: Unfailing

segment_text: He has realized with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras, and divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others.
title: Unfailing

segment_text: He proclaims a teaching that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
title: Unfailing

segment_text: It’s good to see such perfected ones.”
title: Unfailing

segment_text: Then the brahmins and householders of Sālā went up to the Buddha. The Buddha said to them:
title: Unfailing

title: Unfailing

segment_text: “No, sir.”

title: Unfailing

title: Advice to Rāhula at Ambalaṭṭhika

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
title: Advice to Rāhula at Ambalaṭṭhika

segment_text: Now at that time Venerable Rāhula was staying at Ambalaṭṭhikā.
title: Advice to Rāhula at Ambalaṭṭhika

segment_text: Then in the late afternoon, the Buddha came out of retreat and went to Ambalaṭṭhika to see Venerable Rāhula.
title: Advice to Rāhula at Ambalaṭṭhika

segment_text: Rāhula saw the Buddha coming off in the distance.
title: Advice to Rāhula at Ambalaṭṭhika

segment_text: He spread out a seat and placed water for washing the feet.
title: Advice to Rāhula at Ambalaṭṭhika

segment_text: The Buddha sat on the seat spread out,
title: Advice to Rāhula at Ambalaṭṭhika

segment_text: and washed his feet.
title: Advice to Rāhula at Ambalaṭṭhika

segment_text: Rāhula bowed to the Buddha and sat down to one side.
title: Advice to Rāhula at Ambalaṭṭhika

segment_text: Then the Buddha, leaving a little water in the pot, addressed Rāhula,
title: Advice to Rāhula at Ambalaṭṭhika

segment_text: “Rāhula, do you see this little bit of water left in the pot?”
title: Advice to Rāhula at Ambalaṭṭhika

segment_text: “Yes, sir.”
title: Advice to Rāhula at Ambalaṭṭhika

segment_text: “That’s how little of the ascetic’s nature is left in those who are not ashamed to tell a deliberate lie.”
title: Advice to Rāhula at Ambalaṭṭhika

segment_text: Then the Buddha, tossing away what little water was left in the pot, said to Rāhula,
title: Advice to Rāhula at Ambalaṭṭhika

segment_text: “Do you see this little bit of water that was tossed away?”
title: Advice to Rāhula at Ambalaṭṭhika

segment_text: “Yes, sir.”
title: Advice to Rāhula at Ambalaṭṭhika

segment_text: “That’s how the ascetic’s nature is tossed away in those who are not ashamed to tell a deliberate lie.”
title: Advice to Rāhula at Ambalaṭṭhika

segment_text: Then the Buddha, turning the pot upside down, said to Rāhula,
title: Advice to Rāhula at Ambalaṭṭhika

segment_text: “Do you see how this pot is turned upside down?”
title: Advice to Rāhula at Ambalaṭṭhika

segment_text: “Yes, sir.”

segment_text: Suppose there was a royal bull elephant with tusks like chariot-poles, able to draw a heavy load, pedigree and battle-hardened. In battle it uses its fore-feet and hind-feet, its fore-quarters and hind-quarters, its head, ears, tusks, and tail, but it still protects its trunk.
title: Advice to Rāhula at Ambalaṭṭhika

segment_text: So its rider thinks:
title: Advice to Rāhula at Ambalaṭṭhika

segment_text: ‘This royal bull elephant still protects its trunk.
title: Advice to Rāhula at Ambalaṭṭhika

segment_text: It has not yet given its life.’
title: Advice to Rāhula at Ambalaṭṭhika

segment_text: But when that royal bull elephant … in battle uses its fore-feet and hind-feet, its fore-quarters and hind-quarters, its head, ears, tusks, and tail, and its trunk, its rider thinks:
title: Advice to Rāhula at Ambalaṭṭhika

segment_text: ‘This royal bull elephant … in battle uses its fore-feet and hind-feet, its fore-quarters and hind-quarters, its head, ears, tusks, and tail, and its trunk.
title: Advice to Rāhula at Ambalaṭṭhika

segment_text: It has given its life.
title: Advice to Rāhula at Ambalaṭṭhika

segment_text: Now there is nothing that royal bull elephant would not do.’
title: Advice to Rāhula at Ambalaṭṭhika

segment_text: In the same way, when someone is not ashamed to tell a deliberate lie, there is no bad deed they would not do, I say.
title: Advice to Rāhula at Ambalaṭṭhika

segment_text: So you should train like this: ‘I will not tell a lie, even for a joke.’
title: Advice to Rāhula at Ambalaṭṭhika

segment_text: What do you think, Rāhula?

segment_text: What is the purpose of a mirror?”
title: Advice to Rāhula at Ambalaṭṭhika

segment_text: “It’s for checking your reflection, sir.”
title: Advice to Rāhula at Ambalaṭṭhika

segment_text: “In the same way, deeds of body, speech, and mind should be done only after repeated checking.
title: Advice to Rāhula at Ambalaṭṭhika

segment_text: When you want to act with the body, you should check on that same deed:
title: Advice to Rāhula at Ambalaṭṭhika

segment_text: ‘Does this act with the body that I want to do lead to hurting myself, hurting others, or hurting both?
title: Advice to Rāhula at Ambalaṭṭhika

segment_text: Is it unskillful, with suffering as its outcome and result?’
title: Advice to Rāhula at Ambalaṭṭhika

segment_text: If, while checking in this way, you know:
title: Advice to Rāhula at Ambalaṭṭhika

segment_text: ‘This act with the body that I want to do leads to hurting myself, hurting others, or hurting both.
title: Advice to Rāhula at Ambalaṭṭhika

segment_text: It’s unskillful, with suffering as its outcome and result.’ To the best of your ability, Rāhula, you should not do such a deed.
title: Advice to Rāhula at Ambalaṭṭhika

segment_text: But if, while checking in this way, you know:
title: Advice to Rāhula at Ambalaṭṭhika

segment_text: ‘This act with the body that I want to do doesn’t lead to hurting myself, hurting others, or hurting both.
title: Advice to Rāhula at Ambalaṭṭhika

segment_text: It’s skillful, with happiness as its outcome and result.’ Then, Rāhula, you should do such a deed.
title: Advice to Rāhula at Ambalaṭṭhika

segment_text: All the ascetics and brahmins of the past, future, and present who purify their physical, verbal, and mental actions do so after repeatedly checking.
title: Advice to Rāhula at Ambalaṭṭhika

segment_text: So Rāhula, you should train yourself like this: ‘I will purify my physical, verbal, and mental actions after repeatedly checking.’”

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: The Longer Advice to Rāhula

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
title: The Longer Advice to Rāhula

segment_text: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Sāvatthī for alms.
title: The Longer Advice to Rāhula

segment_text: And Venerable Rāhula also robed up and followed behind the Buddha.
title: The Longer Advice to Rāhula

segment_text: Then the Buddha looked back at Rāhula and said,
title: The Longer Advice to Rāhula

segment_text: “Rāhula, you should truly see any kind of form at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; solid or subtle; inferior or superior; far or near: *all* form—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’”
title: The Longer Advice to Rāhula

segment_text: “Only form, Blessed One? Only form, Holy One?”
title: The Longer Advice to Rāhula

segment_text: “Form, Rāhula, as well as feeling and perception and choices and consciousness.”
title: The Longer Advice to Rāhula

segment_text: Then Rāhula thought, “Who would go to the village for alms today after being advised directly by the Buddha?” Turning back, he sat down cross-legged at the root of a certain tree, setting his body straight, and establishing mindfulness in his presence.
title: The Longer Advice to Rāhula

segment_text: Venerable Sāriputta saw him sitting there,
title: The Longer Advice to Rāhula

segment_text: and addressed him,
title: The Longer Advice to Rāhula

segment_text: “Rāhula, develop mindfulness of breathing.
title: The Longer Advice to Rāhula

segment_text: When mindfulness of breathing is developed and cultivated it’s very fruitful and beneficial.”
title: The Longer Advice to Rāhula

segment_text: Then in the late afternoon, Rāhula came out of retreat, went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:
title: The Longer Advice to Rāhula

segment_text: “Sir, how is mindfulness of breathing developed and cultivated to be very fruitful and beneficial?”
title: The Longer Advice to Rāhula

segment_text: “Rāhula, the interior earth element is anything internal, pertaining to an individual, that’s hard, solid, and appropriated. This includes:
title: The Longer Advice to Rāhula

segment_text: head hair, body hair, nails, teeth, skin, flesh, sinews, bones, bone marrow, kidneys, heart, liver, diaphragm, spleen, lungs, intestines, mesentery, undigested food, feces; or anything else internal, pertaining to an individual, that’s hard, solid, and appropriated.
title: The Longer Advice to Rāhula

segment_text: This is called the interior earth element.
title: The Longer Advice to Rāhula

segment_text: The interior earth element and the exterior earth element are just the earth element.
title: The Longer Advice to Rāhula

segment_text: This should be truly seen with right understanding like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
title: The Longer Advice to Rāhula

segment_text: When you truly see with right understanding, you grow disillusioned with the earth element, detaching the mind from the earth element.
title: The Longer Advice to Rāhula

segment_text: Rāhula, meditate like the earth.
title: The Longer Advice to Rāhula

segment_text: For when you meditate like the earth, pleasant and unpleasant contacts will not occupy your mind.
title: The Longer Advice to Rāhula

segment_text: Suppose they were to toss both clean and unclean things on the earth, like feces, urine, spit, pus, and blood. The earth isn’t horrified, repelled, and disgusted because of this.
