segment_text: Develop mindfulness of breathing.
title: The Longer Advice to Rāhula

segment_text: When mindfulness of breathing is developed and cultivated it’s very fruitful and beneficial.
title: The Longer Advice to Rāhula

segment_text: And how is mindfulness of breathing developed and cultivated to be very fruitful and beneficial?
title: The Longer Advice to Rāhula

segment_text: It’s when a mendicant—gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut—sits down cross-legged, sets their body straight, and establishes mindfulness in their presence.
title: The Longer Advice to Rāhula

segment_text: Just mindful, they breath in. Mindful, they breath out.
title: The Longer Advice to Rāhula

segment_text: Breathing in heavily they know: ‘I’m breathing in heavily.’ Breathing out heavily they know: ‘I’m breathing out heavily.’
title: The Longer Advice to Rāhula

segment_text: When breathing in lightly they know: ‘I’m breathing in lightly.’ Breathing out lightly they know: ‘I’m breathing out lightly.’
title: The Longer Advice to Rāhula

segment_text: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in experiencing the whole body.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out experiencing the whole body.’
title: The Longer Advice to Rāhula

segment_text: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in stilling the physical process.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out stilling the physical process.’
title: The Longer Advice to Rāhula

segment_text: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in experiencing rapture.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out experiencing rapture.’
title: The Longer Advice to Rāhula

segment_text: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in experiencing bliss.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out experiencing bliss.’
title: The Longer Advice to Rāhula

segment_text: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in experiencing mental processes.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out experiencing mental processes.’
title: The Longer Advice to Rāhula

segment_text: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in stilling mental processes.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out stilling mental processes.’
title: The Longer Advice to Rāhula

segment_text: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in experiencing the mind.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out experiencing the mind.’
title: The Longer Advice to Rāhula

segment_text: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in gladdening the mind.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out gladdening the mind.’
title: The Longer Advice to Rāhula

segment_text: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in immersing the mind in samādhi.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out immersing the mind in samādhi.’
title: The Longer Advice to Rāhula

segment_text: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in freeing the mind.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out freeing the mind.’
title: The Longer Advice to Rāhula

segment_text: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in observing impermanence.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out observing impermanence.’
title: The Longer Advice to Rāhula

segment_text: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in observing fading away.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out observing fading away.’
title: The Longer Advice to Rāhula

segment_text: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in observing cessation.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out observing cessation.’
title: The Longer Advice to Rāhula

segment_text: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in observing letting go.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out observing letting go.’
title: The Longer Advice to Rāhula

segment_text: Mindfulness of breathing, when developed and cultivated in this way, is very fruitful and beneficial.
title: The Longer Advice to Rāhula

segment_text: When mindfulness of breathing is developed and cultivated in this way, even as the final breaths cease they are known, not unknown.”
title: The Longer Advice to Rāhula

segment_text: That is what the Buddha said.
title: The Longer Advice to Rāhula

segment_text: Satisfied, Venerable Rāhula approved what the Buddha said.
title: The Longer Advice to Rāhula

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: Then as Venerable Māluṅkyaputta was in private retreat this thought came to his mind:
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: “There are several convictions that the Buddha has left undeclared; he has set them aside and refused to comment on them.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: For example: the cosmos is eternal, or not eternal, or finite, or infinite; the soul and the body are the same thing, or they are different things; after death, a realized one still exists, or no longer exists, or both still exists and no longer exists, or neither still exists nor no longer exists.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: The Buddha does not explain these points to me.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: I don’t endorse that, and do not accept it.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: I’ll go to him and ask him about this.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: If he gives me a straight answer on any of these points,
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: I will lead the spiritual life under him.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: If he does not explain these points to me,
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: I shall reject the training and return to a lesser life.”
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: Then in the late afternoon, Māluṅkyaputta came out of retreat and went to the Buddha. He bowed, sat down to one side, and told the Buddha of his thoughts. He then continued:
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: “If the Buddha knows
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: that the cosmos is eternal, please tell me.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: If you know
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: that the cosmos is not eternal, tell me.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: If you don’t know
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: whether the cosmos is eternal or not, then it is straightforward to simply say:
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: ‘I neither know nor see.’
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: If you know
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: that the cosmos is finite,
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: or infinite;
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: that the soul and the body are the same thing,
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: or they are different things;
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: that after death, a realized one still exists,
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: or no longer exists,
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: or both still exists and no longer exists, or neither still exists nor no longer exists, please tell me.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: If you don’t know
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: any of these things, then it is straightforward to simply say:
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: ‘I neither know nor see.’”
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: “What, Māluṅkyaputta, did I ever say to you:
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: ‘Come, Māluṅkyaputta, lead the spiritual life under me, and I will declare these things to you’?”
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: “No, sir.”
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: “Or did you ever say to me:
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: ‘Sir, I will lead the spiritual life under the Buddha, and the Buddha will declare these things to me’?”
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: “No, sir.”
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: “So it seems that I did not say to you:
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: ‘Come, Māluṅkyaputta, lead the spiritual life under me, and I will declare these things to you.’
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: And you never said to me:
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: ‘Sir, I will lead the spiritual life under the Buddha, and the Buddha will declare these things to me.’
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: In that case, you futile man, who are you and what are you rejecting?
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: Suppose someone were to say this:
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: ‘I will not lead the spiritual life under the Buddha until the Buddha declares to me
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: that the cosmos is eternal, or that the cosmos is not eternal …
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: or that after death a realized one neither still exists nor no longer exists.’
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: That would still remain undeclared by the Realized One, and meanwhile that person would die.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: Suppose a man was struck by an arrow thickly smeared with poison.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: His friends and colleagues, relatives and kin would get a surgeon to treat him.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: But the man would say:
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: ‘I won’t extract this arrow as long as I don’t know whether the man who wounded me was an aristocrat, a brahmin, a peasant, or a menial.’
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: He’d say:
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: ‘I won’t extract this arrow as long as I don’t know the following things about the man who wounded me: his name and clan;
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: whether he’s tall, short, or medium;
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: whether his skin is black, brown, or tawny;
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: and what village, town, or city he comes from.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: I won’t extract this arrow as long as I don’t know whether the bow that wounded me was straight or recurved;
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: whether the bow-string is made of swallow-wort fibre, sunn hemp fibre, sinew, sanseveria fibre, or spurge fibre;
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: whether the shaft is made from a bush or a plantation tree;
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: whether the shaft was fitted with feathers from a vulture, a heron, a hawk, a peacock, or a stork;
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: whether the shaft was bound with sinews of a cow, a buffalo, a black lion, or an ape;
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: and whether the arrowhead was spiked, razor-tipped, barbed, made of iron or a calf’s tooth, or lancet-shaped.’
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: That man would still not have learned these things, and meanwhile they’d die.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: In the same way, suppose someone was to say:
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: ‘I will not lead the spiritual life under the Buddha until the Buddha declares to me
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: that the cosmos is eternal, or that the cosmos is not eternal …
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: or that after death a realized one neither still exists nor no longer exists.’
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: That would still remain undeclared by the Realized One, and meanwhile that person would die.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: It’s not true that if there were the view ‘the cosmos is eternal’ there would be the living of the spiritual life.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: It’s not true that if there were the view ‘the cosmos is not eternal’ there would be the living of the spiritual life.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: When there is the view that the cosmos is eternal or that the cosmos is not eternal, there is rebirth, there is old age, there is death, and there is sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: And it is the defeat of these things in this very life that I advocate.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: It’s not true that if there were the view ‘the cosmos is finite’ …
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: ‘the cosmos is infinite’ …
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: ‘the soul and the body are the same thing’ …
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: ‘the soul and the body are different things’ …
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: ‘a realized one still exists after death’ …
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: ‘A realized one no longer exists after death’ …
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: ‘a realized one both still exists and no longer exists after death’ …
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: ‘a realized one neither still exists nor no longer exists after death’ there would be the living of the spiritual life.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: When there are any of these views there is rebirth, there is old age, there is death, and there is sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: And it is the defeat of these things in this very life that I advocate.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: So, Māluṅkyaputta, you should remember what I have not declared as undeclared,
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: and what I have declared as declared.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: And what have I not declared?
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: I have not declared the following: ‘the cosmos is eternal,’
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: ‘the cosmos is not eternal,’
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: ‘the cosmos is finite,’
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: ‘the world is infinite,’
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: ‘the soul and the body are the same thing,’
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: ‘the soul and the body are different things,’
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: ‘a realized one still exists after death,’
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: ‘A realized one no longer exists after death,’
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: ‘a realized one both still exists and no longer exists after death,’
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: ‘a realized one neither still exists nor no longer exists after death.’
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: And why haven’t I declared these things?
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: Because they aren’t beneficial or relevant to the fundamentals of the spiritual life. They don’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: That’s why I haven’t declared them.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: And what have I declared?
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: I have declared the following: ‘this is suffering,’
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: ‘this is the origin of suffering,’
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: ‘this is the cessation of suffering,’
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: ‘this is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: And why have I declared these things?
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: Because they are beneficial and relevant to the fundamentals of the spiritual life. They lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: That’s why I have declared them.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: So, Māluṅkyaputta, you should remember what I have not declared as undeclared,
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: and what I have declared as declared.”
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: That is what the Buddha said.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: Satisfied, Venerable Māluṅkyaputta approved what the Buddha said.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Māluṅkyaputta

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: The Longer Discourse With Māluṅkya

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
title: The Longer Discourse With Māluṅkya

segment_text: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,
title: The Longer Discourse With Māluṅkya

segment_text: “Mendicants!”
title: The Longer Discourse With Māluṅkya

segment_text: “Venerable sir,” they replied.

segment_text: The Buddha said this:

segment_text: “Mendicants, do you remember the five lower fetters taught by me?”

segment_text: When he said this, Venerable Māluṅkyaputta said to him,
title: The Longer Discourse With Māluṅkya

segment_text: “Sir, I remember them.”

segment_text: “But how do you remember them?”
title: The Longer Discourse With Māluṅkya

segment_text: “I remember the lower fetters taught by the Buddha as follows: substantialist view,
title: The Longer Discourse With Māluṅkya

segment_text: doubt,
title: The Longer Discourse With Māluṅkya

segment_text: misapprehension of precepts and observances,
title: The Longer Discourse With Māluṅkya

segment_text: sensual desire,
title: The Longer Discourse With Māluṅkya

segment_text: and ill will.
title: The Longer Discourse With Māluṅkya

segment_text: That’s how I remember the five lower fetters taught by the Buddha.”
title: The Longer Discourse With Māluṅkya

segment_text: “Who on earth do you remember being taught the five lower fetters in that way?

segment_text: When he said this, Venerable Ānanda said to the Buddha,
title: The Longer Discourse With Māluṅkya

segment_text: “Now is the time, Blessed One! Now is the time, Holy One!
title: The Longer Discourse With Māluṅkya

segment_text: May the Buddha teach the five lower fetters. The mendicants will listen and remember it.”
title: The Longer Discourse With Māluṅkya

segment_text: “Well then, Ānanda, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

title: The Longer Discourse With Māluṅkya

segment_text: It’s when a mendicant—due to the seclusion from attachments, the giving up of unskillful qualities, and the complete settling of physical discomforts—quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
title: With Bhaddāli

segment_text: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,
title: With Bhaddāli

segment_text: “Mendicants!”
title: With Bhaddāli

segment_text: “Venerable sir,” they replied.
title: With Bhaddāli

segment_text: The Buddha said this:
title: With Bhaddāli

segment_text: “Mendicants, I eat my food in one sitting per day.
title: With Bhaddāli

segment_text: Doing so, I find that I’m healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.
title: With Bhaddāli

segment_text: You too should eat your food in one sitting per day.
title: With Bhaddāli

segment_text: Doing so, you’ll find that you’re healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.”
title: With Bhaddāli

segment_text: When he said this, Venerable Bhaddāli said to the Buddha,
title: With Bhaddāli

segment_text: “Sir, I’m not going to try to eat my food in one sitting per day.
title: With Bhaddāli

segment_text: For when eating once a day I might feel remorse and regret.”
title: With Bhaddāli

segment_text: “Well then, Bhaddāli, eat one part of the meal in the place where you’re invited, and bring the rest back to eat.
title: With Bhaddāli

segment_text: Eating this way, too, you will sustain yourself.”
title: With Bhaddāli

segment_text: “Sir, I’m not going to try to eat that way, either.
title: With Bhaddāli

segment_text: For when eating that way I might also feel remorse and regret.”
title: With Bhaddāli

segment_text: Then, as this rule was being laid down by the Buddha and the Saṅgha was undertaking it, Bhaddāli announced he would not try to keep it.

segment_text: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. segment_text: The Buddha said this:
title: With Bhaddāli

segment_text: “Suppose a deft horse trainer were to obtain a fine thoroughbred. First of all he’d make it get used to wearing the bit.
title: With Bhaddāli

segment_text: Because it has not done this before, it still resorts to some twists, ducks, and dodges.
title: With Bhaddāli

segment_text: But with regular and gradual practice its bad behavior is extinguished.
title: With Bhaddāli

segment_text: When it has done this, the horse trainer next makes it get used to wearing the harness.
title: With Bhaddāli

segment_text: Because it has not done this before, it still resorts to some twists, ducks, and dodges.
title: With Bhaddāli

segment_text: But with regular and gradual practice its bad behavior is extinguished.
title: With Bhaddāli

segment_text: When it has done this, the horse trainer next makes it get used to walking in procession, circling, prancing, galloping, charging, the protocols and traditions of court, and in the very best speed, fleetness, and camaraderie.
title: With Bhaddāli

segment_text: Because it has not done this before, it still resorts to some twists, ducks, and dodges.
title: With Bhaddāli

segment_text: But with regular and gradual practice its bad behavior is extinguished.
title: With Bhaddāli

segment_text: When it has done this, the horse trainer next rewards it with a grooming and a rub down.
title: With Bhaddāli

segment_text: A fine royal thoroughbred with these ten factors is worthy of a king, fit to serve a king, and reckoned as a factor of kingship.
title: With Bhaddāli

segment_text: In the same way, a mendicant with ten qualities is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of veneration with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.
title: With Bhaddāli

segment_text: What ten?
title: With Bhaddāli

segment_text: It’s when a mendicant has an adept’s right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, right immersion, right knowledge, and right freedom.
title: With Bhaddāli

segment_text: A mendicant with these ten qualities is worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of veneration with joined palms, and is the supreme field of merit for the world.”
title: With Bhaddāli

segment_text: That is what the Buddha said.
title: With Bhaddāli

segment_text: Satisfied, Venerable Bhaddāli approved what the Buddha said.
title: With Bhaddāli

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Aṅguttarāpans, near the town of theirs named Āpaṇa.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Āpaṇa for alms.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: He wandered for alms in Āpaṇa. After the meal, on his return from almsround, he went to a certain forest grove for the day’s meditation.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: Having plunged deep into it, he sat at the root of a certain tree to meditate.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: Venerable Udāyī also robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Āpaṇa for alms.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: He wandered for alms in Āpaṇa. After the meal, on his return from almsround, he went to that forest grove for the day’s meditation.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: Having plunged deep into it, he sat at the root of a certain tree to meditate.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: Then as Venerable Udāyī was in private retreat this thought came to his mind:
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: “The Buddha has rid us of so many things that bring suffering and gifted us so many things that bring happiness!
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: He has rid us of so many unskillful things and gifted us so many skillful things!”
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: Then in the late afternoon, Udāyī came out of retreat and went to the Buddha. He bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: “Just now, sir, as I was in private retreat this thought came to mind:
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: ‘The Buddha has rid us of so many things that bring suffering and gifted us so many things that bring happiness!
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: He has rid us of so many unskillful things and gifted us so many skillful things!’
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: For we used to eat in the evening, the morning, and at the wrong time of day.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: But then there came a time when the Buddha addressed the mendicants, saying,
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: ‘Please, mendicants, give up that meal at the wrong time of day.’
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: At that, sir, we became sad and upset,
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: ‘But these faithful householders give us delicious fresh and cooked foods at the wrong time of day. And the Blessed One tells us to give it up! The Holy One tells us to let it go!’
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: But when we considered our love and respect for the Buddha, and our sense of conscience and prudence, we gave up that meal at the wrong time of day.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: Then we ate in the evening and the morning.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: But then there came a time when the Buddha addressed the mendicants, saying,
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: ‘Please, mendicants, give up that meal at the wrong time of night.’
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: At that, sir, we became sad and upset,
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: ‘But that’s considered the more delicious of the two meals. And the Blessed One tells us to give it up! The Holy One tells us to let it go!’
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: Once it so happened that a certain person got some soup during the day. He said,
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: ‘Come, let’s set this aside; we’ll enjoy it together this evening.’
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: Nearly all meals are prepared at night, only a few in the day.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: But when we considered our love and respect for the Buddha, and our sense of conscience and prudence, we gave up that meal at the wrong time of night.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: In the past, mendicants went wandering for alms in the dark of the night. They walked into a swamp, or fell into a sewer, or collided with a thorn bush, or collided with a sleeping cow, or encountered youths escaping a crime or on their way to commit one, or were invited by a female to commit a lewd act.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: Once it so happened that I was wandering for alms in the dark of the night.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: A woman washing a pot saw me by a flash of lightning.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: Startled, she cried out,
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: ‘Woe is me! It’s a damn goblin!’
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: When she said this, I said to her,
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: ‘Sister, I am no goblin.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: I’m a mendicant waiting for alms.’
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: ‘Die, mendicant’s father! Die, mendicant’s mother!
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: Better to have your belly sliced open with a sharp meat cleaver than to wander for alms in the dark of night for the sake of your belly!’
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: Recollecting that, I thought,
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: ‘The Buddha has rid us of so many things that bring suffering and gifted us so many things that bring happiness!
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: He has rid us of so many unskillful things and gifted us so many skillful things!’”
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: “This is exactly what happens when some silly people are told by me to give something up. They say,
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: ‘What, such a trivial, insignificant thing as this? This ascetic is much too strict!’
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: They don’t give it up, and they nurse bitterness towards me;
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: and for the mendicants who want to train, that becomes a strong, firm, stout bond, a tie that has not rotted, and a heavy yoke.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: Suppose a quail was tied with a vine, and was waiting there to be injured, caged, or killed.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: Would it be right to say that,
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: for that quail, that vine is weak, feeble, rotten, and insubstantial?”
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: “No, sir.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: For that quail, that vine is a strong, firm, stout bond, a tie that has not rotted, and a heavy yoke.”
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: “In the same way, when some silly people are told by me to give something up, they say,
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: ‘What, such a trivial, insignificant thing as this? This ascetic is much too strict!’
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: They don’t give it up, and they nurse bitterness towards me;
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: and for the mendicants who want to train, that becomes a strong, firm, stout bond, a tie that has not rotted, and a heavy yoke.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: But when some gentlemen are told by me to give something up, they say,
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: ‘What, we just have to give up such a trivial, insignificant thing as this, when the Blessed One tells us to give it up, the Holy One tells us to let it go?’
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: They give it up, and they don’t nurse bitterness towards me;
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: and when the mendicants who want to train have given that up, they live relaxed, unruffled, surviving on charity, their hearts free as a wild deer.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: For them, that bond is weak, feeble, rotten, and insubstantial.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: Suppose there was a royal bull elephant with tusks like chariot-poles, able to draw a heavy load, pedigree and battle-hardened. And it was bound with a strong harness. But just by twisting its body a little, it would break apart its bonds and go wherever it wants.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: Would it be right to say that,
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: for that bull elephant, that strong harness is a strong, firm, stout bond, a tie that has not rotted, and a heavy yoke?”
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: “No, sir.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: For that bull elephant, that strong harness is weak, feeble, rotten, and insubstantial.”
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: “In the same way, when some gentlemen are told by me to give something up, they say,
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: ‘What, we just have to give up such a trivial, insignificant thing as this, when the Blessed One tells us to give it up, the Holy One tells us to let it go?’
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: They give it up, and they don’t nurse bitterness towards me;
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: and when the mendicants who want to train have given that up, they live relaxed, unruffled, surviving on charity, their hearts free as a wild deer.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: For them, that bond is weak, feeble, rotten, and insubstantial.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: Suppose there was a poor man, with few possessions and little wealth.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: He had a single broken-down hovel open to the crows, not the best sort; a single broken-down couch, not the best sort; a single pot for storing grain, not the best sort; and a single wifey, not the best sort.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: He’d see a mendicant sitting in meditation in the cool shade, their hands and feet well washed after eating a delectable meal.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: He’d think,
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: ‘The ascetic life is so very pleasant! The ascetic life is so very healthy!
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: If only I could shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness.’
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: But he’s not able to give up his broken-down hovel, his broken-down couch, his pot for storing grain, or his wifey—none of which are the best sort—in order to go forth.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: Would it be right to say that,
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: for that man,
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: those bonds are weak, feeble, rotten, and insubstantial?”
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: “No, sir.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: For that man,
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: they are a strong, firm, stout bond, a tie that has not rotted, and a heavy yoke.”
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: “In the same way, when some silly people are told by me to give something up, they say,
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: ‘What, such a trivial, insignificant thing as this? This ascetic is much too strict!’
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: They don’t give it up, and they nurse bitterness towards me;
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: and for the mendicants who want to train, that becomes a strong, firm, stout bond, a tie that has not rotted, and a heavy yoke.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: Suppose there was a rich householder or householder’s child, affluent, and wealthy. He had a vast amount of gold ingots, grain, fields, lands, wives, and male and female bondservants.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: He’d see a mendicant sitting in meditation in the cool shade, their hands and feet well washed after eating a delectable meal.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: He’d think,
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: ‘The ascetic life is so very pleasant! The ascetic life is so very healthy!
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: If only I could shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness.’
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: And he is able to give up his vast amount of gold ingots, grain, fields, lands, wives, and male and female bondservants in order to go forth.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: Would it be right to say that,
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: for that householder, they are a strong, firm, stout bond, a tie that has not rotted, and a heavy yoke?”
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: “No, sir.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: For that householder,
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: those bonds are weak, feeble, rotten, and insubstantial.”
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: “In the same way, when some gentlemen are told by me to give something up, they say,
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: ‘What, we just have to give up such a trivial, insignificant thing as this, when the Blessed One tells us to give it up, the Holy One tells us to let it go?’
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: They give it up, and they don’t nurse bitterness towards me;
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: and when the mendicants who want to train have given that up, they live relaxed, unruffled, surviving on charity, their hearts free as a wild deer.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: For them, that bond is weak, feeble, rotten, and insubstantial.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: Udāyī, these four people are found in the world.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: What four?
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: Take a certain person practicing to give up and let go of attachments.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: As they do so, memories and thoughts connected with attachments beset them.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: They tolerate them and don’t give them up, get rid of them, eliminate them, and obliterate them.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: I call this person ‘fettered’, not ‘detached’.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: Why is that?
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: Because I understand the diversity of faculties as it applies to this person.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: Take another person practicing to give up and let go of attachments.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: As they do so, memories and thoughts connected with attachments beset them.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: They don’t tolerate them, but give them up, get rid of them, eliminate them, and obliterate them.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: I also call this person ‘fettered’, not ‘detached’.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: Why is that?
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: Because I understand the diversity of faculties as it applies to this person.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: Take another person practicing to give up and let go of attachments.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: As they do so, memories and thoughts connected with attachments beset them every so often, due to the loss of mindfulness.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: Slowly mindfulness arises,
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: then they quickly give up, get rid of, eliminate, and obliterate those thoughts.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: Suppose there was an iron cauldron that had been heated all day, and a person let two or three drops of water fall onto it.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: Slowly the drops fall, but then they quickly dry up and evaporate.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: In the same way, take a person practicing to give up and let go of attachments.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: As they do so, memories and thoughts connected with attachments beset them every so often, due to the loss of mindfulness.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: Slowly mindfulness arises,
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: but then they quickly give up, get rid of, eliminate, and obliterate those thoughts.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: I also call this person ‘fettered’, not ‘detached’.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: Why is that?
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: Because I understand the diversity of faculties as it applies to this person.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: Take another person who, understanding that attachment is the root of suffering,
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: is freed with the ending of attachments.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: I call this person ‘detached’, not ‘fettered’.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: Why is that?
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: Because I understand the diversity of faculties as it applies to this person.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: These are the four people found in the world.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: Udāyī, these are the five kinds of sensual stimulation.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: What five?
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: Sights known by the eye, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: Sounds known by the ear …
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: Smells known by the nose …
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: Tastes known by the tongue …
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: Touches known by the body, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: These are the five kinds of sensual stimulation.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: The pleasure and happiness that arise from these five kinds of sensual stimulation is called sensual pleasure—a filthy, ordinary, ignoble pleasure. Such pleasure should not be cultivated or developed, but should be feared, I say.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: Take a mendicant who, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption …
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: second absorption …
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: third absorption …
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: fourth absorption.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: This is called the pleasure of renunciation, the pleasure of seclusion, the pleasure of peace, the pleasure of awakening. Such pleasure should be cultivated and developed, and should not be feared, I say.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: Take a mendicant who, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: This belongs to the perturbable, I say.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: And what there belongs to the perturbable?
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: Whatever placing of the mind and keeping it connected has not ceased there is what belongs to the perturbable.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: Take a mendicant who, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, enters and remains in the second absorption.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: This belongs to the perturbable, I say.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: And what there belongs to the perturbable?
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: Whatever rapture and bliss has not ceased there is what belongs to the perturbable.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: Take a mendicant who, with the fading away of rapture, enters and remains in the third absorption.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: This belongs to the perturbable.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: And what there belongs to the perturbable?
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: Whatever bliss with equanimity has not ceased there is what belongs to the perturbable.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: Take a mendicant who, giving up pleasure and pain, enters and remains in the fourth absorption.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: This belongs to the imperturbable, I say.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: Take a mendicant who, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: But this is not enough, I say: give it up, go beyond it.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: And what goes beyond it?
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: Take a mendicant who, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, enters and remains in the second absorption. That goes beyond it.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: But this too is not enough, I say: give it up, go beyond it.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: And what goes beyond it?
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: Take a mendicant who, with the fading away of rapture, enters and remains in the third absorption. That goes beyond it.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: But this too is not enough, I say: give it up, go beyond it.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: And what goes beyond it?
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: Take a mendicant who, giving up pleasure and pain, enters and remains in the fourth absorption. That goes beyond it.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: But this too is not enough, I say: give it up, go beyond it.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: And what goes beyond it?
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: Take a mendicant who, going totally beyond perceptions of form, with the ending of perceptions of impingement, not focusing on perceptions of diversity, aware that ‘space is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite space. That goes beyond it.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: But this too is not enough, I say: give it up, go beyond it.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: And what goes beyond it?
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: Take a mendicant who, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite space, aware that ‘consciousness is infinite’, enters and remains in the dimension of infinite consciousness. That goes beyond it.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: But this too is not enough, I say: give it up, go beyond it.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: And what goes beyond it?
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: Take a mendicant who, going totally beyond the dimension of infinite consciousness, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, enters and remains in the dimension of nothingness. That goes beyond it.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: But this too is not enough, I say: give it up, go beyond it.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: And what goes beyond it?
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: Take a mendicant who, going totally beyond the dimension of nothingness, enters and remains in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception. That goes beyond it.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: But this too is not enough, I say: give it up, go beyond it.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: And what goes beyond it?
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: Take a mendicant who, going totally beyond the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, enters and remains in the cessation of perception and feeling. That goes beyond it.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: So, Udāyī, I even recommend giving up the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: Do you see any fetter, large or small, that I don’t recommend giving up?”
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: “No, sir.”
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: That is what the Buddha said.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: Satisfied, Venerable Udāyī approved what the Buddha said.
title: The Simile of the Quail

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: At Cātumā

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Cātumā in a myrobalan grove.
title: At Cātumā

segment_text: Now at that time five hundred mendicants headed by Sāriputta and Moggallāna arrived at Cātumā to see the Buddha.
title: At Cātumā

segment_text: And the visiting mendicants, while exchanging pleasantries with the resident mendicants, preparing their lodgings, and putting away their bowls and robes, made a dreadful racket.
title: At Cātumā

segment_text: Then the Buddha said to Venerable Ānanda,
title: At Cātumā

segment_text: “Ānanda, who’s making that dreadful racket? You’d think it was fishermen hauling in a catch!”
title: At Cātumā

segment_text: And Ānanda told him what had happened.
title: At Cātumā

segment_text: “Well then, Ānanda, in my name tell those mendicants that

title: With Gulissāni

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
title: With Gulissāni

segment_text: Now at that time a wilderness mendicant of boorish behavior named Gulissāni had come down to the midst of the Saṅgha on some business.
title: With Gulissāni

segment_text: There Venerable Sāriputta spoke to the mendicants about Gulissāni:
title: With Gulissāni

segment_text: “Reverends, a wilderness monk who has come to stay in the Saṅgha should have respect and reverence for his spiritual companions.
title: With Gulissāni

segment_text: If he doesn’t, there’ll be some who say:
title: With Gulissāni

segment_text: ‘What’s the point of this wilderness venerable’s staying alone and autonomous in the wilderness, since he has no respect and reverence for his spiritual companions?’
title: With Gulissāni

segment_text: That’s why a wilderness monk who has come to stay in the Saṅgha should have respect and reverence for his spiritual companions.
title: With Gulissāni

segment_text: A wilderness monk who has come to stay in the Saṅgha should be careful where he sits, thinking:
title: With Gulissāni

segment_text: ‘I shall sit so that I don’t intrude on the senior monks and I don’t block the junior monks from a seat.’
title: With Gulissāni

segment_text: If he doesn’t, there’ll be some who say:
title: With Gulissāni

segment_text: ‘What’s the point of this wilderness venerable’s staying alone and autonomous in the wilderness, since he’s not careful where he sits?’
title: With Gulissāni

segment_text: That’s why a wilderness monk who has come to stay in the Saṅgha should be careful where he sits.
title: With Gulissāni

segment_text: A wilderness monk who has come to stay in the Saṅgha should know even the supplementary regulations.
title: With Gulissāni

segment_text: If he doesn’t, there’ll be some who say:
title: With Gulissāni

segment_text: ‘What’s the point of this wilderness venerable’s staying alone and autonomous in the wilderness, since he doesn’t even know the supplementary regulations?’
title: With Gulissāni

segment_text: That’s why a wilderness monk who has come to stay in the Saṅgha should know even the supplementary regulations.
title: With Gulissāni

segment_text: A wilderness monk who has come to stay in the Saṅgha shouldn’t enter the village too early or return too late in the day.
title: With Gulissāni

segment_text: If he does so, there’ll be some who say:
title: With Gulissāni

segment_text: ‘What’s the point of this wilderness venerable’s staying alone and autonomous in the wilderness, since he enters the village too early or returns too late in the day?’
title: With Gulissāni

segment_text: That’s why a wilderness monk who has come to stay in the Saṅgha shouldn’t enter the village too early or return too late in the day.
title: With Gulissāni

segment_text: A wilderness monk who has come to stay in the Saṅgha shouldn’t visit families before or after the meal.
title: With Gulissāni

segment_text: If he does so, there’ll be some who say:
title: With Gulissāni

segment_text: ‘This wilderness venerable, staying alone and autonomous in the wilderness, must be used to wandering about at the wrong time, since he behaves like this when he’s come to the Saṅgha.’
title: With Gulissāni

segment_text: That’s why a wilderness monk who has come to stay in the Saṅgha shouldn’t visit families before or after the meal.
title: With Gulissāni

segment_text: A wilderness monk who has come to stay in the Saṅgha shouldn’t be restless and fickle.
title: With Gulissāni

segment_text: If he is, there’ll be some who say:

segment_text: ‘This wilderness venerable, staying alone and autonomous in the wilderness, must be used to being restless and fickle, since he behaves like this when he’s come to the Saṅgha.’
title: With Gulissāni

segment_text: That’s why a wilderness monk who has come to stay in the Saṅgha shouldn’t be restless and fickle.
title: With Gulissāni

title: With Gulissāni

title: With Gulissāni

title: With Gulissāni

title: With Gulissāni

title: With Gulissāni

segment_text: That’s why a wilderness monk who has come to stay in the Saṅgha should be easy to admonish, with good friends.
title: With Gulissāni

segment_text: A wilderness monk should guard the sense doors.
title: With Gulissāni

segment_text: If he doesn’t, there’ll be some who say:

segment_text: ‘What’s the point of this wilderness venerable’s staying alone and autonomous in the wilderness, since he doesn’t guard the sense doors?’
title: With Gulissāni

segment_text: That’s why a wilderness monk should guard the sense doors.

title: With Gulissāni

title: With Gulissāni

title: With Gulissāni

segment_text: That’s why a wilderness monk should be wise.
title: With Gulissāni

segment_text: A wilderness monk should make an effort in regards to the teaching and training.
title: With Gulissāni

segment_text: There are those who will question a wilderness monk about the teaching and training.
title: With Gulissāni

segment_text: If he is stumped, there’ll be some who say:
title: With Gulissāni

segment_text: ‘What’s the point of this wilderness venerable’s staying alone and autonomous in the wilderness, since he is stumped by a question about the teaching and training?’
title: With Gulissāni

segment_text: That’s why a wilderness monk should make an effort to learn the teaching and training.
title: With Gulissāni

segment_text: A wilderness monk should practice meditation to realize the peaceful liberations that are formless, transcending form.
title: With Gulissāni

segment_text: There are those who will question a wilderness monk about the formless liberations.
title: With Gulissāni

segment_text: If he is stumped, there’ll be some who say:
title: With Gulissāni

segment_text: ‘What’s the point of this wilderness venerable’s staying alone and autonomous in the wilderness, since he is stumped by a question about the formless liberations?’
title: With Gulissāni

segment_text: That’s why a wilderness monk should practice meditation to realize the peaceful liberations that are formless, transcending form.
title: With Gulissāni

segment_text: A wilderness monk should practice meditation to realize the superhuman state.
title: With Gulissāni

segment_text: There are those who will question a wilderness monk about the superhuman state.
title: With Gulissāni

segment_text: If he is stumped, there’ll be some who say:
title: With Gulissāni

segment_text: ‘What’s the point of this wilderness venerable’s staying alone and autonomous in the wilderness, since he doesn’t know the goal for which he went forth?’
title: With Gulissāni

segment_text: That’s why a wilderness monk should practice meditation to realize the superhuman state.”
title: With Gulissāni

segment_text: When Venerable Sāriputta said this, Venerable Mahāmoggallāna said to him,
title: With Gulissāni

segment_text: “Reverend Sāriputta, should these things be undertaken and followed only by wilderness monks, or by those who live within a village as well?”
title: With Gulissāni

segment_text: “Reverend Moggallāna, these things should be undertaken and followed by wilderness monks, and still more by those who live within a village.”
title: With Gulissāni

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was wandering in the land of the Kāsis together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants.
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants:
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: “Mendicants, I abstain from eating at night.
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: Doing so, I find that I’m healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: You too should abstain from eating at night.
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: Doing so, you’ll find that you’re healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.”
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: “Yes, sir,” they replied.
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: Then the Buddha, traveling stage by stage in the land of the Kāsis, arrived at a town of the Kāsis named Kīṭāgiri,
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: and stayed there.
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: Now at that time the mendicants who followed Assaji and Punabbasuka were residing at Kīṭāgiri.
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: Then several mendicants went up to them and said,
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: “Reverends, the Buddha abstains from eating at night, and so does the mendicant Saṅgha.
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: Doing so, they find that they’re healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: You too should abstain from eating at night.
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: Doing so, you’ll find that you’re healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.”
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: When they said this, the mendicants who followed Assaji and Punabbasuka said to them,
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: “Reverends, we eat in the evening, the morning, and at the wrong time of day.
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: Doing so, we find that we’re healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: Why should we give up what is apparent in the present to chase after what takes effect over time?
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: We shall eat in the evening, the morning, and at the wrong time of day.”
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: Since those mendicants were unable to persuade the mendicants who were followers of Assaji and Punabbasuka, they approached the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened.
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: So the Buddha addressed one of the monks,
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: “Please, monk, in my name tell the mendicants who follow Assaji and Punabbasuka that
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: the teacher summons them.”
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: “Yes, sir,” that monk replied. He went to those mendicants and said,
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: “Venerables, the teacher summons you.”
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: “Yes, reverend,” those mendicants replied. They went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side.
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: The Buddha said to them, “Is it really true, mendicants, that several mendicants went to you and said:
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: ‘Reverends, the Buddha abstains from eating at night, and so does the mendicant Saṅgha.
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: Doing so, they find that they’re healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: You too should abstain from eating at night.
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: Doing so, you’ll find that you’re healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.’
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: When they said this, did you really say to them:
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: ‘Reverends, we eat in the evening, the morning, and at the wrong time of day.
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: Doing so, we find that we’re healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: Why should we give up what is apparent in the present to chase after what takes effect over time?
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: We shall eat in the evening, the morning, and at the wrong time of day.’”
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: “Yes, sir.”
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: “Mendicants, have you ever known me to teach the Dhamma like this: no matter what this individual experiences—pleasurable, painful, or neutral—their unskillful qualities decline and their skillful qualities grow?”
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: “No, sir.”
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: “Haven’t you known me to teach the Dhamma like this: ‘When someone feels this kind of pleasant feeling, unskillful qualities grow and skillful qualities decline. But when someone feels that kind of pleasant feeling, unskillful qualities decline and skillful qualities grow. When someone feels this kind of painful feeling, unskillful qualities grow and skillful qualities decline. But when someone feels that kind of painful feeling, unskillful qualities decline and skillful qualities grow. When someone feels this kind of neutral feeling, unskillful qualities grow and skillful qualities decline. But when someone feels that kind of neutral feeling, unskillful qualities decline and skillful qualities grow’?”
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: “Yes, sir.”

segment_text: “Good, mendicants!

segment_text: Mendicants, I don’t say that all these mendicants still have work to do with diligence.
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: Nor do I say that all these mendicants have no work to do with diligence.
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: I say that mendicants don’t have work to do with diligence if they are perfected, with defilements ended, having completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their own goal, utterly ended the fetter of continued existence, and become rightly freed through enlightenment.

segment_text: Why is that?
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: They’ve done their work with diligence.

title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: Mendicants, these seven people are found in the world.

title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: Mendicants, I don’t say that enlightenment is achieved right away.
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: Rather, enlightenment is achieved by gradual training, progress, and practice.
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: And how is enlightenment achieved by gradual training, progress, and practice?
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: It’s when someone in whom faith has arisen approaches a teacher. They pay homage, actively listen, hear the teachings, remember the teachings, reflect on their meaning, and accept them after deliberation. Then enthusiasm springs up; they make an effort, weigh up, and persevere. Persevering, they directly realize the ultimate truth, and see it with penetrating wisdom.
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: Mendicants, there has not been that faith,
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: that approaching,
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: that paying homage,
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: that listening,
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: that hearing the teachings,
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: that remembering the teachings,
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: that reflecting on their meaning,
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: that acceptance after deliberation,
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: that enthusiasm,
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: that making an effort,
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: that weighing up,
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: or that striving.
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: You’re on a bad path, mendicants! You’re practicing the wrong way!
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: How far these futile men have strayed from this teaching and training!
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: There is an exposition in four statements, which a sensible person would quickly understand when it is recited.
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: I shall recite it for you, mendicants. Try to understand it.”
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: “Sir, who are we next to those who understand the teaching?”
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: “Even with a teacher who values things of the flesh, is an heir in things of the flesh, who lives caught up in things of the flesh, you wouldn’t get into such haggling:
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: ‘If we get this, we’ll do that. If we don’t get this, we won’t do it.’ What then of the Realized One, who lives utterly detached from things of the flesh?
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: For a faithful disciple who is practicing to fathom the Teacher’s instructions, this is in line with the teaching:
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: ‘The Buddha is my Teacher, I am his disciple.
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: The Buddha knows, I do not know.’
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: For a faithful disciple who is practicing to fathom the Teacher’s instructions, the Teacher’s instructions are nourishing and nutritious.
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: For a faithful disciple who is practicing to fathom the Teacher’s instructions, this is in line with the teaching:
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: ‘Gladly, let only skin, sinews, and bones remain! Let the flesh and blood waste away in my body! I will not relax my energy until I have achieved what is possible by human strength, energy, and vigor.’
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: For a faithful disciple who is practicing to fathom the Teacher’s instructions, one of two results can be expected:
title: At Kīṭāgiri

segment_text: enlightenment in this very life, or if there’s something left over, non-return.”
