title: To Vacchagotta on the Three Knowledges

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.
title: To Vacchagotta on the Three Knowledges

segment_text: Now at that time the wanderer Vacchagotta was residing in the Single Lotus Monastery of the wanderers.
title: To Vacchagotta on the Three Knowledges

segment_text: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Vesālī for alms.
title: To Vacchagotta on the Three Knowledges

segment_text: Then it occurred to him,
title: To Vacchagotta on the Three Knowledges

segment_text: “It’s too early to wander for alms in Vesālī.
title: To Vacchagotta on the Three Knowledges

segment_text: Why don’t I visit the wanderer Vacchagotta at the Single Lotus Monastery?”
title: To Vacchagotta on the Three Knowledges

segment_text: So that’s what he did.
title: To Vacchagotta on the Three Knowledges

segment_text: Vacchagotta saw the Buddha coming off in the distance,
title: To Vacchagotta on the Three Knowledges

segment_text: and said to him,
title: To Vacchagotta on the Three Knowledges

segment_text: “Let the Blessed One come, sir!
title: To Vacchagotta on the Three Knowledges

segment_text: Welcome to the Blessed One, sir!
title: To Vacchagotta on the Three Knowledges

segment_text: It’s been a long time since you took the opportunity to come here.
title: To Vacchagotta on the Three Knowledges

segment_text: Please, sir, sit down, this seat is ready.”
title: To Vacchagotta on the Three Knowledges

segment_text: The Buddha sat on the seat spread out,
title: To Vacchagotta on the Three Knowledges

segment_text: while Vacchagotta took a low seat and sat to one side.
title: To Vacchagotta on the Three Knowledges

segment_text: Then Vacchagotta said to the Buddha:
title: To Vacchagotta on the Three Knowledges

segment_text: “Sir, I have heard this:
title: To Vacchagotta on the Three Knowledges

segment_text: ‘The ascetic Gotama claims to be all-knowing and all-seeing, to know and see everything without exception, thus:
title: To Vacchagotta on the Three Knowledges

segment_text: “Knowledge and vision are constantly and continually present to me, while walking, standing, sleeping, and waking.”’
title: To Vacchagotta on the Three Knowledges

segment_text: I trust that those who say this repeat what the Buddha has said, and do not misrepresent him with an untruth? Is their explanation in line with the teaching? Are there any legitimate grounds for rebuttal and criticism?”
title: To Vacchagotta on the Three Knowledges

segment_text: “Vaccha, those who say this do not repeat what I have said. They misrepresent me with what is false and untrue.”
title: To Vacchagotta on the Three Knowledges

segment_text: “So how should we answer so as to repeat what the Buddha has said, and not misrepresent him with an untruth? How should we explain in line with his teaching, with no legitimate grounds for rebuttal and criticism?”
title: To Vacchagotta on the Three Knowledges

segment_text: “‘The ascetic Gotama has the three knowledges.’ Answering like this you would repeat what I have said, and not misrepresent me with an untruth. You would explain in line with my teaching, and there would be no legitimate grounds for rebuttal and criticism.
title: To Vacchagotta on the Three Knowledges

segment_text: For, Vaccha, whenever I want, I recollect my many kinds of past lives.
title: To Vacchagotta on the Three Knowledges

segment_text: That is: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. I remember: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so I recollect my many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
title: To Vacchagotta on the Three Knowledges

segment_text: And whenever I want, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, I see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. I understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds.
title: To Vacchagotta on the Three Knowledges

segment_text: And I have realized the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. I live having realized it with my own insight due to the ending of defilements.
title: To Vacchagotta on the Three Knowledges

segment_text: ‘The ascetic Gotama has the three knowledges.’ Answering like this you would repeat what I have said, and not misrepresent me with an untruth. You would explain in line with my teaching, and there would be no legitimate grounds for rebuttal and criticism.”
title: To Vacchagotta on the Three Knowledges

segment_text: When he said this, the wanderer Vacchagotta said to the Buddha,
title: To Vacchagotta on the Three Knowledges

segment_text: “Worthy Gotama, are there any laypeople who, without giving up the fetter of lay life, make an end of suffering when the body breaks up?”
title: To Vacchagotta on the Three Knowledges

segment_text: “No, Vaccha.”
title: To Vacchagotta on the Three Knowledges

segment_text: “But are there any laypeople who, without giving up the fetter of lay life, go to heaven when the body breaks up?”
title: To Vacchagotta on the Three Knowledges

segment_text: “There’s not just one hundred laypeople, Vaccha, or two or three or four or five hundred, but many more than that who, without giving up the fetter of lay life, go to heaven when the body breaks up.”
title: To Vacchagotta on the Three Knowledges

segment_text: “Worthy Gotama, are there any Ājīvaka ascetics who make an end of suffering when the body breaks up?”
title: To Vacchagotta on the Three Knowledges

segment_text: “No, Vaccha.”
title: To Vacchagotta on the Three Knowledges

segment_text: “But are there any Ājīvaka ascetics who go to heaven when the body breaks up?”
title: To Vacchagotta on the Three Knowledges

segment_text: “Vaccha, when I recollect the past ninety-one eons, I can’t find any Ājīvaka ascetics who have gone to heaven, except one;
title: To Vacchagotta on the Three Knowledges

segment_text: and he taught the efficacy of deeds and action.”
title: To Vacchagotta on the Three Knowledges

segment_text: “In that case, worthy Gotama, that sectarian fold is empty even of the chance to go to heaven.”
title: To Vacchagotta on the Three Knowledges

segment_text: “Yes, Vaccha, that sectarian fold is empty even of the chance to go to heaven.”
title: To Vacchagotta on the Three Knowledges

segment_text: That is what the Buddha said.
title: To Vacchagotta on the Three Knowledges

segment_text: Satisfied, the wanderer Vacchagotta approved what the Buddha said.
title: To Vacchagotta on the Three Knowledges

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: With Vacchagotta on Fire

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
title: With Vacchagotta on Fire

segment_text: Then the wanderer Vacchagotta went up to the Buddha and exchanged greetings with him.
title: With Vacchagotta on Fire

segment_text: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to the Buddha:
title: With Vacchagotta on Fire

segment_text: “Worthy Gotama, is this your view: ‘The cosmos is eternal. This is the only truth, anything else is futile’?”
title: With Vacchagotta on Fire

segment_text: “That’s not my view, Vaccha.”
title: With Vacchagotta on Fire

segment_text: “Then is this your view: ‘The cosmos is not eternal. This is the only truth, anything else is futile’?”
title: With Vacchagotta on Fire

segment_text: “That’s not my view, Vaccha.”
title: With Vacchagotta on Fire

segment_text: “Then is this your view: ‘The cosmos is finite. This is the only truth, anything else is futile’?”
title: With Vacchagotta on Fire

segment_text: “That’s not my view, Vaccha.”
title: With Vacchagotta on Fire

segment_text: “Then is this your view: ‘The cosmos is infinite. This is the only truth, anything else is futile’?”
title: With Vacchagotta on Fire

segment_text: “That’s not my view, Vaccha.”
title: With Vacchagotta on Fire

segment_text: “Then is this your view: ‘The soul and the body are the same thing. This is the only truth, anything else is futile’?”
title: With Vacchagotta on Fire

segment_text: “That’s not my view, Vaccha.”
title: With Vacchagotta on Fire

segment_text: “Then is this your view: ‘The soul and the body are different things. This is the only truth, anything else is futile’?”
title: With Vacchagotta on Fire

segment_text: “That’s not my view, Vaccha.”
title: With Vacchagotta on Fire

segment_text: “Then is this your view: ‘A realized one still exists after death. This is the only truth, anything else is futile’?”
title: With Vacchagotta on Fire

segment_text: “That’s not my view, Vaccha.”
title: With Vacchagotta on Fire

segment_text: “Then is this your view: ‘A realized one no longer exists after death. This is the only truth, anything else is futile’?”
title: With Vacchagotta on Fire

segment_text: “That’s not my view, Vaccha.”
title: With Vacchagotta on Fire

segment_text: “Then is this your view: ‘A realized one both still exists and no longer exists after death. This is the only truth, anything else is futile’?”
title: With Vacchagotta on Fire

segment_text: “That’s not my view, Vaccha.”
title: With Vacchagotta on Fire

segment_text: “Then is this your view: ‘A realized one neither still exists nor no longer exists after death. This is the only truth, anything else is futile’?”
title: With Vacchagotta on Fire

segment_text: “That’s not my view, Vaccha.”
title: With Vacchagotta on Fire

segment_text: “Worthy Gotama, when asked these ten questions, you say: ‘That’s not my view.’
title: With Vacchagotta on Fire

segment_text: Seeing what drawback do you avoid all these convictions?”
title: With Vacchagotta on Fire

segment_text: “Each of these ten convictions is the thicket of views, the desert of views, the twist of views, the dodge of views, the fetter of views. They’re beset with suffering, distress, anguish, and fever. They don’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.
title: With Vacchagotta on Fire

segment_text: Seeing this drawback I avoid all these convictions.”
title: With Vacchagotta on Fire

segment_text: “But does the worthy Gotama have any convictions at all?”
title: With Vacchagotta on Fire

segment_text: “A realized one has done away with convictions.
title: With Vacchagotta on Fire

segment_text: For a realized one has seen:
title: With Vacchagotta on Fire

segment_text: ‘Such is form, such is the origin of form, such is the ending of form.
title: With Vacchagotta on Fire

segment_text: Such is feeling, such is the origin of feeling, such is the ending of feeling.
title: With Vacchagotta on Fire

segment_text: Such is perception, such is the origin of perception, such is the ending of perception.
title: With Vacchagotta on Fire

segment_text: Such are choices, such is the origin of choices, such is the ending of choices.
title: With Vacchagotta on Fire

segment_text: Such is consciousness, such is the origin of consciousness, such is the ending of consciousness.’
title: With Vacchagotta on Fire

segment_text: That’s why a Realized One is freed with the ending, fading away, cessation, giving up, and letting go of all conceiving, all churning, and all I-making, mine-making, or underlying tendency to conceit, I say.”
title: With Vacchagotta on Fire

segment_text: “But worthy Gotama, when a mendicant’s mind is freed like this, where are they reborn?”
title: With Vacchagotta on Fire

segment_text: “‘They’re reborn’ doesn’t apply, Vaccha.”
title: With Vacchagotta on Fire

segment_text: “Well then, are they not reborn?”
title: With Vacchagotta on Fire

segment_text: “‘They’re not reborn’ doesn’t apply, Vaccha.”
title: With Vacchagotta on Fire

segment_text: “Well then, are they both reborn and not reborn?”
title: With Vacchagotta on Fire

segment_text: “‘They’re both reborn and not reborn’ doesn’t apply, Vaccha.”
title: With Vacchagotta on Fire

segment_text: “Well then, are they neither reborn nor not reborn?”
title: With Vacchagotta on Fire

segment_text: “‘They’re neither reborn nor not reborn’ doesn’t apply, Vaccha.”
title: With Vacchagotta on Fire

segment_text: “Worthy Gotama, when asked all these questions, you say: ‘It doesn’t apply.’
title: With Vacchagotta on Fire

segment_text: I fail to understand this point, worthy Gotama; I’ve fallen into confusion.
title: With Vacchagotta on Fire

segment_text: ‘With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, may I see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place—and understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds: “These dear beings did bad things by way of body, speech, and mind. They denounced the noble ones; they had wrong view; and they chose to act out of that wrong view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. These dear beings, however, did good things by way of body, speech, and mind. title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: what is that health? And what is that extinguishment?”
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: When he said this, Māgaṇḍiya stroked his own limbs with his hands, saying:
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: “This is that health, worthy Gotama, this is that extinguishment!
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: For I am now healthy and happy, and have no afflictions.”
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: “Māgaṇḍiya, suppose a person was blind from birth.
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: They couldn’t see sights that are dark or bright, or blue, yellow, red, or magenta. They couldn’t see even and uneven ground, or the stars, or the moon and sun.
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: They might hear a sighted person saying:
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: ‘White cloth is really nice, it’s attractive, stainless, and clean.’
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: They’d go in search of white cloth.
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: But someone would cheat them with a dirty, soiled garment, saying:
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: ‘Sir, here is a white cloth for you, it’s attractive, stainless, and clean.’
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: They’d take it and put it on, expressing their gladness:
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: ‘White cloth is really nice, it’s attractive, stainless, and clean.’
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: What do you think, Māgaṇḍiya?
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: Did that person blind from birth do this knowing and seeing,
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: or out of faith in the sighted person?”
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: “They did so not knowing or seeing,
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: but out of faith in the sighted person.”
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: “In the same way, the wanderers of other religions are blind and sightless. Not knowing health and not seeing extinguishment, they still recite this verse:
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: ‘Health is the ultimate blessing; extinguishment, the ultimate happiness.’
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: For this verse was recited by the perfected ones, fully awakened Buddhas of the past:
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: ‘Health is the ultimate blessing;
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: extinguishment, the ultimate happiness.
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: Of paths, the ultimate is eightfold—
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: it’s safe, and leads to freedom from death.’
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: These days it has gradually become a verse used by ordinary people.
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: But Māgaṇḍiya, this body is a disease, a boil, a dart, a misery, an affliction. Yet you say of this body:
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: ‘This is that health, this is that extinguishment!’
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: Māgaṇḍiya, you don’t have the noble vision by which you might know health and see extinguishment.”
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: “I am quite confident that the worthy Gotama
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: is capable of teaching me so that I can know health and see extinguishment.”
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: “Māgaṇḍiya, suppose a person was blind from birth.
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: They couldn’t see sights that are dark or bright, or blue, yellow, red, or magenta. They couldn’t see even and uneven ground, or the stars, or the moon and sun.
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: Their friends and colleagues, relatives and kin would get a surgeon to treat them.
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: The surgeon would make medicine for them,
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: but when they used it their eyes were not cured and they still could not see clearly.
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: What do you think, Māgaṇḍiya?
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: Wouldn’t that doctor just get weary and frustrated?”
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: “Yes, worthy Gotama.”
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: “In the same way, suppose I were to teach you the Dhamma, saying:
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: ‘This is that health, this is that extinguishment.’ But you might not know health or see extinguishment,
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: which would be wearying and troublesome for me.”
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: “I am quite confident that the worthy Gotama
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: is capable of teaching me so that I can know health and see extinguishment.”
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: “Māgaṇḍiya, suppose a person was blind from birth.
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: They couldn’t see sights that are dark or bright, or blue, yellow, red, or magenta. They couldn’t see even and uneven ground, or the stars, or the moon and sun.
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: They might hear a sighted person saying:
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: ‘White cloth is really nice, it’s attractive, stainless, and clean.’
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: They’d go in search of white cloth.
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: But someone would cheat them with a dirty, soiled garment, saying:
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: ‘Sir, here is a white cloth for you, it’s attractive, stainless, and clean.’
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: They’d take it and put it on.
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: Their friends and colleagues, relatives and kin would get a surgeon to treat them.
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: The surgeon would make medicine for them:
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: emetics, purgatives, ointment, counter-ointment, or nasal treatment.
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: And when they used it their eyes would be cured so that they could see clearly.
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: As soon as their eyes were cured they’d lose all desire for that dirty, soiled garment.
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: Then they would consider that person to be no friend, but an enemy, and might even think of murdering them:
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: ‘For such a long time I’ve been cheated, tricked, and deceived by that person with this dirty, soiled garment when he said,
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: “Sir, here is a white cloth for you, it’s attractive, stainless, and clean.”’
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: In the same way, Māgaṇḍiya, suppose I were to teach you the Dhamma, saying:
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: ‘This is that health, this is that extinguishment.’
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: You might know health and see extinguishment.
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: And as soon as your vision arises you might give up desire for the five grasping aggregates.
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: And you might even think:
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: ‘For such a long time I’ve been cheated, tricked, and deceived by this mind.
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: For what I have been grasping is only form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: My grasping is a condition for continued existence. Continued existence is a condition for rebirth. Rebirth is a condition for old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress to come to be.
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: That is how this entire mass of suffering originates.’”
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: “I am quite confident that the worthy Gotama
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: is capable of teaching me so that I can rise from this seat cured of blindness.”
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: “Well then, Māgaṇḍiya, you should associate with true persons.
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: When you associate with true persons, you will hear the true teaching.
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: When you hear the true teaching, you’ll practice in line with the teaching.
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: When you practice in line with the teaching, you’ll know and see for yourself:
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: ‘These are diseases, boils, and darts.
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: And here is where diseases, boils, and darts cease without anything left over.’
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: When my grasping ceases, continued existence ceases. When continued existence ceases, rebirth ceases. When rebirth ceases, old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress cease.
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.”
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: When he said this, Māgaṇḍiya said to him,
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: “Excellent, worthy Gotama! Excellent!
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, worthy Gotama has made the teaching clear in many ways.
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: I go for refuge to the worthy Gotama, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: May I receive the going forth, the ordination in the worthy Gotama’s presence?”
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: “Māgaṇḍiya, if someone formerly ordained in another sect wishes to take the going forth, the ordination in this teaching and training, they must spend four months on probation. When four months have passed, if the mendicants are satisfied, they’ll give the going forth, the ordination into monkhood.
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: However, I have recognized individual differences in this matter.”
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: “Sir, if four months probation are required in such a case, I’ll spend four years on probation. When four years have passed, if the mendicants are satisfied, let them give me the going forth, the ordination into monkhood.”
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: And the wanderer Māgaṇḍiya received the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence.
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: Not long after his ordination, Venerable Māgaṇḍiya, living alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, realized the supreme culmination of the spiritual path in this very life. He lived having achieved with his own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: He understood: “Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is nothing further for this place.”
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: And Venerable Māgaṇḍiya became one of the perfected.
title: With Māgaṇḍiya

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Kosambī, in Ghosita’s Monastery.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: Now at that time the wanderer Sandaka was residing at the cave of the wavy leaf fig tree together with a large assembly of around five hundred wanderers.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Ānanda came out of retreat and addressed the mendicants:
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: “Come, reverends, let’s go to the Devakata Pool to see the cave.”
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: “Yes, reverend,” they replied.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: Then Ānanda together with several mendicants went to the Devakata Pool.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: Now at that time, Sandaka and the large assembly of wanderers were sitting together making an uproar, a dreadful racket. They engaged in all kinds of low talk, such as
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: talk about kings, bandits, and chief ministers; talk about armies, threats, and wars; talk about food, drink, clothes, and beds; talk about garlands and fragrances; talk about family, vehicles, villages, towns, cities, and countries; talk about women and heroes; street talk and well talk; talk about the departed; motley talk; tales of land and sea; and talk about being reborn in this or that state of existence.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: Sandaka saw Ānanda coming off in the distance,
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: and hushed his own assembly,
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: “Be quiet, good fellows, don’t make a sound.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: The ascetic Ānanda, a disciple of the ascetic Gotama, is coming.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: He is included among the disciples of the ascetic Gotama, who is residing near Kosambī.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: Such venerables like the quiet, are educated to be quiet, and praise the quiet.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: Hopefully if he sees that our assembly is quiet he’ll see fit to approach.”
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: Then those wanderers fell silent.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the wanderer Sandaka,
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: who said to him,
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: “Come, worthy Ānanda! Welcome, worthy Ānanda!
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: It’s been a long time since you took the opportunity to come here.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: Please sit down, this seat is ready.”
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: Ānanda sat down on the seat spread out,
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: while Sandaka took a low seat and sat to one side.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: Ānanda said to Sandaka,
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: “Sandaka, what were you sitting talking about just now? What conversation was left unfinished?”
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: “Worthy Ānanda, leave aside what we were sitting talking about just now.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: It won’t be hard for you to hear about that later.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: It’d be great if the worthy Ānanda himself would give a Dhamma talk explaining his own tradition.”
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: “Well then, Sandaka, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: “Yes, worthy sir,” replied Sandaka.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: Venerable Ānanda said this:
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: “Sandaka, these things have been explained by the Blessed One, who knows and sees, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha: four ways that negate the spiritual life, and four kinds of unreliable spiritual life. A sensible person would, to the best of their ability, not practice such spiritual paths, and if they did practice them, they wouldn’t succeed in the system of the skillful teaching.”
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: “But worthy Ānanda, what are the four ways that negate the spiritual life, and the four kinds of unreliable spiritual life?”
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: “Sandaka, take a certain teacher who has this doctrine and view:
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: ‘There’s no meaning in giving, sacrifice, or offerings. There’s no fruit or result of good and bad deeds. There’s no afterlife. There’s no such thing as mother and father, or beings that are reborn spontaneously. And there’s no ascetic or brahmin who is rightly comported and rightly practiced, and who describes the afterlife after realizing it with their own insight.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: This person is made up of the four principal states. When they die, the earth in their body merges and coalesces with the substance of earth. The water in their body merges and coalesces with the substance of water. The fire in their body merges and coalesces with the substance of fire. The air in their body merges and coalesces with the substance of air. The faculties are transferred to space.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: Four men with a bier carry away the corpse.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: Their footprints show the way to the cemetery.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: The bones become bleached.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: Offerings dedicated to the gods end in ashes.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: Giving is a doctrine of morons.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: When anyone affirms a positive teaching it’s just hollow, false nonsense.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: Both the foolish and the astute are annihilated and destroyed when their body breaks up, and they don’t exist after death.’
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: A sensible person reflects on this matter in this way:
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: ‘This teacher has such a doctrine and view.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: If what that teacher says is true, both I who have not accomplished this and one who has accomplished it
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: have attained exactly the same level. Yet I’m not one who says that both of us are annihilated and destroyed when our body breaks up, and we don’t exist after death.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: But it’s superfluous for this teacher to go naked, shaven, persisting in squatting, tearing out their hair and beard. For I’m living at home with my children, using sandalwood imported from Kāsi, wearing garlands, fragrance, and makeup, and accepting gold and currency. Yet I’ll have exactly the same destiny in the next life as this teacher.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: What do I know or see that I should lead the spiritual life under this teacher?
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: This negates the spiritual life.’
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: Realizing this, they leave disappointed.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: This is the first way that negates the spiritual life.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: Furthermore, take a certain teacher who has this doctrine and view:
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: ‘The one who acts does nothing wrong when they punish, mutilate, torture, aggrieve, oppress, intimidate, or when they encourage others to do the same. Nothing bad is done when they kill, steal, break into houses, plunder wealth, steal from isolated buildings, commit highway robbery, commit adultery, and lie.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: If you were to reduce all the living creatures of this earth to one heap and mass of flesh with a razor-edged chakram, no evil comes of that, and no outcome of evil.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: If you were to go along the south bank of the Ganges killing, mutilating, and torturing, and encouraging others to do the same, no evil comes of that, and no outcome of evil.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: If you were to go along the north bank of the Ganges giving and sacrificing and encouraging others to do the same, no merit comes of that, and no outcome of merit.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: In giving, self-control, restraint, and truthfulness there is no merit or outcome of merit.’
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: A sensible person reflects on this matter in this way:
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: ‘This teacher has such a doctrine and view.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: If what that teacher says is true, both I who have not accomplished this and one who has accomplished it
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: have attained exactly the same level. Yet I’m not one who says that when both of us act, nothing wrong is done.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: But it’s superfluous for this teacher to go naked, shaven, persisting in squatting, tearing out their hair and beard. For I’m living at home with my children, using sandalwood imported from Kāsi, wearing garlands, fragrance, and makeup, and accepting gold and currency. Yet I’ll have exactly the same destiny in the next life as this teacher.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: What do I know or see that I should lead the spiritual life under this teacher?
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: This negates the spiritual life.’
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: Realizing this, they leave disappointed.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: This is the second way that negates the spiritual life.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: Furthermore, take a certain teacher who has this doctrine and view:
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: ‘There is no cause or reason for the corruption of sentient beings.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: Sentient beings are corrupted without cause or reason.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: There’s no cause or reason for the purification of sentient beings.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: Sentient beings are purified without cause or reason.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: There is no power, no energy, no human strength or vigor.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: All sentient beings, all living creatures, all beings, all souls lack control, power, and energy. Molded by destiny, circumstance, and nature, they experience pleasure and pain in the six classes of rebirth.’
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: A sensible person reflects on this matter in this way:
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: ‘This teacher has such a doctrine and view.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: If what that teacher says is true, both I who have not accomplished this and one who has accomplished it
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: have attained exactly the same level. Yet I’m not one who says that both of us are purified without cause or reason.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: But it’s superfluous for this teacher to go naked, shaven, persisting in squatting, tearing out their hair and beard. For I’m living at home with my children, using sandalwood imported from Kāsi, wearing garlands, fragrance, and makeup, and accepting gold and currency. Yet I’ll have exactly the same destiny in the next life as this teacher.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: What do I know or see that I should lead the spiritual life under this teacher?
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: This negates the spiritual life.’
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: Realizing this, they leave disappointed.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: This is the third way that negates the spiritual life.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: Furthermore, take a certain teacher who has this doctrine and view:
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: ‘There are these seven substances that are not made, not derived, not created, without a creator, barren, steady as a mountain peak, standing firm like a pillar.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: They don’t move or deteriorate or obstruct each other. They’re unable to cause pleasure, pain, or both pleasure and pain to each other.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: What seven?
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: The substances of earth, water, fire, air; pleasure, pain, and the soul is the seventh.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: These seven substances are not made, not derived, not created, without a creator, barren, steady as a mountain peak, standing firm like a pillar.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: They don’t move or deteriorate or obstruct each other. They’re unable to cause pleasure, pain, or both pleasure and pain to each other.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: And here there is no-one who kills or who makes others kill; no-one who learns or who educates others; no-one who understands or who helps others understand.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: If you chop off someone’s head with a sharp sword, you don’t take anyone’s life.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: The sword simply passes through the gap between the seven substances.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: There are 1.4 million main wombs, and 6,000, and 600. There are 500 deeds, and five, and three. There are deeds and half-deeds. There are 62 paths, 62 sub-eons, six classes of rebirth, and eight stages in a person’s life. There are 4,900 Ājīvaka ascetics, 4,900 wanderers, and 4,900 naked ascetics. There are 2,000 faculties, 3,000 hells, and 36 realms of dust. There are seven percipient embryos, seven non-percipient embryos, and seven knotless embryos. There are seven gods, seven humans, and seven goblins. There are seven lakes, seven rivers, 700 rivers, seven cliffs, and 700 cliffs. There are seven dreams and 700 dreams. There are 8.4 million great eons through which the foolish and the astute transmigrate before making an end of suffering.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: And here there is no such thing as this: “By this precept or observance or fervent austerity or spiritual life I shall force unripened deeds to bear their fruit, or eliminate old deeds by experiencing their results little by little”—for that cannot be.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: Pleasure and pain are allotted. Transmigration lasts only for a limited period, so there’s no increase or decrease, no getting better or worse.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: It’s like how, when you toss a ball of string, it rolls away unraveling.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: In the same way, after transmigrating the foolish and the astute will make an end of suffering.’
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: A sensible person reflects on this matter in this way:
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: ‘This teacher has such a doctrine and view.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: If what that teacher says is true, both I who have not accomplished this and one who has accomplished it
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: have attained exactly the same level. Yet I’m not one who says that after transmigrating both of us will make an end of suffering.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: But it’s superfluous for this teacher to go naked, shaven, persisting in squatting, tearing out their hair and beard. For I’m living at home with my children, using sandalwood imported from Kāsi, wearing garlands, fragrance, and makeup, and accepting gold and currency. Yet I’ll have exactly the same destiny in the next life as this teacher.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: What do I know or see that I should lead the spiritual life under this teacher?
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: This negates the spiritual life.’
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: Realizing this, they leave disappointed.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: This is the fourth way that negates the spiritual life.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: These are the four ways that negate the spiritual life that have been explained by the Blessed One, who knows and sees, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha. A sensible person would, to the best of their ability, not practice such spiritual paths, and if they did practice them, they wouldn’t succeed in the system of the skillful teaching.”
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: “It’s incredible, worthy Ānanda, it’s amazing,
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: how these four ways that negate the spiritual life have been explained by the Buddha.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: But worthy Ānanda, what are the four kinds of unreliable spiritual life?”
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: “Sandaka, take a certain teacher who claims to be all-knowing and all-seeing, to know and see everything without exception, thus:
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: ‘Knowledge and vision are constantly and continually present to me, while walking, standing, sleeping, and waking.’
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: They enter an empty house; they get no almsfood; a dog bites them; they encounter a wild elephant, a wild horse, and a wild cow; they ask the name and clan of a woman or man; they ask the name and path to a village or town.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: When asked, ‘Why is this?’ they answer: ‘I had to enter an empty house, that’s why I entered it. I had to get no almsfood, that’s why I got none. I had to get bitten by a dog, that’s why I was bitten. I had to encounter a wild elephant, a wild horse, and a wild cow, that’s why I encountered them. title: With Sandaka

title: With Sandaka

segment_text: “Sandaka, a mendicant who is perfected—with defilements ended, who has completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their own true goal, utterly ended the fetter of continued existence, and is rightly freed through enlightenment—can’t transgress in five respects.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: A mendicant with defilements ended can’t deliberately take the life of a living creature, take something with the intention to steal, have sex, tell a deliberate lie, or store up goods for their own enjoyment like they used to as a lay person.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: A mendicant who is perfected can’t transgress in these five respects.”
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: “But worthy Ānanda, when a mendicant is perfected, would the knowledge and vision that their defilements are ended be constantly and continually present to them, while walking, standing, sleeping, and waking?”
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: “Well then, Sandaka, I shall give you a simile.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: For by means of a simile some sensible people understand the meaning of what is said.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: Suppose there was a person whose hands and feet had been amputated.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: Would they be aware that their hands and feet had been amputated constantly and continually, while walking, standing, sleeping, and waking?
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: Or would they be aware of it only when they checked it?”
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: “They wouldn’t be aware of it constantly,
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: only when they checked it.”
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: “In the same way, when a mendicant is perfected, the knowledge and vision that their defilements are ended is not constantly and continually present to them, while walking, standing, sleeping, and waking.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: Rather, they are aware of it only when they checked it.”
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: “But Reverend Ānanda, in this teaching and training, how many are emancipated?”
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: “There are not just one hundred who are emancipated, Sandaka, or two or three or four or five hundred, but many more than that in this teaching and training.”
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: “It’s incredible, worthy Ānanda, it’s amazing!
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: Namely, that there’s no glorifying one’s own teaching and putting down the teaching of others. The Dhamma is taught in its own field, and so many emancipated are recognized.
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: But these Ājīvakas, sons of she whose sons are dead, glorify themselves and put others down. And they only recognize three who have been emancipated:
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: Nanda Vaccha, Kisa Saṅkicca, and the bamboo-staffed ascetic Gosāla.”
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: Then the wanderer Sandaka addressed his own assembly,
title: With Sandaka

segment_text: “Go, good fellows. The spiritual life is lived under the ascetic Gotama.

segment_text: It’s not easy for me to forsake possessions, honor, or popularity now.”

title: With Sandaka

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: Now at that time several very well-known wanderers were residing in the monastery of the wanderers in the peacocks’ feeding ground.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: They included Annabhāra, Varadhara, Sakuludāyī, and other very well-known wanderers.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Rājagaha for alms.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: Then it occurred to him,
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: “It’s too early to wander for alms in Rājagaha.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: Why don’t I visit the wanderer Sakuludāyī at the monastery of the wanderers in the peacocks’ feeding ground?”
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: So the Buddha went to the monastery of the wanderers.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: Now at that time, Sakuludāyī was sitting together with a large assembly of wanderers making an uproar, a dreadful racket. They engaged in all kinds of low talk, such as
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: talk about kings, bandits, and chief ministers; talk about armies, threats, and wars; talk about food, drink, clothes, and beds; talk about garlands and fragrances; talk about family, vehicles, villages, towns, cities, and countries; talk about women and heroes; street talk and well talk; talk about the departed; motley talk; tales of land and sea; and talk about being reborn in this or that state of existence.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: Sakuludāyī saw the Buddha coming off in the distance,
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: and hushed his own assembly,
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: “Be quiet, good fellows, don’t make a sound.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: Here comes the ascetic Gotama.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: The venerable likes quiet and praises quiet.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: Hopefully if he sees that our assembly is quiet he’ll see fit to approach.”
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: Then those wanderers fell silent.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: Then the Buddha approached Sakuludāyī,
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: who said to him,
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: “Let the Blessed One come, sir!
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: Welcome to the Blessed One, sir!
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: It’s been a long time since you took the opportunity to come here.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: Please, sir, sit down, this seat is ready.”
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: The Buddha sat on the seat spread out,
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: while Sakuludāyī took a low seat and sat to one side.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: The Buddha said to him,
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: “Udāyī, what were you sitting talking about just now? What conversation was left unfinished?”
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: “Sir, leave aside what we were sitting talking about just now.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: It won’t be hard for you to hear about that later.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: Sir, a few days ago several ascetics and brahmins who follow various other religions were sitting together at the debating hall, and this discussion came up among them:
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: ‘The people of Aṅga and Magadha are so fortunate, so very fortunate!
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: For there are these ascetics and brahmins who lead an order and a community, and tutor a community. They’re well-known and famous religious founders, deemed holy by many people. And they have come down for the rainy season residence at Rājagaha.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: They include Pūraṇa Kassapa,
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: the bamboo-staffed ascetic Gosāla,
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: Ajita of the hair blanket,
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: Pakudha Kaccāyana,
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: Sañjaya Belaṭṭhiputta,
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: and the Jain ascetic of the Ñātika clan.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: This ascetic Gotama also leads an order and a community, and tutors a community. He’s a well-known and famous religious founder, deemed holy by many people.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: And he too has come down for the rains residence at Rājagaha.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: Which of these ascetics and brahmins is honored, respected, revered, and venerated by their disciples? And how do their disciples, honoring and respecting them, remain loyal?’
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: Some of them said:
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: ‘This Pūraṇa Kassapa leads an order and a community, and tutors a community. He’s a well-known and famous religious founder, deemed holy by many people.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: But he’s not honored, respected, revered, and venerated by his disciples. And his disciples, not honoring and respecting him, don’t remain loyal to him.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: Once it so happened that he was teaching an assembly of many hundreds.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: Then one of his disciples made a noise,
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: “My good fellows, don’t ask Pūraṇa Kassapa about that.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: He doesn’t know that.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: I know it. Ask me about it,
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: and I’ll answer you.”
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: Once it so happened that Pūraṇa Kassapa didn’t get his way, though he called out with raised arms,
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: “Be quiet, good fellows, don’t make a sound.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: They’re not asking you, they’re asking me!
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: I’ll answer you!”
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: Indeed, many of his disciples have left him after refuting his doctrine:
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: “You don’t understand this teaching and training. I understand this teaching and training. What, you understand this teaching and training? You’re practicing wrong. I’m practicing right. I stay on topic, you don’t. You said last what you should have said first. You said first what you should have said last. What you’ve thought so much about has been disproved. Your doctrine is refuted. Go on, save your doctrine! You’re trapped; get yourself out of this—if you can!”
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: That’s how Pūraṇa Kassapa is not honored, respected, revered, venerated, and esteemed by his disciples. On the contrary, his disciples, not honoring and respecting him, don’t remain loyal to him.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: Rather, he’s reviled, and rightly so.’
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: It’s like when there’s a person at the crossroads pressing out pure dwarf-bee honey,

segment_text: Even when disciples of the ascetic Gotama, having clashed with their spiritual companions, reject the training and return to a lesser life, they speak only praise of the teacher, the teaching, and the Saṅgha. They blame only themselves, not others: “We were unlucky, we had little merit. For even after going forth in such a well explained teaching and training we weren’t able to practice for life the perfectly full and pure spiritual life.”
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: They become monastery workers or lay followers, and they proceed having undertaken the five precepts.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: That’s how the ascetic Gotama is honored, respected, revered, and venerated by his disciples. And that’s how his disciples, honoring and respecting him, remain loyal to him.’”
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: “But Udāyī, how many qualities do you see in me, because of which my disciples honor, respect, revere, and venerate me; and honoring and respecting me, they remain loyal to me?”
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: “Sir, I see five such qualities in the Buddha.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: What five?
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: The Buddha eats little and praises eating little.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: This is the first such quality I see in the Buddha.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: Furthermore, the Buddha is content with any kind of robe, and praises such contentment.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: This is the second such quality I see in the Buddha.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: Furthermore, the Buddha is content with any kind of almsfood, and praises such contentment.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: This is the third such quality I see in the Buddha.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: Furthermore, the Buddha is content with any kind of lodging, and praises such contentment.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: This is the fourth such quality I see in the Buddha.

segment_text: These are the five qualities I see in the Buddha, because of which his disciples honor, respect, revere, and venerate him; and honoring and respecting him, they remain loyal to him.”

segment_text: “Suppose, Udāyī, my disciples were loyal to me because I eat little. Well, there are disciples of mine who eat a tumbler of food, or half a tumbler; they eat a wood-apple, or half a wood-apple.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: But sometimes I even eat this bowl full to the brim, or even more.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: So if it were the case that my disciples are loyal to me because I eat little, then those disciples who eat even less would not be loyal to me.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: Suppose my disciples were loyal to me because I’m content with any kind of robe. Well, there are disciples of mine who have rag robes, wearing shabby robes. They gather scraps from charnel grounds, rubbish dumps, and shops, make them into a patchwork robe and wear it.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: But sometimes I wear robes offered by householders that are strong, yet next to which bottle-gourd down is coarse.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: So if it were the case that my disciples are loyal to me because I’m content with any kind of robe, then those disciples who wear rag robes would not be loyal to me.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: Suppose my disciples were loyal to me because I’m content with any kind of almsfood. Well, there are disciples of mine who eat only almsfood, wander indiscriminately for almsfood, happy to eat whatever they glean. When they’ve entered an inhabited area, they don’t consent when invited to sit down.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: But sometimes I even eat by invitation boiled fine rice with the dark grains picked out, served with many soups and sauces.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: So if it were the case that my disciples are loyal to me because I’m content with any kind of almsfood, then those disciples who eat only almsfood would not be loyal to me.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: Suppose my disciples were loyal to me because I’m content with any kind of lodging. Well, there are disciples of mine who stay at the root of a tree, in the open air. For eight months they don’t go under a roof.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: But sometimes I even stay in bungalows, plastered inside and out, draft-free, with doors fastened and windows shuttered.

segment_text: So if it were the case that my disciples are loyal to me because I’m content with any kind of lodging, then those disciples who stay at the root of a tree would not be loyal to me.

segment_text: Suppose my disciples were loyal to me because I’m secluded and I praise seclusion. Well, there are disciples of mine who live in the wilderness, in remote lodgings. segment_text: But sometimes I live crowded by monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen; by rulers and their chief ministers, and monastics of other religions and their disciples.

segment_text: ‘This body of mine is formed. It’s made up of the four principal states, produced by mother and father, built up from rice and porridge, liable to impermanence, to wearing away and erosion, to breaking up and destruction.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: And this consciousness of mine is attached to it, tied to it.’
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: And many of my disciples meditate on that having attained perfection and consummation of insight.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: Furthermore, I have explained to my disciples a practice that they use to create from this body another body—formed, mind-made, whole in its major and minor limbs, not deficient in any faculty.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: Suppose a person was to draw a reed out from its sheath.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: They’d think:
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: ‘This is the reed, this is the sheath. The reed and the sheath are different things. The reed has been drawn out from the sheath.’
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: Or suppose a person was to draw a sword out from its scabbard.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: They’d think:
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: ‘This is the sword, this is the scabbard. The sword and the scabbard are different things. The sword has been drawn out from the scabbard.’
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: Or suppose a person was to draw a snake out from its slough.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: They’d think:
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: ‘This is the snake, this is the slough. The snake and the slough are different things. The snake has been drawn out from the slough.’
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: In the same way, I have explained to my disciples a practice that they use to create from this body another body—formed, mind-made, whole in its major and minor limbs, not deficient in any faculty.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: And many of my disciples meditate on that having attained perfection and consummation of insight.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: Furthermore, I have explained to my disciples a practice that they use to wield the many kinds of psychic power: multiplying themselves and becoming one again; appearing and disappearing; going unobstructed through a wall, a rampart, or a mountain as if through space; diving in and out of the earth as if it were water; walking on water as if it were earth; flying cross-legged through the sky like a bird; touching and stroking with the hand the sun and moon, so mighty and powerful. They control the body as far as the realm of divinity.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: Suppose a deft potter or their apprentice had some well-prepared clay. They could produce any kind of pot that they like.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: Or suppose a deft ivory-carver or their apprentice had some well-prepared ivory. They could produce any kind of ivory item that they like.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: Or suppose a deft goldsmith or their apprentice had some well-prepared gold. They could produce any kind of gold item that they like.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: In the same way, I have explained to my disciples a practice that they use to wield the many kinds of psychic power …
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: And many of my disciples meditate on that having attained perfection and consummation of insight.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: Furthermore, I have explained to my disciples a practice that they use so that, with clairaudience that is purified and superhuman, they hear both kinds of sounds, human and heavenly, whether near or far.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: Suppose there was a powerful horn blower. They’d easily make themselves heard in the four quarters.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: Suppose there was a woman or man who was young, youthful, and fond of adornments, and they check their own reflection in a clean bright mirror or a clear bowl of water. If they had a spot they’d know ‘I have a spot’, and if they had no spots they’d know ‘I have no spots’.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: In the same way, I have explained to my disciples a practice that they use to understand the minds of other beings and individuals, having comprehended them with their own mind …
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: And many of my disciples meditate on that having attained perfection and consummation of insight.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: Furthermore, I have explained to my disciples a practice that they use to recollect the many kinds of past lives. That is: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so they recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: Suppose a person was to leave their home village and go to another village. From that village they’d go to yet another village. And from that village they’d return to their home village. They’d think: ‘I went from my home village to another village. There I stood like this, sat like that, spoke like this, or kept silent like that. From that village I went to yet another village. There too I stood like this, sat like that, spoke like this, or kept silent like that. And from that village I returned to my home village.’
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: In the same way, I have explained to my disciples a practice that they use to recollect the many kinds of past lives.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: And many of my disciples meditate on that having attained perfection and consummation of insight.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: Furthermore, I have explained to my disciples a practice that they use so that, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds: ‘These dear beings did bad things by way of body, speech, and mind. They denounced the noble ones; they had wrong view; and they chose to act out of that wrong view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. These dear beings, however, did good things by way of body, speech, and mind. They never denounced the noble ones; they had right view; and they chose to act out of that right view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.’ And so, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: Suppose there were two houses with doors. A person with clear eyes standing in between them would see humans entering and leaving a house and wandering to and fro.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: In the same way, I have explained to my disciples a practice that they use so that, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn …
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: And many of my disciples meditate on that having attained perfection and consummation of insight.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: Furthermore, I have explained to my disciples a practice that they use to realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: Suppose that in a mountain glen there was a lake that was transparent, clear, and unclouded. A person with clear eyes standing on the bank would see the clams and mussels, and pebbles and gravel, and schools of fish swimming about or staying still. They’d think: ‘This lake is transparent, clear, and unclouded. And here are the clams and mussels, and pebbles and gravel, and schools of fish swimming about or staying still.’
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: In the same way, I have explained to my disciples a practice that they use to realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: And many of my disciples meditate on that having attained perfection and consummation of insight.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: This is the fifth quality because of which my disciples are loyal to me.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: These are the five qualities because of which my disciples honor, respect, revere, and venerate me; and honoring and respecting me, they remain loyal to me.”
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: That is what the Buddha said.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: Satisfied, the wanderer Sakuludāyī approved what the Buddha said.
title: The Longer Discourse with Sakuludāyī

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: With Uggāhamāna Samaṇamaṇḍikāputta

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
title: With Uggāhamāna Samaṇamaṇḍikāputta

segment_text: Now at that time the wanderer Uggāhamāna Samaṇamaṇḍikāputta was residing together with around five hundred wanderers in Mallikā’s single-halled monastery for philosophical debates, hedged by pale-moon ebony trees.
title: With Uggāhamāna Samaṇamaṇḍikāputta

segment_text: Then the chamberlain Pañcakaṅga left Sāvatthī in the middle of the day to see the Buddha.
title: With Uggāhamāna Samaṇamaṇḍikāputta

segment_text: It occurred to him,
title: With Uggāhamāna Samaṇamaṇḍikāputta

segment_text: “It’s the wrong time to see the Buddha,
title: With Uggāhamāna Samaṇamaṇḍikāputta

segment_text: as he’s in retreat.
title: With Uggāhamāna Samaṇamaṇḍikāputta

segment_text: And it’s the wrong time to see the esteemed mendicants,
title: With Uggāhamāna Samaṇamaṇḍikāputta

segment_text: as they’re in retreat.
title: With Uggāhamāna Samaṇamaṇḍikāputta

segment_text: Why don’t I go to Mallikā’s monastery to visit the wanderer Uggāhamāna?”
title: With Uggāhamāna Samaṇamaṇḍikāputta

segment_text: So that’s what he did.
title: With Uggāhamāna Samaṇamaṇḍikāputta

segment_text: Now at that time, Uggāhamāna was sitting together with a large assembly of wanderers making an uproar, a dreadful racket. They engaged in all kinds of low talk, such as
title: With Uggāhamāna Samaṇamaṇḍikāputta

segment_text: talk about kings, bandits, and chief ministers; talk about armies, threats, and wars; talk about food, drink, clothes, and beds; talk about garlands and fragrances; talk about family, vehicles, villages, towns, cities, and countries; talk about women and heroes; street talk and well talk; talk about the departed; motley talk; tales of land and sea; and talk about being reborn in this or that state of existence.
title: With Uggāhamāna Samaṇamaṇḍikāputta

segment_text: Uggāhamāna saw Pañcakaṅga coming off in the distance,
title: With Uggāhamāna Samaṇamaṇḍikāputta

segment_text: and hushed his own assembly,
title: With Uggāhamāna Samaṇamaṇḍikāputta

segment_text: “Be quiet, good fellows, don’t make a sound.
title: With Uggāhamāna Samaṇamaṇḍikāputta

segment_text: Here comes Pañcakaṅga, a disciple of the ascetic Gotama.
title: With Uggāhamāna Samaṇamaṇḍikāputta

segment_text: He is included among the white-clothed lay disciples of the ascetic Gotama, who is residing in Sāvatthī.
title: With Uggāhamāna Samaṇamaṇḍikāputta

segment_text: Such venerables like the quiet, are educated to be quiet, and praise the quiet.
title: With Uggāhamāna Samaṇamaṇḍikāputta

segment_text: Hopefully if he sees that our assembly is quiet he’ll see fit to approach.”
title: With Uggāhamāna Samaṇamaṇḍikāputta

segment_text: Then those wanderers fell silent.
title: With Uggāhamāna Samaṇamaṇḍikāputta

segment_text: Then Pañcakaṅga approached Uggāhamāna, and exchanged greetings with him.
title: With Uggāhamāna Samaṇamaṇḍikāputta

segment_text: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side. Uggāhamāna said to him:
title: With Uggāhamāna Samaṇamaṇḍikāputta

segment_text: “Householder, when an individual has four qualities I describe them as an invincible ascetic—accomplished in the skillful, excelling in the skillful, attained to the highest attainment.
title: With Uggāhamāna Samaṇamaṇḍikāputta

segment_text: What four?
title: With Uggāhamāna Samaṇamaṇḍikāputta

segment_text: It’s when they do no bad deeds with their body; speak no bad words; think no bad thoughts; and don’t earn a living by bad livelihood.
title: With Uggāhamāna Samaṇamaṇḍikāputta

segment_text: When an individual has these four qualities I describe them as an invincible ascetic.”
title: With Uggāhamāna Samaṇamaṇḍikāputta

segment_text: Then Pañcakaṅga neither approved nor dismissed the wanderer Uggāhamāna’s statement.
title: With Uggāhamāna Samaṇamaṇḍikāputta

segment_text: He got up from his seat, thinking,
title: With Uggāhamāna Samaṇamaṇḍikāputta

segment_text: “I will learn the meaning of this statement from the Buddha himself.”
title: With Uggāhamāna Samaṇamaṇḍikāputta

segment_text: Then he went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side,
title: With Uggāhamāna Samaṇamaṇḍikāputta

segment_text: and informed the Buddha of all that had been discussed.
title: With Uggāhamāna Samaṇamaṇḍikāputta

segment_text: When he had spoken, the Buddha said to him,
title: With Uggāhamāna Samaṇamaṇḍikāputta

segment_text: “Chamberlain, if what Uggāhamāna says is true, a little baby boy is an invincible ascetic—accomplished in the skillful, excelling in the skillful, attained to the highest attainment.
title: With Uggāhamāna Samaṇamaṇḍikāputta

segment_text: For a little baby doesn’t even have a concept of ‘a body’, so how could they possibly do a bad deed with their body, aside from just wriggling?
title: With Uggāhamāna Samaṇamaṇḍikāputta

segment_text: And a little baby doesn’t even have a concept of ‘speech’, so how could they possibly speak bad words, aside from just crying?
title: With Uggāhamāna Samaṇamaṇḍikāputta

segment_text: And a little baby doesn’t even have a concept of ‘thought’, so how could they possibly think bad thoughts, aside from just whimpering?
title: With Uggāhamāna Samaṇamaṇḍikāputta

segment_text: And a little baby doesn’t even have a concept of ‘livelihood’, so how could they possibly earn a living by bad livelihood, aside from their mother’s breast?
title: With Uggāhamāna Samaṇamaṇḍikāputta

segment_text: If what Uggāhamāna says is true, a little baby boy is an invincible ascetic—accomplished in the skillful, excelling in the skillful, attained to the highest attainment.
title: With Uggāhamāna Samaṇamaṇḍikāputta

segment_text: When an individual has four qualities I describe them, not as an invincible ascetic—accomplished in the skillful, excelling in the skillful, attained to the highest attainment—but as having achieved the same level as a little baby.
title: With Uggāhamāna Samaṇamaṇḍikāputta

segment_text: What four?
title: With Uggāhamāna Samaṇamaṇḍikāputta

segment_text: It’s when they do no bad deeds with their body; speak no bad words; think no bad thoughts; and don’t earn a living by bad livelihood.
title: With Uggāhamāna Samaṇamaṇḍikāputta

segment_text: When an individual has these four qualities I describe them, not as an invincible ascetic, but as having achieved the same level as a little baby.
title: With Uggāhamāna Samaṇamaṇḍikāputta

title: With Uggāhamāna Samaṇamaṇḍikāputta

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Sakuludāyī

segment_text: Now at that time the wanderer Sakuludāyī was residing together with a large assembly of wanderers in the monastery of the wanderers in the peacocks’ feeding ground.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Sakuludāyī

segment_text: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Rājagaha for alms.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Sakuludāyī

segment_text: Then it occurred to him,
title: The Shorter Discourse With Sakuludāyī

segment_text: “It’s too early to wander for alms in Rājagaha.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Sakuludāyī

segment_text: Why don’t I visit the wanderer Sakuludāyī at the monastery of the wanderers in the peacocks’ feeding ground?”
title: The Shorter Discourse With Sakuludāyī

segment_text: Then the Buddha went to the monastery of the wanderers.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Sakuludāyī

segment_text: Now at that time, Sakuludāyī was sitting together with a large assembly of wanderers making an uproar, a dreadful racket. They engaged in all kinds of low talk, such as
title: The Shorter Discourse With Sakuludāyī

segment_text: talk about kings, bandits, and chief ministers; talk about armies, threats, and wars; talk about food, drink, clothes, and beds; talk about garlands and fragrances; talk about family, vehicles, villages, towns, cities, and countries; talk about women and heroes; street talk and well talk; talk about the departed; motley talk; tales of land and sea; and talk about being reborn in this or that state of existence.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Sakuludāyī

segment_text: Sakuludāyī saw the Buddha coming off in the distance,
title: The Shorter Discourse With Sakuludāyī

segment_text: and hushed his own assembly,
title: The Shorter Discourse With Sakuludāyī

segment_text: “Be quiet, good fellows, don’t make a sound.

segment_text: Here comes the ascetic Gotama.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Sakuludāyī

segment_text: The venerable likes quiet and praises quiet.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Sakuludāyī

segment_text: Hopefully if he sees that our assembly is quiet he’ll see fit to approach.”
title: The Shorter Discourse With Sakuludāyī

segment_text: Then those wanderers fell silent.
title: The Shorter Discourse With Sakuludāyī

segment_text: Then the Buddha approached Sakuludāyī,
title: The Shorter Discourse With Sakuludāyī

segment_text: who said to him,

segment_text: “Let the Blessed One come, sir!

segment_text: The Buddha sat on the seat spread out,

segment_text: The Buddha said to him,
