segment_text: Let’s go to see the Blessed One Kassapa, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: For I deem it holy to see that Blessed One.’
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: Then Jotipāla thought,
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: ‘Oh lord, how incredible, how amazing,
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: how this potter Ghaṭīkāra, though of lowly birth, should presume to grab me by the hair of my freshly-washed head!
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: This must be no ordinary matter.’
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: He said to Ghaṭīkāra,
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: ‘You’d even milk it to this extent, dear Ghaṭīkāra?’
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: ‘I even milk it to this extent, dear Jotipāla.
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: For that is how holy I deem it to see that Blessed One.’
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: ‘Well then, dear Ghaṭīkāra, release me, we shall go.’
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: Then Ghaṭīkāra the potter and Jotipāla the student went to the Buddha Kassapa. Ghaṭīkāra bowed and sat down to one side, but Jotipāla exchanged greetings with the Buddha and sat down to one side.
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: Ghaṭīkāra said to the Buddha Kassapa,
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: ‘Sir, this is the student Jotipāla, my dear friend.
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: Please teach him the Dhamma.’
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: Then the Buddha Kassapa educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired Ghaṭīkāra and Jotipāla with a Dhamma talk.
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: Then they got up from their seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha Kassapa, keeping him on their right, before leaving.
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: Then Jotipāla said to Ghatīkāra,
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: ‘Dear Ghaṭīkāra, you have heard this teaching, so why don’t you go forth from the lay life to homelessness?’
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: ‘Don’t you know, dear Jotipāla, that I  provide for my blind old parents?’
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: ‘Well then, dear Ghaṭīkāra, I shall go forth from the lay life to homelessness.’
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: Then Ghaṭīkāra and Jotipāla went to the Buddha Kassapa, bowed and sat down to one side. Ghaṭīkāra said to the Buddha Kassapa,
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: ‘Sir, this is the student Jotipāla, my dear friend.
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: Please give him the going forth.’
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: And Jotipāla the student received the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence.
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: Not long after Jotipāla’s ordination, a fortnight later, the Buddha Kassapa—having stayed in Vebhaliṅga as long as he pleased—set out for Varanasi.
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: Traveling stage by stage, he arrived at Varanasi,
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: where he stayed near Varanasi, in the deer park at Isipatana.
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: King Kikī of Kāsi heard that he had arrived.
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: He had the finest carriages harnessed. He then mounted a fine carriage and, along with other fine carriages, set out in full royal pomp from Varanasi to see the Buddha Kassapa.
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: He went by carriage as far as the terrain allowed, then descended and approached the Buddha Kassapa on foot. He bowed and sat down to one side.
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: The Buddha educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired him with a Dhamma talk.
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: Then King Kikī said to the Buddha,
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: ‘Sir, would the Buddha together with the mendicant Saṅgha please accept tomorrow’s meal from me?’
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: The Buddha Kassapa consented with silence.
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: Then, knowing that the Buddha had consented, King Kikī got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before leaving.
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: And when the night had passed, King Kikī had delicious fresh and cooked foods prepared in his own home—soft saffron rice with the dark grains picked out, served with many soups and sauces. Then he had the Buddha informed of the time, saying,
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: ‘Sir, it’s time. The meal is ready.’
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: Then Kassapa Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to the home of King Kikī, where he sat on the seat spread out, together with the Saṅgha of mendicants.
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: Then King Kikī served and satisfied the mendicant Saṅgha headed by the Buddha with his own hands with delicious fresh and cooked foods.
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: When the Buddha Kassapa had eaten and washed his hand and bowl, King Kikī took a low seat and sat to one side.
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: There he said to the Buddha Kassapa,
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: ‘Sir, may the Buddha please accept my invitation to reside in Varanasi for the rainy season.
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: The Saṅgha will be looked after in the same style.’
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: ‘Enough, great king.
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: I have already accepted an invitation for the rains residence.’
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: For a second time …
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: and a third time King Kikī said to the Buddha Kassapa,
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: ‘Sir, may the Buddha please accept my invitation to reside in Varanasi for the rainy season.
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: The Saṅgha will be looked after in the same style.’
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: ‘Enough, Great King.
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: I have already accepted an invitation for the rains residence.’
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: Then King Kikī, thinking, ‘The Buddha does not accept my invitation to reside for the rains in Varanasi,’ became sad and upset.
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: Then King Kikī said to the Buddha Kassapa,
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: ‘Sir, do you have another supporter better than me?’
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: ‘Great king, there is a market town named Vebhaliṅga,
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: where there is a potter named Ghaṭīkāra.
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: He is my chief supporter.
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: Now, great king, when you thought, “The Buddha does not accept my invitation to reside for the rains in Varanasi,” you became sad and upset.
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: But Ghaṭīkāra doesn’t get upset, nor will he.
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: Ghaṭīkāra has gone for refuge to the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha.
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: He doesn’t kill living creatures, steal, commit sexual misconduct, lie, or consume beer, wine, and liquor intoxicants.
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: He has experiential confidence in the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha, and has the ethics loved by the noble ones.
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: He is free of doubt regarding suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the practice that leads to its cessation.
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: He eats in one part of the day; he’s chaste, ethical, and of good character.
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: He has set aside gems and gold, and rejected gold and currency.
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: He has put down the shovel and doesn’t dig the earth with his own hands.
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: He takes what has crumbled off by a riverbank or been dug up by mice, and brings it back in a carrier. When he has made a pot, he says,
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: “Anyone may leave bagged sesame, mung beans, or chickpeas here and take what they wish.”
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: He provided for his blind old parents.
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: And since he has ended the five lower fetters, Ghaṭīkāra will be reborn spontaneously and will become extinguished there, not liable to return from that world.
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: This one time, great king, I was staying near the market town of Vebhaliṅga.
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: Then I robed up in the morning and, taking my bowl and robe, went to the home of Ghaṭīkāra’s parents, where I said to them,
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: “Excuse me, where has Bhaggava gone?”
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: “Your supporter has gone out, sir. But take rice from the pot and sauce from the pan and eat.”
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: So that’s what I did. And after eating I got up from my seat and left.
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: Then Ghaṭīkāra went up to his parents and said,
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: “Who took rice from the pot and sauce from the pan, ate it, and left?”
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: “It was the Buddha Kassapa, my dear.”
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: Then Ghaṭīkāra thought,
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: “I’m so fortunate, so very fortunate,
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: in that the Buddha Kassapa trusts me so much!”
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: Then joy and happiness did not leave him for a fortnight, or his parents for a week.
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: Another time, great king, I was staying near that same market town of Vebhaliṅga.
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: Then I robed up in the morning and, taking my bowl and robe, went to the home of Ghaṭīkāra’s parents, where I said to them,
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: “Excuse me, where has Bhaggava gone?”
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: “Your supporter has gone out, sir. But take porridge from the pot and sauce from the pan and eat.”
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: So that’s what I did. And after eating I got up from my seat and left.
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: Then Ghaṭīkāra went up to his parents and said,
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: “Who took porridge from the pot and sauce from the pan, ate it, and left?”
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: “It was the Buddha Kassapa, my dear.”
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: Then Ghaṭīkāra thought,
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: “I’m so fortunate, so very fortunate,
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: to be trusted so much by the Buddha Kassapa!”
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: Then joy and happiness did not leave him for a fortnight, or his parents for a week.
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: Another time, great king, I was staying near that same market town of Vebhaliṅga.
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: Now at that time my hut leaked.
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: So I addressed the mendicants,
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: “Mendicants, go to Ghaṭīkāra’s home and find some grass.”
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: When I said this, those mendicants said to me,
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: “Sir, there’s no grass there, but his workshop has a grass roof.”
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: “Then go to the workshop and strip the grass.”
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: So that’s what they did.
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: Then Ghaṭīkāra’s parents said to those mendicants,
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: “Who’s stripping the grass from the workshop?”
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: “It’s the mendicants, sister. The Buddha’s hut is leaking.”
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: “Take it, sirs! Take it, dearest ones!”
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: Then Ghaṭīkāra went up to his parents and said,
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: “Who stripped the grass from the workshop?”
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: “It was the mendicants, dear. It seems the Buddha’s hut is leaking.”
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: Then Ghaṭīkāra thought,
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: “I’m so fortunate, so very fortunate,
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: to be trusted so much by the Buddha Kassapa!”
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: Then joy and happiness did not leave him for a fortnight, or his parents for a week.
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: Then the workshop remained with the atmosphere for a roof for the whole three months, but the heavens did not rain on it.
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: And that, great king, is what Ghaṭīkāra the potter is like.’
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: ‘Ghaṭīkāra the potter is fortunate, very fortunate,
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: to be so trusted by the Buddha Kassapa.’
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: Then King Kikī sent around five hundred loads of rice, soft saffron rice, and suitable sauce to Ghaṭīkāra.
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: Then one of the king’s men approached Ghaṭīkāra and said,
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: ‘Sir, these five hundred loads of rice, soft saffron rice, and suitable sauce have been sent to you by King Kikī of Kāsi.
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: Please accept them.’
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: ‘The king has many duties, and much to do.
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: I have enough.
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: Let this be for the king himself.’
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: Ānanda, you might think:
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: ‘Surely the student Jotipāla must have been someone else at that time?’
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: But you should not see it like this.
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: I myself was the student Jotipāla at that time.”
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: That is what the Buddha said.
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: Satisfied, Venerable Ānanda approved what the Buddha said.
title: With Ghaṭīkāra

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was wandering in the land of the Kurus together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants when he arrived at a town of the Kurus named Thullakoṭṭhika.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: The brahmins and householders of Thullakoṭṭhika heard:
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “It seems the ascetic Gotama—a Sakyan, gone forth from a Sakyan family—has arrived at Thullakoṭṭhika, together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: He has this good reputation:
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: He has realized with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras, and divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: He proclaims a teaching that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: It’s good to see such perfected ones.”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Then the brahmins and householders of Thullakoṭṭhika went up to the Buddha. Before sitting down to one side, some bowed, some exchanged greetings and polite conversation, some held up their joined palms toward the Buddha, some announced their name and clan, while some kept silent.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: When they were seated, the Buddha educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired them with a Dhamma talk.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Now at that time a gentleman named Raṭṭhapāla, the son of the leading clan in Thullakoṭṭhika, was sitting in the assembly.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: He thought,
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “As I understand the Buddha’s teaching, it’s not easy for someone living at home to lead the spiritual life utterly full and pure, like a polished shell.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Why don’t I shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from lay life to homelessness?”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Then, having approved and agreed with what the Buddha said, the brahmins and householders of Thullakoṭṭhika got up from their seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on their right, before leaving.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Soon after they left, Raṭṭhapāla went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “Sir, as I understand the Buddha’s teaching, it’s not easy for someone living at home to lead the spiritual life utterly full and pure, like a polished shell.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: I wish to shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Sir, may I receive the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence?
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: May the Buddha please give me the going forth!”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “But, Raṭṭhapāla, do you have your parents’ permission?”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “No, sir.”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “Raṭṭhapāla, Buddhas don’t give the going forth to the child of parents who haven’t given their permission.”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “I’ll make sure, sir, to get my parents’ permission.”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Then Raṭṭhapāla got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha. Then he went to his parents and said,
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “Mum and dad, as I understand the Buddha’s teachings, it’s not easy for someone living at home to lead the spiritual life utterly full and pure, like a polished shell.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: I wish to shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Please give me permission to go forth.”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: When he said this, Raṭṭhapāla’s parents said to him,
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “But, dear Raṭṭhapāla, you’re our only child. You’re dear to us and we love you. You’re dainty and raised in comfort.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: You know nothing of suffering.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Even when you die we will lose you against our wishes.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: So how can we allow you to go forth while you’re still alive?”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: For a second time,
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: and a third time, Raṭṭhapāla asked his parents for permission, but got the same reply.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Then Raṭṭhapāla thought,
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “My parents don’t allow me to go forth.” He laid down right there on the bare ground, saying,
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “I’ll either die right here or go forth.”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: And he refused to eat, up to the seventh meal.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Then Raṭṭhapāla’s parents said to him,

title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: When you die we will lose you against our wishes.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: So how can we allow you to go forth from lay life to homelessness while you’re still living?
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Get up, Raṭṭhapāla! Eat, drink, and amuse yourself.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: While enjoying sensual pleasures, delight in making merit.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: We don’t allow you to go forth.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: When you die we will lose you against our wishes.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: So how can we allow you to go forth while you’re still alive?”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: When they said this, Raṭṭhapāla kept silent.

segment_text: For a second time,

title: With Raṭṭhapāla

title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Your parents will not allow you to go forth.

segment_text: And for a third time, Raṭṭhapāla kept silent.

title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “Mum and dad, Raṭṭhapāla is lying there on the bare ground saying:

title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: If you don’t allow him to go forth, he’ll die there.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: But if you do allow him to go forth, you’ll see him again afterwards.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: And if he doesn’t enjoy the renunciate life, where else will he have to go? He’ll come right back here.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Please give Raṭṭhapāla permission to go forth.”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “Then, dears, we give Raṭṭhapāla permission to go forth.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: But once gone forth he must visit his parents.”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Then Raṭṭhapāla’s friends went to him and said,
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “Get up, Raṭṭhapāla! Your parents have given you permission to go forth from lay life to homelessness.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: But once gone forth you must visit your parents.”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Raṭṭhapāla got up and regained his strength. He went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “Sir, I have my parents’ permission to go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: May the Buddha please give me the going forth.”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: And Raṭṭhapāla received the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Not long after Venerable Raṭṭhapāla’s ordination, a fortnight later, the Buddha—having stayed in Thullakoṭṭhika as long as he pleased—set out for Sāvatthī.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Traveling stage by stage, he arrived at Sāvatthī,
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: where he stayed in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Then Venerable Raṭṭhapāla, living alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, soon realized the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life. He lived having achieved with his own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: He understood: “Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is nothing further for this place.”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: And Venerable Raṭṭhapāla became one of the perfected.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Then he went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “Sir, I would like to visit my parents, if the Buddha allows it.”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Then the Buddha focused on comprehending Raṭṭhapāla’s mind.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: When he knew that
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: it was impossible for Raṭṭhapāla to resign the training and return to a lesser life, he said,
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “Please, Raṭṭhapāla, go at your convenience.”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: And then Raṭṭhapāla got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right. Then he set his lodgings in order and, taking his bowl and robe, set out for Thullakoṭṭhika.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Traveling stage by stage, he arrived at Thullakoṭṭhika,
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: where he stayed in King Koravya’s deer range.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Then Raṭṭhapāla robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Thullakoṭṭhika for alms.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Wandering indiscriminately for almsfood, he approached his own father’s house.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Now at that time Raṭṭhapāla’s father was having his hair dressed in the hall of the middle gate.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: He saw Raṭṭhapāla coming off in the distance
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: and said,
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “Our dear and beloved only son was made to go forth by these shavelings, these fake ascetics!”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: And at his own father’s home Raṭṭhapāla received neither alms nor a polite refusal,
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: but only abuse.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Now at that time a family bondservant wanted to throw away the previous night’s porridge.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: So Raṭṭhapāla said to her,
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “If that’s to be thrown away, sister, pour it here in my bowl.”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: As she was pouring the porridge into his bowl, she recognized the features of his hands, feet, and voice.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: She then went to his mother and said,
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “Please, madam, you should know this.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Master Raṭṭhapāla has arrived.”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “If you speak the truth, wench, I’ll make you a free woman!”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Then Raṭṭhapāla’s mother went to his father and said,
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “Please householder, you should know this.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: It seems our son Raṭṭhapāla has arrived.”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Now at that time Raṭṭhapāla was eating last night’s porridge by a wall.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Then Raṭṭhapāla’s father went up to him and said,
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “Dear Raṭṭhapāla! How can you be eating last night’s porridge?
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Why not go to your own home?”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “Householder, how could those of us who have gone forth from the lay life to homelessness have a house?
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: We are homeless, householder.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: I came to your house, but there I received neither alms nor a polite refusal,
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: but only abuse.”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “Come, dear Raṭṭhapāla, let’s go to the house.”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “Enough, householder. My meal is finished for today.”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “Well then, dear Raṭṭhapāla, please accept tomorrow’s meal from me.”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Raṭṭhapāla consented with silence.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Then, knowing that Raṭṭhapāla had consented, his father went back to his own house. He made a heap of gold, both coined and uncoined, and hid it under mats. Then he addressed Raṭṭhapāla’s former wives,
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “Please, daughters-in-law, adorn yourselves in the way that our son Raṭṭhapāla found you most adorable.”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: And when the night had passed Raṭṭhapāla’s father had delicious fresh and cooked foods prepared in his own home, and announced the time to the Venerable Raṭṭhapāla, saying,
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “Sir, it’s time. The meal is ready.”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Then Raṭṭhapāla robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to his father’s home, and sat down on the seat spread out. Raṭṭhapāla’s father, revealing the heap of gold, both coined and uncoined, said to him,
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “Dear Raṭṭhapāla, this is your maternal fortune. There’s another paternal fortune, and an ancestral one.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: You can both enjoy your wealth and make merit.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Come, return to a lesser life, enjoy wealth, and make merit!”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “If you’d follow my advice, householder, you’d have this heap of gold, both coined and uncoined, loaded on a cart and carried away to be dumped in the middle of the Ganges river.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Why is that?
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Because this will bring you nothing but sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress.”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Then Raṭṭhapāla’s former wives each clasped his feet and said,
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “What are they like, master, the nymphs for whom you lead the spiritual life?”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “Sisters, I don’t lead the spiritual life for the sake of nymphs.”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Saying, “Our master Raṭṭhapāla addresses us as sisters!” they fainted right away.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Then Raṭṭhapāla said to his father,
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “If there is food to be given, householder, please give it.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: But don’t harass me.”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “Eat, dear Raṭṭhapāla. The meal is ready.”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Then Raṭṭhapāla’s father served and satisfied Venerable Raṭṭhapāla with his own hands with delicious fresh and cooked foods.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: When he had eaten and washed his hand and bowl, he recited this verse while standing right there:
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “See this fancy puppet,
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: a body built of sores,
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: diseased, obsessed over,
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: in which nothing lasts at all.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: See this fancy figure,
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: with its gems and earrings;
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: it is bones encased in skin,
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: made pretty by its clothes.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Rouged feet
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: and powdered face
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: may be enough to beguile a fool,
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: but not a seeker of the far shore.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Hair in eight braids
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: and eyeshadow
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: may be enough to beguile a fool,
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: but not a seeker of the far shore.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: A rotting body all adorned
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: like a freshly painted makeup box
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: may be enough to beguile a fool,
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: but not a seeker of the far shore.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: The hunter laid his snare,
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: but the deer didn’t spring the trap.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: I’ve eaten the bait and now I go,
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: leaving the trapper to lament.”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Then Raṭṭhapāla, having recited this verse while standing, went to King Koravya’s deer range and sat at the root of a tree for the day’s meditation.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Then King Koravya addressed his gamekeeper,
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “My good gamekeeper, tidy up the park of the deer range.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: We will go to see the scenery.”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “Yes, Your Majesty,” replied the gamekeeper. While tidying the deer range he saw Raṭṭhapāla sitting in meditation.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Seeing this, he went to the king, and said,
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “The deer range is tidy, sire.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: And the gentleman named Raṭṭhapāla, the son of the leading clan in Thullakoṭṭhika, of whom you have often spoken highly, is meditating there at the root of a tree.”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “Well then, my good gamekeeper, that’s enough of the park for today.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Now I shall pay homage to the worthy Raṭṭhapāla.”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: And then King Koravya said, “Give away the fresh and cooked foods that have been prepared there.” He had the finest carriages harnessed. Then he mounted a fine carriage and, along with other fine carriages, set out in full royal pomp from Thullakoṭṭhika to see Raṭṭhapāla.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: He went by carriage as far as the terrain allowed, then descended and approached Raṭṭhapāla on foot, together with a group of eminent officials. They exchanged greetings, and, when the greetings and polite conversation were over, he stood to one side and said to Raṭṭhapāla:
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “Here, worthy Raṭṭhapāla, sit on this elephant rug.”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “Enough, great king, you sit on it.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: I’m sitting on my own seat.”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: So the king sat down on the seat spread out, and said:
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “Worthy Raṭṭhapāla, there are these four kinds of decay. Because of these, some people shave off their hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: What four?
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Decay due to old age, decay due to sickness, decay of wealth, and decay of relatives.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: And what is decay due to old age?
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: It’s when someone is old, elderly, and senior, advanced in years, and has reached the final stage of life.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: They reflect:
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: ‘I’m now old, elderly, and senior. I’m advanced in years and have reached the final stage of life.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: It’s not easy for me to acquire more wealth or to increase the wealth I’ve already acquired.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Why don’t I shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness?’
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: So because of that decay due to old age they go forth.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: This is called decay due to old age.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: But worthy Raṭṭhapāla is now a youth, young, with pristine black hair, blessed with youth, in the prime of life.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: You have no decay due to old age.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: So what did you know or see or hear that made you go forth?
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: And what is decay due to sickness?
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: It’s when someone is sick, suffering, gravely ill.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: They reflect:
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: ‘I’m now sick, suffering, gravely ill.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: It’s not easy for me to acquire more wealth or to increase the wealth I’ve already acquired.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Why don’t I go forth from the lay life to homelessness?’
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: So because of that decay due to sickness they go forth.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: This is called decay due to sickness.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: But worthy Raṭṭhapāla is now rarely ill or unwell. Your stomach digests well, being neither too hot nor too cold.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: You have no decay due to sickness.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: So what did you know or see or hear that made you go forth?
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: And what is decay of wealth?
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: It’s when someone is rich, affluent, and wealthy.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: But gradually their wealth dwindles away.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: They reflect:
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: ‘I used to be rich, affluent, and wealthy.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: But gradually my wealth has dwindled away.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: It’s not easy for me to acquire more wealth or to increase the wealth I’ve already acquired.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Why don’t I go forth from the lay life to homelessness?’
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: So because of that decay of wealth they go forth.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: This is called decay of wealth.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: But worthy Raṭṭhapāla is the son of the leading clan here in Thullakoṭṭhika.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: You have no decay of wealth.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: So what did you know or see or hear that made you go forth?
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: And what is decay of relatives?
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: It’s when someone has many friends and colleagues, relatives and kin.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: But gradually their relatives dwindle away.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: They reflect:
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: ‘I used to have many friends and colleagues, relatives and kin.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: But gradually they’ve dwindled away.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: It’s not easy for me to acquire more wealth or to increase the wealth I’ve already acquired.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Why don’t I shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness?’
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: So because of that decay of relatives they go forth.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: This is called decay of relatives.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: But worthy Raṭṭhapāla has many friends and colleagues, relatives and kin right here in Thullakoṭṭhika.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: You have no decay of relatives.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: So what did you know or see or hear that made you go forth?
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: There are these four kinds of decay. Because of these, some people shave off their hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Worthy Raṭṭhapāla has none of these.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: So what did you know or see or hear that made you go forth?”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “Great king, the Blessed One who knows and sees, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha has taught these four summaries of the teaching for recitation. It was after knowing and seeing and hearing these that I went forth from the lay life to homelessness.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: What four?
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: ‘The world is unstable and swept away.’
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: This is the first summary.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: ‘The world has no shelter and no savior.’
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: This is the second summary.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: ‘The world has no owner—you must leave it all behind and pass on.’
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: This is the third summary.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: ‘The world is wanting, insatiable, the slave of craving.’
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: This is the fourth summary.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: The Blessed One who knows and sees, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha taught these four summaries of the teaching. It was after knowing and seeing and hearing these that I went forth from the lay life to homelessness.”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “‘The world is unstable and swept away.’
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: So the worthy Raṭṭhapāla said.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: How should I see the meaning of this statement?”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “What do you think, great king?
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: When you were twenty or twenty-five years of age, were you proficient at riding elephants, horses, and chariots, and at archery and swordsmanship? Were you strong in thigh and arm, capable, and battle-hardened?”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “I was, worthy Raṭṭhapāla.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Sometimes it seems as if I had superpowers then. I don’t see anyone who could have equalled me in strength.”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “What do you think, great king?
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: These days are you just as strong in thigh and arm, capable, and battle-hardened?”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “No, worthy Raṭṭhapāla.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: For now I am old, elderly, and senior, I’m advanced in years and have reached the final stage of life. I am eighty years old.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Sometimes I intend to step in one place, but my foot goes somewhere else.”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “This is what the Buddha was referring to when he said:
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: ‘The world is unstable and swept away.’”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “It’s incredible, worthy Raṭṭhapāla, it’s amazing,
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: how well said this was by the Buddha.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: For the world is indeed unstable and swept away.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: In this royal court you can find divisions of elephants, cavalry, chariots, and infantry. They will serve to defend us from any threats. Yet you said:
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: ‘The world has no shelter and no savior.’
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: How should I see the meaning of this statement?”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “What do you think, great king?
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Do you have any chronic ailments?”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “Yes, I do.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Sometimes my friends and colleagues, relatives and kin surround me, thinking:
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: ‘Now the king will die! Now the king will die!’”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “What do you think, great king?
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Can you get your friends and colleagues, relatives and kin to help:
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: ‘Please, my dear friends and colleagues, relatives and kin, all of you here share my pain so that I may feel less pain.’
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Or must you alone feel that pain?”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “I can’t get my friends to share my pain.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Rather, I alone must feel it.”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “This is what the Buddha was referring to when he said:
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: ‘The world has no shelter and no savior.’”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “It’s incredible, worthy Raṭṭhapāla, it’s amazing,
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: how well said this was by the Buddha.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: For the world indeed has no shelter and no savior.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: In this royal court you can find abundant gold, both coined and uncoined, stored above and below ground. Yet you said:
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: ‘The world has no owner—you must leave it all behind and pass on.’
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: How should I see the meaning of this statement?”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “What do you think, great king?
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: These days you amuse yourself, supplied and provided with the five kinds of sensual stimulation. But is there any way to ensure that in the next life
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: you will continue to amuse yourself in the same way, supplied and provided with the same five kinds of sensual stimulation? Or will others make use of this property, while you pass on according to your deeds?”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “There’s no way to ensure that I will continue to amuse myself in the same way.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Rather, others will take over this property, while I pass on according to my deeds.”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “This is what the Buddha was referring to when he said:
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: ‘The world has no owner—you must leave it all behind and pass on.’”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “It’s incredible, worthy Raṭṭhapāla, it’s amazing,
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: how well said this was by the Buddha.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: For the world indeed has no owner—you must leave it all behind and pass on.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: You also said this: ‘The world is wanting, insatiable, the slave of craving.’
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: How should I see the meaning of this statement?”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “What do you think, great king?
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Do you reign over the prosperous land of Kuru?”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “Indeed I do.”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “What do you think, great king?
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Suppose a trustworthy and dependable man were to come from the east.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: He’d approach you and say:
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: ‘Please great king, you should know this. I come from the east.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: There I saw a large country that is successful and prosperous, populous, full of people.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: They have many divisions of elephants, cavalry, chariots, and infantry.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: And there’s plenty of money and grain,
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: plenty of gold, coined and uncoined, worked and unworked,
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: and plenty of women for the taking.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: With your current forces you can conquer it.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Conquer it, great king!’ What would you do?”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “I would conquer it and reign over it.”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “What do you think, great king?
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Suppose a trustworthy and dependable man were to come from the west,
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: north,
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: south,
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: or from over the ocean.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: He’d approach you and say the same thing.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: What would you do?”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “I would conquer it and reign over it.”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “This is what the Buddha was referring to when he said:
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: ‘The world is wanting, insatiable, the slave of craving.’
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: And it was after knowing and seeing and hearing this that I went forth from the lay life to homelessness.”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “It’s incredible, worthy Raṭṭhapāla, it’s amazing,
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: how well said this was by the Buddha.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: For the world is indeed wanting, insatiable, the slave of craving.”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: This is what Venerable Raṭṭhapāla said.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Then he went on to say:
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: “I see rich humans in the world who,
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: because of delusion, give not <j>the wealth they’ve earned.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Greedily, they hoard their riches,
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: yearning for ever more sensual pleasures.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: A king who conquered the earth by force,
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: ruling the land from sea to sea,
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: unsatisfied with the near shore of the ocean,
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: would still yearn for the further shore.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Not just the king, but others too,
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: reach death not rid of craving.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: They leave the body still wanting,
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: for in this world sensual pleasures never satisfy.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Relatives lament, their hair disheveled,
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: saying ‘Ah! Alas! They’re not immortal!’
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: They take out the body wrapped in a shroud,
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: heap up a pyre, and burn it there.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: It’s poked with stakes while being burnt,
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: in just a single cloth, all wealth gone.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Relatives, friends, and companions
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: can’t help you when you’re dying.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Heirs take your riches,
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: while beings fare on according to their deeds.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Riches don’t follow you when you die;
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: nor do children, wife, wealth, nor kingdom.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Longevity isn’t gained by riches,
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: nor does wealth banish old age;
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: for the attentive say this life is short,
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: it’s perishable and not eternal.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: The rich and the poor feel its touch;
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: the fool and the attentive one feel it too.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: But the fool lies stricken by their own folly,
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: while the attentive one does not tremble at the touch.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Therefore wisdom’s much better than wealth,
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: since by wisdom <j>you reach consummation in this life.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: But if because of delusion <j>you don’t reach consummation,
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: you’ll do evil deeds in life after life.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: One who enters a womb and the world beyond,
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: will transmigrate from one life to the next.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: While someone of little wisdom, <j>placing faith in them,
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: also enters a womb and the world beyond.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: As a bandit caught in a window
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: is punished for his own bad deeds;
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: so after departing, in the world beyond,
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: people are punished for their own bad deeds.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Sensual pleasures are diverse, sweet, delightful;
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: appearing in disguise they disturb the mind.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Seeing danger in sensual stimulations,
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: I went forth, O King.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: As fruit falls from a tree, so the sons of Manu fall,
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: young and old, when the body breaks up.
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: Seeing this, too, I went forth, O King;
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: the ascetic life is unfailingly better.”
title: With Raṭṭhapāla

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Mithilā in the Maghadeva Mango Grove.
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: Then the Buddha smiled at a certain spot.
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: Then Venerable Ānanda thought,
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: “What is the cause, what is the reason why the Buddha smiled?
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: Realized Ones do not smile for no reason.”
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: So Ānanda arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha, and said,
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: “What is the cause, what is the reason why the Buddha smiled?
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: Realized Ones do not smile for no reason.”
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: “Once upon a time, Ānanda, right here in Mithilā there was a just and principled king named Maghadeva, a great king who stood by his duty.
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: He justly treated brahmins and householders, and people of town and country.
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: And he observed the sabbath on the fourteenth, fifteenth, and eighth of the fortnight.
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: Then, after many years, many hundred years, many thousand years had passed, King Maghadeva addressed his barber,
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: ‘My dear barber, when you see grey hairs growing on my head, please tell me.’
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: ‘Yes, Your Majesty,’ replied the barber.
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: When many thousand years had passed, the barber saw grey hairs growing on the king’s head.
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: He said to the king,
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: ‘The messengers of the gods have shown themselves to you. Grey hairs can be seen growing on your head.’
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: ‘Well then, my dear barber, carefully pull them out with tweezers and place them in my cupped hands.’
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: ‘Yes, Your Majesty,’ replied the barber, and he did as the king said.
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: The king gave the barber a prize village, then summoned the crown prince and said,
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: ‘Dear prince, the messengers of the gods have shown themselves to me.
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: Grey hairs can be seen growing on my head.
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: I have enjoyed human pleasures.
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: Now it is time to seek heavenly pleasures.
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: Come, dear prince, rule the realm.
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: I shall shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: For dear prince, you too will one day see grey hairs growing on your head. When this happens, after giving a prize village to the barber and carefully instructing the crown prince in kingship, you should shave off your hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: Keep up this good practice that I have founded. Do not be my final man.
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: When a pair of men are living, the one who breaks such good practice is their final man.
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: Therefore I say to you,
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: “Keep up this good practice that I have founded. Do not be my final man.”’
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: And so, after giving a prize village to the barber and carefully instructing the crown prince in kingship, King Maghadeva shaved off his hair and beard, dressed in ocher robes, and went forth from the lay life to homelessness here in this mango grove.
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: He meditated spreading a heart full of love to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, he spread a heart full of love to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: He meditated spreading a heart full of compassion …
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: rejoicing …
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: equanimity to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, he spread a heart full of equanimity to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: For 84,000 years King Maghadeva played games as a child, for 84,000 years he acted as viceroy, for 84,000 years he ruled the realm, and for 84,000 years he led the spiritual life after going forth here in this mango grove.
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: And having developed the four divine meditations, when his body broke up, after death, he was reborn in a good place, a realm of divinity.
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: Then, after many years, many hundred years, many thousand years had passed, King Maghadeva’s son addressed his barber,
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: ‘My dear barber, when you see grey hairs growing on my head, please tell me.’
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: And all unfolded as in the case of his father.
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: And having developed the four divine meditations, when his body broke up, after death, Maghadeva’s son was reborn in a good place, a realm of divinity.
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: And a lineage of 84,000 kings, sons of sons of King Maghadeva, shaved off their hair and beard, dressed in ocher robes, and went forth from the lay life to homelessness here in this mango grove.
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: They meditated spreading a heart full of love …
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: compassion …
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: rejoicing …
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: equanimity to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of equanimity to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: For 84,000 years they played games as a child, for 84,000 years they acted as viceroy, for 84,000 years they ruled the realm, and for 84,000 years they led the spiritual life after going forth here in this mango grove.
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: And having developed the four divine meditations, when their bodies broke up, after death, they were reborn in a good place, a realm of divinity.
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: Nimi was the last of those kings, a just and principled king, a great king who stood by his duty.
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: He justly treated brahmins and householders, and people of town and country.
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: And he observed the sabbath on the fourteenth, fifteenth, and eighth of the fortnight.
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: Once upon a time, Ānanda, while the gods of the thirty-three were sitting together in the Hall of Justice, this discussion came up among them:
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: ‘The people of Videha are so fortunate, so very fortunate
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: to have Nimi as their king. He is a just and principled king, a great king who stands by his duty.
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: He justly treats brahmins and householders, and people of town and country.
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: And he observes the sabbath on the fourteenth, fifteenth, and eighth of the fortnight.’
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: Then Sakka, lord of gods, addressed the gods of the thirty-three,
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: ‘Good fellows, would you like to see King Nimi?’
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: ‘We would.’
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: Now at that time it was the fifteenth day sabbath, and King Nimi had bathed his head and was sitting upstairs in the royal longhouse to observe the sabbath.
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: Then, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, Sakka vanished from the thirty-three gods and reappeared in front of King Nimi.
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: He said to the king,
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: ‘You’re fortunate, great king, so very fortunate.
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: The gods of the thirty-three were sitting together in the Hall of Justice, where they were singing your praises.
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: They would like to see you.
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: I shall send a chariot harnessed with a thousand thoroughbreds for you, great king.
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: Mount the heavenly chariot, great king, without wavering!’
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: King Nimi consented with silence.
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: Then, knowing that the king had consented, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, Sakka vanished from King Nimi and reappeared among the gods of the thirty-three.
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: Then Sakka, lord of gods, addressed his charioteer Mātali,
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: ‘Come, dear Mātali, harness the chariot with a thousand thoroughbreds. Then go to King Nimi and say,
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: “Great king, this chariot has been sent for you by Sakka, lord of gods.
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: Mount the heavenly chariot, great king, without wavering!”’
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: ‘Yes, lord,’ replied Mātali. He did as Sakka asked, and said to the king,
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: ‘Great king, this chariot has been sent for you by Sakka, lord of gods.
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: Mount the heavenly chariot, great king, without wavering!
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: But which way should we go—the way of those who experience the result of bad deeds, or the way of those who experience the result of good deeds?’
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: ‘Take me both ways, Mātali.’
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: Mātali brought King Nimi to the Hall of Justice.
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: Sakka saw King Nimi coming off in the distance,
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: and said to him:
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: ‘Come, great king!
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: Welcome, great king!
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: The gods of the thirty-three who wanted to see you were sitting together in the Hall of Justice, where they were singing your praises.
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: The gods of the thirty-three would like to see you.
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: Enjoy heavenly glory among the gods!’
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: ‘Enough, good fellow. Send me back to Mithilā right away.
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: That way I shall justly treat brahmins and householders, and people of town and country.
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: And I shall observe the sabbath on the fourteenth, fifteenth, and eighth of the fortnight.’
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: Then Sakka, lord of gods, addressed his charioteer Mātali,
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: ‘Come, dear Mātali, harness the chariot with a thousand thoroughbreds and send King Nimi back to Mithilā right away.’
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: ‘Yes, lord,’ replied Mātali, and did as Sakka asked.
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: And there King Nimi justly treated his people, and observed the sabbath.
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: Then, after many years, many hundred years, many thousand years had passed, King Nimi addressed his barber,
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: ‘My dear barber, when you see grey hairs growing on my head, please tell me.’
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: And all unfolded as before.
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: And having developed the four divine meditations, when his body broke up, after death, King Nimi was reborn in a good place, a realm of divinity.
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: But King Nimi had a son named Kaḷārajanaka.
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: He didn’t go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: He broke that good practice.
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: He was their final man.
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: Ānanda, you might think,
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: ‘Surely King Maghadeva, by whom that good practice was founded, must have been someone else at that time?’
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: But you should not see it like this.
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: I myself was King Maghadeva at that time.
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: I was the one who founded that good practice,
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: which was kept up by those who came after.
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: But that good practice doesn’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment. It only leads as far as rebirth in the realm of divinity.
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: But now I have founded a good practice that does lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: And what is that good practice?
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: It is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: This is the good practice I have now founded that leads to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: Ānanda, I say to you:
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: ‘You all should keep up this good practice that I have founded. Do not be my final men.’
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: When a pair of men are living, the one who breaks such good practice is their final man.
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: Ānanda, I say to you:
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: ‘You all should keep up this good practice that I have founded. Do not be my final men.’”
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: That is what the Buddha said.
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: Satisfied, Venerable Ānanda approved what the Buddha said.
title: About King Maghadeva

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: At Madhurā

segment_text: At one time Venerable Mahākaccāna was staying near Madhurā, in Gunda’s Grove.
title: At Madhurā

segment_text: King Avantiputta of Madhurā heard,
title: At Madhurā

segment_text: “It seems the ascetic Kaccāna is staying near Madhurā, in Gunda’s Grove.
title: At Madhurā

segment_text: He has this good reputation:
title: At Madhurā

segment_text: ‘He is astute, competent, clever, learned, a brilliant speaker, eloquent, mature, a perfected one.’
title: At Madhurā

segment_text: It’s good to see such perfected ones.”
title: At Madhurā

segment_text: And then King Avantiputta had the finest carriages harnessed. He mounted a fine carriage and, along with other fine carriages, set out in full royal pomp from Madhurā to see Mahākaccāna.
title: At Madhurā

segment_text: He went by carriage as far as the terrain allowed, then descended and approached Mahākaccāna on foot. They exchanged greetings, and when the greetings and polite conversation were over, the king sat down to one side and said to Mahākaccāna:
title: At Madhurā

segment_text: “Worthy Kaccāna, the brahmins say:
title: At Madhurā

segment_text: ‘Only brahmins are the best class; other classes are inferior.
title: At Madhurā

segment_text: Only brahmins are the light class; other classes are dark.
title: At Madhurā

segment_text: When he had spoken, King Avantiputta of Madhurā said to Mahākaccāna,
title: At Madhurā

segment_text: “Excellent, worthy Kaccāna! Excellent!
title: At Madhurā

segment_text: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, the worthy Kaccāna has made the teaching clear in many ways.
title: At Madhurā

segment_text: I go for refuge to the worthy Kaccāna, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
title: At Madhurā

segment_text: From this day forth, may the worthy Kaccāna remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
title: At Madhurā

segment_text: “Great king, don’t go for refuge to me.
title: At Madhurā

segment_text: You should go for refuge to that same Blessed One to whom I have gone for refuge.”
title: At Madhurā

segment_text: “But where is that Blessed One at present, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha?”
title: At Madhurā

segment_text: “Great king, the Buddha has already become fully quenched.”
title: At Madhurā

segment_text: “Worthy Kaccāna, if I heard that the Buddha was within ten leagues, or twenty, or even up to a hundred leagues away, I’d go a hundred leagues to see him.
title: At Madhurā

segment_text: But since the Buddha has become fully quenched, I go for refuge to that fully quenched Buddha, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
title: At Madhurā

segment_text: From this day forth, may the worthy Kaccāna remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
title: At Madhurā

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Bhaggas at Crocodile Hill, in the deer park at Bhesakaḷā’s Wood.
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: Now at that time a new stilt longhouse named Pink Lotus had recently been constructed for Prince Bodhi. It had not yet been occupied by an ascetic or brahmin or any person at all.
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: Then Prince Bodhi addressed the student Sañjikāputta,
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: “Please, dear Sañjikāputta, go to the Buddha, and in my name bow with your head to his feet. Ask him if he is healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: And then ask him whether he
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: might accept tomorrow’s meal from me together with the mendicant Saṅgha.”
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: “Yes, worthy sir,” Sañjikāputta replied. He did as Prince Bodhi asked, and
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: the Buddha consented with silence.
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: Then, knowing that the Buddha had consented, Sañjikāputta got up from his seat, went to Prince Bodhi, and said,
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: “I gave your message to the worthy Gotama,
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: and he accepted.”
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: And when the night had passed Prince Bodhi had delicious fresh and cooked foods prepared in his own home. He also had the Pink Lotus longhouse spread with white cloth down to the last step of the staircase. Then he said to Sañjikāputta,
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: “Please, dear Sañjikāputta, go to the Buddha, and announce the time, saying,
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: ‘Sir, it’s time. The meal is ready.’”
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: “Yes, worthy sir,” Sañjikāputta replied, and he did as he was asked.
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to Prince Bodhi’s home.
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: Now at that time Prince Bodhi was standing outside the gates waiting for the Buddha.
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: Seeing the Buddha coming off in the distance,
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: he went out to greet him. After bowing and inviting the Buddha to go first, he approached the Pink Lotus longhouse.
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: But the Buddha stopped by the last step of the staircase.
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: Then Prince Bodhi said to him,
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: “Sir, let the Blessed One ascend on the cloth! Let the Holy One ascend on the cloth!
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: It will be for my lasting welfare and happiness.”
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: But when he said this, the Buddha kept silent.
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: For a second time …
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: and a third time, Prince Bodhi said to him,
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: “Sir, let the Blessed One ascend on the cloth! Let the Holy One ascend on the cloth!
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: It will be for my lasting welfare and happiness.”
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: Then the Buddha glanced at Venerable Ānanda.
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: So Ānanda said to Prince Bodhi,
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: “Fold up the cloth, Prince.
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: The Buddha will not step upon white cloth.
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: The Realized One has sympathy for future generations.”
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: So Prince Bodhi had the cloth folded up and the seats spread out upstairs in the longhouse.
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: Then the Buddha ascended the longhouse and sat on the seats spread out together with the Saṅgha of mendicants.
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: Then Prince Bodhi served and satisfied the mendicant Saṅgha headed by the Buddha with his own hands with delicious fresh and cooked foods.
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: When the Buddha had eaten and washed his hand and bowl, Prince Bodhi took a low seat, sat to one side,
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: and said to him,
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: “Sir, this is what I think:
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: ‘Pleasure is not gained through pleasure; pleasure is gained through pain.’”
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: “Prince, before my awakening—when I was still unawakened but intent on awakening—I too thought:
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: ‘Pleasure is not gained through pleasure; pleasure is gained through pain.’
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: Some time later, while still with pristine black hair, blessed with youth, in the prime of life—though my mother and father wished otherwise, weeping with tearful faces—I shaved off my hair and beard, dressed in ocher robes, and went forth from the lay life to homelessness.
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: Once I had gone forth I set out to discover what is skillful, seeking the supreme state of sublime peace. I approached Āḷāra Kālāma and said to him,
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: ‘Reverend Kālāma, I wish to lead the spiritual life in this teaching and training.’
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: Āḷāra Kālāma replied,
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: ‘Stay, venerable.
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: This teaching is such that a sensible person can soon realize their own tradition with their own insight and live having achieved it.’
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: I quickly memorized that teaching.
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: As far as lip-recital and verbal repetition went, I spoke the doctrine of knowledge, the elder doctrine. I claimed to know and see, and so did others.
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: Then it occurred to me,
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: ‘It is not solely by mere faith that Āḷāra Kālāma declares: “I realize this teaching with my own insight, and live having achieved it.”
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: Surely he meditates knowing and seeing this teaching.’
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: So I approached Āḷāra Kālāma and said to him,
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: ‘Reverend Kālāma, to what extent do you say you’ve realized this teaching with your own insight?’
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: When I said this, he declared the dimension of nothingness.
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: Then it occurred to me,
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: ‘It’s not just Āḷāra Kālāma who has faith,
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: energy,
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: mindfulness,
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: immersion,
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: and wisdom; I too have these things.
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: Why don’t I make an effort to realize the same teaching that Āḷāra Kālāma says he has realized with his own insight?’
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: I quickly realized that teaching with my own insight, and lived having achieved it.
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: So I approached Āḷāra Kālāma and said to him,
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: ‘Reverend Kālāma, is it up to this point that you realized this teaching with your own insight, and declare having achieved it?’
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: ‘I have, reverend.’
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: ‘I too have realized this teaching with my own insight up to this point, and live having achieved it.’
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: ‘We are fortunate, reverend, so very fortunate
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: to see a venerable such as yourself as one of our spiritual companions!
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: So the teaching that I’ve realized with my own insight, and declare having achieved it, you’ve realized with your own insight, and dwell having achieved it.
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: The teaching that you’ve realized with your own insight, and dwell having achieved it, I’ve realized with my own insight, and declare having achieved it.
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: So the teaching that I know, you know, and the teaching you know, I know.
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: I am like you and you are like me.
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: Come now, reverend! We should both lead this community together.’
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: And that is how my tutor Āḷāra Kālāma placed me, his pupil, on the same position as him, and honored me with lofty praise.
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: Then it occurred to me,
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: ‘This teaching doesn’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment. It only leads as far as rebirth in the dimension of nothingness.’
title: With Prince Bodhi

segment_text: Realizing that this teaching was inadequate, I left disappointed.
