segment_text: Wouldn’t the pair that was well tamed and well trained perform the tasks of the tamed, and reach the level of the tamed?”
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: “Yes, sir.”
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: “But would the pair that was not tamed and trained perform the tasks of the tamed and reach the level of the tamed, just like the tamed pair?”
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: “No, sir.”
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: “In the same way, there are things that must be attained by someone with faith, health, integrity, energy, and wisdom. It’s not possible for a faithless, unhealthy, deceitful, lazy, witless person to attain them.”
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: “What the Buddha says appears reasonable.
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: Sir, there are these four classes:
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: aristocrats, brahmins, peasants, and workers.
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: If they had these five factors that support meditation, and if they practiced rightly,
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: would there be any difference between them?”
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: “In that case, I say that there is no difference between the freedom of one and the freedom of the other.
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: Suppose a person took dry teak wood and lit a fire and produced heat.
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: Then another person did the same using sāl wood,
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: another used mango wood,
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: while another used wood of the cluster fig.
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: What do you think, great king?
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: Would there be any difference between the fires produced by these different kinds of wood, that is, in the flame, color, or light?”
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: “No, sir.”
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: “In the same way, when fire has been churned by energy and produced by effort, I say that there is no difference between the freedom of one and the freedom of the other.”
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: “What the Buddha says appears reasonable.
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: But sir, do gods survive?”
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: “But what exactly are you asking?”
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: “Whether those gods come back to this place or not.”
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: “Those gods who are afflicted come back to this place, but those who are unafflicted do not come back.”
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: When he said this, General Viḍūḍabha said to the Buddha,
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: “Sir, will the gods who are afflicted topple or expel from their place the gods who are unafflicted?”
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: Then Venerable Ānanda thought,
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: “This General Viḍūḍabha is King Pasenadi’s son,
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: and I am the Buddha’s son.
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: Now is the time for one son to confer with another.”
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: So Ānanda addressed General Viḍūḍabha,
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: “Well then, general, I’ll ask you about this in return, and you can answer as you like.
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: What do you think, general?
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: As far as the dominion of King Pasenadi of Kosala extends, where he rules as sovereign lord, can he topple or expel from that place any ascetic or brahmin, regardless of whether they are good or bad, or whether or not they are genuine spiritual practitioners?”
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: “He can, worthy.”
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: “What do you think, general?
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: As far as the dominion of King Pasenadi does not extend, where he does not rule as sovereign lord, can he topple or expel from that place any ascetic or brahmin, regardless of whether they are good or bad, or whether or not they are genuine spiritual practitioners?”
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: “He cannot, worthy.”
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: “What do you think, general?
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: Have you heard of the gods of the thirty-three?”
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: “Yes, worthy,
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: I’ve heard of them,
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: and so has the worthy King Pasenadi.”
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: “What do you think, general?
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: Can King Pasenadi topple or expel from their place the gods of the thirty-three?”
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: “King Pasenadi can’t even see the gods of the thirty-three, so how could he possibly topple or expel them from their place?”
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: “In the same way, general, the gods who are afflicted can’t even see the gods who are unafflicted, so how could they possibly topple or expel them from their place?”
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: Then the king said to the Buddha,
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: “Sir, what is this mendicant’s name?”
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: “Ānanda, great king.”
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: “A joy he is, and a joy he seems!
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: What Venerable Ānanda says seems reasonable.
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: But sir, does a divinity survive?”
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: “But what exactly are you asking?”
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: “Whether that Divinity comes back to this place or not.”
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: “A divinity who is afflicted comes back to this place, but one who is unafflicted does not come back.”
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: Then a certain man said to the king,
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: “Great king, Sañjaya, the brahmin of the Ākāsa clan, has come.”
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: Then King Pasenadi asked Sañjaya,
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: “Brahmin, who introduced this topic of discussion to the royal compound?”
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: “It was General Viḍūḍabha, great king.”
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: But Viḍūḍabha said,
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: “It was Sañjaya, great king, the brahmin of the Ākāsa clan.”
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: Then a certain man said to the king,
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: “It’s time to depart, great king.”
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: So the king said to the Buddha,
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: “Sir, I asked you about omniscience, and you answered.
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: I endorse and accept this, and am satisfied with it.
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: I asked you about purification in the four classes,
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: about the gods,
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: and about divinities, and you answered in each case.
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: Whatever I asked the Buddha about, he answered.
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: I endorse and accept this, and am satisfied with it.
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: Well, now, sir, I must go.
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: I have many duties, and much to do.”
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: “Please, great king, go at your convenience.”
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: Then King Pasenadi approved and agreed with what the Buddha said. Then he got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before leaving.
title: At Kaṇṇakatthala

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was wandering in the land of the Videhans together with a large Saṅgha of five hundred mendicants.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: Now at that time the brahmin Brahmāyu was residing in Mithilā. He was old, elderly, and senior, advanced in years, having reached the final stage of life; he was a hundred and twenty years old. He had mastered the three Vedas, together with their vocabularies and ritual performance, their phonology and word classification, and the testaments as fifth. He knew them word-by-word, and their grammar. He was well versed in cosmology and the marks of a great man.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: He heard:
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: “It seems the ascetic Gotama—a Sakyan, gone forth from a Sakyan family—is wandering in the land of the Videhans, together with a large Saṅgha of five hundred mendicants.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: He has this good reputation:
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: He has realized with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras, and divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: He proclaims a teaching that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: It’s good to see such perfected ones.”
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: Now at that time the brahmin Brahmāyu had a pupil named Uttara. He too had mastered the Vedic curriculum.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: Brahmāyu told Uttara of the Buddha’s presence in the land of the Videhans, and added:
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: “Please, dear Uttara, go to the ascetic Gotama and find out whether or not he lives up to his reputation.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: Through you I shall learn about the worthy Gotama.”
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: “But sir, how shall I find out whether or not the ascetic Gotama lives up to his reputation?”
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: “Dear Uttara, the thirty-two marks of a great man have been handed down in our hymns. A great man who possesses these has only two possible destinies, no other.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: If he stays at home he becomes a king, a wheel-turning monarch, a just and principled king. His dominion extends to all four sides, he achieves stability in the country, and he possesses the seven treasures.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: He has the following seven treasures:
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: the wheel, the elephant, the horse, the jewel, the woman, the householder, and the commander as the seventh treasure.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: He has over a thousand sons who are valiant and heroic, crushing the armies of his enemies.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: After conquering this land girt by sea, he reigns by principle, without rod or sword.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: But if he goes forth from the lay life to homelessness, he becomes a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha, who draws back the veil from the world.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: But, dear Uttara, I am the one who gives the hymns,
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: and you are the one who receives them.”
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: “Yes, worthy sir,” replied Uttara. He got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled Brahmāyu before setting out for the land of the Videhans where the Buddha was wandering.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: Traveling stage by stage, he came to the Buddha and exchanged greetings with him.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side,
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: and scrutinized his body for the thirty-two marks of a great man.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: He saw all of them except for two,
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: which he had doubts about:
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: whether the private parts are covered in a foreskin, and the largeness of the tongue.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: Then it occurred to the Buddha,
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: “This student Uttara sees all the marks except for two,
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: which he has doubts about:
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: whether the private parts are covered in a foreskin, and the largeness of the tongue.”
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: So the Buddha used his psychic power to will that Uttara would see his private parts covered in a foreskin.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: And he stuck out his tongue and stroked back and forth on his ear holes and nostrils, and covered his entire forehead with his tongue.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: Then Uttara thought,
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: “The ascetic Gotama possesses the thirty-two marks.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: Why don’t I follow him and observe his deportment?”
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: So Uttara followed the Buddha like a shadow for seven months.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: When seven months had passed he set out wandering towards Mithilā.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: There he approached the brahmin Brahmāyu, bowed, and sat down to one side. Brahmāyu said to him,
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: “Well, dear Uttara, does the worthy Gotama live up to his reputation or not?”
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: “He does, sir.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: The worthy Gotama possesses the thirty-two marks.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: He has well-planted feet.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: On the soles of his feet there are thousand-spoked wheels, with rims and hubs, complete in every detail.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: He has stretched heels.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: He has long fingers.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: His hands and feet are tender.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: He has serried hands and feet.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: The tops of his feet are arched.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: His calves are like those of an antelope.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: When standing upright and not bending over, the palms of both hands touch the knees.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: His private parts are covered in a foreskin.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: He is golden colored; his skin shines like lustrous gold.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: He has delicate skin, so delicate that dust and dirt don’t stick to his body.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: His hairs grow one per pore.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: His hairs stand up; they’re blue-black and curl clockwise.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: His body is tall and straight-limbed.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: He has bulging muscles in seven places.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: His chest is like that of a lion.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: He is filled out between the shoulders.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: He has the proportional circumference of a banyan tree: the span of his arms equals the height of his body.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: His torso is cylindrical.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: He has ridged taste buds.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: His jaw is like that of a lion.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: He has forty teeth.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: His teeth are even.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: His teeth have no gaps.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: His teeth are perfectly white.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: He has a large tongue.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: He has the voice of the Divinity, like a cuckoo’s call.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: His eyes are indigo.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: He has eyelashes like a cow’s.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: Between his eyebrows there grows a tuft, soft and white like cotton-wool.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: The crown of his head is like a turban.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: These are the thirty-two marks of a great man possessed by the worthy Gotama.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: When he’s walking he takes the first step with the right foot.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: He doesn’t lift his foot too far or place it too near.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: He doesn’t walk too slow or too fast.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: He walks without knocking his knees or ankles together.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: When he’s walking he keeps his thighs neither too straight nor too bent, neither too tight nor too loose.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: When he walks, only the lower half of his body moves, and he walks effortlessly.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: When he turns to look he does so with the whole body.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: He doesn’t look directly up or down.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: He doesn’t look all around while walking, but focuses a plough’s length in front. Beyond that he has unhindered knowledge and vision.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: When entering an inhabited area he keeps his body neither too straight nor too bent, neither too tight nor too loose.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: He turns around neither too far nor too close to the seat. He doesn’t lean on his hand when sitting down. And he doesn’t just plonk his body down on the seat.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: When sitting in inhabited areas he doesn’t fidget with his hands or feet.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: He doesn’t sit with his knees or ankles crossed.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: He doesn’t sit with his hand holding his chin.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: When sitting in inhabited areas he doesn’t shake, tremble, quake, or get nervous, and so he is not nervous at all.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: When sitting in inhabited areas he still practices seclusion.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: When receiving water for rinsing the bowl, he holds the bowl neither too straight nor too bent, neither too tight nor too loose.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: He receives neither too little nor too much water.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: He rinses the bowl without making a sloshing noise, or spinning it around. He doesn’t put the bowl on the ground to rinse his hands; his hands and bowl are rinsed at the same time.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: He doesn’t throw the bowl rinsing water away too far or too near, or splash it about.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: When receiving rice, he holds the bowl neither too straight nor too bent, neither too close nor too loose.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: He receives neither too little nor too much rice.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: He eats sauce in a moderate proportion, and doesn’t put too much sauce on his portions.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: He chews over each portion two or three times before swallowing.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: But no grain of rice enters his body unchewed, and none remain in his mouth.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: Only then does he raise another portion to his lips.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: He eats experiencing the taste, but without experiencing greed for the taste.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: He eats food thinking of eight reasons:
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: ‘Not for fun, indulgence, adornment, or decoration, but only to sustain this body, to avoid harm, and to support spiritual practice. In this way, I shall put an end to old discomfort and not give rise to new discomfort, and I will have the means to keep going, blamelessness, and a comfortable abiding.’
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: After eating, when receiving water for washing the bowl, he holds the bowl neither too straight nor too bent, neither too tight nor too loose.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: He receives neither too little nor too much water.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: He washes the bowl without making a sloshing noise, or spinning it around. He doesn’t put the bowl on the ground to wash his hands; his hands and bowl are washed at the same time.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: He doesn’t throw the bowl washing water away too far or too near, or splash it about.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: After eating he doesn’t put the bowl on the ground too far away or too close. He’s not careless with his bowl, nor does he spend too much time on it.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: After eating he sits a while in silence, but doesn’t wait too long to give the verses of appreciation.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: After eating he expresses appreciation without criticizing the meal or expecting another one.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: Invariably, he educates, encourages, fires up, and inspires that assembly with a Dhamma talk.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: Then he gets up from his seat and leaves.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: He walks neither too fast nor too slow, without wanting to get out of there.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: He wears his robe on his body neither too high nor too low, neither too clinging nor too loose.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: The wind doesn’t blow his robe off his body.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: And dust and dirt don’t stick to his body.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: When he has gone to the monastery he sits on a seat spread out and washes his feet.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: But he doesn’t waste time with pedicures.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: When he has washed his feet, he sits down cross-legged, sets his body straight, and establishes mindfulness in his presence.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: He has no intention to hurt himself, hurt others, or hurt both.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: He only wishes for the welfare of himself, of others, of both, and of the whole world.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: In the monastery when he teaches Dhamma to an assembly, he neither flatters them nor rebukes them.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: Invariably, he educates, encourages, fires up, and inspires that assembly with a Dhamma talk.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: The sound of his voice has eight qualities:
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: it is clear, comprehensible, charming, audible, lucid, undistorted, deep, and resonant.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: He makes sure his voice is intelligible as far as the assembly goes, but the sound doesn’t extend outside the assembly.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: And when they’ve been inspired with a Dhamma talk by the worthy Gotama they get up from their seats and leave looking back at him alone, and not forgetting their lesson.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: I have seen the worthy Gotama walking and standing; entering inhabited areas, and sitting and eating there; sitting silently after eating, and expressing appreciation; going to the monastery, sitting silently there, and teaching Dhamma to an assembly there.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: Such is the worthy Gotama; such he is and more than that.”
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: When he had spoken, the brahmin Brahmāyu got up from his seat, arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha, and uttered this aphorism three times:
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: “Homage to that Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha!
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: Homage to that Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha!
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: Homage to that Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha!
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: Hopefully, some time or other I’ll get to meet him, and we can have a discussion.”
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: And then the Buddha, traveling stage by stage in the Videhan lands, arrived at Mithilā,
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: where he stayed in the Maghadeva Mango Grove.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: The brahmins and householders of Mithilā heard:
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: “It seems the ascetic Gotama—a Sakyan, gone forth from a Sakyan family—has arrived at Mithilā, where he is staying in the Maghadeva Mango Grove.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: He has this good reputation:
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: He has realized with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras, and divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: He proclaims a teaching that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: It’s good to see such perfected ones.”
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: Then the brahmins and householders of Mithilā went up to the Buddha. Before sitting down to one side, some bowed, some exchanged greetings and polite conversation, some held up their joined palms toward the Buddha, some announced their name and clan, while some kept silent.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: The brahmin Brahmāyu also heard that the Buddha had arrived.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: So he went to the Maghadeva Mango Grove together with several disciples.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: Not far from the grove he thought,
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: “It wouldn’t be appropriate for me to go to see the ascetic Gotama without first letting him know.”
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: So he addressed one of his young students:
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: “Here, young student, go to the ascetic Gotama and in my name bow with your head to his feet. Ask him if he is healthy and well, nimble, strong, and living comfortably.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: And then say:
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: ‘Worthy Gotama, , the brahmin Brahmāyu is old, elderly, and senior, advanced in years, having reached the final stage of life; he is a hundred and twenty years old. He has mastered the three Vedas, together with their vocabularies and ritual performance, their phonology and word classification, and the testaments as fifth. He knows them word-by-word, and their grammar. He is well versed in cosmology and the marks of a great man.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: Of all the brahmins and householders residing in Mithilā, Brahmāyu is said to be the foremost in
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: wealth,
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: hymns,
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: lifespan, and fame.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: He wants to see the worthy Gotama.’”
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: “Yes, worthy sir,” that young student replied. He did as he was asked, and the Buddha said,
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: “Please, student, let Brahmāyu come when he’s ready.”
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: The young student went back to Brahmāyu and said to him,
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: “Your request for an audience with the ascetic Gotama has been granted.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: Please go at your convenience.”
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: Then the brahmin Brahmāyu went up to the Buddha.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: The assembly saw him coming off in the distance,
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: and made way for him, as he was well-known and famous.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: Brahmāyu said to that retinue,
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: “Enough, gentlemen.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: Please sit on your own seats.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: I shall sit here by the ascetic Gotama.”
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: Then the brahmin Brahmāyu went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side,
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: and scrutinized the Buddha’s body for the thirty-two marks of a great man.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: He saw all of them except for two,
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: which he had doubts about:
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: whether the private parts are covered in a foreskin, and the largeness of the tongue.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: Then Brahmāyu addressed the Buddha in verse:
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: “I have learned of the thirty-two
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: marks of a great man.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: There are two that I don’t see
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: on the body of the worthy Gotama.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: Are the private parts covered in a foreskin,
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: O supreme person?
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: Though called by a word of the feminine gender,
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: perhaps your tongue is a manly one?
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: Perhaps your tongue is large,
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: as we have been informed.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: Please stick it out in its full extent,
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: and so, O seer, dispel my doubt.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: For my welfare and benefit in this life,
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: and happiness in the next.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: And I ask you to grant the opportunity
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: to ask whatever I desire.”
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: Then the Buddha thought,
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: “Brahmāyu sees all the marks except for two,
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: which he has doubts about:
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: whether the private parts are covered in a foreskin, and the largeness of the tongue.”
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: So the Buddha used his psychic power to will that Divinityyu would see his private parts covered in a foreskin.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: And he stuck out his tongue and stroked back and forth on his ear holes and nostrils, and covered his entire forehead with his tongue.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: Then the Buddha replied to Brahmāyu in verse:
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: “The thirty-two marks of a great man
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: that you have learned
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: are all found on my body:
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: so do not doubt, brahmin.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: I have known what should be known,
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: and developed what should be developed,
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: and given up what should be given up:
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: and so, brahmin, I am a Buddha.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: For your welfare and benefit in this life,
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: and happiness in the next:
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: I grant you the opportunity
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: to ask whatever you desire.”
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: Then Brahmāyu thought:
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: “My request has been granted.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: Should I ask him about
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: what is beneficial in this life or the next?”
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: Then he thought,
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: “I’m well versed in the benefits that apply to this life,
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: and others ask me about this.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: Why don’t I ask the ascetic Gotama about the benefit that specifically applies to lives to come?”
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: So Brahmāyu addressed the Buddha in verse:
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: “How do you become a brahmin?
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: And how do you become a knowledge master?
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: How a master of the three knowledges?
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: And how is one called a scholar?
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: How do you become a perfected one?
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: And how a consummate one?
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: How do you become a sage?
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: And how is one declared to be awakened?”
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: Then the Buddha replied to Brahmāyu in verse:
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: “One who knows their past lives,
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: sees heaven and places of loss,
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: and has attained the end of rebirth:
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: such a sage has perfect insight.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: They know their mind is pure,
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: completely freed from greed;
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: they’ve given up birth and death,
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: and have completed the spiritual journey.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: Gone beyond all things,
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: such a one is declared to be awakened.”
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: When he said this, Brahmāyu got up from his seat and arranged his robe on one shoulder. He bowed with his head at the Buddha’s feet, caressing them and covering them with kisses, and pronounced his name:
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: “I am the brahmin Brahmāyu, worthy Gotama!
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: I am the brahmin Brahmāyu!”
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: Then that assembly, their minds full of wonder and amazement, thought,
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: “Oh lord, how incredible, how amazing,
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: that Divinityyu, who is so well-known and famous, should show the Buddha such utmost devotion.”
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: Then the Buddha said to Brahmāyu,
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: “Enough, brahmin. Get up, and sit in your own seat, since your mind has such confidence in me.”
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: So Brahmāyu got up and sat in his own seat.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: Then the Buddha taught him step by step, with
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: a talk on giving, ethical conduct, and heaven.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: He explained the drawbacks of sensual pleasures, so sordid and corrupt, and the benefit of renunciation.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: And when the Buddha knew that Divinityyu’s mind was ready, pliable, rid of hindrances, elated, and confident he explained the special teaching of the Buddhas:
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: suffering, its origin, its cessation, and the path.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: Just as a clean cloth rid of stains would properly absorb dye,
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: in that very seat the stainless, immaculate vision of the Dhamma arose in the brahmin Brahmāyu:
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: “Everything that has a beginning has an end.”
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: Then Brahmāyu saw, attained, understood, and fathomed the Dhamma. He went beyond doubt, got rid of indecision, and became self-assured and independent of others regarding the Teacher’s instructions. He said to the Buddha:
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: “Excellent, worthy Gotama! Excellent!
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, worthy Gotama has made the teaching clear in many ways.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: I go for refuge to the worthy Gotama, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: From this day forth, may the worthy Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: Would you and the mendicant Saṅgha please accept a meal from me tomorrow?”
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: The Buddha consented with silence.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: Then, knowing that the Buddha had consented, Brahmāyu got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before leaving.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: And when the night had passed Brahmāyu had delicious fresh and cooked foods prepared in his own home. Then he had the Buddha informed of the time, saying,
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: “It’s time, worthy Gotama, the meal is ready.”
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to the home of the brahmin Brahmāyu, where he sat on the seat spread out, together with the Saṅgha of mendicants.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: For seven days, Brahmāyu served and satisfied the mendicant Saṅgha headed by the Buddha with his own hands with delicious fresh and cooked foods.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: When the seven days had passed, the Buddha departed to wander in the Videhan lands.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: Not long after the Buddha left, Brahmāyu passed away.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: Then several mendicants went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: “Sir, Brahmāyu has passed away.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: Where has he been reborn in his next life?”
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: “Mendicants, the brahmin Brahmāyu was astute. He practiced in line with the teachings, and did not trouble me about the teachings.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: With the ending of the five lower fetters, he’s been reborn spontaneously and will become extinguished there, not liable to return from that world.”
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: That is what the Buddha said.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
title: With Brahmāyu

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: With Sela

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was wandering together with a large Saṅgha of 1,250 mendicants in the land of the Aṅguttarāpans when he arrived at a town of theirs named Āpaṇa.
title: With Sela

segment_text: The matted-hair ascetic Keṇiya heard:
title: With Sela

segment_text: “It seems the ascetic Gotama—a Sakyan, gone forth from a Sakyan family—has arrived at Āpaṇa, together with a large Saṅgha of 1,250 mendicants.
title: With Sela

segment_text: He has this good reputation:
title: With Sela

segment_text: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’
title: With Sela

segment_text: He has realized with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras, and divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others.
title: With Sela

segment_text: He proclaims a teaching that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
title: With Sela

segment_text: It’s good to see such perfected ones.”
title: With Sela

segment_text: So Keṇiya approached the Buddha and exchanged greetings with him.
title: With Sela

segment_text: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side.
title: With Sela

segment_text: The Buddha educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired him with a Dhamma talk.
title: With Sela

segment_text: Then he said to the Buddha,
title: With Sela

segment_text: “Would the worthy Gotama together with the mendicant Saṅgha please accept tomorrow’s meal from me?”
title: With Sela

segment_text: When he said this, the Buddha said to him,
title: With Sela

segment_text: “The Saṅgha is large, Keṇiya; there are 1,250 mendicants. And you are devoted to the brahmins.”
title: With Sela

segment_text: For a second time, Keṇiya asked the Buddha to accept a meal offering.
title: With Sela

segment_text: “Never mind that the Saṅgha is large, with 1,250 mendicants, and that I am devoted to the brahmins.
title: With Sela

segment_text: Would the worthy Gotama together with the mendicant Saṅgha please accept tomorrow’s meal from me?”
title: With Sela

segment_text: And for a second time, the Buddha gave the same reply.
title: With Sela

segment_text: For a third time, Keṇiya asked the Buddha to accept a meal offering.
title: With Sela

segment_text: “Never mind that the Saṅgha is large, with 1,250 mendicants, and that I am devoted to the brahmins.
title: With Sela

segment_text: Would the worthy Gotama together with the mendicant Saṅgha please accept tomorrow’s meal from me?”
title: With Sela

segment_text: The Buddha consented with silence.
title: With Sela

segment_text: Then, knowing that the Buddha had consented, Keṇiya got up from his seat and went to his own hermitage. There he addressed his friends and colleagues, relatives and kin,
title: With Sela

segment_text: “My friends and colleagues, relatives and kin: please listen!
title: With Sela

segment_text: The ascetic Gotama together with the mendicant Saṅgha has been invited by me for tomorrow’s meal.
title: With Sela

segment_text: Please help me out with the manual preparations.”
title: With Sela

segment_text: “Yes, worthy sir,” they replied. Some dug ovens, some chopped wood, some washed dishes, some set out a water jar, and some spread out seats.
title: With Sela

segment_text: Meanwhile, Keṇiya set up the pavilion himself.
title: With Sela

segment_text: Now at that time the brahmin Sela was residing in Āpaṇa. He had mastered the three Vedas, together with their vocabularies and ritual performance, their phonology and word classification, and the testaments as fifth. He knew them word-by-word, and their grammar. He was well versed in cosmology and the marks of a great man. And he was teaching three hundred young students to recite the hymns.
title: With Sela

segment_text: And at that time Keṇiya was devoted to Sela.
title: With Sela

segment_text: Then Sela, while going for a walk escorted by the three hundred young students, approached Keṇiya’s hermitage.
title: With Sela

segment_text: He saw the preparations going on,
title: With Sela

segment_text: and said to Keṇiya,
title: With Sela

segment_text: “Keṇiya, is your son or daughter being married? Or are you setting up a big sacrifice? Or has King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha been invited for tomorrow’s meal?”
title: With Sela

segment_text: “There is no marriage, Sela, and the king is not coming.
title: With Sela

segment_text: Rather, I am setting up a big sacrifice.
title: With Sela

segment_text: The ascetic Gotama has arrived at Āpaṇa, together with a large Saṅgha of 1,250 mendicants.
title: With Sela

segment_text: He has this good reputation:
title: With Sela

segment_text: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’
title: With Sela

segment_text: He has been invited by me for tomorrow’s meal together with the mendicant Saṅgha.”
title: With Sela

segment_text: “Worthy Keṇiya, did you say ‘the awakened one’?”
title: With Sela

segment_text: “I said ‘the awakened one’.”
title: With Sela

segment_text: “Did you say ‘the awakened one’?”
title: With Sela

segment_text: “I said ‘the awakened one’.”
title: With Sela

segment_text: Then Sela thought,
title: With Sela

segment_text: “It’s hard to even find the word ‘awakened one’ in the world.
title: With Sela

segment_text: The thirty-two marks of a great man have been handed down in our hymns. A great man who possesses these has only two possible destinies, no other.
title: With Sela

segment_text: If he stays at home he becomes a king, a wheel-turning monarch, a just and principled king. His dominion extends to all four sides, he achieves stability in the country, and he possesses the seven treasures.
title: With Sela

segment_text: He has the following seven treasures:
title: With Sela

segment_text: the wheel, the elephant, the horse, the jewel, the woman, the householder, and the commander as the seventh treasure.
title: With Sela

segment_text: He has over a thousand sons who are valiant and heroic, crushing the armies of his enemies.
title: With Sela

segment_text: After conquering this land girt by sea, he reigns by principle, without rod or sword.
title: With Sela

segment_text: But if he goes forth from the lay life to homelessness, he becomes a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha, who draws back the veil from the world.”
title: With Sela

segment_text: “But Keṇiya, where is the Blessed One at present, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha?”
title: With Sela

segment_text: When he said this, Keṇiya pointed with his right arm and said,
title: With Sela

segment_text: “There, worthy Sela, at that line of blue forest.”
title: With Sela

segment_text: Then Sela, together with his young students, approached the Buddha.
title: With Sela

segment_text: He said to his young students,
title: With Sela

segment_text: “Come quietly, gentlemen, tread gently.
title: With Sela

segment_text: For the Buddhas are intimidating, like a lion living alone.
title: With Sela

segment_text: When I’m consulting with the ascetic Gotama, don’t interrupt.
title: With Sela

segment_text: Wait until I’ve finished speaking.”
title: With Sela

segment_text: Then Sela went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.
title: With Sela

segment_text: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side,
title: With Sela

segment_text: and scrutinized the Buddha’s body for the thirty-two marks of a great man.
title: With Sela

segment_text: He saw all of them except for two,
title: With Sela

segment_text: which he had doubts about:
title: With Sela

segment_text: whether the private parts are covered in a foreskin, and the largeness of the tongue.
title: With Sela

segment_text: Then it occurred to the Buddha,
title: With Sela

segment_text: “Sela sees all the marks except for two,
title: With Sela

segment_text: which he has doubts about:
title: With Sela

segment_text: whether the private parts are covered in a foreskin, and the largeness of the tongue.”
title: With Sela

segment_text: The Buddha used his psychic power to will that Sela would see his private parts covered in a foreskin.
title: With Sela

segment_text: And he stuck out his tongue and stroked back and forth on his ear holes and nostrils, and covered his entire forehead with his tongue.
title: With Sela

segment_text: Then Sela thought,
title: With Sela

segment_text: “The ascetic Gotama possesses the thirty-two marks completely, lacking none.
title: With Sela

segment_text: But I don’t know whether or not he is an awakened one.
title: With Sela

segment_text: I have heard that brahmins of the past who were elderly and senior, the tutors of tutors, said,
title: With Sela

segment_text: ‘Those who are perfected ones, fully awakened Buddhas reveal themselves when praised.’
title: With Sela

segment_text: Why don’t I extoll him in his presence with fitting verses?”
title: With Sela

segment_text: Then Sela extolled the Buddha in his presence with fitting verses:
title: With Sela

segment_text: “O Blessed One, your body’s perfect,
title: With Sela

segment_text: you’re radiant, handsome, lovely to behold;
title: With Sela

segment_text: golden colored,
title: With Sela

segment_text: with teeth so white; you’re strong.
title: With Sela

segment_text: The characteristics
title: With Sela

segment_text: of a handsome man,
title: With Sela

segment_text: the marks of a great man,
title: With Sela

segment_text: are all found on your body.
title: With Sela

segment_text: Your eyes are clear, your face is fair,
title: With Sela

segment_text: you’re formidable, upright, majestic.
title: With Sela

segment_text: In the midst of the Saṅgha of ascetics,
title: With Sela

segment_text: you shine like the sun.
title: With Sela

segment_text: You’re a mendicant fine to see,
title: With Sela

segment_text: with skin that shines like lustrous gold.
title: With Sela

segment_text: But with such excellent appearance,
title: With Sela

segment_text: what do you want with the ascetic life?
title: With Sela

segment_text: You’re fit to be a king,
title: With Sela

segment_text: a wheel-turning monarch, chief of charioteers,
title: With Sela

segment_text: victorious in the four quarters,
title: With Sela

segment_text: lord of the Black Plum Tree Land.
title: With Sela

segment_text: Aristocrats, nobles, and kings
title: With Sela

segment_text: ought follow your rule.
title: With Sela

segment_text: Gotama, may you reign
title: With Sela

segment_text: as king of kings, lord of mankind!”
title: With Sela

segment_text: “I am a king, Sela,
title: With Sela

segment_text: the supreme king of the teaching.
title: With Sela

segment_text: By the teaching I roll forth the wheel
title: With Sela

segment_text: which cannot be rolled back.”
title: With Sela

segment_text: “You claim to be awakened,
title: With Sela

segment_text: the supreme king of the teaching.
title: With Sela

segment_text: ‘I roll forth the teaching’:
title: With Sela

segment_text: so you say, Gotama.
title: With Sela

segment_text: Then who is your general,
title: With Sela

segment_text: the disciple who follows the Teacher’s way?
title: With Sela

segment_text: Who keeps rolling the wheel
title: With Sela

segment_text: of teaching you rolled forth?”
title: With Sela

segment_text: “By me the wheel was rolled forth,”
title: With Sela

segment_text: said the Buddha,
title: With Sela

segment_text: “the supreme wheel of teaching.
title: With Sela

segment_text: Sāriputta, taking after the Realized One,
title: With Sela

segment_text: keeps it rolling on.
title: With Sela

segment_text: I have known what should be known,
title: With Sela

segment_text: and developed what should be developed,
title: With Sela

segment_text: and given up what should be given up:
title: With Sela

segment_text: and so, brahmin, I am a Buddha.
title: With Sela

segment_text: Dispel your doubt in me—
title: With Sela

segment_text: make up your mind, brahmin!
title: With Sela

segment_text: The sight of a Buddha
title: With Sela

segment_text: is hard to find again.
title: With Sela

segment_text: I am a Buddha, brahmin,
title: With Sela

segment_text: the supreme surgeon,
title: With Sela

segment_text: one of those whose appearance in the world
title: With Sela

segment_text: is hard to find again.
title: With Sela

segment_text: A manifestation of divinity, unequaled,
title: With Sela

segment_text: crusher of Māra’s army;
title: With Sela

segment_text: having subdued all my opponents,
title: With Sela

segment_text: I rejoice, fearing nothing from any quarter.”
title: With Sela

segment_text: “Pay heed, sirs, to what
title: With Sela

segment_text: is spoken by the Clear-eyed One.
title: With Sela

segment_text: The surgeon, the great hero,
title: With Sela

segment_text: roars like a lion in the jungle.
title: With Sela

segment_text: A manifestation of divinity, unequaled,
title: With Sela

segment_text: crusher of Māra’s army;
title: With Sela

segment_text: who would not be inspired by him,
title: With Sela

segment_text: even one born in a dark class?
title: With Sela

segment_text: Those who wish may follow me;
title: With Sela

segment_text: those who don’t may go.
title: With Sela

segment_text: Right here, I’ll go forth in his presence,
title: With Sela

segment_text: the one of such splendid wisdom.”
title: With Sela

segment_text: “Sir, if you endorse
title: With Sela

segment_text: the teaching of the Buddha,
title: With Sela

segment_text: we’ll also go forth in his presence,
title: With Sela

segment_text: the one of such splendid wisdom.”
title: With Sela

title: With Assalāyana

title: With Assalāyana

segment_text: Now at that time the student Assalāyana was residing in Sāvatthī. He was young, tonsured, and sixteen years old. He had mastered the three Vedas, together with their vocabularies and ritual performance, their phonology and word classification, and the testaments as fifth. He knew them word-by-word, and their grammar. He was well versed in cosmology and the marks of a great man.

title: With Assalāyana

title: With Assalāyana

segment_text: “They say that the ascetic Gotama is a speaker of principle.
title: With Assalāyana
