segment_text: When he said this, Udena stepped down from the walking path, entered his dwelling, and sat down on the seat spread out.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: Ghoṭamukha also stepped down from the walking path and entered the dwelling, where he stood to one side.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: Udena said to him,
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: “There are seats, brahmin.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: Please sit if you wish.”
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: “I was just waiting for you to sit down.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: For how could one such as I presume to sit first without being invited?”
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: Then he took a low seat and sat to one side,
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: where he said,
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: “Worthy ascetic, there is no such thing as a principled renunciate life;
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: that’s what I think.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: Yet I have not seen honorable ones such as yourself, or a relevant teaching.”
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: “Brahmin, we can discuss this. But only if you allow what should be allowed, and reject what should be rejected. And if you ask me the meaning of anything you don’t understand, saying:
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: ‘Sir, why is this? What does that mean?’”
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: “Let us discuss this. I will do as you say.”
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: “Brahmin, these four people are found in the world.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: What four?
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: One person mortifies themselves, committed to the practice of mortifying themselves.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: One person mortifies others, committed to the practice of mortifying others.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: One person mortifies themselves and others, committed to the practice of mortifying themselves and others.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: One person doesn’t mortify either themselves or others, committed to the practice of not mortifying themselves or others.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: They live without wishes in this very life, quenched, cooled, experiencing bliss, with self become divine.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: Which one of these four people do you like the sound of?”
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: “Sir, I don’t like the sound of the first three people.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: I only like the sound of the last person, who doesn’t mortify either themselves or others.”
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: “But why don’t you like the sound of those three people?”
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: “Sir, the person who mortifies themselves does so even though they want to be happy and recoil from pain.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: That’s why I don’t like the sound of that person.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: The person who mortifies others does so even though others want to be happy and recoil from pain.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: That’s why I don’t like the sound of that person.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: The person who mortifies themselves and others does so even though both themselves and others want to be happy and recoil from pain.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: That’s why I don’t like the sound of that person.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: The person who doesn’t mortify either themselves or others—living without wishes, quenched, cooled, experiencing bliss, with self become divine—does not torment themselves or others, both of whom want to be happy and recoil from pain.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: That’s why I like the sound of that person.”
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: “There are, brahmin, these two groups of people.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: What two?
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: There’s one group of people who, being obsessed with jeweled earrings, seeks partners and children, male and female bondservants, fields and lands, and gold and currency.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: And there’s another group of people who, not being obsessed with jeweled earrings, has given up partner and children, male and female bondservants, fields and lands, and gold and currency, and goes forth from the lay life to homelessness.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: Now, brahmin, that person who doesn’t mortify either themselves or others—
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: in which of these two groups of people do you usually find such a person?”
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: “I usually find such a person in
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: the group that has gone forth from the lay life to homelessness.”
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: “Just now I understood you to say:
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: ‘Worthy ascetic, there is no such thing as a principled renunciate life;
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: that’s what I think.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: Yet I have not seen honorable ones such as yourself, or a relevant teaching.”
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: “Well, I obviously had my reasons for saying that, master Udena.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: But there is such a thing as a principled renunciate life.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: That’s what I think,
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: and that’s how you should remember me.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: Now, these four people that you’ve spoken of in a brief summary: please explain them to me in detail, out of sympathy.”
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: “Well then, brahmin, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: “Yes, worthy sir,” replied Ghoṭamukha.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: Udena said this:
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: “What person mortifies themselves, committed to the practice of mortifying themselves?
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: It’s when a person goes naked, ignoring conventions. They lick their hands, and don’t come or wait when called. They don’t consent to food brought to them, or food prepared on their behalf, or an invitation for a meal.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: They don’t receive anything from a pot or bowl; or from someone who keeps sheep, or who has a weapon or a shovel in their home; or where a couple is eating; or where there is a woman who is pregnant, breastfeeding, or who lives with a man; or where there’s a dog waiting or flies buzzing. They accept no fish or meat or beer or wine, and drink no fermented gruel.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: They go to just one house for alms, taking just one mouthful, or two houses and two mouthfuls, up to seven houses and seven mouthfuls.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: They feed on one saucer a day, two saucers a day, up to seven saucers a day.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: They eat once a day, once every second day, up to once a week, and so on, even up to once a fortnight. They live committed to the practice of eating food at set intervals.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: They eat herbs, millet, wild rice, poor rice, water lettuce, rice bran, scum from boiling rice, sesame flour, grass, or cow dung. They survive on forest roots and fruits, or eating fallen fruit.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: They wear robes of sunn hemp, mixed hemp, corpse-wrapping cloth, rags, lodh tree bark, antelope hide (whole or in strips), kusa grass, bark, wood-chips, human hair, horse-tail hair, or owls’ wings.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: They tear out their hair and beard, committed to this practice.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: They constantly stand, refusing seats.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: They squat, committed to the endeavor of squatting.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: They lie on a mat of thorns, making a mat of thorns their bed.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: They’re devoted to ritual bathing three times a day, including the evening.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: And so they live committed to practicing these various ways of mortifying and tormenting the body.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: This is called a person who mortifies themselves, being committed to the practice of mortifying themselves.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: And what person mortifies others, committed to the practice of mortifying others?
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: It’s when a person is a slaughterer of sheep, pigs, poultry, or deer, a hunter or fisher, a bandit, an executioner, a butcher of cattle, a jailer, or has some other cruel livelihood.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: This is called a person who mortifies others, being committed to the practice of mortifying others.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: And what person mortifies themselves and others, being committed to the practice of mortifying themselves and others?
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: It’s when a person is an anointed aristocratic king or a well-to-do brahmin.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: He has a new ceremonial hall built to the east of the citadel. He shaves off his hair and beard, dresses in a rough antelope hide, and smears his body with ghee and oil. Scratching his back with antlers, he enters the hall with his chief queen and the brahmin high priest.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: There he lies on the bare ground strewn with grass.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: The king feeds on the milk from one teat of a cow that has a calf of the same color. The chief queen feeds on the milk from the second teat. The brahmin high priest feeds on the milk from the third teat. The milk from the fourth teat is served to the sacred flame. The calf feeds on the remainder.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: He says:
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: ‘Slaughter this many bulls, bullocks, heifers, goats, rams, and horses for the sacrifice! Fell this many trees and reap this much grass for the sacrificial equipment!’
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: His bondservants, servants, and workers do their jobs under threat of punishment and danger, weeping with tearful faces.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: This is called a person who mortifies themselves and others, being committed to the practice of mortifying themselves and others.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: And what person doesn’t mortify either themselves or others, committed to the practice of not mortifying themselves or others,
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: living without wishes in this very life, quenched, cooled, experiencing bliss, with self become divine?
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: It’s when a Realized One arises in the world, perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: He has realized with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras, and divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: He proclaims a teaching that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: A householder hears that teaching, or a householder’s child, or someone reborn in a good family.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: They gain faith in the Realized One,
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: and reflect:
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: ‘Life at home is cramped and dirty, life gone forth is wide open.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: It’s not easy for someone living at home to lead the spiritual life utterly full and pure, like a polished shell.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: Why don’t I shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness?’
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: After some time they give up a large or small fortune, and a large or small family circle. They shave off hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: Once they’ve gone forth, they take up the training and livelihood of the mendicants. They give up killing living creatures, renouncing the rod and the sword. They’re scrupulous and kind, living full of sympathy for all living beings.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: They give up stealing. They take only what’s given, and expect only what’s given. They keep themselves clean by not thieving.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: They give up unchastity. They are chaste, set apart, avoiding the vulgar act of sex.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: They give up lying. They speak the truth and stick to the truth. They’re honest and dependable, and don’t trick the world with their words.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: They give up divisive speech. They don’t repeat in one place what they heard in another so as to divide people against each other. Instead, they reconcile those who are divided, supporting unity, delighting in harmony, loving harmony, speaking words that promote harmony.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: They give up harsh speech. They speak in a way that’s mellow, pleasing to the ear, lovely, going to the heart, polite, likable and agreeable to the people.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: They give up talking nonsense. Their words are timely, true, and meaningful, in line with the teaching and training. They say things at the right time which are valuable, reasonable, succinct, and beneficial.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: They refrain from injuring plants and seeds.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: They eat in one part of the day, abstaining from eating at night and food at the wrong time.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: They refrain from seeing shows of dancing, singing, and music .
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: They refrain from beautifying and adorning themselves with garlands, fragrance, and makeup.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: They refrain from high and luxurious beds.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: They refrain from receiving gold and currency,
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: raw grains,
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: raw meat,
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: women and girls,
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: male and female bondservants,
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: goats and sheep,
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: chickens and pigs,
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: elephants, cows, horses, and mares,
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: and fields and land.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: They refrain from running errands and messages;
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: buying and selling;
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: falsifying weights, metals, or measures;
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: bribery, fraud, cheating, and duplicity;
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: mutilation, murder, abduction, banditry, plunder, and violence.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: They’re content with robes to look after the body and almsfood to look after the belly. Wherever they go, they set out taking only these things.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: They’re like a bird: wherever it flies, wings are its only burden.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: In the same way, a mendicant is content with robes to look after the body and almsfood to look after the belly. Wherever they go, they set out taking only these things.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: When they have this entire spectrum of noble ethics, they experience a blameless happiness inside themselves.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: When they see a sight with their eyes, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: If the faculty of sight were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of sight, and achieving its restraint.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: When they hear a sound with their ears …
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: When they smell an odor with their nose …
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: When they taste a flavor with their tongue …
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: When they feel a touch with their body …
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: When they know an idea with their mind, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: If the faculty of mind were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of mind, and achieving its restraint.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: When they have this noble sense restraint, they experience an unsullied bliss inside themselves.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: They act with situational awareness when going out and coming back; when looking ahead and aside; when bending and extending the limbs; when bearing the outer robe, bowl and robes; when eating, drinking, chewing, and tasting; when urinating and defecating; when walking, standing, sitting, sleeping, waking, speaking, and keeping silent.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: When they have this entire spectrum of noble ethics, this noble contentment, this noble sense restraint, and this noble mindfulness and situational awareness,
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: they frequent a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: After the meal, they return from almsround, sit down cross-legged, set their body straight, and establish mindfulness in their presence.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: Giving up covetousness for the world, they meditate with a heart rid of covetousness, cleansing the mind of covetousness.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: Giving up ill will and malevolence, they meditate with a mind rid of ill will, full of sympathy for all living beings, cleansing the mind of ill will.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: Giving up dullness and drowsiness, they meditate with a mind rid of dullness and drowsiness, perceiving light, mindful and aware, cleansing the mind of dullness and drowsiness.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: Giving up restlessness and remorse, they meditate without restlessness, their mind peaceful inside, cleansing the mind of restlessness and remorse.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: Giving up doubt, they meditate having gone beyond doubt, not undecided about skillful qualities, cleansing the mind of doubt.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: They give up these five hindrances, corruptions of the heart that weaken wisdom.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: Then, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, they enter and remain in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, they enter and remain in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: And with the fading away of rapture, they enter and remain in the third absorption, where they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: Giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, they enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward recollection of past lives.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: They recollect many kinds of past lives. That is: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. They remember: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so they recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward knowledge of the death and rebirth of sentient beings.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds: ‘These dear beings did bad things by way of body, speech, and mind. They denounced the noble ones; they had wrong view; and they chose to act out of that wrong view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. These dear beings, however, did good things by way of body, speech, and mind. They never denounced the noble ones; they had right view; and they chose to act out of that right view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.’ And so, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: They truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: They truly understand: ‘These are defilements’ … ‘This is the origin of defilements’ … ‘This is the cessation of defilements’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of defilements’.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: Knowing and seeing like this, their mind is freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: This is called a person who neither mortifies themselves or others, being committed to the practice of not mortifying themselves or others.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: They live without wishes in this very life, quenched, cooled, experiencing bliss, with self become divine.”
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: When he had spoken, Ghoṭamukha said to him,
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: “Excellent, worthy Udena! Excellent!
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, the worthy Udena has made the teaching clear in many ways.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: I go for refuge to the worthy Udena, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: From this day forth, may the worthy Udena remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: “Brahmin, don’t go for refuge to me.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: You should go for refuge to that same Blessed One to whom I have gone for refuge.”
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: “But worthy Udena, where is the Blessed One at present, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha?”
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: “Brahmin, the Buddha has already become fully quenched.”
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: “Worthy Udena, if I heard that the Buddha was within ten leagues, or twenty, or even up to a hundred leagues away, I’d go a hundred leagues to see him.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: But since the Buddha has become fully quenched, I go for refuge to that fully quenched Buddha, to the teaching, and to the Saṅgha.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: From this day forth, may the worthy Udena remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: Worthy Udena, the king of Aṅga gives me a regular daily allowance. I will give you one portion of that.”
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: “But brahmin, what does the king of Aṅga give you as a regular daily allowance?”
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: “Five hundred dollars.”
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: “It’s not proper for us to receive gold and currency.”
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: “If that’s not proper, I will have a dwelling built for the worthy Udena.”
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: “If you want to build me a dwelling, then build an assembly hall for the Saṅgha at Pāṭaliputta.”
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: “Now I’m even more delighted and satisfied with the worthy Udena, since he encourages me to give to the Saṅgha.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: So with this allowance and another one I will have an assembly hall built for the Saṅgha at Pāṭaliputta.”
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: And so he had that hall built.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: And these days it’s called the “Ghoṭamukhī”.
title: With Ghoṭamukha

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was wandering in the land of the Kosalans together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants when he arrived at a village of the Kosalan brahmins named Opāsāda.
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: He stayed in the Godswood of sal trees to the north of Opāsāda.
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: Now at that time the brahmin Caṅkī was living in Opāsāda. It was a crown property given by King Pasenadi of Kosala, teeming with living creatures, full of hay, wood, water, and grain, a royal park endowed to a brahmin.
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: The brahmins and householders of Opāsāda heard:
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: “It seems the ascetic Gotama—a Sakyan, gone forth from a Sakyan family—has arrived at Opāsāda together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants. He is staying in the Godswood to the north.
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: He has this good reputation:
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: He has realized with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras, and divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others.
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: He proclaims a teaching that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: It’s good to see such perfected ones.”
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: Then, having departed Opāsāda, they formed into companies and headed north to the Godswood.
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: Now at that time the brahmin Caṅkī had retired to the upper floor of his stilt longhouse for his midday nap.
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: He saw the brahmins and householders heading for the Godswood,
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: and addressed his butler,
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: “My butler, why are the brahmins and householders heading north for the Godswood?”
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: “The ascetic Gotama has arrived at Opāsāda together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants. He is staying in the Godswood to the north.
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: He has this good reputation:
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: They’re going to see that worthy Gotama.”
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: “Well then, go to the brahmins and householders and say to them:
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: ‘Sirs, the brahmin Caṅkī asks
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: you to wait, as he will also go to see the ascetic Gotama.’”
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: “Yes, sir,” replied the butler, and did as he was asked.
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: Now at that time around five hundred brahmins from abroad were residing in Opāsāda on some business.

segment_text: They heard that
title: With Caṅkī

title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: “Is it really true that you are going to see the ascetic Gotama?”

segment_text: “Please don’t!

segment_text: it’s appropriate that he comes to see you.

title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: For this reason it’s not appropriate for you to go to see the ascetic Gotama;
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: it’s appropriate that he comes to see you.

You know them word-by-word, and their grammar. You are well versed in cosmology and the marks of a great man. …

segment_text: You’re a good speaker who enunciates well, with a polished, clear, and articulate voice that expresses the meaning. …

title: With Caṅkī

title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: “Well then, gentlemen, listen to why it’s appropriate for me to go to see the ascetic Gotama,

title: With Caṅkī

title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: He has the thirty-two marks of a great man. …

segment_text: King Seniya Bimbisāra of Magadha and his wives and children have gone for refuge for life to the ascetic Gotama. …
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: King Pasenadi of Kosala and his wives and children have gone for refuge for life to the ascetic Gotama. …
title: With Caṅkī

title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: The ascetic Gotama has arrived to stay in the Godswood to the north of Opāsāda.
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: Any ascetic or brahmin who comes to stay in our village district is our guest,
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: and should be honored and respected as such.
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: For this reason, too, it’s not appropriate for the worthy Gotama to come to see me,
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: rather, it’s appropriate for me to go to see him.
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: This is the extent of the worthy Gotama’s praise that I have memorized. But his praises are not confined to this,
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: for the praise of the worthy Gotama is limitless.
title: With Caṅkī

title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: rather, it’s appropriate for me to go to see him.
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: Well then, gentlemen, let’s all go to see the ascetic Gotama.”
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: Then Caṅkī together with a large group of brahmins went to the Buddha and exchanged greetings with him.
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side.
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: Now at that time the Buddha was sitting engaged in some polite conversation together with some very senior brahmins.
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: And the student Kāpaṭika was sitting in that assembly. He was young, tonsured, and sixteen years old. He had mastered the three Vedas, together with their vocabularies and ritual performance, their phonology and word classification, and the testaments as fifth. He knew them word-by-word, and their grammar. He was well versed in cosmology and the marks of a great man.
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: While the senior brahmins were conversing together with the Buddha, he interrupted.
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: Then the Buddha rebuked Kāpaṭika,
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: “Venerable Bhāradvāja, don’t interrupt the senior brahmins.
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: Wait until they’ve finished speaking.”
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: When he had spoken, Caṅkī said to the Buddha,
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: “Worthy Gotama, don’t rebuke the student Kāpaṭika.
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: He’s a gentleman, learned and astute, who enunciates well. He is capable of debating with the worthy Gotama about this.”
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: Then it occurred to the Buddha,
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: “Clearly the student Kāpaṭika will talk about the scriptural heritage of the three Vedas.
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: That’s why the brahmins put him at the front.”
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: Then Kāpaṭika thought,
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: “When the ascetic Gotama looks at me, I’ll ask him a question.”
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: Then the Buddha, knowing Kāpaṭika’s train of thought, looked at him.
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: Then Kāpaṭika thought,
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: “The ascetic Gotama is engaging with me.
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: Why don’t I ask him a question?”
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: Then he said,
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: “Worthy Gotama, regarding that which by the lineage of testament and by canonical authority is the ancient hymnal of the brahmins, the brahmins come to the categorical conclusion:
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: ‘This is the only truth, anything else is futile.’
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: What do you say about this?”
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: “Well, Bhāradvāja, is there even a single one of the brahmins who says this:
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: ‘I know this, I see this:
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: this is the only truth, anything else is futile’?”
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: “No, worthy Gotama.”
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: “Well, is there even a single tutor of the brahmins, or a tutors’ tutor, or anyone back to the seventh generation of tutors, who says this:
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: ‘I know this, I see this:
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: this is the only truth, anything else is futile’?”
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: “No, worthy Gotama.”
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: “Well, what of the ancient seers of the brahmins, namely Aṭṭhaka, Vāmaka, Vāmadeva, Vessāmitta, Yamadaggi, Aṅgīrasa, Bhāradvāja, Vāseṭṭha, Kassapa, and Bhagu? They were the authors and propagators of the hymns. Their hymnal was sung and propagated and compiled in ancient times; and these days, brahmins continue to sing and chant it, chanting what was chanted and teaching what was taught.
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: Did even they say:
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: ‘We know this, we see this:
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: this is the only truth, anything else is futile’?”
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: “No, worthy Gotama.”
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: “So, Bhāradvāja, it seems that there is not a single one of the brahmins,
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: not even anyone back to the seventh generation of tutors,
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: nor even the ancient seers of the brahmins who say:
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: ‘We know this, we see this:
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: this is the only truth, anything else is futile.’
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: Suppose there was a queue of blind men, each holding the one in front: the first one does not see, the middle one does not see, and the last one does not see.
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: In the same way, it seems to me that the brahmins’ statement turns out to be like a queue of blind men: the first one does not see, the middle one does not see, and the last one does not see.
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: What do you think, Bhāradvāja?
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: This being so, doesn’t the brahmins’ faith turn out to be baseless?”
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: “The brahmins don’t just honor this because of faith, but also because of oral transmission.”
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: “First you relied on faith, now you speak of oral transmission.
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: These five things can be seen to turn out in two different ways.
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: What five?
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: Faith, endorsement, oral transmission, reasoned train of thought, and acceptance of a view after deliberation.
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: Even though you have full faith in something, it may be vacuous, hollow, and false.
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: And even if you don’t have full faith in something, it may be true and real, not otherwise.
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: Even though you fully endorse something …
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: something may be well transmitted …
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: something may be well thought out …
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: something may be well deliberated, it may be vacuous, hollow, and false.
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: And even if something is not well deliberated, it may be true and real, not otherwise.
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: For a sensible person who is preserving truth this is not sufficient to come to the categorical conclusion:
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: ‘This is the only truth, anything else is futile.’”
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: “But worthy Gotama, how do you define the preservation of truth?”
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: “If a person has faith,
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: they preserve truth by saying, ‘Such is my faith.’
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: But they don’t yet come to the categorical conclusion:
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: ‘This is the only truth, anything else is futile.’
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: If a person has a belief …
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: or has received an oral transmission …
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: or has a reasoned reflection about something …
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: or has accepted a view after contemplation,
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: they preserve truth by saying, ‘Such is the view I have accepted after contemplation.’
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: But they don’t yet come to the categorical conclusion:
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: ‘This is the only truth, anything else is futile.’
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: That’s how the preservation of truth is defined, Bhāradvāja. I describe the preservation of truth as defined in this way.
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: But this is not yet the awakening to the truth.”
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: “That’s how the preservation of truth is defined, worthy Gotama. We regard the preservation of truth as defined in this way.
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: But worthy Gotama, how do you define awakening to the truth?”
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: “Bhāradvāja, take the case of a mendicant living supported by a town or village.
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: A householder or their child approaches and scrutinizes them for three kinds of things:
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: things that arouse greed, things that provoke hate, and things that promote delusion.
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: ‘Does this venerable have any qualities that arouse greed? Such qualities that, were their mind to be overwhelmed by them, they might say
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: that they know, even though they don’t know, or that they see, even though they don’t see;
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: or that they might encourage others to do what is for their lasting harm and suffering?’
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: Scrutinizing them they find:
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: ‘This venerable has no such qualities that arouse greed.
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: Rather, that venerable has bodily and verbal behavior like that of someone without greed.
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: And the principle that they teach is deep, hard to see, hard to understand, peaceful, sublime, beyond the scope of logic, subtle, comprehensible to the astute.
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: It’s not easy for someone with greed to teach this.’
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: Scrutinizing them in this way they see that they are purified of qualities that arouse greed. Next, they search them for qualities that provoke hate.
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: ‘Does this venerable have any qualities that provoke hate? Such qualities that, were their mind to be overwhelmed by them, they might say
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: that they know, even though they don’t know, or that they see, even though they don’t see;
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: or that they might encourage others to do what is for their lasting harm and suffering?’
title: With Caṅkī

title: With Caṅkī

title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: And the principle that they teach is deep, hard to see, hard to understand, peaceful, sublime, beyond the scope of logic, subtle, comprehensible to the astute.
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: It’s not easy for someone with hate to teach this.’
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: Scrutinizing them in this way they see that they are purified of qualities that provoke hate. Next, they scrutinize them for qualities that promote delusion.
title: With Caṅkī

title: With Caṅkī

title: With Caṅkī

title: With Caṅkī

title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: And the principle that they teach is deep, hard to see, hard to understand, peaceful, sublime, beyond the scope of logic, subtle, comprehensible to the astute.
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: It’s not easy for someone with delusion to teach this.’
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: Scrutinizing them in this way they see that they are purified of qualities that promote delusion.
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: Next, they place faith in them. When faith has arisen they approach the teacher. They pay homage, actively listen, hear the teachings, remember the teachings, reflect on their meaning, and accept them after deliberation. Then enthusiasm springs up; they apply zeal, weigh up, and strive. Striving, they directly realize the ultimate truth, and see it with penetrating wisdom.
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: That’s how the awakening to truth is defined, Bhāradvāja. I describe the awakening to truth as defined in this way.
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: But this is not yet the attainment of truth.”
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: “That’s how the awakening to truth is defined, worthy Gotama. I regard the awakening to truth as defined in this way.
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: But worthy Gotama, how do you define the attainment of truth?”
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: “By the cultivation, development, and making much of these very same things there is the attainment of truth.
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: That’s how the attainment of truth is defined, Bhāradvāja. I describe the attainment of truth as defined in this way.”
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: “That’s how the attainment of truth is defined, worthy Gotama. I regard the attainment of truth as defined in this way.
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: But what quality is helpful for arriving at the truth?”
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: “Striving is helpful for arriving at the truth.
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: If you don’t strive, you won’t arrive at the truth.
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: You arrive at the truth because you strive.
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: That’s why striving is helpful for arriving at the truth.”
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: “But what quality is helpful for striving?”
title: With Caṅkī

title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: Enthusiasm is helpful for zeal …
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: Acceptance of the teachings after deliberation is helpful for enthusiasm …
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: Reflecting on the meaning of the teachings is helpful for accepting them after deliberation …
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: Remembering the teachings is helpful for reflecting on their meaning …
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: Hearing the teachings is helpful for remembering the teachings …
title: With Caṅkī

title: With Caṅkī

title: With Caṅkī

title: With Caṅkī

title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: You approach a teacher because you have faith.
title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: That’s why faith is helpful for approaching a teacher.”
title: With Caṅkī

title: With Caṅkī

title: With Caṅkī

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

segment_text: Then Esukārī the brahmin went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.
title: With Esukārī

segment_text: “Worthy Gotama, the brahmins prescribe four kinds of service:

segment_text: for a brahmin, an aristocrat, a peasant, and a menial.

segment_text: This is the service they prescribe for a brahmin:
title: With Esukārī

segment_text: ‘A brahmin, an aristocrat, a peasant, and a menial may all serve a brahmin.’
title: With Esukārī

segment_text: This is the service they prescribe for an aristocrat:
title: With Esukārī

segment_text: ‘An aristocrat, a peasant, and a menial may all serve an aristocrat.’
title: With Esukārī

segment_text: This is the service they prescribe for a peasant:
title: With Esukārī

segment_text: ‘A peasant or a menial may serve a peasant.’
title: With Esukārī

segment_text: This is the service they prescribe for a menial:
title: With Esukārī

segment_text: ‘Only a menial may serve a menial.
title: With Esukārī

segment_text: For who else will serve a menial?’
title: With Esukārī

segment_text: These are the four kinds of service that the brahmins prescribe.
title: With Esukārī

segment_text: What do you say about this?”
title: With Esukārī

segment_text: “But brahmin, did the whole world authorize the brahmins to prescribe these four kinds of service?”
title: With Esukārī

segment_text: “No, worthy Gotama.”

segment_text: “It’s as if they were to force a chop on a poor, penniless person, telling them, ‘Eat this meat and pay for it!’

segment_text: In the same way, the brahmins have prescribed these four kinds of service without the consent of those ascetics and brahmins.

segment_text: Brahmin, I don’t say that you should serve everyone, nor do I say that you shouldn’t serve anyone.

segment_text: I say that you shouldn’t serve someone if serving them makes you worse, not better.

segment_text: And I say that you should serve someone if serving them makes you better, not worse.

title: With Esukārī

segment_text: Answering rightly, an aristocrat would say,
title: With Esukārī

segment_text: ‘Someone in whose service I get better.’

segment_text: Listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”

segment_text: “Yes, worthy sir,” replied Dhanañjāni.

segment_text: Venerable Sāriputta said this:
title: With Dhanañjāni

segment_text: “And what is a path to company with Divinity?
title: With Dhanañjāni

segment_text: Firstly, a mendicant meditates spreading a heart full of love to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of love to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.
title: With Dhanañjāni

segment_text: This is a path to company with Divinity.
title: With Dhanañjāni

segment_text: Furthermore, a mendicant meditates spreading a heart full of compassion …
title: With Dhanañjāni

segment_text: They meditate spreading a heart full of rejoicing …
title: With Dhanañjāni

segment_text: They meditate spreading a heart full of equanimity to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of equanimity to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.
title: With Dhanañjāni

segment_text: This is a path to company with Divinity.”
title: With Dhanañjāni

segment_text: “Well then, worthy Sāriputta, in my name bow with your head at the Buddha’s feet. Say to him:

segment_text: He bows with his head to your feet.’”

segment_text: Then Sāriputta, after establishing Dhanañjāni in the inferior realm of divinity, got up from his seat and left while there was still more left to do.
title: With Dhanañjāni

segment_text: Then the Buddha said to the mendicants,
title: With Dhanañjāni

segment_text: “Mendicants, Sāriputta, after establishing Dhanañjāni in the inferior realm of divinity, got up from his seat and left while there was still more left to do.”

title: With Dhanañjāni

segment_text: “Sir, the brahmin Dhanañjāni is sick, suffering, gravely ill.

segment_text: He bows with his head to your feet.”

segment_text: “But Sāriputta, after establishing Dhanañjāni in the inferior realm of divinity, why did you get up from your seat and leave while there was still more left to do?”

title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying in a forest near Icchānaṅgala.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: Now at that time several very well-known well-to-do brahmins were residing in Icchānaṅgala. They included
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: the brahmins Caṅkī, Tārukkha, Pokkharasāti, Jānussoṇi, Todeyya, and others.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: Then as the students Vāseṭṭha and Bhāradvāja were going for a walk they began to discuss the question:
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: “How do you become a brahmin?”
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: Bhāradvāja said this:
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: “When you’re well born on both your mother’s and father’s side, of pure descent, with irrefutable and impeccable genealogy back to the seventh paternal generation—
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: then you’re a brahmin.”
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: Vāseṭṭha said this:
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: “When you’re ethical and accomplished in doing your duties—
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: then you’re a brahmin.”
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: But neither was able to persuade the other.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: So Vāseṭṭha said to Bhāradvāja,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: “Worthy Bhāradvāja, the ascetic Gotama—a Sakyan, gone forth from a Sakyan family—is staying in a forest near Icchānaṅgala.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: He has this good reputation:
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: Come, let’s go to see him and ask him about this matter.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: As he answers, so we’ll remember it.”
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: “Yes, worthy sir,” replied Bhāradvāja.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: So they went to the Buddha and exchanged greetings with him.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, they sat down to one side,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: and Vāseṭṭha addressed the Buddha in verse:
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: “We’re both authorized masters
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: of the three Vedas.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: I’m a student of Pokkharasāti,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: and he of Tārukkha.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: We’re fully qualified
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: in all the Vedic experts teach.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: As philologists and grammarians,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: we match our tutors in recitation.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: We have a dispute
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: regarding genealogy.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: For Bhāradvāja says that
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: one is a brahmin due to birth,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: but I declare it’s because of one’s deeds.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: Oh Clear-eyed One, know this as our debate.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: Since neither of us was able
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: to convince the other,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: we’ve come to ask you, sir,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: renowned as the awakened one.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: As people honor with joined palms
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: the moon on the cusp of waxing,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: bowing, they revere
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: Gotama in the world.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

title: With Vāseṭṭha

title: With Vāseṭṭha

title: With Vāseṭṭha

title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: We don’t know, please tell us,
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: so we can recognize a brahmin.”

segment_text: “Excellent, worthy Gotama! Excellent!
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, worthy Gotama has made the teaching clear in many ways.
title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: We go for refuge to the worthy Gotama, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.

title: With Vāseṭṭha

segment_text: So I have heard.
