segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
title: With Subha

segment_text: Now at that time the student Subha, Todeyya’s son, was residing in Sāvatthī at a certain householder’s home on some business.
title: With Subha

segment_text: Then Subha said to that householder,
title: With Subha

segment_text: “Householder, I have heard that
title: With Subha

segment_text: Sāvatthī does not lack for perfected ones.
title: With Subha

segment_text: What ascetic or brahmin might we pay homage to today?”
title: With Subha

segment_text: “Sir, the Buddha is staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
title: With Subha

segment_text: You can pay homage to him.”
title: With Subha

segment_text: Acknowledging that householder, Subha went to the Buddha and exchanged greetings with him.
title: With Subha

segment_text: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to the Buddha:
title: With Subha

segment_text: “Worthy Gotama, the brahmins say:
title: With Subha

segment_text: ‘Laypeople succeed in the system of the skillful teaching, not renunciates.’
title: With Subha

segment_text: What do you say about this?”
title: With Subha

segment_text: “On this point, student, I speak after analyzing the question,
title: With Subha

segment_text: not one-sidedly.
title: With Subha

segment_text: I don’t praise wrong practice for either laypeople or renunciates.
title: With Subha

segment_text: Because of wrong practice, neither laypeople nor renunciates succeed in the system of the skillful teaching.
title: With Subha

segment_text: I praise right practice for both laypeople and renunciates.
title: With Subha

segment_text: Because of right practice, both laypeople and renunciates succeed in the system of the skillful teaching.”
title: With Subha

segment_text: “Worthy Gotama, the brahmins say:
title: With Subha

segment_text: ‘Since the work of the lay life has many requirements, duties, issues, and undertakings it is very fruitful.
title: With Subha

segment_text: But since the work of the renunciate has few requirements, duties, issues, and undertakings it is not very fruitful.’
title: With Subha

segment_text: What do you say about this?”
title: With Subha

segment_text: “On this point, too, I speak after analyzing the question,
title: With Subha

segment_text: not one-sidedly.
title: With Subha

segment_text: Some work has many requirements, duties, issues, and undertakings, and when it fails it’s not very fruitful.
title: With Subha

segment_text: Some work has many requirements, duties, issues, and undertakings, and when it succeeds it is very fruitful.
title: With Subha

segment_text: Some work has few requirements, duties, issues, and undertakings, and when it fails it’s not very fruitful.
title: With Subha

segment_text: Some work has few requirements, duties, issues, and undertakings, and when it succeeds it is very fruitful.
title: With Subha

segment_text: And what work has many requirements, duties, issues, and undertakings, and when it fails it’s not very fruitful?
title: With Subha

segment_text: Farming.
title: With Subha

segment_text: And what work has many requirements, duties, issues, and undertakings, and when it succeeds it is very fruitful?
title: With Subha

segment_text: Again, it is farming.
title: With Subha

segment_text: And what work has few requirements, duties, issues, and undertakings, and when it fails it’s not very fruitful?
title: With Subha

segment_text: Trade.
title: With Subha

segment_text: And what work has few requirements, duties, issues, and undertakings, and when it succeeds it is very fruitful?
title: With Subha

segment_text: Again, it’s trade.
title: With Subha

segment_text: The lay life is like farming in that it’s work with many requirements and when it fails it’s not very fruitful;
title: With Subha

segment_text: but when it succeeds it is very fruitful.
title: With Subha

segment_text: The renunciate life is like trade in that it’s work with few requirements and when it fails it’s not very fruitful;
title: With Subha

segment_text: but when it succeeds it is very fruitful.”
title: With Subha

segment_text: “Worthy Gotama, the brahmins prescribe five things for making merit and succeeding in the skillful.”
title: With Subha

segment_text: “If you don’t mind,
title: With Subha

segment_text: please explain these in this assembly.”
title: With Subha

segment_text: “It’s no trouble when good fellows such as yourself are sitting here.”
title: With Subha

segment_text: “Well, speak then, student.”
title: With Subha

segment_text: “Worthy Gotama, truth is the first thing.
title: With Subha

segment_text: Fervor is the second thing.
title: With Subha

segment_text: Chastity is the third thing.
title: With Subha

segment_text: Recitation is the fourth thing.
title: With Subha

segment_text: Generosity is the fifth thing.
title: With Subha

segment_text: These are the five things that the brahmins prescribe for making merit and succeeding in the skillful.
title: With Subha

segment_text: What do you say about this?”
title: With Subha

segment_text: “Well, student, is there even a single one of the brahmins who says this:
title: With Subha

segment_text: ‘I declare the result of these five things after realizing it with my own insight’?”
title: With Subha

segment_text: “No, worthy Gotama.”
title: With Subha

segment_text: “Well, is there even a single tutor of the brahmins, or a tutor’s tutor, or anyone back to the seventh generation of tutors, who says this:
title: With Subha

segment_text: ‘I declare the result of these five things after realizing it with my own insight’?”
title: With Subha

segment_text: “No, worthy Gotama.”
title: With Subha

segment_text: “Well, what of the ancient seers of the brahmins, namely Aṭṭhaka, Vāmaka, Vāmadeva, Vessāmitta, Yamadaggi, Aṅgīrasa, Bhāradvāja, Vāseṭṭha, Kassapa, and Bhagu? They were the authors and propagators of the hymns. Their hymnal was sung and propagated and compiled in ancient times; and these days, brahmins continue to sing and chant it, chanting what was chanted and teaching what was taught.
title: With Subha

segment_text: Did even they say:
title: With Subha

segment_text: ‘We declare the result of these five things after realizing it with our own insight’?”
title: With Subha

segment_text: “No, worthy Gotama.”
title: With Subha

segment_text: “So, student, it seems that there is not a single one of the brahmins,
title: With Subha

segment_text: not even anyone back to the seventh generation of tutors,
title: With Subha

segment_text: nor even the ancient seers of the brahmins
title: With Subha

segment_text: who says:
title: With Subha

segment_text: ‘We declare the result of these five things after realizing it with our own insight.’
title: With Subha

segment_text: Suppose there was a queue of blind men, each holding the one in front: the first one does not see, the middle one does not see, and the last one does not see.
title: With Subha

segment_text: In the same way, it seems to me that the brahmins’ statement turns out to be comparable to a queue of blind men: the first one does not see, the middle one does not see, and the last one does not see.”
title: With Subha

segment_text: When he said this, Subha became angry and upset with the Buddha because of the simile of the queue of blind men. He even attacked and badmouthed the Buddha himself, saying,
title: With Subha

segment_text: “The ascetic Gotama will be worsted!” He said to the Buddha:
title: With Subha

segment_text: “Worthy Gotama, the brahmin Pokkharasāti Upamañña of the Subhaga Forest says:
title: With Subha

segment_text: ‘This is exactly what happens with some ascetics and brahmins. They claim to have a superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones.
title: With Subha

segment_text: But their statement turns out to be a joke—mere words, vacuous and hollow.
title: With Subha

segment_text: For how on earth can a human being know or see or realize a superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones?
title: With Subha

segment_text: That is not possible.’”
title: With Subha

segment_text: “But student, does Pokkharasāti understand the minds of all these ascetics and brahmins, having comprehended them with his mind?”
title: With Subha

segment_text: “Worthy Gotama, Pokkharasāti doesn’t even know the mind of his own bonded maid Puṇṇikā, so how could he know all those ascetics and brahmins?”
title: With Subha

segment_text: “Suppose there was a person blind from birth. They couldn’t see sights that are dark or bright, or blue, yellow, red, or magenta. They couldn’t see even and uneven ground, or the stars, or the moon and sun.
title: With Subha

segment_text: They’d say:
title: With Subha

segment_text: ‘There’s no such thing as dark and bright sights, and no-one who sees them.
title: With Subha

segment_text: There’s no such thing as blue,
title: With Subha

segment_text: yellow,
title: With Subha

segment_text: red,
title: With Subha

segment_text: magenta,
title: With Subha

segment_text: even and uneven ground,
title: With Subha

segment_text: stars,
title: With Subha

segment_text: moon and sun, and no-one who sees these things.
title: With Subha

segment_text: I don’t know it or see it,
title: With Subha

segment_text: therefore it doesn’t exist.’
title: With Subha

segment_text: Would they be speaking rightly?”
title: With Subha

segment_text: “No, worthy Gotama.
title: With Subha

segment_text: There are such things as dark and bright sights, and one who sees them.
title: With Subha

segment_text: There is blue,
title: With Subha

segment_text: yellow,
title: With Subha

segment_text: red,
title: With Subha

segment_text: magenta,
title: With Subha

segment_text: even and uneven ground,
title: With Subha

segment_text: stars,
title: With Subha

segment_text: moon and sun, and one who sees these things.
title: With Subha

segment_text: So it’s not right to say this: ‘I don’t know it or see it,
title: With Subha

segment_text: therefore it doesn’t exist.’”
title: With Subha

segment_text: “In the same way, Pokkharasāti is blind and sightless.
title: With Subha

segment_text: It is quite impossible for him to know or see or realize a superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones.
title: With Subha

segment_text: What do you think, student?
title: With Subha

segment_text: There are well-to-do brahmins of Kosala such as
title: With Subha

segment_text: the brahmins Caṅkī, Tārukkha, Pokkharasāti, Jānussoṇi, and your father Todeyya. What’s better for them: that their speech agrees or disagrees with the consensus of opinion?”
title: With Subha

segment_text: “That it agrees, worthy Gotama.”
title: With Subha

segment_text: “What’s better for them: that their speech is thoughtful or thoughtless?”
title: With Subha

segment_text: “That it is thoughtful.”
title: With Subha

segment_text: “What’s better for them: that their speech follows reflection or is unreflective?”
title: With Subha

segment_text: “That it follows reflection.”
title: With Subha

segment_text: “What’s better for them: that their speech is beneficial or worthless?”
title: With Subha

segment_text: “That it’s beneficial.”
title: With Subha

segment_text: “What do you think, student?
title: With Subha

segment_text: If this is so, does Pokkharasāti’s speech agree or disagree with the consensus of opinion?”
title: With Subha

segment_text: “It disagrees, worthy Gotama.”
title: With Subha

segment_text: “Is it thoughtful or thoughtless?”
title: With Subha

segment_text: “Thoughtless.”
title: With Subha

segment_text: “Is it reflective or unreflective?”
title: With Subha

segment_text: “Unreflective.”
title: With Subha

segment_text: “Is it beneficial or worthless?”
title: With Subha

segment_text: “Worthless.”
title: With Subha

segment_text: “Student, there are these five hindrances.
title: With Subha

segment_text: What five?
title: With Subha

segment_text: The hindrances of sensual desire, ill will, dullness and drowsiness, restlessness and remorse, and doubt.
title: With Subha

segment_text: These are the five hindrances.
title: With Subha

segment_text: Pokkharasāti is veiled, shrouded, covered, and engulfed by these five hindrances.
title: With Subha

segment_text: It is quite impossible for him to know or see or realize a superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones.
title: With Subha

segment_text: There are these five kinds of sensual stimulation.
title: With Subha

segment_text: What five?
title: With Subha

segment_text: There are sights known by the eye, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
title: With Subha

segment_text: There are sounds known by the ear …
title: With Subha

segment_text: smells known by the nose …
title: With Subha

segment_text: tastes known by the tongue …
title: With Subha

segment_text: touches known by the body, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
title: With Subha

segment_text: These are the five kinds of sensual stimulation.
title: With Subha

segment_text: Pokkharasāti enjoys himself with these five kinds of sensual stimulation, tied, infatuated, attached, blind to the drawbacks, and not understanding the escape.
title: With Subha

segment_text: It is quite impossible for him to know or see or realize a superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones.
title: With Subha

segment_text: What do you think, student?
title: With Subha

segment_text: Which would have better flames, color, and radiance: a fire that depends on grass and logs as fuel, or one that does not?”
title: With Subha

segment_text: “If it were possible for a fire to burn without depending on grass and logs as fuel, that would have better flames, color, and radiance.”
title: With Subha

segment_text: “But it isn’t possible, except by psychic power.
title: With Subha

segment_text: Rapture that depends on the five kinds of sensual stimulation is like a fire that depends on grass and logs as fuel.
title: With Subha

segment_text: Rapture that’s apart from sensual pleasures and unskillful qualities is like a fire that doesn’t depend on grass and logs as fuel.
title: With Subha

segment_text: And what is rapture that’s apart from sensual pleasures and unskillful qualities?
title: With Subha

segment_text: It’s when a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
title: With Subha

segment_text: This is rapture that’s apart from sensual pleasures and unskillful qualities.
title: With Subha

segment_text: Furthermore, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, they enter and remain in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.
title: With Subha

segment_text: This too is rapture that’s apart from sensual pleasures and unskillful qualities.
title: With Subha

segment_text: Of the five things that the brahmins prescribe for making merit and succeeding in the skillful, which do they say is the most fruitful?”
title: With Subha

segment_text: “Generosity.”
title: With Subha

segment_text: “What do you think, student?
title: With Subha

segment_text: Suppose a brahmin was setting up a big sacrifice.
title: With Subha

segment_text: Then two brahmins came along,
title: With Subha

segment_text: thinking to participate.
title: With Subha

segment_text: Then one of those brahmins thought:
title: With Subha

segment_text: ‘Oh, I hope that I alone get the best seat, the best drink, and the best almsfood in the refectory, not some other brahmin.’
title: With Subha

segment_text: But it’s possible that some other brahmin gets the best seat, the best drink, and the best almsfood in the refectory.
title: With Subha

segment_text: Thinking, ‘Some other brahmin has got the best seat, the best drink, the best almsfood,’
title: With Subha

segment_text: they get angry and bitter.
title: With Subha

segment_text: What do the brahmins say is the result of this?”
title: With Subha

segment_text: “Worthy Gotama, brahmins don’t give gifts so that
title: With Subha

segment_text: others will get angry and upset.
title: With Subha

segment_text: Rather, they give only out of sympathy.”
title: With Subha

segment_text: “In that case, isn’t compassion a sixth ground for making merit?”
title: With Subha

segment_text: “In that case, compassion is a sixth ground for making merit.”
title: With Subha

segment_text: “Of the five things that the brahmins prescribe for making merit and succeeding in the skillful, where do you usually find them:
title: With Subha

segment_text: among laypeople or renunciates?”
title: With Subha

segment_text: “Mostly among renunciates, and less so among lay people.
title: With Subha

segment_text: For a lay person has many requirements, duties, issues, and undertakings, and they can’t always tell the truth,
title: With Subha

segment_text: be fervent,
title: With Subha

segment_text: be chaste,
title: With Subha

segment_text: do lots of recitation,
title: With Subha

segment_text: or be very generous.
title: With Subha

segment_text: But a renunciate has few requirements, duties, issues, and undertakings, and they can always tell the truth, be fervent,
title: With Subha

segment_text: be chaste,
title: With Subha

segment_text: do lots of recitation,
title: With Subha

segment_text: and be very generous.
title: With Subha

segment_text: Of the five things that the brahmins prescribe for making merit and succeeding in the skillful, I usually find them among renunciates, and less so among laypeople.”
title: With Subha

segment_text: “I say that the five things prescribed by the brahmins for making merit are prerequisites of the mind for
title: With Subha

segment_text: developing a mind free of enmity and ill will.
title: With Subha

segment_text: Take a mendicant who speaks the truth.
title: With Subha

segment_text: Thinking, ‘I’m truthful,’ they find inspiration in the meaning and the teaching, and find joy connected with the teaching.
title: With Subha

segment_text: And I say that joy connected with the skillful is a prerequisite of the mind for
title: With Subha

segment_text: developing a mind free of enmity and ill will.
title: With Subha

segment_text: Take a mendicant who is fervent …
title: With Subha

segment_text: is chaste …
title: With Subha

segment_text: does lots of recitation …
title: With Subha

segment_text: and is very generous.
title: With Subha

segment_text: Thinking, ‘I’m very generous,’ they find inspiration in the meaning and the teaching, and find joy connected with the teaching.
title: With Subha

segment_text: And I say that joy connected with the skillful is a prerequisite of the mind for
title: With Subha

segment_text: developing a mind free of enmity and ill will.
title: With Subha

segment_text: I say that these five things prescribed by the brahmins for making merit are prerequisites of the mind for
title: With Subha

segment_text: developing a mind free of enmity and ill will.”
title: With Subha

segment_text: When he had spoken, Subha said to him,
title: With Subha

segment_text: “Worthy Gotama, I have heard that
title: With Subha

segment_text: the ascetic Gotama knows a path to company with divinity.”
title: With Subha

segment_text: “What do you think, student?
title: With Subha

segment_text: Is the village of Naḷakāra nearby?”
title: With Subha

segment_text: “Yes it is, sir.”
title: With Subha

segment_text: “What do you think, student? Suppose a person was born and raised in Naḷakāra.
title: With Subha

segment_text: And as soon as they left the town some people asked them for the road to Naḷakāra.
title: With Subha

segment_text: Would they be slow or hesitant to answer?”
title: With Subha

segment_text: “No, worthy Gotama.
title: With Subha

segment_text: Why is that?
title: With Subha

segment_text: Because they were born and raised in Naḷakāra. They’re well acquainted with all the roads to the village.”
title: With Subha

segment_text: “Still, it’s possible they might be slow or hesitant to answer. But the Realized One is never slow or hesitant when questioned about the realm of divinity or the practice that leads to the realm of divinity.
title: With Subha

segment_text: I understand divinity, the realm of divinity, and the practice that leads to the realm of divinity, practicing in accordance with which one is reborn in the realm of divinity.”
title: With Subha

segment_text: “Worthy Gotama, I have heard that
title: With Subha

segment_text: the ascetic Gotama teaches a path to company with divinity.
title: With Subha

segment_text: Please teach me that path.”
title: With Subha

segment_text: “Well then, student, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”
title: With Subha

segment_text: “Yes, worthy sir,” replied Subha.
title: With Subha

segment_text: The Buddha said this:
title: With Subha

segment_text: “And what is a path to company with divinity?
title: With Subha

segment_text: Firstly, a mendicant meditates spreading a heart full of love to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of love to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.
title: With Subha

segment_text: When the heart’s release by love has been developed like this, any limited deeds they’ve done don’t remain or persist there.
title: With Subha

segment_text: Suppose there was a powerful horn blower. They’d easily make themselves heard in the four quarters.
title: With Subha

segment_text: In the same way, when the heart’s release by love has been developed like this, any limited deeds they’ve done don’t remain or persist there.
title: With Subha

segment_text: This is a path to company with divinity.
title: With Subha

segment_text: Furthermore, a mendicant meditates spreading a heart full of compassion …
title: With Subha

segment_text: They meditate spreading a heart full of rejoicing …
title: With Subha

segment_text: They meditate spreading a heart full of equanimity to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of equanimity to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.
title: With Subha

segment_text: When the heart’s release by equanimity has been developed and cultivated like this, any limited deeds they’ve done don’t remain or persist there.
title: With Subha

segment_text: Suppose there was a powerful horn blower. They’d easily make themselves heard in the four quarters.
title: With Subha

segment_text: In the same way, when the heart’s release by equanimity has been developed and cultivated like this, any limited deeds they’ve done don’t remain or persist there.
title: With Subha

segment_text: This too is a path to company with divinity.”
title: With Subha

segment_text: When he had spoken, Subha said to him,
title: With Subha

segment_text: “Excellent, worthy Gotama! Excellent!
title: With Subha

segment_text: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, worthy Gotama has made the teaching clear in many ways.
title: With Subha

segment_text: I go for refuge to the worthy Gotama, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
title: With Subha

segment_text: From this day forth, may the worthy Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.
title: With Subha

segment_text: Well, now, worthy Gotama, I must go.
title: With Subha

segment_text: I have many duties, and much to do.”
title: With Subha

segment_text: “Please, student, go at your convenience.”
title: With Subha

segment_text: And then Subha approved and agreed with what the Buddha said. He got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before leaving.
title: With Subha

segment_text: Now at that time the brahmin Jānussoṇi drove out from Sāvatthī in the middle of the day in an all-white chariot drawn by mares.
title: With Subha

segment_text: He saw the student Subha coming off in the distance,
title: With Subha

segment_text: and said to him,
title: With Subha

segment_text: “So, worthy Bhāradvāja, where are you coming from in the middle of the day?”
title: With Subha

segment_text: “Just now, good fellow, I’ve come from the presence of the ascetic Gotama.”
title: With Subha

segment_text: “What do you think of the ascetic Gotama’s lucidity of wisdom? Do you think he’s astute?”
title: With Subha

segment_text: “My good man, who am I to judge the ascetic Gotama’s lucidity of wisdom?
title: With Subha

segment_text: You’d really have to be on the same level to judge his lucidity of wisdom.”
title: With Subha

segment_text: “Worthy Bhāradvāja praises the ascetic Gotama with lofty praise indeed.”
title: With Subha

segment_text: “Who am I to praise the ascetic Gotama?
title: With Subha

segment_text: He is praised by the praised as the best among gods and humans.
title: With Subha

segment_text: The five things that the brahmins prescribe for making merit and succeeding in the skillful
title: With Subha

segment_text: he says are prerequisites of the mind for
title: With Subha

segment_text: developing a mind free of enmity and ill will.”
title: With Subha

segment_text: When he had spoken, Jānussoṇi got down from his chariot, arranged his robe over one shoulder, raised his joined palms toward the Buddha, and expressed this heartfelt sentiment three times,
title: With Subha

segment_text: “King Pasenadi of Kosala is lucky, so very lucky
title: With Subha

segment_text: that the Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha is living in his realm!”
title: With Subha

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was wandering in the land of the Kosalans together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants.
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: Now at that time a brahmin lady named Dhanañjānī was residing at Caṇḍalakappa. She was devoted to the Buddha, the teaching, and the Saṅgha.
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: Once, she tripped and expressed this heartfelt sentiment three times:
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: “Homage to that Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha!
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: Homage to that Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha!
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: Homage to that Blessed One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha!”
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: Now at that time the student Saṅgārava was residing in Caṇḍalakappa. He was young, newly tonsured; he was sixteen years old. He had mastered the three Vedas, together with their vocabularies and ritual performance, their phonology and word classification, and the testaments as fifth. He knew them word-by-word, and their grammar. He was well versed in cosmology and the marks of a great man.
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: Hearing Dhanañjānī’s exclamation,
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: he said to her,
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: “The brahmin lady Dhanañjānī is a disgrace! Though brahmins proficient in the three Vedas are found, she praises that shaveling, that fake ascetic.”
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: “But dearest boy, you don’t understand the Buddha’s ethics and wisdom.
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: If you did, you’d never think of abusing or insulting him.”
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: “Well then, ma’am, let me know when the Buddha arrives in Caṇḍalakappa.”
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: “I will, dearest,” she replied.
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: And then the Buddha, traveling stage by stage in the Kosalan lands, arrived at Caṇḍalakappa,
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: where he stayed in the mango grove of the Todeyya brahmins.
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: Dhanañjānī heard that he had arrived.
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: So she went to Saṅgārava and told him, adding,
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: “Please, dearest boy, go at your convenience.”
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: “Yes, ma’am,” replied Saṅgārava. He went to the Buddha and exchanged greetings with him.
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to the Buddha:
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: “Worthy Gotama, there are some ascetics and brahmins who claim to have mastered the fundamentals of the spiritual life having attained perfection and consummation of insight in this life.
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: Where do you stand regarding these?”
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: “I say there is a diversity among those who claim to have mastered the fundamentals of the spiritual life having attained perfection and consummation of insight in this life.
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: There are some ascetics and brahmins who are oral transmitters.
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: Through oral transmission they claim to have mastered the fundamentals of the spiritual life.
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: For example, the brahmins who are proficient in the three Vedas.
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: There are some ascetics and brahmins who solely by mere faith claim to have mastered the fundamentals of the spiritual life.
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: For example, those who rely on logic and inquiry.
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: There are some ascetics and brahmins who, having directly known for themselves the principle regarding teachings not learned before from another, claim to have mastered the fundamentals of the spiritual life.
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: I am one of those.
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: And here’s a way to understand that I am one of them.
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: Before my awakening—when I was still unawakened but intent on awakening—I thought:
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: ‘Life at home is cramped and dirty, life gone forth is wide open.
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: It’s not easy for someone living at home to lead the spiritual life utterly full and pure, like a polished shell.
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: Why don’t I shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness?’
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: Some time later, while still with pristine black hair, blessed with youth, in the prime of life—though my mother and father wished otherwise, weeping with tearful faces—I shaved off my hair and beard, dressed in ocher robes, and went forth from the lay life to homelessness.
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: Once I had gone forth I set out to discover what is skillful, seeking the supreme state of sublime peace. I approached Āḷāra Kālāma and said to him,
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: ‘Reverend Kālāma, I wish to lead the spiritual life in this teaching and training.’
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: Āḷāra Kālāma replied,
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: ‘Stay, venerable.
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: This teaching is such that a sensible person can soon realize their own tradition with their own insight and live having achieved it.’
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: I quickly memorized that teaching.
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: As far as lip-recital and verbal repetition went, I spoke the doctrine of knowledge, the elder doctrine. I claimed to know and see, and so did others.
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: Then it occurred to me,
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: ‘It is not solely by mere faith that Āḷāra Kālāma declares: “I realize this teaching with my own insight, and live having achieved it.”
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: Surely he meditates knowing and seeing this teaching.’
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: So I approached Āḷāra Kālāma and said to him:
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: ‘Reverend Kālāma, to what extent do you say you’ve realized this teaching with your own insight?’
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: When I said this, he declared the dimension of nothingness.
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: Then it occurred to me,
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: ‘It’s not just Āḷāra Kālāma who has faith,
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: energy,
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: mindfulness,
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: immersion,
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: and wisdom; I too have these things.
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: Why don’t I make an effort to realize the same teaching that Āḷāra Kālāma says he has realized with his own insight?’
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: I quickly realized that teaching with my own insight, and lived having achieved it.
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: So I approached Āḷāra Kālāma and said to him,
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: ‘Reverend Kālāma, is it up to this point that you realized this teaching with your own insight, and declare having achieved it?’
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: ‘I have, reverend.’
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: ‘I too have realized this teaching with my own insight up to this point, and live having achieved it.’
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: ‘We are fortunate, reverend, so very fortunate
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: to see a venerable such as yourself as one of our spiritual companions!
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: So the teaching that I’ve realized with my own insight, and declare having achieved it, you’ve realized with your own insight, and dwell having achieved it.
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: The teaching that you’ve realized with your own insight, and dwell having achieved it, I’ve realized with my own insight, and declare having achieved it.
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: So the teaching that I know, you know, and the teaching you know, I know.
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: I am like you and you are like me.
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: Come now, reverend! We should both lead this community together.’
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: And that is how my tutor Āḷāra Kālāma placed me, his pupil, on the same position as him, and honored me with lofty praise.
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: Then it occurred to me,
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: ‘This teaching doesn’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment. It only leads as far as rebirth in the dimension of nothingness.’
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: Realizing that this teaching was inadequate, I left disappointed.

segment_text: There I saw a delightful park, a lovely grove with a flowing river that was clean and charming, with smooth banks. And nearby was a village to resort to for alms.

title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: So I sat down right there, thinking:

title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: And then these three similes, which were neither supernaturally inspired, nor learned before in the past, occurred to me.

segment_text: Suppose there was a green, sappy log, and it was lying in water.

title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: Why is that?
title: With Saṅgārava
