segment_text: But then there was an intense burning in my body,
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: like two strong men grabbing a weaker man by the arms to burn and scorch him on a pit of glowing coals.
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: My energy was roused up and unflagging, and my mindfulness was established and lucid, but my body was disturbed, not tranquil, because I’d pushed too hard with that painful striving.
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: Then some deities saw me and said,
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: ‘The ascetic Gotama is dead.’
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: Others said,
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: ‘He’s not dead, but he’s dying.’
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: Others said,
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: ‘He’s not dead or dying. The ascetic Gotama is a perfected one, for that is how the perfected ones live.’
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: Then it occurred to me,
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: ‘Why don’t I practice completely cutting off food?’
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: But deities came to me and said,
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: ‘Good fellow, don’t practice totally cutting off food.
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: If you do, we’ll infuse heavenly nectar into your pores and you will live on that.’
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: Then it occurred to me,
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: ‘If I claim to be completely fasting while these deities are infusing heavenly nectar in my pores, that would be a lie on my part.’
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: So I dismissed those deities, saying, ‘There’s no need.’
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: Then it occurred to me,
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: ‘Why don’t I just take a little bit of food each time, a handful of broth made from mung beans, horse gram, chickpeas, or green gram?’
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: So that’s what I did,
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: until my body became extremely emaciated.
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: Due to eating so little, my major and minor limbs became like the joints of an eighty-year-old or a dying man,
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: my bottom became like a camel’s hoof,
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: my vertebrae stuck out like beads on a string,
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: and my ribs were as gaunt as the broken-down rafters on an old barn.
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: Due to eating so little, the gleam of my eyes sank deep in their sockets, like the gleam of water sunk deep down a well.
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: Due to eating so little, my scalp shriveled and withered like a green bitter-gourd in the wind and sun.
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: Due to eating so little, the skin of my belly stuck to my backbone, so that when I tried to rub the skin of my belly I grabbed my backbone, and when I tried to rub my backbone I rubbed the skin of my belly.
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: Due to eating so little, when I tried to urinate or defecate I fell face down right there.
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: Due to eating so little, when I tried to relieve my body by rubbing my limbs with my hands, the hair, rotted at its roots, fell out.
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: Then some people saw me and said: ‘The ascetic Gotama is black.’
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: Some said: ‘He’s not black, he’s brown.’
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: Some said: ‘He’s neither black nor brown. The ascetic Gotama has tawny skin.’
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: That’s how far the pure, bright complexion of my skin had been ruined by taking so little food.
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: Then it occurred to me,
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: ‘Whatever ascetics and brahmins have experienced painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings due to overexertion—whether in the past, future, or present—this is as far as it goes, no-one has done more than this.
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: But I have not achieved any superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones by this severe, grueling work.
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: Could there be another path to awakening?’
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: Then it occurred to me,
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: ‘I recall sitting in the cool shade of a black plum tree while my father the Sakyan was off working. Quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, I entered and remained in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: Could that be the path to awakening?’
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: Stemming from that memory came the understanding:
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: ‘*That* is the path to awakening!’
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: Then it occurred to me,
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: ‘Why am I afraid of that pleasure, for it has nothing to do with sensual pleasures or unskillful qualities?’
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: I thought,
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: ‘I’m not afraid of that pleasure, for it has nothing to do with sensual pleasures or unskillful qualities.’
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: Then it occurred to me,
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: ‘I can’t achieve that pleasure with a body so excessively emaciated. Why don’t I eat some solid food, some rice and porridge?’
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: So I ate some solid food.
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: Now at that time the five mendicants were attending on me, thinking,
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: ‘The ascetic Gotama will tell us of any truth that he realizes.’
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: But when I ate some solid food, they left disappointed in me, saying,
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: ‘The ascetic Gotama has become indulgent; he has strayed from the struggle and returned to indulgence.’
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: After eating solid food and gathering my strength, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, I entered and remained in the first absorption …
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected were stilled, I entered and remained in the second absorption …
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: third absorption …
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: fourth absorption.
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: When my mind had immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—I extended it toward recollection of past lives.
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: I recollected many past lives. That is: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. And so I recollected my many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: This was the first knowledge, which I achieved in the first watch of the night.
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: Ignorance was destroyed and knowledge arose; darkness was destroyed and light arose, as happens for a meditator who is diligent, keen, and resolute.
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: When my mind had immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—I extended it toward knowledge of the death and rebirth of sentient beings.
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, I saw sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. I understood how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds …
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: This was the second knowledge, which I achieved in the middle watch of the night.
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: Ignorance was destroyed and knowledge arose; darkness was destroyed and light arose, as happens for a meditator who is diligent, keen, and resolute.
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: When my mind had immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—I extended it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements.
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: I truly understood: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: I truly understood: ‘These are defilements’ … ‘This is the origin of defilements’ … ‘This is the cessation of defilements’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of defilements’.
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: Knowing and seeing like this, my mind was freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: When it was freed, I knew it was freed.
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: I understood: ‘Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is nothing further for this place.’
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: This was the third knowledge, which I achieved in the last watch of the night.
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: Ignorance was destroyed and knowledge arose; darkness was destroyed and light arose, as happens for a meditator who is diligent, keen, and resolute.”
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: When he had spoken, Saṅgārava said to the Buddha,
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: “The striving of the worthy Gotama was indeed assiduous and that of a true person,
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: since he is a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha.
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: But worthy Gotama, do gods survive?”
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: “I’ve understood about gods in terms of causes.”
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: “But worthy Gotama, when asked ‘Do gods survive?’ why did you say that you have understood about gods in terms of causes?
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: That being so, is it not hollow and false?”
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: “When asked ‘Do gods survive’, whether you reply ‘Gods survive’ or ‘I’ve understood in terms of causes’
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: a sensible person would come to the categorical conclusion in this matter that
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: gods survive.”
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: “But why didn’t you say that in the first place?”
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: “It is agreed by the eminent in the world that gods survive.”
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: When he had spoken, Saṅgārava said to the Buddha,
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: “Excellent, worthy Gotama! Excellent!
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, worthy Gotama has made the Teaching clear in many ways.
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: I go for refuge to the worthy Gotama, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: From this day forth, may the worthy Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
title: With Saṅgārava

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans, near the Sakyan town named Devadaha.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: “Mendicants!”
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: “Venerable sir,” they replied.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: The Buddha said this:
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: “Mendicants, there are some ascetics and brahmins who have this doctrine and view:
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: ‘Everything this individual experiences—pleasurable, painful, or neutral—is because of past deeds.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: So, due to eliminating past deeds by fervent mortification, and not doing any new deeds, there’s nothing to come up in the future.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: With no future consequence, deeds end. With the ending of deeds, suffering ends. With the ending of suffering, feeling ends. And with the ending of feeling, all suffering will have been worn away.’
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: Such is the doctrine of the Jain ascetics.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: I’ve gone up to the Jain ascetics who say this and said,
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: ‘Is it really true that this is the venerables’ view?’
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: They admitted that it is.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: I said to them,
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: ‘But reverends, do you know
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: for sure that you existed in the past, and it is not the case that you did not exist?’
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: ‘No we don’t, reverend.’
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: ‘But reverends, do you know
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: for sure that you did bad deeds in the past?’
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: ‘No we don’t, reverend.’
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: ‘But reverends, do you know
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: that you did such and such bad deeds?’
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: ‘No we don’t, reverend.’
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: ‘But reverends, do you know
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: that so much suffering has already been worn away? Or that so much suffering still remains to be worn away? Or that when so much suffering is worn away all suffering will have been worn away?’
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: ‘No we don’t, reverend.’
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: ‘But reverends, do you know
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: about giving up unskillful qualities in this very life and embracing skillful qualities?’
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: ‘No we don’t, reverend.’
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: ‘So it seems that you don’t know any of these things.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: In that case, it’s not appropriate for the Jain venerables to declare this.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: Now, supposing you did know these things.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: In that case, it would be appropriate for the Jain venerables to declare this.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: Suppose a man was struck by an arrow thickly smeared with poison,
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: causing painful feelings, sharp and severe.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: Their friends and colleagues, relatives and kin would get a surgeon to treat them.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: The surgeon would cut open the wound with a scalpel,
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: causing painful feelings, sharp and severe.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: They’d probe for the arrow,
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: causing painful feelings, sharp and severe.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: They’d extract the arrow,
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: causing painful feelings, sharp and severe.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: They’d apply cauterizing medicine to the wound,
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: causing painful feelings, sharp and severe.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: After some time that wound would be healed and the skin regrown. They’d be healthy, happy, autonomous, master of themselves, able to go where they wanted.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: They’d think,
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: “Earlier I was struck by an arrow thickly smeared with poison,
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: causing painful feelings, sharp and severe.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: My friends and colleagues, relatives and kin got a surgeon to treat me.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: At each step, the treatment was painful.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: But these days that wound is healed and the skin regrown. I’m healthy, happy, autonomous, my own master, able to go where I want.”
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: In the same way, reverends, if you knew about these things,
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: it would be appropriate for the Jain venerables to declare this.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: But since you don’t know any of these things,
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: it’s not appropriate for the Jain venerables to declare this.’
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: When I said this, those Jain ascetics said to me,
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: ‘Reverend, the Jain ascetic of the Ñātika clan claims to be all-knowing and all-seeing, to know and see everything without exception, thus:
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: “Knowledge and vision are constantly and continually present to me, while walking, standing, sleeping, and waking.”
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: He says:
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: “O reverend Jain ascetics, you have done bad deeds in a past life. Wear them away with these severe and grueling austerities.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: And when in the present you are restrained in body, speech, and mind, you’re not doing any bad deeds for the future.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: So, due to eliminating past deeds by fervent mortification, and not doing any new deeds, there’s nothing to come up in the future.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: With no future consequence, deeds end. With the ending of deeds, suffering ends. With the ending of suffering, feeling ends. And with the ending of feeling, all suffering will have been worn away.”
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: We endorse and accept this, and we are satisfied with it.’
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: When they said this, I said to them,
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: ‘These five things can be seen to turn out in two different ways.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: What five?
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: Faith, endorsement, oral transmission, reasoned train of thought, and acceptance of a view after deliberation.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: These are the five things that can be seen to turn out in two different ways.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: In this case, what faith in your teacher do you have when it comes to the past? What endorsement, oral transmission, reasoned train of thought, or acceptance of a view after deliberation?’
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: When I said this, I did not see any legitimate defense of their doctrine from the Jains.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: Furthermore, I said to those Jain ascetics,
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: ‘What do you think, reverends?
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: At a time of intense exertion and striving do you suffer painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings due to overexertion?
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: Whereas at a time without intense exertion and striving do you not suffer painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings due to overexertion?’
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: ‘Reverend Gotama, at a time of intense exertion we suffer painful, sharp feelings due to overexertion,
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: not without intense exertion.’
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: ‘So it seems that only at a time of intense exertion do you suffer painful, sharp feelings due to overexertion,
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: not without intense exertion.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: In that case, it’s not appropriate for the Jain venerables to declare:
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: “Everything this individual experiences—pleasurable, painful, or neutral—is because of past deeds. …”
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: If at a time of intense exertion you did not suffer painful, sharp feelings due to overexertion,
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: and if without intense exertion you did experience such feelings,
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: it would be appropriate for the Jain venerables to declare this.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: But since this is not the case,
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: aren’t you experiencing painful, sharp feelings due only to your own exertion, which out of ignorance, unknowing, and confusion you misconstrue to imply:
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: “Everything this individual experiences—pleasurable, painful, or neutral—is because of past deeds. …”?’
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: When I said this, I did not see any legitimate defense of their doctrine from the Jains.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: Furthermore, I said to those Jain ascetics,
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: ‘What do you think, reverends? If a deed is to be experienced in this life, can exertion make it be experienced in lives to come?’
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: ‘No, reverend.’
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: ‘But if a deed is to be experienced in lives to come, can exertion make it be experienced in this life?’
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: ‘No, reverend.’
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: ‘What do you think, reverends? If a deed is to be experienced as pleasure, can exertion make it be experienced as pain?’
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: ‘No, reverend.’
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: ‘But if a deed is to be experienced as pain, can exertion make it be experienced as pleasure?’
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: ‘No, reverend.’
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: ‘What do you think, reverends? If a deed is to be experienced when fully ripened, can exertion make it be experienced when not fully ripened?’
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: ‘No, reverend.’
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: ‘But if a deed is to be experienced when not fully ripened, can exertion make it be experienced when fully ripened?’
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: ‘No, reverend.’
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: ‘What do you think, reverends? If a deed is to be experienced strongly, can exertion make it be experienced weakly?’
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: ‘No, reverend.’
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: ‘But if a deed is to be experienced weakly, can exertion make it be experienced strongly?’
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: ‘No, reverend.’
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: ‘What do you think, reverends? If a deed is to be experienced, can exertion make it not be experienced?’
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: ‘No, reverend.’
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: ‘But if a deed is not to be experienced, can exertion make it be experienced?’
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: ‘No, reverend.’
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: ‘So it seems that exertion cannot change the way deeds are experienced in any of these ways.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: This being so, your exertion and striving are fruitless.’
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: Such is the doctrine of the Jain ascetics.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: Saying this, the Jain ascetics deserve rebuttal and criticism on ten legitimate grounds.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: If sentient beings experience pleasure and pain because of past deeds,
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: clearly the Jains have done bad deeds in the past, since they now experience such intense pain.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: If sentient beings experience pleasure and pain because of God Almighty’s creation,
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: clearly the Jains were created by a bad God, since they now experience such intense pain.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: If sentient beings experience pleasure and pain because of circumstance and nature,
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: clearly the Jains arise from bad circumstances, since they now experience such intense pain.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: If sentient beings experience pleasure and pain because of the class of rebirth,
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: clearly the Jains have been reborn in a bad class, since they now experience such intense pain.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: If sentient beings experience pleasure and pain because of exertion in this life,
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: clearly the Jains exert themselves badly in this life, since they now experience such intense pain.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: The Jains deserve criticism whether or not sentient beings experience pleasure and pain because of past deeds,
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: or God Almighty’s creation,
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: or circumstance and nature,
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: or class of rebirth,
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: or exertion in this life.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: Such is the doctrine of the Jain ascetics.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: The Jain ascetics who say this deserve rebuttal and criticism on these ten legitimate grounds.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: That’s how exertion and striving is fruitless.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: And how is exertion and striving fruitful?
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: It’s when a mendicant doesn’t bring suffering upon themselves; and they don’t forsake legitimate pleasure, but they’re not besotted with that pleasure.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: They understand:
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: ‘When I actively strive I become dispassionate towards this source of suffering. But when I develop equanimity I become dispassionate towards this other source of suffering.’
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: So they either actively strive or develop equanimity as appropriate.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: Through active striving they become dispassionate towards that specific source of suffering,
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: and so that suffering is worn away.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: Through developing equanimity they become dispassionate towards that other source of suffering,
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: and so that suffering is worn away.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: Suppose a man is in love with a woman, full of intense desire and lust.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: Then he sees her standing together with another man, chatting, giggling, and laughing.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: What do you think, mendicants?
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: Would that give rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress for him?”
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: “Yes, sir.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: Why is that?
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: Because that man is in love with that woman, full of intense desire and lust.”
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: “Then that man might think:
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: ‘I’m in love with that woman, full of intense desire and lust.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: When I saw her standing together with another man, chatting, giggling, and laughing, it gave rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress for me.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: Why don’t I give up that desire and lust for that woman?’
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: So that’s what he did.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: Some time later he sees her again standing together with another man, chatting, giggling, and laughing.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: What do you think, mendicants?
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: Would that give rise to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress for him?”
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: “No, sir.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: Why is that?
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: Because he no longer desires that woman.”
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: “In the same way, a mendicant doesn’t bring suffering upon themselves; and they don’t forsake legitimate pleasure, but they’re not besotted with that pleasure.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: They understand:
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: ‘When I actively strive I become dispassionate towards this source of suffering. But when I develop equanimity I become dispassionate towards this other source of suffering.’
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: So they either actively strive or develop equanimity as appropriate.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: Through active striving they become dispassionate towards that specific source of suffering,
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: and so that suffering is worn away.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: Through developing equanimity they become dispassionate towards that other source of suffering,
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: and so that suffering is worn away.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: That’s how exertion and striving is fruitful.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: Furthermore, a mendicant reflects:
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: ‘When I live as I please, unskillful qualities grow and skillful qualities decline.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: But when I strive painfully, unskillful qualities decline and skillful qualities grow.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: Why don’t I strive painfully?’
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: So that’s what they do,
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: and as they do so unskillful qualities decline and skillful qualities grow.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: After some time, they no longer strive painfully.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: Why is that?
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: Because they have accomplished the goal for which they strived painfully.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: Suppose an arrowsmith was heating an arrow shaft between two firebrands, making it straight and fit for use.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: After it’s been made straight and fit for use, they’d no longer heat it to make it straight and fit for use.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: Why is that?
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: Because they have accomplished the goal for which they heated it.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: In the same way, a mendicant reflects:
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: ‘When I live as I please, unskillful qualities grow and skillful qualities decline.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: But when I strive painfully, unskillful qualities decline and skillful qualities grow.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: Why don’t I strive painfully?’ …
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: After some time, they no longer strive painfully.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: That too is how exertion and striving is fruitful.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: Furthermore, a Realized One arises in the world, perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: He has realized with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras, and divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: He proclaims a teaching that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: A householder hears that teaching, or a householder’s child, or someone reborn in a good family.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: They gain faith in the Realized One,
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: and reflect:
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: ‘Life at home is cramped and dirty, life gone forth is wide open.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: It’s not easy for someone living at home to lead the spiritual life utterly full and pure, like a polished shell.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: Why don’t I shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness?’
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: After some time they give up a large or small fortune, and a large or small family circle. They shave off hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: Once they’ve gone forth, they take up the training and livelihood of the mendicants. They give up killing living creatures, renouncing the rod and the sword. They’re scrupulous and kind, living full of sympathy for all living beings.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: They give up stealing. They take only what’s given, and expect only what’s given. They keep themselves clean by not thieving.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: They give up unchastity. They are chaste, set apart, avoiding the vulgar act of sex.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: They give up lying. They speak the truth and stick to the truth. They’re honest and dependable, and don’t trick the world with their words.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: They give up divisive speech. They don’t repeat in one place what they heard in another so as to divide people against each other. Instead, they reconcile those who are divided, supporting unity, delighting in harmony, loving harmony, speaking words that promote harmony.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: They give up harsh speech. They speak in a way that’s mellow, pleasing to the ear, lovely, going to the heart, polite, likable and agreeable to the people.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: They give up talking nonsense. Their words are timely, true, and meaningful, in line with the teaching and training. They say things at the right time which are valuable, reasonable, succinct, and beneficial.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: They refrain from injuring plants and seeds.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: They eat in one part of the day, abstaining from eating at night and food at the wrong time.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: They refrain from seeing shows of dancing, singing, and music .
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: They refrain from beautifying and adorning themselves with garlands, fragrance, and makeup.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: They refrain from high and luxurious beds.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: They refrain from receiving gold and currency,
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: raw grains,
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: raw meat,
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: women and girls,
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: male and female bondservants,
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: goats and sheep,
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: chickens and pigs,
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: elephants, cows, horses, and mares,
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: and fields and land.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: They refrain from running errands and messages;
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: buying and selling;
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: falsifying weights, metals, or measures;
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: bribery, fraud, cheating, and duplicity;
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: mutilation, murder, abduction, banditry, plunder, and violence.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: They’re content with robes to look after the body and almsfood to look after the belly. Wherever they go, they set out taking only these things.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: They’re like a bird: wherever it flies, wings are its only burden.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: In the same way, a mendicant is content with robes to look after the body and almsfood to look after the belly. Wherever they go, they set out taking only these things.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: When they have this entire spectrum of noble ethics, they experience a blameless happiness inside themselves.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: When they see a sight with their eyes, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: If the faculty of sight were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of sight, and achieving its restraint.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: When they hear a sound with their ears …
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: When they smell an odor with their nose …
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: When they taste a flavor with their tongue …
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: When they feel a touch with their body …
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: When they know an idea with their mind, they don’t get caught up in the features and details.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: If the faculty of mind were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure would become overwhelming. For this reason, they practice restraint, protecting the faculty of mind, and achieving its restraint.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: When they have this noble sense restraint, they experience an unsullied bliss inside themselves.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: They act with situational awareness when going out and coming back; when looking ahead and aside; when bending and extending the limbs; when bearing the outer robe, bowl and robes; when eating, drinking, chewing, and tasting; when urinating and defecating; when walking, standing, sitting, sleeping, waking, speaking, and keeping silent.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: When they have this entire spectrum of noble ethics, this noble contentment, this noble sense restraint, and this noble mindfulness and situational awareness,
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: they frequent a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: After the meal, they return from almsround, sit down cross-legged, set their body straight, and establish mindfulness in their presence.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: Giving up covetousness for the world, they meditate with a heart rid of covetousness, cleansing the mind of covetousness.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: Giving up ill will and malevolence, they meditate with a mind rid of ill will, full of sympathy for all living beings, cleansing the mind of ill will.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: Giving up dullness and drowsiness, they meditate with a mind rid of dullness and drowsiness, perceiving light, mindful and aware, cleansing the mind of dullness and drowsiness.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: Giving up restlessness and remorse, they meditate without restlessness, their mind peaceful inside, cleansing the mind of restlessness and remorse.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: Giving up doubt, they meditate having gone beyond doubt, not undecided about skillful qualities, cleansing the mind of doubt.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: They give up these five hindrances, corruptions of the heart that weaken wisdom.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: Then, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, they enter and remain in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: That too is how exertion and striving is fruitful.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: Furthermore, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, they enter and remain in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: That too is how exertion and striving is fruitful.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: Furthermore, with the fading away of rapture, a mendicant enters and remains in the third absorption, where they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: That too is how exertion and striving is fruitful.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: Furthermore, giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, they enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: That too is how exertion and striving is fruitful.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward recollection of past lives.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: They recollect many kinds of past lives, that is, one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. They remember: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so they recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: That too is how exertion and striving is fruitful.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward knowledge of the death and rebirth of sentient beings.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understood how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds: ‘These dear beings did bad things by way of body, speech, and mind. They denounced the noble ones; they had wrong view; and they chose to act out of that wrong view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell. These dear beings, however, did good things by way of body, speech, and mind. They never denounced the noble ones; they had right view; and they chose to act out of that right view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.’ And so, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: That too is how exertion and striving is fruitful.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: They truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: They truly understand: ‘These are defilements’ … ‘This is the origin of defilements’ … ‘This is the cessation of defilements’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of defilements’.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: Knowing and seeing like this, their mind is freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: That too is how exertion and striving is fruitful.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: Such is the doctrine of the Realized One.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: Saying this, the Realized One deserves praise on ten legitimate grounds.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: If sentient beings experience pleasure and pain because of past deeds,
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: clearly the Realized One has done good deeds in the past, since he now experiences such undefiled pleasure.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: If sentient beings experience pleasure and pain because of God Almighty’s creation,
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: clearly the Realized One was created by a good God, since he now experiences such undefiled pleasure.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: If sentient beings experience pleasure and pain because of circumstance and nature,
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: clearly the Realized One arises from good circumstances, since he now experiences such undefiled pleasure.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: If sentient beings experience pleasure and pain because of the class of rebirth,
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: clearly the Realized One was reborn in a good class, since he now experiences such undefiled pleasure.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: If sentient beings experience pleasure and pain because of exertion in this life,
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: clearly the Realized One exerts himself well in this life, since he now experiences such undefiled pleasure.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: The Realized One deserves praise whether or not sentient beings experience pleasure and pain because of past deeds,
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: or God Almighty’s creation,
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: or circumstance and nature,
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: or class of rebirth,
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: or exertion in this life.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: Such is the doctrine of the Realized One.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: Saying this, the Realized One deserves praise on these ten legitimate grounds.”
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: That is what the Buddha said.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
title: At Devadaha

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: The Five and Three

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
title: The Five and Three

segment_text: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,
title: The Five and Three

segment_text: “Mendicants!”
title: The Five and Three

segment_text: “Venerable sir,” they replied.
title: The Five and Three

segment_text: The Buddha said this:
title: The Five and Three

segment_text: “Mendicants, there are some ascetics and brahmins who speculate and theorize about the future, and assert various hypotheses concerning the future.
title: The Five and Three

segment_text: Some propose this: ‘The self is percipient and healthy after death.’
title: The Five and Three

segment_text: Some propose this: ‘The self is non-percipient and healthy after death.’
title: The Five and Three

segment_text: Some propose this: ‘The self is neither percipient nor non-percipient and healthy after death.’
title: The Five and Three

segment_text: But some assert the annihilation, eradication, and obliteration of an existing being, while others propose extinguishment in this life.
title: The Five and Three

segment_text: Thus they assert an existent self that is free of disease after death; or they assert the annihilation of an existing being; while some propose extinguishment in this life.
title: The Five and Three

segment_text: In this way five become three, and three become five.
title: The Five and Three

segment_text: This is the summary recital of the five and three.
title: The Five and Three

segment_text: Now, the ascetics and brahmins who assert a self that is percipient and healthy after death describe it as formed, or formless, or both formed and formless, or neither formed nor formless. Or they describe it as of unified perception, or of diverse perception, or of limited perception, or of limitless perception. Or some among those who go beyond this propose universal consciousness, limitless and imperturbable.
title: The Five and Three

segment_text: The Realized One understands this as follows.
title: The Five and Three

segment_text: There are ascetics and brahmins who assert a self that is percipient and healthy after death, describing it as formed, or formless, or both formed and formless, or neither formed nor formless. Or they describe it as of unified perception, or of diverse perception, or of limited perception, or of limitless perception.
title: The Five and Three

segment_text: Or some, aware that ‘there is nothing at all’, propose the dimension of nothingness, limitless and imperturbable. They declare that this is the purest, highest, best, and supreme of all those perceptions, whether of form or of formlessness or of unity or of diversity.
title: The Five and Three

segment_text: ‘That much is conditioned and crude. But there is the cessation of conditions—*that* is real.’
title: The Five and Three

segment_text: Understanding this and seeing the escape from it, the Realized One has gone beyond all that.
title: The Five and Three

segment_text: Now, the ascetics and brahmins who assert a self that is non-percipient and healthy after death describe it as formed, or formless, or both formed and formless, or neither formed nor formless.
title: The Five and Three

segment_text: So they reject those who assert a self that is percipient and healthy after death.
title: The Five and Three

segment_text: Why is that?
title: The Five and Three

segment_text: Because they believe that perception is a disease, a boil, a dart, and that the state of non-perception is peaceful and sublime.
title: The Five and Three

segment_text: The Realized One understands this as follows.
title: The Five and Three

segment_text: There are ascetics and brahmins who assert a self that is non-percipient and healthy after death, describing it as formed, or formless, or both formed and formless, or neither formed nor formless.
title: The Five and Three

segment_text: But if any ascetic or brahmin should say this:
title: The Five and Three

segment_text: ‘Apart from form, feeling, perception, and choices, I will describe the coming and going of consciousness, its passing away and reappearing, its growth, increase, and maturity.’
title: The Five and Three

segment_text: That is not possible.
title: The Five and Three

segment_text: ‘All that is conditioned and crude. But there is the cessation of conditions—*that* is real.’
title: The Five and Three

segment_text: Understanding this and seeing the escape from it, the Realized One has gone beyond all that.
title: The Five and Three

segment_text: Now, the ascetics and brahmins who assert a self that is neither percipient nor non-percipient and healthy after death describe it as formed, or formless, or both formed and formless, or neither formed nor formless.
title: The Five and Three

segment_text: So they reject those who assert a self that is percipient and healthy after death, as well as those who assert a self that is non-percipient and healthy after death.
title: The Five and Three

segment_text: Why is that?
title: The Five and Three

segment_text: Because they believe that perception is a disease, a boil, a dart; that non-perception is a stupor; and that the state of neither perception nor non-perception is peaceful and sublime.
title: The Five and Three

segment_text: The Realized One understands this as follows.
title: The Five and Three

segment_text: There are ascetics and brahmins who assert a self that is neither percipient nor non-percipient and healthy after death, describing it as formed, or formless, or both formed and formless, or neither formed nor formless.
title: The Five and Three

segment_text: Some ascetics or brahmins assert the embracing of that dimension merely through the conditioned phenomena of what is able to be seen, heard, thought, and known. But that is said to be a disastrous approach.
title: The Five and Three

segment_text: For that dimension is said to be not attainable by means of conditioned phenomena,
title: The Five and Three

segment_text: but only with a residue of conditioned phenomena.
title: The Five and Three

segment_text: ‘All that is conditioned and crude. But there is the cessation of conditions—*that* is real.’
title: The Five and Three

segment_text: Understanding this and seeing the escape from it, the Realized One has gone beyond all that.
title: The Five and Three

segment_text: Now, the ascetics and brahmins who assert the annihilation, eradication, and obliteration of an existing being reject those who assert a self that is healthy after death, whether percipient or non-percipient or neither percipient non-percipient.
title: The Five and Three

segment_text: Why is that?
title: The Five and Three

segment_text: Because they think: ‘All of those ascetics and brahmins only assert their attachment to heading upstream:
title: The Five and Three

segment_text: “After death we shall be like this! After death we shall be like that!”
title: The Five and Three

segment_text: Suppose a trader was going to market, thinking:
title: The Five and Three

segment_text: “With this, that shall be mine! This way, I shall get that!”
title: The Five and Three

segment_text: In the same way, those ascetics and brahmins seem to be like traders when they say:
title: The Five and Three

segment_text: “After death we shall be like this! After death we shall be like that!”’
title: The Five and Three

segment_text: The Realized One understands this as follows.
title: The Five and Three

segment_text: The ascetics and brahmins who assert the annihilation, eradication, and obliteration of an existing being; from fear and disgust with substantial reality, they just keep running and circling around substantial reality.
title: The Five and Three

segment_text: Suppose a dog on a leash was tethered to a strong post or pillar. It would just keeping running and circling around that post or pillar.
title: The Five and Three

segment_text: In the same way, those ascetics and brahmins, from fear and disgust with substantial reality, just keep running and circling around substantial reality.
title: The Five and Three

segment_text: ‘All that is conditioned and crude. But there is the cessation of conditions—*that* is real.’
title: The Five and Three

segment_text: Understanding this and seeing the escape from it, the Realized One has gone beyond all that.
title: The Five and Three

segment_text: Whatever ascetics and brahmins speculate and theorize about the future, and propose various hypotheses concerning the future, all of them propose one or other of these five theses.
title: The Five and Three

segment_text: There are some ascetics and brahmins who theorize about the past, and propose various hypotheses concerning the past. They propose the following, each insisting that theirs is the only truth and that everything else is wrong.
title: The Five and Three

title: The Five and Three

title: The Five and Three

title: The Five and Three

title: The Five and Three

title: The Five and Three

title: The Five and Three

title: The Five and Three

title: The Five and Three

segment_text: ‘The self and the cosmos are eternal. This is the only truth, anything else is futile.’ It’s simply not possible for them to have personal knowledge of this that is pure and bright, apart from faith, endorsement, oral transmission, reasoned train of thought, or acceptance of a view after deliberation.
title: The Five and Three

title: The Five and Three

title: The Five and Three

title: At Sāmagāma

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans near the village of Sāma.
title: At Sāmagāma

segment_text: Now at that time the Jain ascetic of the Ñātika clan had recently passed away at Pāvā.
title: At Sāmagāma

segment_text: With his passing the Jain ascetics split, dividing into two factions, arguing, quarreling, and disputing, continually wounding each other with barbed words:
title: At Sāmagāma

segment_text: “You don’t understand this teaching and training. I understand this teaching and training. What, you understand this teaching and training? You’re practicing wrong. I’m practicing right. I stay on topic, you don’t. You said last what you should have said first. You said first what you should have said last. What you’ve thought so much about has been disproved. Your doctrine is refuted. Go on, save your doctrine! You’re trapped; get yourself out of this—if you can!”
title: At Sāmagāma

segment_text: You’d think there was nothing but slaughter going on among the Jain ascetics.
title: At Sāmagāma

segment_text: And the Jain Ñātika’s white-clothed lay disciples were disillusioned, dismayed, and disappointed in the Jain ascetics. They were equally disappointed with a teaching and training so poorly explained and poorly propounded, not emancipating, not leading to peace, proclaimed by someone who is not a fully awakened Buddha, with broken monument and without a refuge.
title: At Sāmagāma

segment_text: And then, after completing the rainy season residence near Pāvā, the novice Cunda went to see Venerable Ānanda at Sāma village. He bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened.
title: At Sāmagāma

segment_text: Ānanda said to him,
title: At Sāmagāma

segment_text: “Reverend Cunda, we should see the Buddha about this matter.
title: At Sāmagāma

segment_text: Come, let’s go to the Buddha and inform him about this.”
title: At Sāmagāma

segment_text: “Yes, sir,” replied Cunda.
title: At Sāmagāma

segment_text: Then Ānanda and Cunda went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and Ānanda informed him of what Cunda had said. He went on to say,
title: At Sāmagāma

segment_text: “Sir, it occurs to me:
title: At Sāmagāma

segment_text: ‘When the Buddha has passed away, let no dispute arise in the Saṅgha.
title: At Sāmagāma

segment_text: For such a dispute would be for the detriment and suffering of the people, against the people, for the harm, detriment, and suffering of gods and humans.’”
title: At Sāmagāma

segment_text: “What do you think, Ānanda?
title: At Sāmagāma

segment_text: Do you see even two mendicants whose opinion differs regarding the things I have taught from my direct knowledge, that is,
title: At Sāmagāma

segment_text: the four kinds of mindfulness meditation, the four right efforts, the four bases of psychic power, the five faculties, the five powers, the seven awakening factors, and the noble eightfold path?”
title: At Sāmagāma

segment_text: “No, sir, I do not.
title: At Sāmagāma

segment_text: Nevertheless, there are some individuals who appear to live obedient to the Buddha, but when the Buddha has passed away they might create a dispute in the Saṅgha regarding livelihood or the monastic code.
title: At Sāmagāma

segment_text: Such a dispute would be for the detriment and suffering of the people, against the people, for the harm, detriment, and suffering of gods and humans.”
title: At Sāmagāma

segment_text: “Ānanda, dispute about livelihood or the monastic code is a minor matter.
title: At Sāmagāma

segment_text: But should a dispute arise in the Saṅgha concerning the path or the practice, that would be for the detriment and suffering of the people, against the people, for the harm, detriment, and suffering of gods and humans.

title: At Sāmagāma

segment_text: There are seven methods for the settlement of any disciplinary issues that might arise.

segment_text: And how is there the covering over as if with grass?
title: At Sāmagāma

segment_text: It’s when the mendicants continually argue, quarrel, and dispute, doing and saying many things that are not proper for an ascetic.
title: At Sāmagāma

segment_text: Those mendicants should all sit together in harmony.
title: At Sāmagāma

segment_text: A competent mendicant of one party, having got up from their seat, arranged their robe over one shoulder, and raised their joined palms, should inform the Saṅgha:
title: At Sāmagāma

segment_text: ‘Sir, let the Saṅgha listen to me.
title: At Sāmagāma

segment_text: We have been continually arguing, quarreling, and disputing, doing and saying many things that are not proper for an ascetic.
title: At Sāmagāma

segment_text: If it seems appropriate to the Saṅgha, then—for the benefit of these venerables and myself—I disclose in the middle of the Saṅgha by means of covering over as if with grass any offenses committed by these venerables and by myself, excepting only those that are gravely blameworthy and those connected with laypeople.’
title: At Sāmagāma

segment_text: Ānanda, these six warm-hearted qualities make for fondness and respect, conducing to inclusion, harmony, and unity, without quarreling.
title: At Sāmagāma

segment_text: What six?
title: At Sāmagāma

segment_text: Firstly, a mendicant consistently treats their spiritual companions with bodily kindness, both in public and in private.
title: At Sāmagāma

segment_text: This warm-hearted quality makes for fondness and respect, conducing to inclusion, harmony, and unity, without quarreling.
title: At Sāmagāma

segment_text: Furthermore, a mendicant consistently treats their spiritual companions with verbal kindness …
title: At Sāmagāma

segment_text: This too is a warm-hearted quality.
title: At Sāmagāma

segment_text: Furthermore, a mendicant consistently treats their spiritual companions with mental kindness …
title: At Sāmagāma

segment_text: This too is a warm-hearted quality.
title: At Sāmagāma

segment_text: Furthermore, a mendicant shares without reservation any material things they have gained by legitimate means, even the food placed in the alms-bowl, using them in common with their ethical spiritual companions.
title: At Sāmagāma

segment_text: This too is a warm-hearted quality.
title: At Sāmagāma

segment_text: Furthermore, a mendicant lives according to the precepts shared with their spiritual companions, both in public and in private. Those precepts are intact, impeccable, spotless, and unmarred, liberating, praised by sensible people, not mistaken, and leading to immersion.
title: At Sāmagāma

segment_text: This too is a warm-hearted quality.
title: At Sāmagāma

segment_text: Furthermore, a mendicant lives according to the view shared with their spiritual companions, both in public and in private. That view is noble and emancipating, and delivers one who practices it to the complete ending of suffering.
title: At Sāmagāma

segment_text: This too is a warm-hearted quality.
title: At Sāmagāma

segment_text: These six warm-hearted qualities make for fondness and respect, conducing to inclusion, harmony, and unity, without quarreling.
title: At Sāmagāma

segment_text: If you should undertake and follow these six warm-hearted qualities, do you see any criticism, large or small, that you could not endure?”
title: At Sāmagāma

segment_text: “No, sir.”
title: At Sāmagāma

segment_text: “That’s why, Ānanda, you should undertake and follow these six warm-hearted qualities.
title: At Sāmagāma

segment_text: That will be for your lasting welfare and happiness.”
title: At Sāmagāma

segment_text: That is what the Buddha said.
title: At Sāmagāma

segment_text: Satisfied, Venerable Ānanda approved what the Buddha said.
title: At Sāmagāma

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: Now at that time several mendicants had declared their enlightenment in the Buddha’s presence:
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: “We understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’”
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: Sunakkhatta the Licchavi heard about this.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: He went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: “Sir, I have heard that
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: several mendicants have declared their enlightenment in the Buddha’s presence.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: I trust they did so rightly—or are there some who declared enlightenment out of overestimation?”
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: “Some of them did so rightly, Sunakkhatta, while others did so out of overestimation.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: Now, when mendicants declare enlightenment rightly, that is their truth.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: But when mendicants declare enlightenment out of overestimation, the Realized One thinks:
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: ‘I should teach them the Dhamma.’
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: If the Realized One thinks
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: he should teach them the Dhamma,
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: but then certain futile men, having carefully planned a question, approach the Realized One and ask it,
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: then the Realized One
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: changes his mind.”
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: “Now is the time, Blessed One! Now is the time, Holy One!
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: Let the Buddha teach the Dhamma. The mendicants will listen and remember it.”
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: “Well then, Sunakkhatta, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: “Yes, sir,” replied Sunakkhatta.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: The Buddha said this:
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: “Sunakkhatta, there are these five kinds of sensual stimulation.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: What five?
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: Sights known by the eye, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: Sounds known by the ear …
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: Smells known by the nose …
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: Tastes known by the tongue …
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: Touches known by the body, which are likable, desirable, agreeable, pleasant, sensual, and arousing.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: These are the five kinds of sensual stimulation.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: It’s possible that a certain individual may be intent on worldly pleasures of the flesh.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: Such an individual engages in pertinent conversation, thinking and considering in line with that. They associate with that kind of person, and they find it satisfying.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: But when talk connected with the imperturbable is going on they don’t want to listen. They don’t actively listen or try to understand. They don’t associate with that kind of person, and they don’t find it satisfying.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: Suppose a person had left their own village or town long ago,
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: and they saw another person who had only recently left there.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: They would ask about whether their village was safe, with plenty of food and little disease,
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: and the other person would tell them the news.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: What do you think, Sunakkhatta?
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: Would that person want to listen to that other person? Would they actively listen and try to understand? Would they associate with that person, and find it satisfying?”
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: “Yes, sir.”
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: “In the same way, it’s possible that a certain individual may be intent on worldly pleasures of the flesh.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: Such an individual engages in pertinent conversation, thinking and considering in line with that. They associate with that kind of person, and they find it satisfying.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: But when talk connected with the imperturbable is going on they don’t want to listen. They don’t actively listen or try to understand. They don’t associate with that kind of person, and they don’t find it satisfying.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: You should know of them:
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: ‘That individual is intent on pleasures of the flesh, for they’re detached from things connected with the imperturbable.’
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: It’s possible that a certain individual may be intent on the imperturbable.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: Such an individual engages in pertinent conversation, thinking and considering in line with that. They associate with that kind of person, and they find it satisfying.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: But when talk connected with worldly pleasures of the flesh is going on they don’t want to listen. They don’t actively listen or try to understand. They don’t associate with that kind of person, and they don’t find it satisfying.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: Suppose there was a fallen, withered leaf. It’s incapable of becoming green again.
