title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: It’s possible that a certain individual may be intent on the dimension of nothingness.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: Such an individual engages in pertinent conversation, thinking and considering in line with that. They associate with that kind of person, and they find it satisfying.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: But when talk connected with the imperturbable is going on they don’t want to listen. They don’t actively listen or try to understand. They don’t associate with that kind of person, and they don’t find it satisfying.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: Suppose there was a broad rock that had been broken in half, so that it could not be put back together again.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: In the same way, an individual intent on the dimension of nothingness has broken the connection with the imperturbable.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: You should know of them:
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: ‘That individual is intent on the dimension of nothingness, for they’re detached from things connected with the imperturbable.’
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: It’s possible that a certain individual may be intent on the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: Such an individual engages in pertinent conversation, thinking and considering in line with that. They associate with that kind of person, and they find it satisfying.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: But when talk connected with the dimension of nothingness is going on they don’t want to listen. They don’t actively listen or try to understand. They don’t associate with that kind of person, and they don’t find it satisfying.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: Suppose someone had eaten some delectable food and thrown it up.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: What do you think, Sunakkhatta?
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: Would that person want to eat that food again?”
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: “No, sir.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: Why is that?
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: Because that food is deemed repulsive.”
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: “In the same way, an individual intent on the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception has vomited the connection with the dimension of nothingness.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: You should know of them:
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: ‘That individual is intent on the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception, for they’re detached from things connected with the dimension of nothingness.’
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: It’s possible that a certain individual may be rightly intent on extinguishment.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: Such an individual engages in pertinent conversation, thinking and considering in line with that. They associate with that kind of person, and they find it satisfying.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: But when talk connected with the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception is going on they don’t want to listen. They don’t actively listen or try to understand. They don’t associate with that kind of person, and they don’t find it satisfying.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: Suppose there was a palm tree with its crown cut off. It’s incapable of further growth.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: In the same way, an individual rightly intent on extinguishment has cut off the connection with the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception at the root, made it like a palm stump, obliterated it, so it’s unable to arise in the future.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: You should know of them:
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: ‘That individual is rightly intent on extinguishment, for they’re detached from things connected with the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.’
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: It’s possible that a certain mendicant might think:
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: ‘The Ascetic has said that craving is a dart; and that the poison of ignorance is inflicted by desire and ill will.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: I have given up the dart of craving and expelled the poison of ignorance; I am rightly intent on extinguishment.’
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: Having such conceit, though it’s not based in fact,
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: they would engage in things unconducive to extinguishment: unsuitable sights, sounds, smells, tastes, touches, and ideas.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: Doing so, lust infects their mind,
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: resulting in death or deadly pain.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: Suppose a man was struck by an arrow thickly smeared with poison.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: Their friends and colleagues, relatives and kin would get a surgeon to treat them.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: The surgeon would cut open the wound with a scalpel,
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: probe for the arrow,
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: extract it, and expel the poison, leaving some residue behind.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: Imagining that no residue remained, the surgeon would say:
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: ‘My good man, the dart has been extracted and the poison expelled without residue.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: It is still capable of harming you.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: Eat only suitable food. Don’t eat unsuitable food, or else the wound may get infected.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: Regularly wash the wound and anoint the opening, or else it’ll get covered with pus and blood.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: Don’t walk too much in the wind and sun, or else dust and dirt will infect the wound.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: Take care of the wound, my good fellow, heal it.’
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: They’d think:
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: ‘The dart has been extracted and the poison expelled with no residue.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: It’s not capable of harming me.’
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: They’d eat unsuitable food, and the wound would get infected.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: And they wouldn’t regularly wash and anoint the opening, so it would get covered in pus and blood.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: And they’d walk too much in the wind and sun, so dust and dirt infected the wound.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: And they wouldn’t take care of the wound or heal it.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: Then both because they did what was unsuitable, and because of the residue of unclean poison, the wound would spread,
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: resulting in death or deadly pain.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: In the same way, it’s possible that a certain mendicant might think:
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: ‘The Ascetic has said that craving is a dart; and that the poison of ignorance is inflicted by desire and ill will.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: I have given up the dart of craving and expelled the poison of ignorance; I am rightly intent on extinguishment.’
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: Having such conceit, though it’s not based in fact,
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: they would engage in things unconducive to extinguishment: unsuitable sights, sounds, smells, tastes, touches, and ideas.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: Doing so, lust infects their mind,
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: resulting in death or deadly pain.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: For it is death in the training of the Noble One to reject the training and return to a lesser life.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: And it is deadly pain to commit one of the corrupt offenses.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: It’s possible that a certain mendicant might think:
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: ‘The Ascetic has said that craving is a dart; and that the poison of ignorance is inflicted by desire and ill will.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: I have given up the dart of craving and expelled the poison of ignorance; I am rightly intent on extinguishment.’
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: Being rightly intent on extinguishment, they wouldn’t engage in things unconducive to extinguishment: unsuitable sights, sounds, smells, tastes, touches, and ideas.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: Doing so, lust wouldn’t infect their mind,
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: so no death or deadly pain would result.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: Suppose a man was struck by an arrow thickly smeared with poison.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: Their friends and colleagues, relatives and kin would get a surgeon to treat them.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: The surgeon would cut open the wound with a scalpel,
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: probe for the arrow,
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: extract it, and expel the poison, leaving no residue behind.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: Knowing that no residue remained, the surgeon would say:
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: ‘My good man, the dart has been extracted and the poison expelled with no residue.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: It’s not capable of harming you.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: Eat only suitable food. Don’t eat unsuitable food, or else the wound may get infected.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: Regularly wash the wound and anoint the opening, or else it’ll get covered with pus and blood.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: Don’t walk too much in the wind and sun, or else dust and dirt will infect the wound.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: Take care of the wound, my good fellow, heal it.’
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: They’d think:
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: ‘The dart has been extracted and the poison expelled with no residue.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: It’s not capable of harming me.’
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: They’d eat suitable food, and the wound wouldn’t get infected.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: And they’d regularly wash and anoint the opening, so it wouldn’t get covered in pus and blood.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: And they wouldn’t walk too much in the wind and sun, so dust and dirt wouldn’t infect the wound.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: And they’d take care of the wound and heal it.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: Then both because they did what was suitable, and the unclean poison had left no residue, the wound would heal,
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: and no death or deadly pain would result.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: In the same way, it’s possible that a certain mendicant might think:
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: ‘The Ascetic has said that craving is a dart; and that the poison of ignorance is inflicted by desire and ill will.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: I have given up the dart of craving and expelled the poison of ignorance; I am rightly intent on extinguishment.’
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: Being rightly intent on extinguishment, they wouldn’t engage in things unconducive to extinguishment: unsuitable sights, sounds, smells, tastes, touches, and ideas.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: Doing so, lust wouldn’t infect their mind,
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: so no death or deadly pain would result.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: I’ve made up this simile to make a point.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: And this is the point:
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: ‘Wound’ is a term for the six interior sense fields.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: ‘Poison’ is a term for ignorance.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: ‘Dart’ is a term for craving.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: ‘Probing’ is a term for mindfulness.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: ‘Scalpel’ is a term for noble wisdom.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: ‘Surgeon’ is a term for the Realized One, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: Truly, Sunakkhatta, that mendicant practices restraint regarding the six fields of contact.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: Understanding that attachment is the root of suffering, they are freed with the ending of attachments. It’s not possible that they would apply their body or interest their mind in any attachment.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: Suppose there was a bronze goblet of beverage that had a nice color, aroma, and flavor.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: But it was mixed with poison.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: Then a person would come along who wants to live and doesn’t want to die, who wants to be happy and recoils from pain.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: What do you think, Sunakkhatta?
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: Would that person drink that beverage if they knew that
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: it would result in death or deadly suffering?”
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: “No, sir.”
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: “In the same way, Sunakkhatta, that mendicant practices restraint regarding the six fields of contact.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: Understanding that attachment is the root of suffering, they are freed with the ending of attachments. It’s not possible that they would apply their body or interest their mind in any attachment.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: Suppose there was a lethal viper.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: Then a person would come along who wants to live and doesn’t want to die, who wants to be happy and recoils from pain.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: What do you think, Sunakkhatta?
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: Would that person give that lethal viper their hand or finger if they knew that
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: it would result in death or deadly suffering?”
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: “No, sir.”
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: “In the same way, Sunakkhatta, that mendicant practices restraint regarding the six fields of contact.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: Understanding that attachment is the root of suffering, they are freed with the ending of attachments. It’s not possible that they would apply their body or interest their mind in any attachment.”
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: That is what the Buddha said.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: Satisfied, Sunakkhatta of the Licchavi clan approved what the Buddha said.
title: With Sunakkhatta

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Kurus, near the Kuru town named Kammāsadamma.
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: “Mendicants!”
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: “Venerable sir,” they replied.
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: The Buddha said this:
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: “Mendicants, sensual pleasures are impermanent, hollow, false, and deceptive.
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: This is made by illusion, mendicants, lamented by fools.
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: Sensual pleasures in this life and in lives to come,
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: sensual perceptions in this life and in lives to come;
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: both of these are Māra’s dominion, Māra’s domain, Māra’s lair, and Māra’s range.
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: They conduce to bad, unskillful qualities such as desire, ill will, and aggression.
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: And they create an obstacle for a noble disciple training here.
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: A noble disciple reflects on this:
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: ‘Sensual pleasures in this life and in lives to come,
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: sensual perceptions in this life and in lives to come;
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: both of these are Māra’s dominion, Māra’s domain, Māra’s lair, and Māra’s range.
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: They conduce to bad, unskillful qualities such as desire, ill will, and aggression.
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: And they create an obstacle for a noble disciple training here.
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: Why don’t I meditate with an abundant, expansive heart, having mastered the world and stabilized the mind?
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: Then I will have no more bad, unskillful qualities such as desire, ill will, and aggression.
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: And by giving them up my mind, no longer limited, will become limitless and well developed.’
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: Practicing in this way and meditating on it often their mind becomes confident in this dimension.
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: Being confident, they either attain the imperturbable now, or are freed by wisdom.
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: When their body breaks up, after death, it’s possible that that conducive consciousness will be reborn in the imperturbable.
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: This is said to be the first way of practice suitable for attaining the imperturbable.
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: Furthermore, a noble disciple reflects:
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: ‘Sensual pleasures in this life and in lives to come,
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: sensual perceptions in this life and in lives to come;
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: whatever form there is, all form is the four principal states, or form derived from the four principal states.’
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: Practicing in this way and meditating on it often their mind becomes confident in this dimension.
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: Being confident, they either attain the imperturbable now, or are freed by wisdom.
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: When their body breaks up, after death, it’s possible that that conducive consciousness will be reborn in the imperturbable.
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: ‘Sensual pleasures in this life and in lives to come,
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: sensual perceptions in this life and in lives to come,
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: visions in this life and in lives to come,
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: perceptions of visions in this life and in lives to come;
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: all of these are impermanent.
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: And what’s impermanent is not worth approving, welcoming, or clinging to.’
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: sensual perceptions in this life and in lives to come,
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: Where they cease without anything left over, that is peaceful, that is sublime,
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: namely the dimension of nothingness.’
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: Practicing in this way and meditating on it often their mind becomes confident in this dimension.
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: Being confident, they either attain the dimension of nothingness now, or are freed by wisdom.
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: When their body breaks up, after death, it’s possible that that conducive consciousness will be reborn in the dimension of nothingness.
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: This is said to be the first way of practice suitable for attaining the dimension of nothingness.
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: Furthermore, a noble disciple has gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut, and reflects like this:
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: ‘This is empty of a self or what belongs to a self.’
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: Practicing in this way and meditating on it often their mind becomes confident in this dimension.
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: Being confident, they either attain the dimension of nothingness now, or are freed by wisdom.
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: When their body breaks up, after death, it’s possible that that conducive consciousness will be reborn in the dimension of nothingness.
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: This is said to be the second way of practice suitable for attaining the dimension of nothingness.
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: Furthermore, a noble disciple reflects:
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: ‘I don’t belong to anyone anywhere! And nothing belongs to me anywhere!’
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: Practicing in this way and meditating on it often their mind becomes confident in this dimension.
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: Being confident, they either attain the dimension of nothingness now, or are freed by wisdom.

segment_text: When their body breaks up, after death, it’s possible that that conducive consciousness will be reborn in the dimension of nothingness.
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: ‘Sensual pleasures in this life and in lives to come,
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: sensual perceptions in this life and in lives to come,
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: visions in this life and in lives to come,
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: perceptions of visions in this life and in lives to come,
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: perceptions of the imperturbable, and perceptions of the dimension of nothingness;
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: all are perceptions.
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: Where they cease without anything left over, that is peaceful, that is sublime,
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: namely the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.’
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: Practicing in this way and meditating on it often their mind becomes confident in this dimension.
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: Being confident, they either attain the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception now, or are freed by wisdom.
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: When their body breaks up, after death, it’s possible that that conducive consciousness will be reborn in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: This is said to be the way of practice suitable for attaining the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.”
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: When he said this, Venerable Ānanda said to the Buddha:
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: “Sir, take a mendicant who practices like this:
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: ‘It might not be, and it might not be mine. It will not be, and it will not be mine. I am giving up what exists, what has come to be.’
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: In this way they gain equanimity.
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: Would that mendicant become extinguished or not?”
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: “One such mendicant might become extinguished, Ānanda, while another might not.”
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: “What is the cause, sir, what is the reason for this?”
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: “Ānanda, take a mendicant who practices like this:
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: ‘It might not be, and it might not be mine. It will not be, and it will not be mine. I am giving up what exists, what has come to be.’
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: In this way they gain equanimity.
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: They approve, welcome, and keep clinging to that equanimity.
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: Their consciousness has that as support and fuel for grasping.
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: A mendicant with fuel for grasping does not become extinguished.”
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: “But sir, what is that mendicant grasping?”
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: “The dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.”
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: “Sir, it seems that mendicant is grasping the best thing to grasp!”
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: “Indeed, Ānanda.
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: For the best thing to grasp is
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: Take a mendicant who practices like this:
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: ‘It might not be, and it might not be mine. It will not be, and it will not be mine. I am giving up what exists, what has come to be.’
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: In this way they gain equanimity.
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: They don’t approve, welcome, or keep clinging to that equanimity.
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: So their consciousness doesn’t have that as support and fuel for grasping.
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: A mendicant free of grasping becomes extinguished.”
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: “It’s incredible, sir, it’s amazing!
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: It seems the Buddha has explained to us how to cross over the flood by relying on one support or another.
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: But sir, what is noble liberation?”
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: “Ānanda, it’s when a noble disciple reflects like this:
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: ‘Sensual pleasures in this life and in lives to come,
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: sensual perceptions in this life and in lives to come,
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: visions in this life and in lives to come,
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: perceptions of visions in this life and in lives to come,
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: perceptions of the imperturbable, perceptions of the dimension of nothingness, perceptions of the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception;
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: that is substantial reality as far as substantial reality extends.
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: But this is freedom from death, namely the liberation of the mind through not grasping.
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: So, Ānanda, I have taught the ways of practice suitable for attaining the imperturbable, the dimension of nothingness, and the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception. I have taught how to cross the flood by relying on one support or another, and I have taught noble liberation.
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: Out of sympathy, I’ve done what a teacher should do who wants what’s best for their disciples.
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: Here are these roots of trees, and here are these empty huts. Practice absorption, Ānanda! Don’t be negligent! Don’t regret it later! This is my instruction to you.”
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: That is what the Buddha said.
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: Satisfied, Venerable Ānanda approved what the Buddha said.
title: Conducive to the Imperturbable

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in the stilt longhouse of Migāra’s mother in the Eastern Monastery.
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: Then the brahmin Moggallāna the Accountant went up to the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to the Buddha:
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: “Worthy Gotama, in this stilt longhouse we can see gradual progress
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: down to the last step of the staircase.
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: Among the brahmins we can see gradual progress
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: in recitation.
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: Among archers we can see gradual progress
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: in archery.
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: Among us accountants, who earn a living by accounting, we can see gradual progress
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: in mathematics.
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: For when we get an apprentice we first make them count:
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: ‘One one, two twos, three threes, four fours, five fives, six sixes, seven sevens, eight eights, nine nines, ten tens.’
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: We even make them count up to a hundred.
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: Is it possible to similarly describe a gradual training, gradual progress, and gradual practice in this teaching and training?”
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: “It is possible, brahmin.
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: Suppose a deft horse trainer were to obtain a fine thoroughbred. First of all he’d make it get used to wearing the bit.
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: In the same way, when the Realized One gets a person for training they first guide them like this:
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: ‘Come, mendicant, be ethical and restrained in the monastic code, conducting yourself well and resorting for alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, keep the rules you’ve undertaken.’
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: When they have ethical conduct, the Realized One guides them further:
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: ‘Come, mendicant, guard your sense doors. When you see a sight with your eyes, don’t get caught up in the features and details.
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: If the faculty of sight were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure would become overwhelming. For this reason, practice restraint, protect the faculty of sight, and achieve restraint over it.
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: When you hear a sound with your ears …
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: When you smell an odor with your nose …
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: When you taste a flavor with your tongue …
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: When you feel a touch with your body …
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: When you know an idea with your mind, don’t get caught up in the features and details.
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: If the faculty of mind were left unrestrained, bad unskillful qualities of covetousness and displeasure would become overwhelming. For this reason, practice restraint, protect the faculty of mind, and achieve its restraint.’
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: When they guard their sense doors, the Realized One guides them further:
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: ‘Come, mendicant, eat in moderation.
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: Reflect rationally on the food that you eat:
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: ‘Not for fun, indulgence, adornment, or decoration, but only to sustain this body, to avoid harm, and to support spiritual practice. In this way, I shall put an end to old discomfort and not give rise to new discomfort, and I will have the means to keep going, blamelessness, and a comfortable abiding.’
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: When they eat in moderation, the Realized One guides them further:
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: ‘Come, mendicant, be committed to wakefulness. Practice walking and sitting meditation by day, purifying your mind from obstacles. In the first watch of the night, continue to practice walking and sitting meditation. In the middle watch, lie down in the lion’s posture—on the right side, placing one foot on top of the other—mindful and aware, and focused on the time of getting up. In the last watch, get up and continue to practice walking and sitting meditation, purifying your mind from obstacles.’
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: When they are committed to wakefulness, the Realized One guides them further:
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: ‘Come, mendicant, have mindfulness and situational awareness. Act with situational awareness when going out and coming back; when looking ahead and aside; when bending and extending the limbs; when bearing the outer robe, bowl and robes; when eating, drinking, chewing, and tasting; when urinating and defecating; when walking, standing, sitting, sleeping, waking, speaking, and keeping silent.’
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: When they have mindfulness and situational awareness, the Realized One guides them further:
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: ‘Come, mendicant, frequent a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw.’
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: And they do so.
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: After the meal, they return from almsround, sit down cross-legged, set their body straight, and establish mindfulness in their presence.
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: Giving up covetousness for the world, they meditate with a heart rid of covetousness, cleansing the mind of covetousness.
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: Giving up ill will and malevolence, they meditate with a mind rid of ill will, full of sympathy for all living beings, cleansing the mind of ill will.
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: Giving up dullness and drowsiness, they meditate with a mind rid of dullness and drowsiness, perceiving light, mindful and aware, cleansing the mind of dullness and drowsiness.
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: Giving up restlessness and remorse, they meditate without restlessness, their mind peaceful inside, cleansing the mind of restlessness and remorse.
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: Giving up doubt, they meditate having gone beyond doubt, not undecided about skillful qualities, cleansing the mind of doubt.
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: They give up these five hindrances, corruptions of the heart that weaken wisdom.
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: Then, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, they enter and remain in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, they enter and remain in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: And with the fading away of rapture, they enter and remain in the third absorption, where they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: Giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, they enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: That’s how I instruct the mendicants who are trainees—who haven’t achieved their heart’s desire, but live aspiring to the supreme sanctuary from the yoke.
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: But for those mendicants who are perfected—who have ended the defilements, completed the spiritual journey, done what had to be done, laid down the burden, achieved their own goal, utterly ended the fetter of continued existence, and are rightly freed through enlightenment—these things lead to blissful meditation in this life, and to mindfulness and awareness.”
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: When he had spoken, Moggallāna the Accountant said to the Buddha,
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: “When his disciples are instructed and advised like this by the worthy Gotama, do all of them achieve the ultimate goal, extinguishment, or do some of them fail?”
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: “Some succeed, while others fail.”
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: “What is the cause, worthy Gotama, what is the reason why, though extinguishment is present, the path leading to extinguishment is present, and the worthy Gotama is present to encourage them,
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: still some succeed while others fail?”
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: “Well then, brahmin, I’ll ask you about this in return, and you can answer as you like.
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: What do you think, brahmin?
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: Are you skilled in the road to Rājagaha?”
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: “Yes, I am.”
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: “What do you think, brahmin?
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: Suppose a person was to come along who wanted to go to Rājagaha.
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: He’d approach you and say:
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: ‘Sir, I wish to go to Rājagaha.
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: Please point out the road to Rājagaha.’
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: You’d say to them:
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: ‘Here, worthy man, this road goes to Rājagaha.
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: Go along it for an hour, and you’ll see a certain village. Go along an hour further, and you’ll see a certain town.
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: Go along an hour further and you’ll see Rājagaha with its delightful parks, woods, meadows, and lotus ponds.’
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: Instructed like this by you, they might still take the wrong road, heading west.
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: But a second person might come with the same question and receive the same instructions.
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: Instructed by you, they might safely arrive at Rājagaha.
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: What is the cause, brahmin, what is the reason why, though Rājagaha is present, the path leading to Rājagaha is present, and you are there to encourage them,
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: one person takes the wrong path and heads west, while another arrives safely at Rājagaha?”
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: “What can I do about that, worthy Gotama?
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: I am the one who shows the way.”
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: “In the same way, though extinguishment is present, the path leading to extinguishment is present, and I am present to encourage them,
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: still some of my disciples, instructed and advised like this, achieve the ultimate goal, extinguishment, while some of them fail.
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: What can I do about that, brahmin?
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: The Realized One is the one who shows the way.”
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: When he had spoken, Moggallāna the Accountant said to the Buddha,
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: “Worthy Gotama, there are those faithless people who went forth from the lay life to homelessness not out of faith but to earn a livelihood. They’re devious, deceitful, and sneaky. They’re restless, insolent, fickle, scurrilous, and loose-tongued. They do not guard their sense doors or eat in moderation, and they are not committed to wakefulness. They don’t care about the ascetic life, and don’t keenly respect the training. They’re indulgent and slack, leaders in backsliding, neglecting seclusion, lazy, and lacking energy. They’re unmindful, lacking situational awareness and immersion, with straying minds, witless and idiotic. the worthy Gotama does not live together with these.
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: But there are those gentlemen who went forth from the lay life to homelessness out of faith. They’re not devious, deceitful, and sneaky. They’re not restless, insolent, fickle, scurrilous, and loose-tongued. They guard their sense doors and eat in moderation, and they are committed to wakefulness. They care about the ascetic life, and keenly respect the training. They’re not indulgent or slack, nor are they leaders in backsliding, neglecting seclusion. They’re energetic and determined. They’re mindful, with situational awareness, immersion, and unified minds; wise and clever. the worthy Gotama does live together with these.
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: Of all kinds of fragrant root, spikenard is said to be the best.
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: Of all kinds of fragrant heartwood, red sandalwood is said to be the best.
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: Of all kinds of fragrant flower, jasmine is said to be the best.
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: In the same way, worthy Gotama’s advice is the best of contemporary teachings.
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: Excellent, worthy Gotama! Excellent!
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, worthy Gotama has made the Teaching clear in many ways.
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: I go for refuge to the worthy Gotama, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: From this day forth, may the worthy Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
title: With Moggallāna the Accountant

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: At one time Venerable Ānanda was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground. It was not long after the Buddha had become fully quenched.
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: Now at that time King Ajātasattu of Magadha, son of the princess of Videha, being suspicious of King Pajjota, was having Rājagaha fortified.
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: Then Venerable Ānanda robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Rājagaha for alms.
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: Then it occurred to him,
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: “It’s too early to wander for alms in Rājagaha.
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: Why don’t I go to see the brahmin Moggallāna the Guardian at his place of work?”
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: So that’s what he did.
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: Moggallāna the Guardian saw Ānanda coming off in the distance
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: and said to him,
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: “Come, worthy Ānanda!
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: Welcome, worthy Ānanda!
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: It’s been a long time since you took the opportunity to come here.
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: Please, sir, sit down, this seat is ready.”
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: Ānanda sat down on the seat spread out,
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: while Moggallāna took a low seat and sat to one side.
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: Then he said to Ānanda,
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: “Worthy Ānanda, is there even a single mendicant who has all the same qualities in each and every way as possessed by the worthy Gotama, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha?”
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: “No, brahmin, there is not.
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: For the Blessed One gave rise to the unarisen path, gave birth to the unborn path, and explained the unexplained path. He is the knower of the path, the discoverer of the path, the expert on the path.
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: And now the disciples live following the path; they acquire it later.”
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: But this conversation between Ānanda and Moggallāna the Guardian was left unfinished.
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: For just then the brahmin Vassakāra, a minister of Magadha, while supervising the work at Rājagaha, approached Ānanda at Moggallāna’s place of work and exchanged greetings with him.
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to Ānanda,
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: “Worthy Ānanda, what were you sitting talking about just now? What conversation was left unfinished?”
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: So Ānanda told him of the conversation that they were having when Vassakāra arrived. Vassakāra said:
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: “Worthy Ānanda, is there even a single mendicant who was appointed by the worthy Gotama, saying:
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: ‘This one will be your refuge when I have passed away,’ to whom you would now turn?”
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: “No, there is not.”
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: “But is there even a single mendicant who has been elected to such a position by the Saṅgha and appointed by several senior mendicants?”
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: “No, there is not.”
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: “But since you lack a refuge, worthy Ānanda, what’s the reason for your harmony?”
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: “We don’t lack a refuge, brahmin,
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: we have a refuge.
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: The teaching is our refuge.”
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: “But worthy Ānanda, when asked whether there was even a single mendicant—either appointed by the Buddha,
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: or elected by the Saṅgha and appointed by several senior mendicants—
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: who serves as your refuge after the Buddha passed away, to whom you now turn,
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: you replied, ‘No, there is not.’
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: But you say that the reason for your harmony is that you have
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: the teaching as a refuge.
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: How should I see the meaning of this statement?”
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: “The Blessed One, who knows and sees, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha laid down training rules and recited the monastic code for the mendicants.
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: On the day of the sabbath all of us who live in dependence on one village district gather together as one.
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: We invite one who transmits the code to recite it.
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: If anyone remembers an offense or transgression while they’re reciting, we make them act in line with the teachings and in line with the instructions.
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: It’s not the good fellows who make us act,
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: it’s the teaching that makes us act.”
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: “Worthy Ānanda, is there even a single mendicant who you honor, respect, revere, venerate, and rely on?”
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: “There is not, brahmin.”
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: “Worthy Ānanda, when asked whether there was even a single mendicant—either appointed by the Buddha,
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: or elected by the Saṅgha and appointed by several senior mendicants—
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: who serves as your refuge after the Buddha passed away, to whom you now turn,
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: you replied, ‘No, there is not.’
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: And when asked whether there is even a single mendicant who you honor, respect, revere, venerate, and rely on,
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: you replied, ‘There is not.’
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: How should I see the meaning of this statement?”
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: “There are ten inspiring things explained by the Blessed One, who knows and sees, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: We honor anyone in whom these things are found.
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: What ten?
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: It’s when a mendicant is ethical, restrained in the monastic code, conducting themselves well and resorting for alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, they keep the rules they’ve undertaken.
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: They’re very learned, remembering and keeping what they’ve learned.
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: These teachings are good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased, describing a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure. They are very learned in such teachings, remembering them, rehearsing them, mentally scrutinizing them, and comprehending them theoretically.
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: They’re content with robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and supplies for the sick.
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: They get the four absorptions—blissful meditations in this life that belong to the higher mind—when they want, without trouble or difficulty.
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: They wield the many kinds of psychic power: multiplying themselves and becoming one again; appearing and disappearing; going unobstructed through a wall, a rampart, or a mountain as if through space; diving in and out of the earth as if it were water; walking on water as if it were earth; flying cross-legged through the sky like a bird; touching and stroking with the hand the sun and moon, so mighty and powerful. They control the body as far as the realm of divinity.
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: With clairaudience that is purified and superhuman, they hear both kinds of sounds, human and heavenly, whether near or far.
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: They understand the minds of other beings and individuals, having comprehended them with their own mind.
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: They understand mind with greed as ‘mind with greed’,
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: and mind without greed as ‘mind without greed’.
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: They understand mind with hate …
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: mind without hate …
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: mind with delusion …
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: mind without delusion …
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: constricted mind …
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: scattered mind …
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: expansive mind …
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: unexpansive mind …
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: mind that is not supreme …
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: mind that is supreme …
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: mind immersed in samādhi …
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: mind not immersed in samādhi …
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: freed mind …
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: They understand unfreed mind as ‘unfreed mind’.
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: They recollect many kinds of past lives. That is: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. They remember: ‘There, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn somewhere else. There, too, I was named this, my clan was that, I looked like this, and that was my food. This was how I felt pleasure and pain, and that was how my life ended. When I passed away from that place I was reborn here.’ And so they recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds.
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: They realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: These are the ten inspiring things explained by the Blessed One, who knows and sees, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: We honor anyone in whom these things are found, and rely on them.”
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: When he had spoken, Vassakāra addressed General Upananda,
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: “What do you think, general?
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: Do these venerables honor, respect, revere, and venerate those who are worthy?”
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: “Indeed they do.
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: For if these venerables were not to honor, respect, revere, and venerate them,
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: then who exactly would they honor?”
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: Then Vassakāra said to Ānanda,
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: “Where are you staying at present?”
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: “In the Bamboo Grove, brahmin.”
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: “I hope the Bamboo Grove is delightful, quiet and still, far from the madding crowd, remote from human settlements, and fit for retreat?”
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: “Indeed it is, brahmin. And it is like that owing to such protectors and guardians as yourself.”
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: “Surely, worthy Ānanda, it is owing to the good fellows who meditate, making a habit of meditating.
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: For the good fellows do in fact meditate and make a habit of meditating.
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: This one time, worthy Ānanda, worthy Gotama was staying near Vesālī, at the Great Wood, in the hall with the peaked roof.
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: So I went there to see him.
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: And there he spoke about meditation in many ways.
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: He meditated, and made a habit of meditating.
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: And he praised all kinds of meditation.”
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: “No, brahmin, the Buddha did not praise all kinds of meditation, nor did he dispraise all kinds of meditation.
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: And what kind of meditation did he not praise?
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: It’s when someone’s heart is overcome and mired in sensual desire, and they don’t truly understand the escape from sensual desire that has arisen.
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: Hiding sensual desire within, they meditate and concentrate and contemplate and ruminate.
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: Their heart is overcome and mired in ill will …
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: dullness and drowsiness …
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: restlessness and remorse …
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: doubt, and they don’t truly know and see the escape from doubt that has arisen.
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: Hiding doubt within, they meditate and concentrate and contemplate and ruminate.
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: The Buddha didn’t praise this kind of meditation.
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: And what kind of meditation did he praise?
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: It’s when a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, they enter and remain in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: And with the fading away of rapture, they enter and remain in the third absorption, where they meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: Giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, they enter and remain in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: The Buddha praised this kind of meditation.”
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: “Well, worthy Ānanda, it seems that worthy Gotama criticized the kind of meditation that deserves criticism and praised that deserving of praise.
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: Well, now, worthy Ānanda, I must go.
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: I have many duties, and much to do.”
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: “Please, brahmin, go at your convenience.”
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: Then Vassakāra the brahmin, having approved and agreed with what Venerable Ānanda said, got up from his seat and left.
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: Soon after he had left, Moggallāna the Guardian said to Ānanda,
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: “Worthy Ānanda, you still haven’t answered my question.”
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: “But brahmin, didn’t I say:
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: ‘There is no single mendicant who has all the same qualities in each and every way as possessed by the worthy Gotama, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha.
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: For the Blessed One gave rise to the unarisen path, gave birth to the unborn path, and explained the unexplained path. He is the knower of the path, the discoverer of the path, the expert on the path.
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: And now the disciples live following the path; they acquire it later.’”
title: With Moggallāna the Guardian

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in the stilt longhouse of Migāra’s mother in the Eastern Monastery.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: Now, at that time it was the sabbath—the full moon on the fifteenth day—and the Buddha was sitting in the open surrounded by the Saṅgha of monks.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: Then one of the mendicants got up from their seat, arranged their robe over one shoulder, raised their joined palms toward the Buddha, and said,
title: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: “I’d like to ask the Buddha about a certain point, if you’d take the time to answer.”
title: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: “Well then, mendicant, take your own seat and ask what you wish.”
title: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: That mendicant took his seat and said to the Buddha:
title: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: “Sir, are these the five grasping aggregates:
title: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness?”
title: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: “Yes, they are,” replied the Buddha.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: Saying “Good, sir”, that mendicant approved and agreed with what the Buddha said. Then he asked another question:
title: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: “But sir, what is the root of these five grasping aggregates?”
title: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: “These five grasping aggregates are rooted in desire.”
title: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: “But sir, is that grasping the exact same thing as the five grasping aggregates? Or is grasping one thing and the five grasping aggregates another?”
title: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: “Neither.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: The desire and greed for the five grasping aggregates is the grasping there.”
title: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: “But sir, can there be different kinds of desire and greed for the five grasping aggregates?”
title: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: “There can,” said the Buddha.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: “It’s when someone thinks:
title: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: ‘In the future, may I be of such form, such feeling, such perception, such choices, and such consciousness!’
title: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: That’s how there can be different kinds of desire and greed for the five grasping aggregates.”
title: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: “Sir, what is the scope of the term ‘aggregates’ as applied to the aggregates?”
title: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: “Any kind of form at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; solid or subtle; inferior or superior; far or near: this is called the aggregate of form.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: Any kind of feeling at all …
title: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: Any kind of perception at all …
title: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: Any kind of choices at all …
title: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: Any kind of consciousness at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; solid or subtle; inferior or superior; far or near: this is called the aggregate of consciousness.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: That’s the scope of the term ‘aggregates’ as applied to the aggregates.”
title: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: “What is the cause, sir, what is the reason why the aggregate of form is found?
title: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: What is the cause, what is the reason why the aggregate of feeling …
title: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: perception …
title: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: choices …
title: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: consciousness is found?”
title: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: “The four principal states are the reason why the aggregate of form is found.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: Contact is the reason why the aggregates of feeling …
title: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: Name and form are the reasons why the aggregate of consciousness is found.”
title: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: “But sir, how does substantialist view come about?”
title: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: “It’s when an unlearned ordinary person has not seen the noble ones, and is neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the noble ones. They’ve not seen true persons, and are neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the true persons.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: They regard form as self, self as having form, form in self, or self in form.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: They regard feeling as self, self as having feeling, feeling in self, or self in feeling.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: They regard perception as self, self as having perception, perception in self, or self in perception.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: They regard choices as self, self as having choices, choices in self, or self in choices.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: They regard consciousness as self, self as having consciousness, consciousness in self, or self in consciousness.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: That’s how substantialist view comes about.”
title: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: “But sir, how does substantialist view not come about?”
title: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: “It’s when a learned noble disciple has seen the noble ones, and is skilled and trained in the teaching of the noble ones. They’ve seen true persons, and are skilled and trained in the teaching of the true persons.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: They don’t regard form as self, self as having form, form in self, or self in form.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: They don’t regard feeling as self, self as having feeling, feeling in self, or self in feeling.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: They don’t regard perception as self, self as having perception, perception in self, or self in perception.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: They don’t regard choices as self, self as having choices, choices in self, or self in choices.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: They don’t regard consciousness as self, self as having consciousness, consciousness in self, or self in consciousness.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: That’s how substantialist view does not come about.”
title: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: Now at that time one of the mendicants had the thought,
title: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: Then what self will the deeds done by not-self affect?”
title: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

title: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

title: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

title: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: Then what self will the deeds done by not-self affect?’
title: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

title: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

title: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

title: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’”
title: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: That is what the Buddha said.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: And while this discourse was being spoken, the minds of sixty mendicants were freed from defilements by not grasping.
title: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in the stilt longhouse of Migāra’s mother in the Eastern Monastery.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: Now, at that time it was the sabbath—the full moon on the fifteenth day—and the Buddha was sitting in the open surrounded by the Saṅgha of monks.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: Then the Buddha looked around the Saṅgha of mendicants, who were so very silent. He addressed them,
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: “Mendicants, could an untrue person know of an untrue person:
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: ‘This worthy one is an untrue person’?”
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: “No, sir.”
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: “Good, mendicants!
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: It’s impossible, it can’t happen, that an untrue person could know of an untrue person:
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: ‘This worthy one is an untrue person.’
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: But could an untrue person know of a true person:
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: ‘This worthy one is a true person’?”
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: “No, sir.”
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: “Good, mendicants!
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: That too is impossible.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: A untrue person has bad qualities, is devoted to untrue persons, and has the intentions, counsel, speech, actions, views, and giving of an untrue person.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: And how does an untrue person have bad qualities?
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: It’s when an untrue person is faithless, shameless, imprudent, unlearned, lazy, unmindful, and witless.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: That’s how an untrue person has bad qualities.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: And how is an untrue person devoted to untrue persons?
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: It’s when an untrue person is a friend and companion of ascetics and brahmins who are faithless, shameless, imprudent, unlearned, lazy, unmindful, and witless.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: That’s how an untrue person is devoted to untrue persons.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: And how does an untrue person have the intentions of an untrue person?
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: It’s when an untrue person intends to hurt themselves, hurt others, and hurt both.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: That’s how an untrue person has the intentions of an untrue person.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: And how does an untrue person offer the counsel of an untrue person?
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: It’s when an untrue person offers counsel that hurts themselves, hurts others, and hurts both.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: That’s how an untrue person offers the counsel of an untrue person.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: And how does an untrue person have the speech of an untrue person?
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: It’s when an untrue person uses speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, and nonsensical.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: That’s how an untrue person has the speech of an untrue person.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: And how does an untrue person have the action of an untrue person?
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: It’s when an untrue person kills living creatures, steals, and commits sexual misconduct.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: That’s how an untrue person has the actions of an untrue person.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: And how does an untrue person have the view of an untrue person?
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: It’s when an untrue person has such a view:
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: ‘There’s no meaning in giving, sacrifice, or offerings. There’s no fruit or result of good and bad deeds. There’s no afterlife. There’s no such thing as mother and father, or beings that are reborn spontaneously. And there’s no ascetic or brahmin who is rightly comported and rightly practiced, and who describes the afterlife after realizing it with their own insight.’
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: That’s how an untrue person has the view of an untrue person.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: And how does an untrue person give the gifts of an untrue person?
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: It’s when an untrue person gives a gift carelessly, not with their own hand, and thoughtlessly. They give the dregs, and they give without consideration for consequences.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: That’s how an untrue person gives the gifts of an untrue person.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: That untrue person—who has such bad qualities, frequents untrue persons, and has the intentions, counsel, speech, actions, views, and giving of an untrue person—
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: when their body breaks up, after death, is reborn in the place where untrue persons are reborn.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

title: The Shorter Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: Hell or the animal realm.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

title: The Shorter Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

title: The Shorter Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

title: The Shorter Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: A true person has good qualities, is devoted to true persons, and has the intentions, counsel, speech, actions, views, and giving of a true person.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: And how does a true person have good qualities?
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: It’s when a true person is faithful, conscientious, prudent, learned, energetic, mindful, and wise.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: That’s how a true person has good qualities.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

title: The Shorter Discourse on the Full-Moon Night
