title: The Shorter Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: That’s how a true person has the intentions of a true person.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: And how does a true person offer the counsel of a true person?
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: It’s when a true person offers counsel that doesn’t hurt themselves, hurt others, and hurt both.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: That’s how a true person offers the counsel of a true person.
title: The Shorter Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

title: The Shorter Discourse on the Full-Moon Night

segment_text: It’s when a true person refrains from killing living creatures, stealing, and committing sexual misconduct.

segment_text: That’s how a true person has the action of a true person.

title: One by One

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
title: One by One

segment_text: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,
title: One by One

segment_text: “Mendicants!”
title: One by One

segment_text: “Venerable sir,” they replied.
title: One by One

segment_text: The Buddha said this:
title: One by One

segment_text: “Sāriputta is astute, mendicants.
title: One by One

segment_text: He has great wisdom,
title: One by One

segment_text: widespread wisdom,
title: One by One

segment_text: laughing wisdom,
title: One by One

segment_text: swift wisdom,
title: One by One

segment_text: sharp wisdom,
title: One by One

segment_text: and penetrating wisdom.
title: One by One

segment_text: For a fortnight he practiced discernment of phenomena one by one.
title: One by One

segment_text: And this is how he did it.
title: One by One

segment_text: Quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, he entered and remained in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
title: One by One

segment_text: And he distinguished the phenomena of the first absorption one by one: placing and keeping and rapture and bliss and unification of mind; contact, feeling, perception, intention, mind, enthusiasm, decision, energy, mindfulness, equanimity, and application of mind.
title: One by One

segment_text: He knew those phenomena as they arose, as they remained, and as they went away.
title: One by One

segment_text: Once I had gone forth, I took up the training and livelihood of the mendicants. I gave up killing living creatures, renouncing the rod and the sword. I was scrupulous and kind, living full of sympathy for all living beings.
title: The Sixfold Purification

segment_text: I gave up stealing. I took only what’s given, and expected only what’s given. I kept myself clean by not thieving.
title: The Sixfold Purification

title: The Sixfold Purification

segment_text: I gave up lying. I spoke the truth and stuck to the truth. I was honest and dependable, not tricking the world with my words.
title: The Sixfold Purification

segment_text: I gave up divisive speech. I didn’t repeat in one place what I heard in another so as to divide people against each other. Instead, I reconciled those who are divided, supporting unity, delighting in harmony, loving harmony, speaking words that promote harmony.

segment_text: I gave up harsh speech. I spoke in a way that’s mellow, pleasing to the ear, lovely, going to the heart, polite, likable and agreeable to the people.

title: Many Elements

segment_text: Consciousness is a condition for name and form.

segment_text: Feeling is a condition for craving.
title: Many Elements

segment_text: Continued existence is a condition for rebirth.

segment_text: Rebirth is a condition for old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress to come to be.

segment_text: When contact ceases, feeling ceases.

segment_text: When feeling ceases, craving ceases.
title: Many Elements

segment_text: When craving ceases, grasping ceases.
title: Many Elements

segment_text: When grasping ceases, continued existence ceases.
title: Many Elements

segment_text: When continued existence ceases, rebirth ceases.
title: Many Elements

segment_text: When rebirth ceases, old age and death, sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress cease.
title: Many Elements

segment_text: That is how this entire mass of suffering ceases.’

segment_text: That’s how a mendicant is qualified to be called ‘skilled in dependent origination’.”

segment_text: Mendicants, when mindfulness of breathing is developed and cultivated it is very fruitful and beneficial.

segment_text: And how is mindfulness of breathing developed and cultivated to be very fruitful and beneficial?
title: Mindfulness of Breathing

segment_text: It’s when a mendicant—gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut—sits down cross-legged, sets their body straight, and establishes mindfulness in their presence.

segment_text: Mindfulness of breathing, when developed and cultivated in this way, is very fruitful and beneficial.

segment_text: And how is mindfulness of breathing developed and cultivated so as to fulfill the four kinds of mindfulness meditation?
title: Mindfulness of Breathing

title: Mindfulness of Breathing

title: Mindfulness of Breathing

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: Then after the meal, on return from almsround, several mendicants sat together in the assembly hall and this discussion came up among them.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: “It’s incredible, reverends, it’s amazing,
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: how the Blessed One, who knows and sees, the perfected one, the fully awakened Buddha has said that mindfulness of the body, when developed and cultivated, is very fruitful and beneficial.”
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: But their conversation was left unfinished. Then the Buddha came out of retreat and went to the assembly hall. He sat on the seat spread out
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: and addressed the mendicants,
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: “Mendicants, what were you sitting talking about just now? What conversation was left unfinished?”
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: So the mendicants told him what they had been talking about. The Buddha said:
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: “And how, mendicants, is mindfulness of the body developed and cultivated to be very fruitful and beneficial?
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: It’s when a mendicant—gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut—sits down cross-legged, sets their body straight, and establishes mindfulness in their presence.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: Just mindful, they breathe in. Mindful, they breathe out.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: Breathing in heavily they know: ‘I’m breathing in heavily.’ Breathing out heavily they know: ‘I’m breathing out heavily.’
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: When breathing in lightly they know: ‘I’m breathing in lightly.’ Breathing out lightly they know: ‘I’m breathing out lightly.’
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in experiencing the whole body.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out experiencing the whole body.’
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe in stilling the physical process.’ They practice like this: ‘I’ll breathe out stilling the physical process.’
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: As they meditate like this—diligent, keen, and resolute—memories and thoughts tied to domestic life are given up.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: Their mind becomes stilled internally; it settles, unifies, and becomes immersed in samādhi.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: That’s how a mendicant develops mindfulness of the body.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: Furthermore, when a mendicant is walking they know ‘I am walking’. When standing they know ‘I am standing’. When sitting they know ‘I am sitting’. And when lying down they know ‘I am lying down’.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: Whatever posture their body is in, they know it.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: As they meditate like this—diligent, keen, and resolute—memories and thoughts tied to domestic life are given up.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: Their mind becomes stilled internally; it settles, unifies, and becomes immersed in samādhi.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: That too is how a mendicant develops mindfulness of the body.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: Furthermore, a mendicant acts with situational awareness when going out and coming back; when looking ahead and aside; when bending and extending the limbs; when bearing the outer robe, bowl and robes; when eating, drinking, chewing, and tasting; when urinating and defecating; when walking, standing, sitting, sleeping, waking, speaking, and keeping silent.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: As they meditate like this—diligent, keen, and resolute—memories and thoughts tied to domestic life are given up.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: Their mind becomes stilled internally; it settles, unifies, and becomes immersed in samādhi.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: That too is how a mendicant develops mindfulness of the body.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: Furthermore, a mendicant examines their own body, up from the soles of the feet and down from the tips of the hairs, wrapped in skin and full of many kinds of filth.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: ‘In this body there is head hair, body hair, nails, teeth, skin, flesh, sinews, bones, bone marrow, kidneys, heart, liver, diaphragm, spleen, lungs, intestines, mesentery, undigested food, feces, bile, phlegm, pus, blood, sweat, fat, tears, grease, saliva, snot, synovial fluid, urine.’
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: It’s as if there were a bag with openings at both ends, filled with various kinds of grains, such as
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: fine rice, wheat, mung beans, peas, sesame, and ordinary rice.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: And someone with clear eyes were to open it and examine the contents:
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: ‘These grains are fine rice, these are wheat, these are mung beans, these are peas, these are sesame, and these are ordinary rice.’
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: In the same way, a mendicant examines their own body, up from the soles of the feet and down from the tips of the hairs, wrapped in skin and full of many kinds of filth. …
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: As they meditate like this—diligent, keen, and resolute—memories and thoughts tied to domestic life are given up.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: Their mind becomes stilled internally; it settles, unifies, and becomes immersed in samādhi.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: That too is how a mendicant develops mindfulness of the body.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: Furthermore, a mendicant examines their own body, whatever its placement or posture, according to the elements:
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: ‘In this body there is the earth element, the water element, the fire element, and the air element.’
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: It’s as if a deft butcher or butcher’s apprentice were to kill a cow and sit down at the crossroads with the meat cut into chops.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: In the same way, a mendicant examines their own body, whatever its placement or posture, according to the elements:
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: ‘In this body there is the earth element, the water element, the fire element, and the air element.’
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: As they meditate like this—diligent, keen, and resolute—memories and thoughts tied to domestic life are given up.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: Their mind becomes stilled internally; it settles, unifies, and becomes immersed in samādhi.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: That too is how a mendicant develops mindfulness of the body.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: Furthermore, suppose a mendicant were to see a corpse discarded in a charnel ground. And it had been dead for one, two, or three days, bloated, livid, and festering.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: They’d compare it with their own body:
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: ‘This body is also of that same nature, that same kind, and cannot go beyond that.’
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: As they meditate like this—diligent, keen, and resolute—memories and thoughts tied to domestic life are given up.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: Their mind becomes stilled internally; it settles, unifies, and becomes immersed in samādhi.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: That too is how a mendicant develops mindfulness of the body.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: Or suppose they were to see a corpse discarded in a charnel ground being devoured by crows, hawks, vultures, herons, dogs, tigers, leopards, jackals, and many kinds of little creatures.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: They’d compare it with their own body:
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: ‘This body is also of that same nature, that same kind, and cannot go beyond that.’
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: That too is how a mendicant develops mindfulness of the body.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: Furthermore, suppose they were to see a corpse discarded in a charnel ground, a skeleton with flesh and blood, held together by sinews …
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: A skeleton without flesh but smeared with blood, and held together by sinews …
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: A skeleton rid of flesh and blood, held together by sinews …
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: Bones rid of sinews scattered in every direction. Here a hand-bone, there a foot-bone, here an ankle bone, there a shin-bone, here a thigh-bone, there a hip-bone, here a rib-bone, there a back-bone, here an arm-bone, there a neck-bone, here a jaw-bone, there a tooth, here the skull. …
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: White bones, the color of shells …
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: Decrepit bones, heaped in a pile …
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: Bones rotted and crumbled to powder.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: They’d compare it with their own body:
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: ‘This body is also of that same nature, that same kind, and cannot go beyond that.’
title: Mindfulness of the Body

title: Mindfulness of the Body

title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: That too is how a mendicant develops mindfulness of the body.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: Furthermore, a mendicant, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unskillful qualities, enters and remains in the first absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of seclusion, while placing the mind and keeping it connected.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: They drench, steep, fill, and spread their body with rapture and bliss born of seclusion. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with rapture and bliss born of seclusion.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: It’s like when a deft bathroom attendant or their apprentice pours bath powder into a bronze dish, sprinkling it little by little with water. They knead it until the ball of bath powder is soaked and saturated with moisture, spread through inside and out; yet no moisture oozes out.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: In the same way, they drench, steep, fill, and spread their body with rapture and bliss born of seclusion. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with rapture and bliss born of seclusion.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: As they meditate like this—diligent, keen, and resolute—memories and thoughts tied to lay life are given up.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: Their mind becomes stilled internally; it settles, unifies, and becomes immersed in samādhi.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: That too is how a mendicant develops mindfulness of the body.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: Furthermore, as the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, a mendicant enters and remains in the second absorption, which has the rapture and bliss born of immersion, with internal clarity and mind at one, without placing the mind and keeping it connected.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: They drench, steep, fill, and spread their body with rapture and bliss born of immersion. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with rapture and bliss born of immersion.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: It’s like a deep lake fed by spring water. There’s no inlet to the east, west, north, or south, and the heavens would not properly bestow showers from time to time. But the stream of cool water welling up in the lake drenches, steeps, fills, and spreads throughout the lake. There’s no part of the lake that’s not spread through with cool water.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: In the same way, a mendicant drenches, steeps, fills, and spreads their body with rapture and bliss born of immersion. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with rapture and bliss born of immersion.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: That too is how a mendicant develops mindfulness of the body.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: Furthermore, with the fading away of rapture, a mendicant enters and remains in the third absorption. They meditate with equanimity, mindful and aware, personally experiencing the bliss of which the noble ones declare, ‘Equanimous and mindful, one meditates in bliss.’
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: They drench, steep, fill, and spread their body with bliss free of rapture. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with bliss free of rapture.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: It’s like a pool with blue water lilies, or pink or white lotuses. Some of them sprout and grow in the water without rising above it, thriving underwater. From the tip to the root they’re drenched, steeped, filled, and soaked with cool water. There’s no part of them that’s not soaked with cool water.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: In the same way, a mendicant drenches, steeps, fills, and spreads their body with bliss free of rapture. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread with bliss free of rapture.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: That too is how a mendicant develops mindfulness of the body.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: Furthermore, a mendicant, giving up pleasure and pain, and ending former happiness and sadness, enters and remains in the fourth absorption, without pleasure or pain, with pure equanimity and mindfulness.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: They sit spreading their body through with pure bright mind. There’s no part of the body that’s not filled with pure bright mind.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: It’s like someone sitting wrapped from head to foot with white cloth. There’s no part of the body that’s not spread over with white cloth.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: In the same way, they sit spreading their body through with pure bright mind. There’s no part of the body that’s not filled with pure bright mind.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: As they meditate like this—diligent, keen, and resolute—memories and thoughts tied to domestic life are given up.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: Their mind becomes stilled internally; it settles, unifies, and becomes immersed in samādhi.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: That too is how a mendicant develops mindfulness of the body.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: Anyone who has developed and cultivated mindfulness of the body includes all of the skillful qualities that play a part in realization.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: Anyone who brings into their mind the great ocean includes all of the streams that run down into it.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: In the same way, anyone who has developed and cultivated mindfulness of the body includes all of the skillful qualities that play a part in realization.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: When a mendicant has not developed or cultivated mindfulness of the body, Māra finds a vulnerability and gets hold of them.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: Suppose a person were to throw a heavy stone ball at a mound of wet clay.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: What do you think, mendicants?
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: Would that heavy stone ball find an entry into that mound of wet clay?”
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: “Yes, sir.”
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: “In the same way, when a mendicant has not developed or cultivated mindfulness of the body, Māra finds a vulnerability and gets hold of them.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

title: Mindfulness of the Body

title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: Suppose a chariot stood harnessed to thoroughbreds at a level crossroads, with a goad ready.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: A deft horse trainer, a master charioteer, might mount the chariot, taking the reins in his right hand and goad in the left. He’d drive out and back wherever he wishes, whenever he wishes.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: In the same way, when a mendicant has developed and cultivated mindfulness of the body, they extend the mind to realize by insight each and every thing that can be realized by insight; and they are capable of realizing those things, since each and every one is within range.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: You can expect ten benefits when mindfulness of the body has been cultivated, developed, and practiced, made a vehicle and a basis, kept up, consolidated, and properly implemented.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: They prevail over desire and discontent, and live having mastered desire and discontent whenever they arose.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: They prevail over fear and dread, and live having mastered fear and dread whenever they arose.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: They endure cold, heat, hunger, and thirst; the touch of flies, mosquitoes, wind, sun, and reptiles; rude and unwelcome criticism; and put up with physical pain—sharp, severe, acute, unpleasant, disagreeable, and life-threatening.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: They get the four absorptions—blissful meditations in this life that belong to the higher mind—when they want, without trouble or difficulty.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: They wield the many kinds of psychic power: multiplying themselves and becoming one again … They control the body as far as the realm of divinity.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: With clairaudience that is purified and superhuman, they hear both kinds of sounds, human and heavenly, whether near or far. …
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: They understand the minds of other beings and individuals, having comprehended them with their own mind. …
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: They recollect many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: They realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.
title: Mindfulness of the Body

segment_text: You can expect these ten benefits when mindfulness of the body has been cultivated, developed, and practiced, made a vehicle and a basis, kept up, consolidated, and properly implemented.”

title: The Shorter Discourse on Emptiness

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in the stilt longhouse of Migāra’s mother in the Eastern Monastery.
title: The Shorter Discourse on Emptiness

segment_text: Then in the late afternoon, Venerable Ānanda came out of retreat and went to the Buddha. He bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him:
title: The Shorter Discourse on Emptiness

segment_text: “Sir, this one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans where they have a town named Townsville.
title: The Shorter Discourse on Emptiness

segment_text: There I heard and learned this in the presence of the Buddha:
title: The Shorter Discourse on Emptiness

segment_text: ‘Ānanda, these days I usually practice the meditation on emptiness.’
title: The Shorter Discourse on Emptiness

segment_text: I trust I properly heard, learned, applied the mind, and remembered that from the Buddha?”
title: The Shorter Discourse on Emptiness

segment_text: “Indeed, Ānanda, you properly heard, learned, applied the mind, and remembered that.
title: The Shorter Discourse on Emptiness

segment_text: Now, as before, I usually practice the meditation on emptiness.
title: The Shorter Discourse on Emptiness

segment_text: Consider this stilt longhouse of Migāra’s mother. It’s empty of elephants, cows, horses, and mares; of gold and silver; and of gatherings of men and women.
title: The Shorter Discourse on Emptiness

segment_text: There is only this that is not emptiness, namely, the oneness dependent on the mendicant Saṅgha.
title: The Shorter Discourse on Emptiness

segment_text: In the same way, a mendicant—ignoring the perception of the village and the perception of people—focuses on the oneness dependent on the perception of wilderness.
title: The Shorter Discourse on Emptiness

segment_text: Their mind leaps forth, gains confidence, settles down, and becomes decided in that perception of wilderness.
title: The Shorter Discourse on Emptiness

segment_text: They understand:
title: The Shorter Discourse on Emptiness

segment_text: ‘Here there is no stress due to the perception of village or the perception of people.
title: The Shorter Discourse on Emptiness

segment_text: There is only this modicum of stress, namely the oneness dependent on the perception of wilderness.’
title: The Shorter Discourse on Emptiness

segment_text: They understand: ‘This field of perception is empty of the perception of the village. It is empty of the perception of people.
title: The Shorter Discourse on Emptiness

segment_text: There is only this that is not emptiness, namely the oneness dependent on the perception of wilderness.’
title: The Shorter Discourse on Emptiness

segment_text: And so they regard it as empty of what is not there, but as to what remains they understand that it is present.
title: The Shorter Discourse on Emptiness

segment_text: That’s how emptiness manifests in them—genuine, undistorted, and pure.
title: The Shorter Discourse on Emptiness

segment_text: Furthermore, a mendicant—ignoring the perception of people and the perception of wilderness—focuses on the oneness dependent on the perception of earth.
title: The Shorter Discourse on Emptiness

segment_text: Their mind leaps forth, gains confidence, settles down, and becomes decided in that perception of earth.
title: The Shorter Discourse on Emptiness

segment_text: As a bull’s hide is rid of folds when fully stretched out by a hundred pegs,
title: The Shorter Discourse on Emptiness

segment_text: so too, ignoring the hilly terrain, inaccessible riverlands, stumps and thorns, and rugged mountains, they focus on the oneness dependent on the perception of earth.

segment_text: And their disciples want to listen. They actively listen and try to understand. They don’t proceed having turned away from the Teacher’s instruction.

title: The Longer Discourse on Emptiness

segment_text: So, Ānanda, treat me as a friend, not as an enemy.
title: The Longer Discourse on Emptiness

segment_text: That will be for your lasting welfare and happiness.
title: The Longer Discourse on Emptiness

segment_text: I shall not mollycoddle you like a potter with their damp, unfired pots.

title: The Longer Discourse on Emptiness

segment_text: pressing you again and again.

title: Incredible and Amazing

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
title: Incredible and Amazing

segment_text: Then after the meal, on return from almsround, several mendicants sat together in the assembly hall and this discussion came up among them:
title: Incredible and Amazing

segment_text: “It’s incredible, reverends, it’s amazing! The Realized One has such psychic power and might!
title: Incredible and Amazing

segment_text: For he is able to know the Buddhas of the past who have become completely quenched, cut off proliferation, cut off the track, finished off the cycle, and transcended all suffering.
title: Incredible and Amazing

segment_text: He knows their birth, names, clans, conduct, teaching, wisdom, meditation, and freedom.”
title: Incredible and Amazing

segment_text: When they said this, Venerable Ānanda said,
title: Incredible and Amazing

segment_text: “The Realized Ones are incredible, reverends, and they have incredible qualities.
title: Incredible and Amazing

segment_text: They’re amazing, and they have amazing qualities.”
title: Incredible and Amazing

segment_text: But this conversation among those mendicants was left unfinished.
title: Incredible and Amazing

segment_text: Then in the late afternoon, the Buddha came out of retreat, went to the assembly hall, sat down on the seat spread out,
title: Incredible and Amazing

segment_text: and addressed the mendicants:
title: Incredible and Amazing

segment_text: “Mendicants, what were you sitting talking about just now? What conversation was left unfinished?”
title: Incredible and Amazing

segment_text: So the mendicants told him what they had been talking about. The Buddha said,
title: Incredible and Amazing

segment_text: “Well then, Ānanda, say some more about the incredible and amazing qualities of the Realized One.”
title: Incredible and Amazing

segment_text: “Sir, I have heard and learned this in the presence of the Buddha:

segment_text: ‘Mindful and aware, the being intent on awakening was reborn in the host of joyful gods.’
title: Incredible and Amazing

segment_text: This I remember as an incredible quality of the Buddha.
title: Incredible and Amazing

segment_text: I have learned this in the presence of the Buddha:
title: Incredible and Amazing

segment_text: ‘Mindful and aware, the being intent on awakening remained in the host of joyful gods.’
title: Incredible and Amazing

segment_text: This too I remember as an incredible quality of the Buddha.
title: Incredible and Amazing

segment_text: I have learned this in the presence of the Buddha:
title: Incredible and Amazing

segment_text: ‘For the whole of that life, the being intent on awakening remained in the host of joyful gods.’
title: Incredible and Amazing

segment_text: This too I remember as an incredible quality of the Buddha.
title: Incredible and Amazing

segment_text: I have learned this in the presence of the Buddha:
title: Incredible and Amazing

segment_text: ‘Mindful and aware, the being intent on awakening passed away from the host of joyful gods and was conceived in his mother’s womb.’
title: Incredible and Amazing

segment_text: This too I remember as an incredible quality of the Buddha.
title: Incredible and Amazing

segment_text: I have learned this in the presence of the Buddha:
title: Incredible and Amazing

segment_text: ‘When the being intent on awakening passes away from the host of joyful gods, he is conceived in his mother’s womb.
title: Incredible and Amazing

segment_text: And then—in this world with its gods, Māras, and divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—an immeasurable, magnificent light appears, surpassing the glory of the gods.
title: Incredible and Amazing

segment_text: Even in the boundless void of interstellar space—so utterly dark that even the light of the moon and the sun, so mighty and powerful, makes no impression—an immeasurable, magnificent light appears, surpassing the glory of the gods.

segment_text: And even the sentient beings reborn there recognize each other by that light: “So, it seems other sentient beings have been reborn here!”

segment_text: I have learned this in the presence of the Buddha:

segment_text: This too I remember as an incredible quality of the Buddha.

segment_text: I have learned this in the presence of the Buddha:
title: Incredible and Amazing

segment_text: ‘When the being intent on awakening is conceived in his mother’s belly, she becomes naturally ethical. She refrains from killing living creatures, stealing, sexual misconduct, lying, and beer, wine, and liquor intoxicants.’

segment_text: This too I remember as an incredible quality of the Buddha.

segment_text: I have learned this in the presence of the Buddha:
title: Incredible and Amazing

segment_text: This too I remember as an incredible quality of the Buddha.
title: Incredible and Amazing

segment_text: I have learned this in the presence of the Buddha:
title: Incredible and Amazing

segment_text: This too I remember as an incredible quality of the Buddha.

segment_text: I have learned this in the presence of the Buddha:
title: Incredible and Amazing

segment_text: ‘When the being intent on awakening is conceived in his mother’s belly, no afflictions beset her. She’s happy and free of bodily fatigue. And she sees the being intent on awakening in her womb, whole in his major and minor limbs, not deficient in any faculty.
title: Incredible and Amazing

segment_text: Suppose there was a beryl gem that was naturally beautiful, eight-faceted, well-worked. And it was strung with a thread of blue, yellow, red, white, or golden brown.

segment_text: In the same way, when the being intent on awakening is conceived in his mother’s belly, no afflictions beset her. She’s happy and free of bodily fatigue. And she sees the being intent on awakening in her womb, whole in his major and minor limbs, not deficient in any faculty.’
title: Incredible and Amazing

title: Incredible and Amazing

segment_text: I have learned this in the presence of the Buddha:
title: Incredible and Amazing

segment_text: ‘Other women carry the infant in the womb for nine or ten months before giving birth. Not so the mother of the being intent on awakening. She gives birth after exactly ten months.’

title: Incredible and Amazing

segment_text: I have learned this in the presence of the Buddha:
title: Incredible and Amazing

segment_text: This too I remember as an incredible quality of the Buddha.
title: Incredible and Amazing

segment_text: I have learned this in the presence of the Buddha:
title: Incredible and Amazing

title: Incredible and Amazing

segment_text: This too I remember as an incredible quality of the Buddha.
title: Incredible and Amazing

segment_text: I have learned this in the presence of the Buddha:
title: Incredible and Amazing

segment_text: ‘When the being intent on awakening emerges from his mother’s womb, before he reaches the ground, four godlings receive him and place him before his mother, saying: “Rejoice, O Queen! An illustrious son is born to you.”’
title: Incredible and Amazing

segment_text: This too I remember as an incredible quality of the Buddha.
title: Incredible and Amazing

segment_text: I have learned this in the presence of the Buddha:
title: Incredible and Amazing

segment_text: ‘When the being intent on awakening emerges from his mother’s womb, he emerges already clean, unsoiled by waters, mucus, blood, or any other kind of impurity, pure and clean.

segment_text: Not long after his ordination, Venerable Kassapa, living alone, withdrawn, diligent, keen, and resolute, soon realized the supreme end of the spiritual path in this very life. He lived having achieved with his own insight the goal for which gentlemen rightly go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

segment_text: He understood: “Rebirth is ended; the spiritual journey has been completed; what had to be done has been done; there is nothing further for this place.”

title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: Now at that time the novice Aciravata was staying in a wilderness hut.
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: Then as Prince Jayasena was going for a walk he approached Aciravata, and exchanged greetings with him.
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to Aciravata,
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: “Worthy Aggivessana, I have heard that
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: a mendicant who meditates diligently, keenly, and resolutely can experience unification of mind.”
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: “That’s so true, Prince! That’s so true!
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: A mendicant who meditates diligently, keenly, and resolutely can experience unification of mind.”
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: “Worthy Aggivessana, please teach me the Dhamma as you have learned and memorized it.”
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: “I’m not competent to do so, Prince.
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: For if I were to teach you the Dhamma as I have learned and memorized it, you might not understand the meaning, which would be wearying and troublesome for me.”
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: “Worthy Aggivessana, please teach me the Dhamma as you have learned and memorized it.
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: Hopefully I will understand the meaning of what you say.”
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: “I shall teach you.
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: If you understand the meaning of what I say, that’s good.
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: If not, then leave each to his own, and do not question me about it further.”
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: “Worthy Aggivessana, please teach me the Dhamma as you have learned and memorized it.
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: If I understand the meaning of what you say, that’s good.

segment_text: Then the novice Aciravata taught Prince Jayasena the Dhamma as he had learned and memorized it.
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: When he had spoken, Jayasena said to him,
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: “It is impossible, worthy Aggivessana, it cannot happen that a mendicant who meditates diligently, keenly, and resolutely can experience unification of mind.”
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: Having declared that this was impossible, Jayasena got up from his seat and left.
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: Not long after he had left, Aciravata went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side,
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: and informed the Buddha of all they had discussed.
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: When he had spoken, the Buddha said to him,
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: “How could it possibly be otherwise, Aggivessana?
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: Prince Jayasena dwells in the midst of sensual pleasures, enjoying them, consumed by thoughts of them, burning with fever for them, and eagerly seeking more. It’s simply impossible for him to know or see or realize what can only be known, seen, and realized by renunciation.
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: Suppose there was a pair of elephants or horse or oxen in training who were well tamed and well trained. And there was a pair who were not tamed or trained.
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: What do you think, Aggivessana?
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: Wouldn’t the pair that was well tamed and well trained perform the tasks of the tamed and reach the level of the tamed?”
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: “Yes, sir.”
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: “But would the pair that was not tamed and trained perform the tasks of the tamed and reach the level of the tamed, just like the tamed pair?”
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: “No, sir.”
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: “In the same way, Prince Jayasena dwells in the midst of sensual pleasures, enjoying them, consumed by thoughts of them, burning with fever for them, and eagerly seeking more. It’s simply impossible for him to know or see or realize what can only be known, seen, and realized by renunciation.
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: Suppose there was a big mountain not far from a town or village.
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: And two friends set out from that village or town, lending each other a hand up to the mountain. Once there, one friend would remain at the foot of the mountain, while the other would climb to the peak.
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: The one standing at the foot would say to the one at the peak,
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: ‘My friend, what do you see, standing there at the peak?’
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: They’d reply,
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: ‘Standing at the peak, I see delightful parks, woods, meadows, and lotus ponds!’
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: But the other would say,
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: ‘It’s impossible, it cannot happen that, standing at the peak, you can see delightful parks, woods, meadows, and lotus ponds.’
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: So their friend would come down from the peak, take their friend by the arm, and make them climb to the peak. After giving them a while to catch their breath, they’d say,
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: ‘My friend, what do you see, standing here at the peak?’
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: They’d reply,
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: ‘Standing at the peak, I see delightful parks, woods, meadows, and lotus ponds!’
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: They’d say,
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: ‘Just now I understood you to say:
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: “It’s impossible, it cannot happen that, standing at the peak, you can see delightful parks, woods, meadows, and lotus ponds.”
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: But now you say:
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: “Standing at the peak, I see delightful parks, woods, meadows, and lotus ponds!”’
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: They’d say,
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: ‘But my friend, it was because I was obstructed by this big mountain that I didn’t see what could be seen.’
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: But bigger than that is the mass of ignorance by which Prince Jayasena is veiled, shrouded, covered, and engulfed.
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: Prince Jayasena dwells in the midst of sensual pleasures, enjoying them, consumed by thoughts of them, burning with fever for them, and eagerly seeking more. It is quite impossible for him to know or see or realize what can only be known, seen, and realized by renunciation.
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: It would be no wonder if, had these two similes occurred to you, Prince Jayasena would have gained confidence in you and shown his confidence.”
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: “But sir, how could these two similes have occurred to me as they did to the Buddha, since they were neither supernaturally inspired, nor learned before in the past?”
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: “Suppose, Aggivessana, an anointed aristocratic king was to address his elephant tracker,
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: ‘Please, my good elephant tracker, mount the royal bull elephant and enter the elephant wood. When you see a wild bull elephant, tether it by the neck to the royal elephant.’
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: ‘Yes, Your Majesty,’ replied the elephant tracker, and did as he was asked.
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: The royal elephant leads the wild elephant out into the open;
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: and it’s only then that it comes out into the open,
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: for a wild bull elephant clings to the elephant wood.
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: The elephant tracker informs the king,
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: ‘Sire, the wild elephant has come out into the open.’
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: Then the king addresses his elephant trainer,
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: ‘Please, my good elephant trainer, tame the wild bull elephant. Subdue its wild behaviors, its wild memories and thoughts, and its wild stress, weariness, and fever. Make it happy to be within a village, and instill behaviors congenial to humans.’
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: ‘Yes, Your Majesty,’ replied the elephant trainer. He dug a large post into the earth and tethered the elephant to it by the neck, so as to subdue its wild behaviors, its wild memories and thoughts, and its wild stress, weariness, and fever, and to make it happy to be within a village, and instill behaviors congenial to humans.
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: He spoke in a way that’s mellow, pleasing to the ear, lovely, going to the heart, polite, likable and agreeable to the people.
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: Spoken to in such a way by the elephant trainer, the wild elephant wanted to listen. It actively listened and tried to understand.
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: So the elephant trainer rewards it with grass, fodder, and water.
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: When the wild elephant accepts the grass, fodder, and water, the trainer knows,
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: ‘Now the wild elephant will survive!’
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: He sets it a further task:
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: ‘Pick it up, worthy sir! Put it down, worthy sir!’
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: When the wild elephant picks up and puts down when the trainer says, following instructions, the trainer sets it a further task:
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: ‘Forward, worthy sir! Back, worthy sir!’
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: When the wild elephant goes forward and back when the trainer says, following instructions, the trainer sets it a further task:
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: ‘Stand, worthy sir! Sit, worthy sir!’
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: When the wild elephant stands and sits when the trainer says, following instructions, the trainer sets the task called imperturbability. He fastens a large plank to its trunk; a lancer sits on its neck; other lancers surround it on all sides; and the trainer himself stands in front with a long lance.
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: While practicing this task, it doesn’t budge its fore-feet or hind-feet, its fore-quarters or hind-quarters, its head, ears, tusks, tail, or trunk.
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: The wild bull elephant endures being struck by spears, swords, arrows, and axes; it endures the thunder of the drums, kettledrums, horns, and tom-toms. Rid of all crooks and flaws, and purged of defects, it is worthy of a king, fit to serve a king, and considered a factor of kingship.
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: In the same way, Aggivessana, a Realized One arises in the world, perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: He realizes with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras, and divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others.
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: He proclaims a teaching that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: A householder hears that teaching, or a householder’s child, or someone reborn in a good family.
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: They gain faith in the Realized One
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: and reflect,
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: ‘Life at home is cramped and dirty, life gone forth is wide open.
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: It’s not easy for someone living at home to lead the spiritual life utterly full and pure, like a polished shell.
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: Why don’t I shave off my hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness?’
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: After some time they give up a large or small fortune, and a large or small family circle. They shave off hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: And it’s only then that a noble disciple comes out into the open,
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: for gods and humans cling to the five kinds of sensual stimulation.
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: The Realized One guides them further:
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: ‘Come, mendicant, be ethical and restrained in the monastic code, conducting yourself well and resorting for alms in suitable places. Seeing danger in the slightest fault, keep the rules you’ve undertaken.’
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: When they have ethical conduct, the Realized One guides them further:
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: ‘Come, mendicant, guard your sense doors. When you see a sight with your eyes, don’t get caught up in the features and details. …
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: (Tell in full as in MN 107, the Discourse with Moggallāna the Accountant.)
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: They give up these five hindrances, corruptions of the heart that weaken wisdom.
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: Then they meditate observing an aspect of the body—keen, aware, and mindful, rid of covetousness and displeasure for the world.
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: They meditate observing an aspect of feelings …
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: mind …
title: The Level of the Tamed

title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: It’s like when the elephant trainer dug a large post into the earth and tethered the elephant to it by the neck, so as to subdue its wild behaviors, its wild memories and thoughts, and its wild stress, weariness, and fever, and to make it happy to be within a village, and instill behaviors congenial to humans.
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: In the same way, a noble disciple has these four kinds of mindfulness meditation as tethers for the mind so as to subdue behaviors tied to domestic life, memories and thoughts tied to domestic life, stress, weariness, and fever tied to domestic life, to discover the system, and to realize extinguishment.
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: The Realized One guides them further:
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: ‘Come, mendicant, meditate observing an aspect of the body, but don’t think thoughts connected with sensual pleasures.
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: Meditate observing an aspect of feelings …
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: mind …
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: As the placing of the mind and keeping it connected are stilled, they enter and remain in the second absorption …
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: third absorption …
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: fourth absorption.
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward recollection of past lives.
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: They recollect many kinds of past lives. That is: one, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand rebirths; many eons of the world contracting, many eons of the world expanding, many eons of the world contracting and expanding. And so they recollect their many kinds of past lives, with features and details.
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward knowledge of the death and rebirth of sentient beings.
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: With clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, they see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. They understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds.
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: When their mind has become immersed in samādhi like this—purified, bright, flawless, rid of corruptions, pliable, workable, steady, and imperturbable—they extend it toward knowledge of the ending of defilements.
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: They truly understand: ‘This is suffering’ … ‘This is the origin of suffering’ … ‘This is the cessation of suffering’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering’.
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: They truly understand: ‘These are defilements’ … ‘This is the origin of defilements’ … ‘This is the cessation of defilements’ … ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of defilements’.
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: Knowing and seeing like this, their mind is freed from the defilements of sensuality, desire to be reborn, and ignorance.
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: Such a mendicant endures cold, heat, hunger, and thirst; the touch of flies, mosquitoes, wind, sun, and reptiles; rude and unwelcome criticism; and puts up with physical pain—sharp, severe, acute, unpleasant, disagreeable, and life-threatening.
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: Rid of all greed, hate, and delusion, and purged of defects, they are worthy of offerings dedicated to the gods, worthy of hospitality, worthy of a religious donation, worthy of greeting with joined palms, and are the supreme field of merit for the world.
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: If a royal bull elephant passes away untamed and untrained—whether in their old age, middle age, or youth—they’re considered a royal bull elephant who passed away untamed.
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: In the same way, if a mendicant passes away without having ended the defilements—whether as a senior, middle, or junior—they’re considered as a mendicant who passed away untamed.
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: If a royal bull elephant passes away tamed and trained—whether in their old age, middle age, or youth—they’re considered a royal bull elephant who passed away tamed.
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: In the same way, if a mendicant passes away having ended the defilements—whether as a senior, middle, or junior—they’re considered as a mendicant who passed away tamed.”
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: That is what the Buddha said.
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: Satisfied, the novice Aciravata approved what the Buddha said.
title: The Level of the Tamed

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: With Bhūmija

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrels’ feeding ground.
title: With Bhūmija

segment_text: Then Venerable Bhūmija robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to the home of Prince Jayasena, where he sat on the seat spread out.

title: With Bhūmija

segment_text: “If that’s what your teacher says, worthy Bhūmija, he clearly stands head and shoulders above all the various other ascetics and brahmins.”

segment_text: Then Prince Jayasena served Venerable Bhūmija from his own dish.

title: With Anuruddha

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
title: With Anuruddha

segment_text: And then the chamberlain Pañcakaṅga addressed a man,
title: With Anuruddha

segment_text: “Please, worthy man, go to Venerable Anuruddha, and in my name bow with your head to his feet. Say to him,
title: With Anuruddha

segment_text: ‘Sir, the chamberlain Pañcakaṅga bows with his head to your feet.’
title: With Anuruddha

segment_text: And then ask him whether he
title: With Anuruddha

segment_text: might please accept tomorrow’s meal from Pañcakaṅga together with the mendicant Saṅgha.
title: With Anuruddha

segment_text: And ask whether he might please come earlier than usual,
title: With Anuruddha

segment_text: for Pañcakaṅga has many duties, and much work to do for the king.”
title: With Anuruddha

segment_text: “Yes, sir,” that man replied. He did as Pañcakaṅga asked, and
title: With Anuruddha

segment_text: Venerable Anuruddha consented with silence.
title: With Anuruddha

segment_text: Then when the night had passed, Anuruddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to Pañcakaṅga’s home, where he sat on the seat spread out.
title: With Anuruddha

segment_text: Then Pañcakaṅga served and satisfied Anuruddha with his own hands with delicious fresh and cooked foods.
title: With Anuruddha

segment_text: When Anuruddha had eaten and washed his hands and bowl, Pañcakaṅga took a low seat, sat to one side,
title: With Anuruddha

segment_text: and said to him:
title: With Anuruddha

segment_text: “Sir, some senior mendicants have come to me and said,
title: With Anuruddha

segment_text: ‘Householder, develop the limitless release of heart.’
title: With Anuruddha

segment_text: Others have said,
title: With Anuruddha

segment_text: ‘Householder, develop the expansive release of heart.’
title: With Anuruddha

segment_text: Now, the limitless release of the heart and the expansive release of the heart:
title: With Anuruddha

segment_text: do these things differ in both meaning and phrasing? Or do they mean the same thing, and differ only in the phrasing?”
title: With Anuruddha

segment_text: “Well then, householder, let me know what you think about this. Afterwards you’ll get it without fail.”
title: With Anuruddha

segment_text: “Sir, this is what I think.
title: With Anuruddha

segment_text: The limitless release of the heart and the expansive release of the heart mean the same thing, and differ only in the phrasing.”
title: With Anuruddha

segment_text: “The limitless release of the heart and the expansive release of the heart differ in both meaning and phrasing.
title: With Anuruddha

segment_text: This is a way to understand how these things differ in both meaning and phrasing.
title: With Anuruddha

segment_text: And what is the limitless release of the heart?
title: With Anuruddha

segment_text: It’s when a mendicant meditates spreading a heart full of love to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of love to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.

title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: “Mendicants!”
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: “Venerable sir,” they replied.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: The Buddha said this:
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: “These are the three characteristics, signs, and manifestations of a fool.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: What three?
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: A fool thinks poorly, speaks poorly, and acts poorly.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: If a fool didn’t think poorly, speak poorly, and act poorly, then how would the astute know of them,
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: ‘This worthy one is a fool, an untrue person’?
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: But since a fool does think poorly, speak poorly, and act poorly, then the astute do know of them,
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: ‘This worthy one is a fool, an untrue person’.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: A fool experiences three kinds of suffering and sadness in this very life.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: Suppose a fool is sitting in a council hall, a street, or a crossroad,
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: where people are discussing what is proper and fitting.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: And suppose that fool is someone who kills living creatures, steals, commits sexual misconduct, lies, and consumes beer, wine, and liquor intoxicants.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: Then that fool thinks,
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: ‘These people are discussing what is proper and fitting.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: But those bad things are found in me and I exhibit them!’
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: This is the first kind of suffering and sadness that a fool experiences in this very life.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: Furthermore, a fool sees that the kings have arrested a bandit, a criminal, and subjected them to various punishments—
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: whipping, caning, and clubbing; cutting off hands or feet, or both; cutting off ears or nose, or both; the ‘porridge pot’, the ‘shell-shave’, the ‘Rāhu’s mouth’, the ‘garland of fire’, the ‘burning hand’, the ‘bulrush twist’, the ‘bark dress’, the ‘antelope’, the ‘meat hook’, the ‘coins’, the ‘caustic pickle’, the ‘twisting bar’, the ‘straw mat’; being splashed with hot oil, being fed to the dogs, being impaled alive, and being beheaded.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: Then that fool thinks,
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: ‘The kinds of deeds for which the kings inflict such punishments—
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: those things are found in me and I exhibit them!
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: If the kings find out about me, they will inflict the same kinds of punishments on me!’
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: This is the second kind of suffering and sadness that a fool experiences in this very life.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: Furthermore, when a fool is resting on a chair or a bed or on the ground, their past bad deeds—misconduct of body, speech, and mind—settle down upon them, rest down upon them, and lay down upon them.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: It is like the shadow of a great mountain peak in the evening as it settles down, rests down, and lays down upon the earth.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: In the same way, when a fool is resting on a chair or a bed or on the ground, their past bad deeds—misconduct of body, speech, and mind—settle down upon them, rest down upon them, and lay down upon them.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: Then that fool thinks,
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: ‘Alas, I haven’t done good and skillful things that keep me safe.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: And I have done bad things, violence and sin.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: When I depart, I’ll go to the place where people who’ve done such things go.’
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: They sorrow and wail and lament, beating their breasts and falling into confusion.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: This is the third kind of suffering and sadness that a fool experiences in this very life.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: Having done bad things by way of body, speech, and mind, when their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: And if there’s anything of which it may be rightly said that
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: it is utterly unlikable, undesirable, and disagreeable, it is of hell that this should be said.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: So much so that it’s not easy to give a simile for how painful hell is.”
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: When he said this, one of the mendicants asked the Buddha,
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: “But sir, is it possible to give a simile?”
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: “It’s possible,” said the Buddha.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: “Suppose they arrest a bandit, a criminal and present him to the king, saying,
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: ‘Your Majesty, this is a bandit, a criminal. Punish him as you will.’
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: The king would say,
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: ‘Go, my men, and strike this man in the morning with a hundred spears!’
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: The king’s men did as they were told.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: Then at midday the king would say,
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: ‘My men, how is that man?’
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: ‘He’s still alive, Your Majesty.’
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: The king would say,
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: ‘Go, my men, and strike this man in the midday with a hundred spears!’
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: The king’s men did as they were told.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: Then late in the afternoon the king would say,
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: ‘My men, how is that man?’
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: ‘He’s still alive, Your Majesty.’
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: The king would say,
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: ‘Go, my men, and strike this man in the late afternoon with a hundred spears!’
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: The king’s men did as they were told.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: What do you think, mendicants?
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: Would that man experience pain and distress from being struck with three hundred spears?”
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: “Sir, that man would experience pain and distress from being struck with one spear, let alone three hundred spears!”
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: Then the Buddha, picking up a stone the size of his palm, addressed the mendicants,
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: “What do you think, mendicants?
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: Which is bigger: the stone the size of my palm that I’ve picked up, or the Himalayas, the king of mountains?”
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: “Sir, the stone you’ve picked up is tiny. Compared to the Himalayas, it doesn’t count, it’s not worth a fraction, there’s no comparison.”
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: “In the same way, compared to the suffering in hell, the pain and distress experienced by that man due to being struck with three hundred spears doesn’t count, it’s not worth a fraction, there’s no comparison.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: The wardens of hell punish them with the five-fold crucifixion.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: They drive red-hot stakes through the hands and feet, and another in the middle of the chest.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: And there they feel painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings—but they don’t die until that bad deed is eliminated.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: The wardens of hell throw them down and hack them with axes. …
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: They hang them upside-down and hack them with hatchets. …
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: They harness them to a chariot, and drive them back and forth across burning ground, blazing and glowing. …
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: They make them climb up and down a huge mountain of burning coals, blazing and glowing. …
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: The wardens of hell turn them upside down and throw them into a red-hot copper pot, burning, blazing, and glowing.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: There they’re seared in boiling scum, and they’re swept up and down and round and round.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: And there they feel painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings—but they don’t die until that bad deed is eliminated.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: The wardens of hell toss them in the Great Hell.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: Now, about that Great Hell:
title: The Foolish and the Astute

title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: neatly divided in equal parts.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: Surrounded by an iron wall,
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: of iron is its roof.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: The ground is even made of iron,
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: it burns with fierce fire.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: a hundred leagues around.’

segment_text: I could tell you many different things about hell.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: So much so that it’s not easy to completely describe the suffering in hell.

title: The Foolish and the Astute

title: The Foolish and the Astute

title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: I could tell you many different things about the animal realm.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: So much so that it’s not easy to completely describe the suffering in the animal realm.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: Mendicants, suppose a person were to throw a yoke with a single hole into the ocean.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: The east wind wafts it west; the west wind wafts it east; the north wind wafts it south; and the south wind wafts it north.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: And there was a one-eyed turtle who popped up once every hundred years.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: What do you think, mendicants?
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: Would that one-eyed turtle still poke its neck through the hole in that yoke?”
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: “No, sir.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: Only after a very long time, sir, if ever.”
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: “That one-eyed turtle would poke its neck through the hole in that yoke sooner than a fool who has fallen to the underworld would be reborn as a human being, I say.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: Why is that?
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: Because in that place there’s no principled or moral conduct, and no doing what is good and skillful.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: There they just prey on each other, preying on the weak.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: And suppose that fool, after a very long time, returned to the human realm.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: They’d be reborn in a low class family—a family of corpse-workers, hunters, bamboo-workers, chariot-makers, or scavengers.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: Such families are poor, with little to eat or drink, where life is tough, and food and shelter are hard to find.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: And they’d be ugly, unsightly, deformed, sickly—one-eyed, crippled, lame, or half-paralyzed. They don’t get to have food, drink, clothes, and vehicles; garlands, fragrance, and makeup; or bed, house, and lighting.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: And they do bad things by way of body, speech, and mind.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: Suppose a gambler were to lose his wife and child, all his property, and then get thrown in jail with his first losing hand.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: Such a losing hand is trivial compared to
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: the losing hand whereby a fool, having done bad things by way of body, speech, and mind, when their body breaks up, after death, is reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: This is the total fulfillment of the fool’s level.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

title: The Foolish and the Astute
