segment_text: What seven?
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: It’s when, on the fifteenth day sabbath, an anointed aristocratic king has bathed his head and gone upstairs in the royal longhouse to observe the sabbath. And the heavenly wheel-treasure appears to him, with a thousand spokes, with rim and hub, complete in every detail.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: Seeing this, the king thinks,
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: ‘I have heard that when the heavenly wheel-treasure appears to a king in this way, he becomes a wheel-turning monarch.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: Am I then a wheel-turning monarch?’
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: Then the anointed aristocratic king, taking a ceremonial vase in his left hand, besprinkled the wheel-treasure with his right hand, saying,
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: ‘Roll forth, O wheel-treasure! Triumph, O wheel-treasure!’
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: Then the wheel-treasure rolls towards the east. And the king follows it together with his army of four divisions. In whatever place the wheel-treasure stands still, there the king comes to stay together with his army.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: And any opposing rulers of the eastern quarter come to the wheel-turning monarch and say,
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: ‘Come, great king! Welcome, great king! We are yours, great king, instruct us.’
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: The wheel-turning monarch says,
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: ‘Do not kill living creatures. Do not steal. Do not commit sexual misconduct. Do not lie. Do not drink liquor. Maintain the current level of taxation.’
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: And so the opposing rulers of the eastern quarter become his vassals.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: Then the wheel-treasure, having plunged into the eastern ocean and emerged again, rolls towards the south. …
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: Having plunged into the southern ocean and emerged again, it rolls towards the west. …
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: Having plunged into the western ocean and emerged again, it rolls towards the north, followed by the king together with his army of four divisions. In whatever place the wheel-treasure stands still, there the king comes to stay together with his army.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: And any opposing rulers of the northern quarter come to the wheel-turning monarch and say,
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: ‘Come, great king! Welcome, great king! We are yours, great king, instruct us.’
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: The wheel-turning monarch says,
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: ‘Do not kill living creatures. Do not steal. Do not commit sexual misconduct. Do not lie. Do not drink liquor. Maintain the current level of taxation.’
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: And so the opposing rulers of the eastern quarter become his vassals.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: And then the wheel-treasure, having triumphed over this land surrounded by ocean, returns to the royal capital. There it stands still at the gate to the royal compound as if fixed to an axle, illuminating the royal compound.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: Such is the wheel-treasure that appears to the wheel-turning monarch.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: Next, the elephant-treasure appears to the wheel-turning monarch.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: It was an all-white sky-walker with psychic power, touching the ground in seven places, a king of elephants named Sabbath.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: Seeing him, the king was impressed,
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: ‘This would truly be a fine elephant vehicle, if he would submit to taming.’
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: Then the elephant-treasure submitted to taming, as if he were a fine thoroughbred elephant that had been tamed for a long time.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: Once it so happened that the wheel-turning monarch, testing that same elephant-treasure, mounted him in the morning and traversed the land surrounded by ocean before returning to the royal capital in time for breakfast.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: Such is the elephant-treasure that appears to the wheel-turning monarch.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: Next, the horse-treasure appears to the wheel-turning monarch.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: It was an all-white sky-walker with psychic power, with head of black and mane like woven reeds, a royal steed named Thundercloud.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: Seeing him, the king was impressed,
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: ‘This would truly be a fine horse vehicle, if he would submit to taming.’
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: Then the horse-treasure submitted to taming, as if he were a fine thoroughbred horse that had been tamed for a long time.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: Once it so happened that the wheel-turning monarch, testing that same horse-treasure, mounted him in the morning and traversed the land surrounded by ocean before returning to the royal capital in time for breakfast.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: Such is the horse-treasure that appears to the wheel-turning monarch.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: Next, the jewel-treasure appears to the wheel-turning monarch.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: It is a beryl gem that’s naturally beautiful, eight-faceted, well-worked.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: And the radiance of that jewel spreads all-round for a league.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: Once it so happened that the wheel-turning monarch, testing that same jewel-treasure, mobilized his army of four divisions and, with the jewel hoisted on his banner, set out in the dark of the night.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: Then the villagers around them set off to work, thinking that it was day.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: Such is the jewel-treasure that appears to the wheel-turning monarch.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: Next, the woman-treasure appears to the wheel-turning monarch.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: She is attractive, good-looking, lovely, of surpassing beauty. She’s neither too tall nor too short; neither too thin nor too fat; neither too dark nor too light. She outdoes human beauty without reaching heavenly beauty.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: And her touch is like a tuft of cotton-wool or kapok.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: When it’s cool her limbs are warm, and when it’s warm her limbs are cool.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: The fragrance of sandal floats from her body, and lotus from her mouth.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: She gets up before the king and goes to bed after him, and is obliging, behaving nicely and speaking politely.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: The woman-treasure does not betray the wheel-turning monarch even in thought, still less in deed.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: Such is the woman-treasure who appears to the wheel-turning monarch.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: Next, the householder-treasure appears to the wheel-turning monarch.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: The power of clairvoyance manifests in him as a result of past deeds, by which he sees hidden treasure, both owned and ownerless.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: He approaches the wheel-turning monarch and says,
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: ‘Relax, sire. I will take care of the treasury.’
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: Once it so happened that the wheel-turning monarch, testing that same householder-treasure, boarded a boat and sailed to the middle of the Ganges river. Then he said to the householder-treasure,
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: ‘Householder, I need gold, both coined and uncoined.’
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: ‘Well then, great king, draw the boat up to one shore.’
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: ‘It’s right here, householder, that I need gold, both coined and uncoined.’
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: Then that householder-treasure, immersing both hands in the water, pulled up a pot full of gold, both coined and uncoined, and said to the king,
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: ‘Is this sufficient, great king? Has enough been done, great king, enough offered?’
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: The wheel-turning monarch said,
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: ‘That is sufficient, householder. Enough has been done, enough offered.’
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: Such is the householder-treasure that appears to the wheel-turning monarch.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: Next, the commander-treasure appears to the wheel-turning monarch.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: He is astute, competent, intelligent, and capable of getting the king to appoint who should be appointed, dismiss who should be dismissed, and retain who should be retained.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: He approaches the wheel-turning monarch and says,
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: ‘Relax, sire. I shall issue instructions.’
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: Such is the commander-treasure that appears to the wheel-turning monarch.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: These are the seven treasures possessed by a wheel-turning monarch.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: And what are the four blessings?
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: A wheel-turning monarch is attractive, good-looking, lovely, of surpassing beauty, more so than other humans.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: This is the first blessing.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: Furthermore, he is long-lived, more so than other humans.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: This is the second blessing.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: Furthermore, he is rarely ill or unwell, and his stomach digests well, being neither too hot nor too cold, more so than other humans.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: This is the third blessing.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: Furthermore, a wheel-turning monarch is as dear and beloved to the brahmins and householders
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: as a father is to his children.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: And the brahmins and householders are as dear to the wheel-turning monarch
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: as children are to their father.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: Once it so happened that a wheel-turning monarch went with his army of four divisions to visit a park.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: Then the brahmins and householders went up to him and said,
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: ‘Slow down, Your Majesty, so we may see you longer!’
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: And the king addressed his charioteer,
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: ‘Drive slowly, charioteer, so I can see the brahmins and householders longer!’
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: This is the fourth blessing.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: These are the four blessings possessed by a wheel-turning monarch.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: What do you think, mendicants?
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: Would a wheel-turning monarch who possessed these seven treasures and these four blessings experience pleasure and happiness because of them?”
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: “Sir, a wheel-turning monarch who possessed even a single one of these treasures would experience pleasure and happiness because of that, let alone all seven treasures and four blessings!”
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: Then the Buddha, picking up a stone the size of his palm, addressed the mendicants,
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: “What do you think, mendicants?
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: Which is bigger: the stone the size of my palm that I’ve picked up, or the Himalayas, the king of mountains?”
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: “Sir, the stone you’ve picked up is tiny. Compared to the Himalayas, it doesn’t count, it’s not worth a fraction, there’s no comparison.”
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: “In the same way, compared to the happiness of heaven, the pleasure and happiness experienced by a wheel-turning monarch due to those seven treasures and those four blessings doesn’t even count, it’s not even a fraction, there’s no comparison.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: And suppose that astute person, after a very long time, returned to the human realm.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: They’d be reborn in a well-to-do family of aristocrats, brahmins, or householders—rich, affluent, and wealthy, with lots of gold and silver, lots of property and assets, and lots of money and grain.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: And they’d be attractive, good-looking, lovely, of surpassing beauty. They’d get to have food, drink, clothes, and vehicles; garlands, fragrance, and makeup; and a bed, house, and lighting.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: And they do good things by way of body, speech, and mind.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: Suppose a gambler was to win a big pile of money with the first perfect hand.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: Such a perfect hand is trivial compared to
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: the perfect hand whereby an astute person, when their body breaks up, after death, is reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: This is the total fulfillment of the astute person’s level.”
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: That is what the Buddha said.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
title: The Foolish and the Astute

segment_text: So I have heard.
title: Messengers of the Gods

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
title: Messengers of the Gods

segment_text: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,
title: Messengers of the Gods

segment_text: “Mendicants!”
title: Messengers of the Gods

segment_text: “Venerable sir,” they replied.
title: Messengers of the Gods

segment_text: The Buddha said this:
title: Messengers of the Gods

segment_text: “Mendicants, suppose there were two houses with doors. A person with clear eyes standing in between them would see humans entering and leaving a house and wandering to and fro.
title: Messengers of the Gods

segment_text: In the same way, with clairvoyance that is purified and superhuman, I see sentient beings passing away and being reborn—inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, in a good place or a bad place. I understand how sentient beings are reborn according to their deeds: ‘These dear beings did good things by way of body, speech, and mind. They never denounced the noble ones; they had right view; and they chose to act out of that right view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm, or among humans. These dear beings did bad things by way of body, speech, and mind. They denounced the noble ones; they had wrong view; and they chose to act out of that wrong view. When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in the ghost realm, the animal realm, or in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.’
title: Messengers of the Gods

segment_text: The wardens of hell take them by the arms and present them to King Yama, saying,
title: Messengers of the Gods

segment_text: ‘Your Majesty, this person did not pay due respect to their mother and father, ascetics and brahmins, or honor the elders in the family.
title: Messengers of the Gods

segment_text: May Your Majesty punish them!’
title: Messengers of the Gods

segment_text: King Yama pursues, presses, and grills them about the first messenger of the gods.
title: Messengers of the Gods

segment_text: ‘Worthy man, did you not see the first messenger of the gods that appeared among human beings?’
title: Messengers of the Gods

segment_text: He says,
title: Messengers of the Gods

segment_text: ‘I saw nothing, sir.’
title: Messengers of the Gods

segment_text: King Yama says to them,
title: Messengers of the Gods

segment_text: ‘Worthy man, did you not see among human beings a little baby collapsed in their own urine and feces?’
title: Messengers of the Gods

segment_text: He says,
title: Messengers of the Gods

segment_text: ‘I saw that, sir.’
title: Messengers of the Gods

segment_text: King Yama says to them,
title: Messengers of the Gods

segment_text: ‘Worthy man, did it not occur to you—being sensible and mature—
title: Messengers of the Gods

segment_text: “I, too, am liable to be born. I’m not exempt from rebirth. I’d better do good by way of body, speech, and mind”?’
title: Messengers of the Gods

segment_text: He says,
title: Messengers of the Gods

segment_text: ‘I couldn’t, sir. I was negligent.’
title: Messengers of the Gods

segment_text: King Yama says to them,
title: Messengers of the Gods

segment_text: ‘Worthy man, because you were negligent, you didn’t do good by way of body, speech, and mind.

title: Messengers of the Gods

segment_text: That bad deed wasn’t done by your mother, father, brother, or sister. It wasn’t done by friends and colleagues, by relatives and kin, by ascetics and brahmins, or by the deities. That bad deed was done by you alone, and you alone will experience the result.’

segment_text: The wardens of hell punish them with the five-fold crucifixion.
title: Messengers of the Gods

segment_text: They drive red-hot stakes through the hands and feet, and another in the middle of the chest.
title: Messengers of the Gods

segment_text: And there they suffer painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings—but they don’t die until that bad deed is eliminated.
title: Messengers of the Gods

segment_text: The wardens of hell throw them down and hack them with axes. …
title: Messengers of the Gods

segment_text: They hang them upside-down and hack them with hatchets. …
title: Messengers of the Gods

segment_text: They harness them to a chariot, and drive them back and forth across burning ground, blazing and glowing. …
title: Messengers of the Gods

segment_text: They make them climb up and down a huge mountain of burning coals, blazing and glowing. …
title: Messengers of the Gods

segment_text: The wardens of hell turn them upside down and throw them in a red-hot copper pot, burning, blazing, and glowing.
title: Messengers of the Gods

segment_text: There they’re seared in boiling scum, and they’re swept up and down and round and round.
title: Messengers of the Gods

segment_text: And there they suffer painful, sharp, severe, acute feelings—but they don’t die until that bad deed is eliminated.
title: Messengers of the Gods

segment_text: The wardens of hell toss them into the Great Hell.
title: Messengers of the Gods

segment_text: Now, about that Great Hell:
title: Messengers of the Gods

segment_text: ‘Four are its corners, four its doors,
title: Messengers of the Gods

segment_text: neatly divided in equal parts.

title: The Shorter Analysis of Deeds

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
title: The Shorter Analysis of Deeds

segment_text: Then the student Subha, Todeyya’s son, approached the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.
title: The Shorter Analysis of Deeds

segment_text: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side and said to the Buddha:
title: The Shorter Analysis of Deeds

segment_text: “What is the cause, worthy Gotama, what is the reason why even among those who are human beings some are seen to be inferior and superior?
title: The Shorter Analysis of Deeds

segment_text: For people are seen who are short-lived and long-lived,
title: The Shorter Analysis of Deeds

segment_text: sickly and healthy,
title: The Shorter Analysis of Deeds

segment_text: ugly and beautiful,
title: The Shorter Analysis of Deeds

segment_text: insignificant and illustrious,
title: The Shorter Analysis of Deeds

segment_text: poor and rich,
title: The Shorter Analysis of Deeds

segment_text: from low and eminent families,
title: The Shorter Analysis of Deeds

segment_text: witless and wise.
title: The Shorter Analysis of Deeds

segment_text: What is the reason why even among those who are human beings some are seen to be inferior and superior?”
title: The Shorter Analysis of Deeds

segment_text: “Student, sentient beings are the owners of their deeds and heir to their deeds. Deeds are their womb, their relative, and their refuge.
title: The Shorter Analysis of Deeds

segment_text: It is deeds that divide beings into
title: The Shorter Analysis of Deeds

segment_text: inferior and superior.”
title: The Shorter Analysis of Deeds

segment_text: “I don’t understand the meaning of what the worthy Gotama has said in brief, without explaining the details.
title: The Shorter Analysis of Deeds

segment_text: Worthy Gotama, please teach me this matter in detail so I can understand the meaning.”
title: The Shorter Analysis of Deeds

segment_text: “Well then, student, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”
title: The Shorter Analysis of Deeds

segment_text: “Yes, worthy sir,” replied Subha.
title: The Shorter Analysis of Deeds

segment_text: The Buddha said this:
title: The Shorter Analysis of Deeds

segment_text: “Take some woman or man who kills living creatures. They’re violent, bloody-handed, a hardened killer, merciless to living beings.
title: The Shorter Analysis of Deeds

segment_text: Because of undertaking such deeds, when their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a place of loss, a bad place, the underworld, hell.
title: The Shorter Analysis of Deeds

segment_text: If they’re not reborn in a place of loss, but return to the human realm, then wherever they’re reborn they’re short-lived.
title: The Shorter Analysis of Deeds

segment_text: For killing living creatures is the path leading to a short lifespan.
title: The Shorter Analysis of Deeds

segment_text: But take some woman or man who gives up killing living creatures. They renounce the rod and the sword. They’re scrupulous and kind, living full of sympathy for all living beings.
title: The Shorter Analysis of Deeds

segment_text: Because of undertaking such deeds, when their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in a good place, a heavenly realm.
title: The Shorter Analysis of Deeds

segment_text: If they’re not reborn in a heavenly realm, but return to the human realm, then wherever they’re reborn they’re long-lived.
title: The Shorter Analysis of Deeds

segment_text: For not killing living creatures is the path leading to a long lifespan.
title: The Shorter Analysis of Deeds

segment_text: Take some woman or man who habitually hurts living creatures with a fist, stone, rod, or sword.
title: The Shorter Analysis of Deeds

segment_text: Because of undertaking such deeds, after death they’re reborn in a place of loss …
title: The Shorter Analysis of Deeds

segment_text: or if they return to the human realm, they’re sickly …
title: The Shorter Analysis of Deeds

segment_text: But take some woman or man who would never hurt living creatures with a fist, stone, rod, or sword.
title: The Shorter Analysis of Deeds

segment_text: Because of undertaking such deeds, after death they’re reborn in a heavenly realm …
title: The Shorter Analysis of Deeds

segment_text: or if they return to the human realm, they’re healthy …

title: The Shorter Analysis of Deeds

segment_text: “Excellent, worthy Gotama! Excellent!
title: The Shorter Analysis of Deeds

segment_text: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, worthy Gotama has made the Teaching clear in many ways.

segment_text: Now, Ānanda, gifts to the following persons may be expected to yield the following returns. To an animal, a hundred times. To an unethical ordinary person, a thousand. To an ethical ordinary person, a hundred thousand. To an outsider free of desire for sensual pleasures, 10,000,000,000. But a gift to someone practicing to realize the fruit of stream-entry may be expected to yield incalculable, immeasurable returns. How much more so a gift to a stream-enterer, someone practicing to realize the fruit of once-return, a once-returner, someone practicing to realize the fruit of non-return, a non-returner, someone practicing to realize the fruit of perfection, a perfected one, or an independent Buddha? How much more so a Realized One, a perfected one, a fully awakened Buddha?

segment_text: When he said this, Anāthapiṇḍika cried and burst out in tears.
title: Advice to Anāthapiṇḍika

segment_text: Venerable Ānanda said to him,
title: Advice to Anāthapiṇḍika

segment_text: “Are you failing, householder? Are you fading, householder?”
title: Advice to Anāthapiṇḍika

segment_text: “No, Honorable Ānanda.
title: Advice to Anāthapiṇḍika

segment_text: But for a long time I have paid homage to the Buddha and the esteemed mendicants.
title: Advice to Anāthapiṇḍika

segment_text: Yet I have never before heard such a Dhamma talk.”
title: Advice to Anāthapiṇḍika

segment_text: “Householder, such Dhamma talk does not strike when teaching white-clothed laypeople.
title: Advice to Anāthapiṇḍika

segment_text: Rather, it strikes when teaching those gone forth.”
title: Advice to Anāthapiṇḍika

segment_text: “Well then, Honorable Sāriputta, let such Dhamma talk strike when teaching white-clothed laypeople as well!
title: Advice to Anāthapiṇḍika

segment_text: There are gentlemen with little dust in their eyes. They’re in decline because they haven’t heard the teaching.
title: Advice to Anāthapiṇḍika

segment_text: There will be those who understand the teaching!”
title: Advice to Anāthapiṇḍika

segment_text: And when the venerables Sāriputta and Ānanda had given the householder Anāthapiṇḍika this advice they got up from their seat and left.
title: Advice to Anāthapiṇḍika

segment_text: Not long after they had left, Anāthapiṇḍika passed away and was reborn in the host of joyful gods.
title: Advice to Anāthapiṇḍika

segment_text: Then, late at night, the glorious godling Anāthapiṇḍika, lighting up the entire Jeta’s Grove, went up to the Buddha, bowed, stood to one side,
title: Advice to Anāthapiṇḍika

title: Advice to Anāthapiṇḍika

segment_text: “This is indeed that Jeta’s Grove,
title: Advice to Anāthapiṇḍika

title: Advice to Anāthapiṇḍika

segment_text: where the King of Dhamma stayed:
title: Advice to Anāthapiṇḍika

segment_text: it brings me joy!
title: Advice to Anāthapiṇḍika

segment_text: Deeds, knowledge, and principle;
title: Advice to Anāthapiṇḍika

segment_text: ethical conduct, an excellent livelihood;
title: Advice to Anāthapiṇḍika

segment_text: by these are mortals purified,
title: Advice to Anāthapiṇḍika

segment_text: not by clan or wealth.
title: Advice to Anāthapiṇḍika

title: Advice to Anāthapiṇḍika

title: Advice to Anāthapiṇḍika

title: Advice to Anāthapiṇḍika

title: Advice to Anāthapiṇḍika

title: Advice to Anāthapiṇḍika

segment_text: When he had spoken, Venerable Ānanda said to the Buddha:

segment_text: “Good, good, Ānanda.

title: Advice to Channa

segment_text: That’s what I’ll think, Blessed One.
title: Advice to Puṇṇa

segment_text: That’s what I’ll think, Holy One.”
title: Advice to Puṇṇa

segment_text: “But if they do take your life with a sharp knife, what will you think of them then?”
title: Advice to Puṇṇa

segment_text: “If they take my life with a sharp knife, I’ll think:
title: Advice to Puṇṇa

segment_text: ‘There are disciples of the Buddha who looked for a suicide weapon because they were horrified, repelled, and disgusted with the body and with life. And I have found this without looking!’
title: Advice to Puṇṇa

segment_text: That’s what I’ll think, Blessed One.
title: Advice to Puṇṇa

segment_text: That’s what I’ll think, Holy One.”
title: Advice to Puṇṇa

segment_text: “Good, good Puṇṇa!
title: Advice to Puṇṇa

segment_text: Having such self-control and peacefulness, you will be quite capable of living in Sunāparanta.
title: Advice to Puṇṇa

segment_text: Now, Puṇṇa, go at your convenience.”
title: Advice to Puṇṇa

segment_text: And then Puṇṇa welcomed and agreed with the Buddha’s words. He got up from his seat, bowed, and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right. Then he set his lodgings in order and, taking his bowl and robe, set out for Sunāparanta.
title: Advice to Puṇṇa

segment_text: Traveling stage by stage, he arrived at Sunāparanta,
title: Advice to Puṇṇa

segment_text: and stayed there.
title: Advice to Puṇṇa

segment_text: Within that rainy season he confirmed around five hundred male and five hundred female lay followers. And within that same rainy season he realized the three knowledges.
title: Advice to Puṇṇa

segment_text: Some time later he became fully extinguished.
title: Advice to Puṇṇa

segment_text: Then several mendicants went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and said to him,
title: Advice to Puṇṇa

segment_text: “Sir, the gentleman named Puṇṇa, who was advised in brief by the Buddha, has passed away.
title: Advice to Puṇṇa

segment_text: Where has he been reborn in his next life?”
title: Advice to Puṇṇa

segment_text: “Mendicants, Puṇṇa was astute. He practiced in line with the teachings, and did not trouble me about the teachings.
title: Advice to Puṇṇa

segment_text: Puṇṇa has become fully quenched.”
title: Advice to Puṇṇa

segment_text: That is what the Buddha said.
title: Advice to Puṇṇa

segment_text: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
title: Advice to Puṇṇa

segment_text: So I have heard.

segment_text: Sisters, by developing and cultivating these seven awakening factors, a mendicant realizes the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.
title: Advice from Nandaka

title: Advice from Nandaka

segment_text: It’s when a mendicant develops the awakening factors of mindfulness,
title: Advice from Nandaka

title: Advice from Nandaka

segment_text: energy,
title: Advice from Nandaka

segment_text: rapture,
title: Advice from Nandaka

title: Advice from Nandaka

segment_text: immersion,
title: Advice from Nandaka

segment_text: and equanimity, which rely on seclusion, fading away, and cessation, and ripen as letting go.
title: Advice from Nandaka

segment_text: It is by developing and cultivating these seven awakening factors that a mendicant realizes the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.”

segment_text: Then after giving this advice to the nuns, Nandaka dismissed them, saying,

title: Advice from Nandaka

segment_text: Then those nuns bowed to the Buddha respectfully circled him, keeping him on their right, before departing.

segment_text: Soon after those nuns had left, the Buddha addressed the mendicants:
title: Advice from Nandaka

segment_text: “Suppose, mendicants, it was the sabbath of the fourteenth day. You wouldn’t get lots of people
title: Advice from Nandaka

title: Advice from Nandaka

title: Advice from Nandaka

segment_text: “Yes, sir,” Nandaka replied.

title: With the People of Nagaravinda

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was wandering in the land of the Kosalans together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants when he arrived at a village of the Kosalan brahmins named Nagaravinda.
title: With the People of Nagaravinda

segment_text: The brahmins and householders of Nagaravinda heard,
title: With the People of Nagaravinda

segment_text: “It seems the ascetic Gotama—a Sakyan, gone forth from a Sakyan family—while wandering in the land of the Kosalans has arrived at Nagaravinda, together with a large Saṅgha of mendicants.
title: With the People of Nagaravinda

segment_text: He has this good reputation:
title: With the People of Nagaravinda

segment_text: ‘That Blessed One is perfected, a fully awakened Buddha, accomplished in knowledge and conduct, holy, knower of the world, supreme guide for those who wish to train, teacher of gods and humans, awakened, blessed.’
title: With the People of Nagaravinda

segment_text: He has realized with his own insight this world—with its gods, Māras, and divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, gods and humans—and he makes it known to others.
title: With the People of Nagaravinda

segment_text: He proclaims a teaching that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, meaningful and well-phrased. And he reveals a spiritual practice that’s entirely full and pure.
title: With the People of Nagaravinda

segment_text: It’s good to see such perfected ones.”
title: With the People of Nagaravinda

segment_text: Then the brahmins and householders of Nagaravinda went up to the Buddha. Before sitting down to one side, some bowed, some exchanged greetings and polite conversation, some held up their joined palms toward the Buddha, some announced their name and clan, while some kept silent. The Buddha said to them:

segment_text: “Householders, if wanderers who follow another religion were to ask you:

segment_text: You should answer them:
title: With the People of Nagaravinda

segment_text: ‘There are ascetics and brahmins who are not free of greed, hate, and delusion for sights known by the eye, who are not peaceful inside, and who conduct themselves badly among the good by way of body, speech, and mind. They don’t deserve honor, respect, reverence, and veneration.
title: With the People of Nagaravinda

segment_text: Why is that?
title: With the People of Nagaravinda

segment_text: Because we ourselves are not free of these things, so we do not see that they have any higher good conduct than us.

segment_text: That’s why they don’t deserve honor, respect, reverence, and veneration.

title: The Development of the Faculties

segment_text: At one time the Buddha was staying near Kajaṅgalā in a bamboo grove.
title: The Development of the Faculties

segment_text: Then the student Uttara, a pupil of the brahmin Pārāsariya, approached the Buddha, and exchanged greetings with him.
title: The Development of the Faculties

segment_text: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him,
title: The Development of the Faculties

segment_text: “Uttara, does Pārāsariya teach his disciples the development of the faculties?”
title: The Development of the Faculties

segment_text: “He does, worthy Gotama.”
title: The Development of the Faculties

segment_text: “But how does he teach it?”
title: The Development of the Faculties

segment_text: “Worthy Gotama, it’s when the eye sees no sight and the ear hears no sound.
title: The Development of the Faculties

segment_text: That’s how Pārāsariya teaches his disciples the development of the faculties.”
title: The Development of the Faculties

segment_text: “In that case, Uttara, a blind person and a deaf person will have developed faculties
title: The Development of the Faculties

segment_text: according to what Pārāsariya says.
title: The Development of the Faculties

segment_text: For a blind person sees no sight with the eye and a deaf person hears no sound with the ear.”
title: The Development of the Faculties

segment_text: When he said this, Uttara sat silent, dismayed, shoulders drooping, downcast, depressed, with nothing to say.
title: The Development of the Faculties

segment_text: Knowing this, the Buddha addressed Venerable Ānanda,
title: The Development of the Faculties

segment_text: “Ānanda, the development of the faculties taught by Pārāsariya is quite different from the supreme development of the faculties in the training of the Noble One.”
title: The Development of the Faculties

segment_text: “Now is the time, Blessed One! Now is the time, Holy One.
title: The Development of the Faculties

segment_text: Let the Buddha teach the supreme development of the faculties in the training of the Noble One. The mendicants will listen and remember it.”
title: The Development of the Faculties

segment_text: “Well then, Ānanda, listen and apply your mind well, I will speak.”
title: The Development of the Faculties

segment_text: “Yes, sir,” Ānanda replied.
title: The Development of the Faculties

segment_text: The Buddha said this:
title: The Development of the Faculties

segment_text: “And how, Ānanda, is there the supreme development of the faculties in the training of the Noble One?
title: The Development of the Faculties

segment_text: When a mendicant sees a sight with their eyes, in them arises what is agreeable, what is disagreeable, and what is both agreeable and disagreeable.
title: The Development of the Faculties

segment_text: They understand:
title: The Development of the Faculties

segment_text: ‘What is agreeable, what is disagreeable, and what is both agreeable and disagreeable have arisen in me.
title: The Development of the Faculties

segment_text: That’s conditioned, crude, and dependently originated.
title: The Development of the Faculties

segment_text: But this is peaceful and sublime, namely
title: The Development of the Faculties

segment_text: equanimity.’
title: The Development of the Faculties

segment_text: Then the agreeable, the disagreeable, and the both agreeable and disagreeable that arose in them cease,
title: The Development of the Faculties

segment_text: and equanimity becomes stabilized.
title: The Development of the Faculties

segment_text: It’s like how a person with clear eyes might open their eyes then shut them; or might shut their eyes then open them.
title: The Development of the Faculties

segment_text: Such is the speed, the swiftness, the ease with which anything agreeable, disagreeable, and both agreeable and disagreeable that arose in them cease, and equanimity becomes stabilized.
title: The Development of the Faculties

segment_text: In the training of the Noble One this is called the supreme development of the faculties regarding sights known by the eye.
